author: {'steamid': '76561198152514993', 'num_games_owned': 768, 'num_reviews': 315, 'playtime_forever': 455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 345, 'playtime_at_review': 455, 'last_played': 1710063938}
review:
[h1]类型[/h1]
探索，收集

[h1]游戏内容[/h1]
除连接区域外，探索三大主片区内各种小谜题。
和成就相关的内容：
1.收集每个片区内的6个符号以激活相应成就。
2.每个区域有一处奇怪谜题，需要依靠在别的区域找到线索来解开。
3.每个片区还有1个隐藏小房间，需要探索完下一个区域再返回来才能开门，可以主线通关后再探索，用于解锁秘密结局。

[h1]优点[/h1]
+谜题无难度，但类型比较丰富。

[h1]缺点[/h1]
-画面简陋且优化不佳，建筑制作粗糙，基本就是各种方形堆在一起，没有很强的设计感和震撼感。
-操作手感差，对操作完全没有优化，非常油滑的手感。
-对于在大尺寸的建筑中穿梭来说，视场角太小，拉大后画面又畸变。
-控制器支持不完善。虽然游戏内可以用手柄操作，但是菜单只能用鼠标。对于一个内容并不复杂的游戏来说，实在不理解菜单界面加上手柄操作有什么难点。
-房间转场生硬。不同房间靠传送门连接，简陋了点。

[h1]感想[/h1]
有意思，但不多，艺术效果没有达到应有的高度，只能勉勉强强给个好评。

author: {'steamid': '76561198036538203', 'num_games_owned': 347, 'num_reviews': 174, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1709418649}
review:
Reminiscent of wondrous tech demos of the 90's and 2000's, where the wonder to be had is simply the existence of the surreal 3D world itself and the experience of walking around in it, taking it in, and with even the simplest interaction a highlight. You walk, run, jump, can push stuff by walking into it, and that's it. You're here to live in this eerie world and wander its dusty halls. The game even first drops you into the start of itself, there being no main menu you first see from which to start a new game.

This is successfully foreboding; despite the complete lack of foes or any life in the world being shown, the wonder, and existential dread, I've felt in my mere 25 minutes of playing this so far are among the strongest any playable experience has caused me in well over a "decade". I had to pull out this early because my heart began to pick up.

The puzzles are as minimalistic as the gameplay- and still feel fair and satisfying to ponder, enact, and solve. What's more, because some folks have ungelike puzzle experiences from others, the devs went the extra mile to include hints in the pause menu. Don't worry, they're optional; even if you click the "hints" button, you then click "hint 1", 2, or 3 to show the actual hint, so you decide your challenge level.

All the above inspires me to recommend this dreamlike experience. It helps that it runs smoothly even on this little laptop of mine, so even if you're on a budget, you may have found a graphics dollop of a game for you to try out.

And for $5? A steal, in my mind. That is, if you like these traits that make Kairo, Kairo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967815270', 'num_games_owned': 437, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 1046, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1046, 'last_played': 1705171141}
review:
An atmospheric puzzler that uses simple mechanics to deliver a short and surreal experience. While clearly a passion project there's a lack of polish to the game that can't be ignored and will make or break your experience.

The majority of puzzles in Kairo were fine but there are a handful of secrets that are too esoteric to even consider solving. One puzzle could only be solved by the community for example, and that event came and went years ago so a guide is the only way to 100% the game. Meanwhile most of the early details I thought would be clues to later puzzles ended up being entirely irrelevant. The game design is unrefined in that sense but thankfully most of the game is intuitive enough to solo.

Kairo's world, its minimalism, and dashes of environmental storytelling will likely decide if you enjoy the experience or not as beyond the puzzles there's not really anything else to the game. The world is more atmospheric with implied poetic themes and liminal open spaces while being very linear to traverse, so if you need a story and clear instructions this isn't the one for you.

Personally I had no qualms following a guide once I hit certain dead ends and despite that I ended up enjoying the experience for the most part. I was still trying the puzzles first before looking for solutions and filling in gaps. Kairo has a lot of rough edges but the developer's heart is on full display and I can't fault a first attempt too harshly, just expect your mileage to vary.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059947383', 'num_games_owned': 1036, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1698407168}
review:
Pensa em um jogo que você quer gostar, mas que ele não gosta de você e faz de tudo pra que você também não goste dele.
Bem... essa foi a minha experiência com Kairo.

A parte boa do jogo é justamente a ideia dele, de ser um walk simulator que passa por diferentes liminal spaces - diversos lugares minimalistas e estranhos, que variam desde salas pequenas e claustrofóbicas à titânicas torres e florestas brutalistas - que ao mesmo tempo que são esquisitos, sempre causando sensações de desconforto e solidão, são belos e impressionantes.
Agora o resto do jogo...

...Bem, pra iniciar as críticas, comecemos com o software do jogo, que simplesmente se recusava a funcionar no meu monitor. Tiver que fazer altas gambiarras pra conseguir abrir o programa em modo janela pra ele rodar. Depois disso, o show de horrores: O jogo é CHEIO de salas diferentes, e sempre que você troca de sala, o jogo fecha e reabre. Beleza, isso não seria tão incomodo, se não fosse por ele sempre reabrir no exato ponto que divide meus dois monitores. Toda vez, para cada sala que eu ia - em um jogo REPLETO de salas - eu tinha que puxar a janela do jogo pro centro do meu monitor primário. Nem preciso dizer o quão irritante isso era.

Quanto a parte de gameplay, o objetivo, ao explorar as salas, é achar e completar puzzles que vão abrindo novos caminhos (e mais salas). Esses puzzles são, em sua maioria, ridículos, nem podendo ser chamados de puzzles direito. Apenas uns dois ou três foram realmente interessantes de completar, o restante sendo bem fracos e até irritantes pela lentidão do jogo. Falando em lentidão, esse é outro aspecto que incomoda muito durante a gameplay: o seu personagem não corre, ele só anda um pouco mais rápido, o que complica bastante trafegar por cenários colossais que você já passou enquanto procura puzzles.
Pra fechar a torrente de desgraça, a câmera do jogo, depois de jogar um tempo, começa a te dar dor de cabeça. Não sei o que fizeram de diferente nela, mas nas 3 vezes que joguei tive dor de cabeça - não vou mentir, porém, que essa parte pode estar relacionada a eu ter que reposicionar a janela sempre que mudava de sala - dificilmente ela ficava centralizada certo, e essa leve variação pode ter ajudado a causar a dor.

Enfim, a conclusão é que eu deveria ter dado ouvidos aos alertas do jogo desde o começo e abandonado ele, porque, mesmo com cenários incríveis, o pacote bônus de problemas que vem junto está longe de valer a pena.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087000489', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1682021285}
review:
It's just kind of boring. The puzzles are arbitrary, not really difficult but also not interesting. It's mostly a case of pushing buttons in the correct order. There aren't really any real puzzle mechanics that carry through the game other than "sometimes an object can be pushed" and "stand in the right spot". One puzzle has you running on in-game treadmills which felt incredibly out of place. 

The collectables feel even more arbitrary than the puzzles, they're little runes that you can find if you explore the world thoroughly, but the world is big and empty so thoroughly looking around is boring, and on the off-chance that you find one it's incredibly anti-climactic. 

I get the feeling that the game is trying to be deep by putting pictures of real life events, people, and historic paintings in the environments, but it just feels like they were put there at random.

It just lacks a lot of polish. The default setting for "smooth camera movement" makes the game feel sluggish and unresponsive by making the camera lag behind your mouse movement, turn that off right away. Sprinting is only barely faster than walking speed. If you set your FOV to MAX and stand next to a wall, the near clipping plane of the camera allows you to see through the wall. Some objects are missing geometry. Falling off of a level puts you back in the last place you stood with solid ground, but I encountered one level where this didn't happen and I kept falling, forcing me to reopen the game. In another case I jumped to a lower platform that I could not jump back up from, and jumping into the void put me back there, softlocking me and again forcing to reopen the game. 

The little praise I have is that it performs amazingly even on low end hardware, and the music/ambiance is pretty spot on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023115742', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1680533875}
review:
An underrated and sadly overlooked [i]Myst[/i]-like that I still come back to years later.

Its minimalist art style (and plot) might put off some people, but I honestly find it works in the game's favor. It manages to pull off a really unique, relaxing, and mysterious atmosphere despite how "simple" the construction of its environments are. Fans of [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/265690/NaissanceE/][i]NaissanceE[/i][/url] should definitely take note, as both games share a similar sense of minimalist brutalist architecture and environment design (though [i]NaissanceE[/i] definitely puts more emphasis on the sheer vastness of its environments rather than [i]Kairo[/i]'s bespoke puzzle rooms).

The puzzles are fairly straightforward and generally intuitive, which helps keep the game flowing at a decent pace and gives you a good sense of progression. There are a few harder puzzles here and there, but those are optional and completing everything the game has to offer ultimately lead towards a secret (joke) ending.

If any of this sounds intriguing to you, then please give it a try! It's become an old favorite of mine and deserves more contemporary recognition.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026663817', 'num_games_owned': 986, 'num_reviews': 354, 'playtime_forever': 565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 565, 'last_played': 1430551757}
review:
Full disclosure: this is an abstract walking sim. You do some minor puzzle solving, but the main “fun” or engagement in this game comes from exploring its desolate halls. There is no dialogue, no definitive answers, nothing of the sort. So if you expect some kind of gripping narrative… well.

I still the narrative is there. After a fashion, that is. There’s some amount of environmental storytelling, but considering how abstract everything is… I mean, it’s cubes, colours, voids… and some other things.

Other things.

I wouldn’t classify this game as horror. But I’ve seen one person nope out of playing this, because of how THICK the atmosphere is. You know the trope, “Nothing is scarier”? Well, that’s what you have here. Or do you? Is Kairo really this desolate, empty place that it looks to be?

Ultimately, this is the main driving question of the game. What is this place? Why are you here? What’s your purpose?

Are you alone in here?

If those questions, mixed with the aesthetic visible on the screenshots, sound interesting to you - I’d say check this out. I loved it to bits, but this is one of those experiences that can vary from person to person.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064202235', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1674296387}
review:
I want to recommend Kairo badly, but I just can't.. Kairo does a great job at atmosphere and being imaginative. I really appreciated the simplistic art style, calming music, and overall tone of the game. The entire experience felt like a lucid dream, exploring the empty worlds and seeing where this experience takes you.
 
However, the other parts surrounding the game really hampered my experience. After the first area of the game it seems like it takes a nosedive in quality. I found the puzzles became either way too simple or too unclear. Some puzzles I found myself thinking 'oh, guess I solved it..' and then moved on. Other puzzles had me spending 20 to 30 minutes trying to solve, leading to frustration and looking up the solution (which is still very unclear why that is the solution). The most frustrating puzzle was the tilting one that had you lining up two wheels with symbols up. You can accidentally solve the first part without it being clear why that was the solution. That puzzle gets harder, with the last round making no sense to me whatsoever. A circle? How does that make sense in the way the puzzle presents the other rounds? It just seems inconsistent. There are many parts of the game that feel inconsistent, which again hampers my experience. How was I supposed to know the gate without a teleporting texture is actually a teleport? Why are those symbols everywhere but are only used in maybe two puzzles to figure out the solution? Sometimes the solutions are just plain given to you, but not until you spend time trying to solve the puzzle yourself (thinking it is more logical than it actually is).
 
Another frustrating aspect was although the game encourages exploration to find the ruins, yet the world is way too large to go on a hunt. Sometimes the ruins are very easy to miss because they blend into the texturing (I passed by a ruin twice without noticing it because it matched the texture on the wall). There are secret doors hidden throughout the game that will grant you partial access to the secret ending. I noticed those doors while exploring, but since I didn't click a button in a later part of the level, they didn't open for me! What, how does that make sense? And the worst part is none of this is hinted at at all. The ruins at least make sense because you'll eventually run into one or two on your play through, but the rest of the 'secrets' seem too obtuse.
 
Without getting into spoilers, the ending and overarching story didn't leave me satisfied. I'm very happy for the developer for making their game and not giving up, but it doesn't quite leave a satisfying ending for those that spent time playing it..

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198025310681', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1654027729}
review:
Kairo is half puzzle game, half walking sim that has a few bright spots amidst a dull whole. I would recommend this game [b]only[/b] to fans of both walking sims and puzzle games that don't mind a "student project" feel to a game.
By far, my favorite part of this game and the part that the developer really nails is the atmosphere. A unsettling, eerie vibe permeates most of the game. This is mostly achieved through the minimalist visual style and dark ambient score. Exploring this world is such a treat; it was the main reason why I played and finished the game. A few of the puzzles were enjoyable too.
Unfortunately, that was were my enjoyment ended. A majority of the puzzles felt tedious, with a few being completely non-nonsensical and maddening (rotating wheels with shapes being the worst offender). While the tone of the game is generally very good, the developer doesn't really do anything with it for most of the game. This wouldn't be a problem if they hadn't completely shifted the game's tone right at the end with no warning. It felt like the developer trashed the one redeeming quality of their experience by an urge to give the players a [spoiler] "happy/uplifting ending".[/spoiler] It feels completely unearned and so sudden that it feels emotionally opposite than what I would assume to be the intended feeling.  Maybe the "secret ending" explains this problem, but I'm simply not compelled to.

author: {'steamid': '76561198245793172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 664, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1653598792}
review:
I played the entirety of this game, earned all of the achievements, solved all of its puzzles, and saw all of its endings. Even after all this, pretty much 10 hours, I never once felt the satisfaction I was hoping for.

It was really disappointing to do all of this and to not even have a coherent story at the end. Like, I was really hoping to find out who was the guy I kept seeing on the screens and how this connects to the war imagery throughout the game.

But even if you're desperate enough -- like me-- to spend hours just to get to the "secret ending"... well, let's just say it was probably the biggest "fuck you" I have ever seen in a game so far.

Look, I can forgive its graphics for being a result of its time, but everything is just so boring. Like, there's the same walking audio for all environments you are in, even when you're in water or even air. And long walkways and sometimes impossible puzzles provide no reward except the blind hope of a story at the end to make this all worth while.

TDLR; To sum this all up, Kairo felt like a complete waste of time and is a really bad game. The visuals barely made up for it and solving the puzzles in this game did not feel as satisfying as I had hoped.

----
Side note, I actually came here from Naissancee in hopes that this would be another atmospheric game I could get lost in. This is absolutely not the case. Kairo and Naissance both don't have stories but Naissancee's main focus is its sublime and gorgeous visuals; Kairo just doesn't have that. In fact, go play Naissance instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198809680193', 'num_games_owned': 351, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 513, 'last_played': 1642869964}
review:
Tiens tiens, mais quel est cet OVNI. J’ai joué au jeu parce que j’aime les jeux de réflexions et aussi j’étais intrigué par le côté architectural de l'œuvre. Sur ce dernier point je n’ai pas été déçu, dans le jeu on ne fait quasiment que visiter des endroits vides mais j’ai pris beaucoup de plaisir à le faire (c’est peut-être que moi). J’ai cette impression d’être perdu dans la grandeur, de me sentir tout petit, d’explorer des mécanismes qui doivent avoir un but précis mais qui restent biens mystérieux. Apparemment ce jeu raconte vraiment une histoire, le preuve: http://www.electrondance.com/the-secret-of-kairo/

En ce qui concerne les énigmes, elles sont mystérieuses aussi, parfois on ne comprend pas ce qu’on est censé faire mais elles ont le mérite d’être originales. Est-ce un bon jeu pour autant ? je ne pense pas, mais j’aime quand même.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118348887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1649090011}
review:
Honestly, I hated it. 
I'm a completionist and puzzle game lover. But this game felt like a chore. This game has a HUGE map for every room, with hardly any hidden things- pixel scouring sucks, especially when there's static and annoying visual and audio to make it harder to find the tiny hidden pixel. The maps feel like running through someone's minecraft server, and often are large just to be large and make you run through the room a lot. Too little puzzle and too much running around looking for what could even be considered a puzzle. 

If you don't need even a scrap of story and love running aimlessly, this game is for you! It was definitively not for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968022278', 'num_games_owned': 4026, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1646690767}
review:
"i hear the roar of a big machine/two worlds and in between/hot metal and methedrine/i hear empire down" - lucretia my reflection, the sisters of mercy (1988)

playing kairo feels awful at first. i don't know if it was a deliberate design choice or if early unity first person games just had horrific locomotion, but the first impression is that you are controlling a daytona usa car on ice. and unfortunately that feeling never fully goes away, and i want to be upfront about this. once you get your head around the movement physics, you are introduced to a world of abandoned brutalist structures that house unfathomably large and unknown machines. your role is to activate these machines. as you do this, you slowly become immersed in what feels like playing the game version of one of nine inch nails's Ghosts ambient-industrial albums. it's a great feeling, and it gets stronger the deeper into the game you go, with game adding in themes of constant, unknown surveillance and a feeling that maybe you *shouldn't* be turning on these machines. the puzzles to turn on the machines are reasonable at first but become more challenging as the game progresses, to the point it became necessary to use the very well made hints system (which makes me nostalgic for the old 90's Universal Hint Files program). there are a couple puzzles that just felt like pure luck (and im not talking about the one that is Literally That by design), but it never feels maddening. while i didn't get the true ending due to the busy work involved, the ending i did get was. fine? it felt a little simple for what it was building up, but that's ok. games often don't stick the landing fully. i liked kairo, and it gave me that weird surreal and unsettling feeling that i very much enjoy, but i wish it controlled better. also, i'd love to be able to buy that ost!

author: {'steamid': '76561197981548323', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 2295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2174, 'last_played': 1641966335}
review:
Somehow i've been failing to give it a playthrough for years despite 4 or 5 efforts made. It has it's decent share of immersiveness and crude scenery worth a look at and makes up fine for a walking sim at times (or even all the way through).
May seem too unnessessarily complicated, disordered and slow-paced in letting you have progress without getting bored or lost. Only seem so, i think. I often have to choose between playing in a state of drowsyness or not playing at all and mostly  been preferring the first option so far. And, for this reason, often losing my way or idea of what i'm doing, especially in games like this one, with no combat, extreme driving or steering or anything else of a kind to keep your eyes peeled and brain phocused on making fast decisions all the time.
Now that i've occasionally made it far enough to have gone to something looking like an intermediate ending covering three achievements (of 11 it has) and, right after the tytles, spawning you back to the last crossroads you chose your way on, it looks good and totally worth playing on to see what else is there.
To make a long story short - in my world it's (at least) an 8-of-10-ish  immersive and (in its own way) beautiful adventure game, totally worth trying unless you can't stand any standard part of this genre's games' routines like wondering about, seeing sceneries, collecting collectables, pressing buttons, solving puzzles, reading notes and trying to figure what you're doing all this for and whot you could've missed or done the wrong way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046669010', 'num_games_owned': 632, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1640139031}
review:
Basically, it's a boring walking sim. The visuals are interesting at first, but get old fast, and the absolutely humongous places with extra slow walking speeds won't help that - especially when you go for completion and need to find all the symbols.

Puzzles are so simple your mind will go numb while solving them; contrary, the vision puzzles don't make any sense - thus unsolvable without a guide.

The so-called atmospheric music combined with the above explained problems makes you feel angry and want to just finish and uninstall the game ASAP.

I'd say, a much faster paced gameplay and better puzzles would have been better. But that would make the atmospheric walking sim aspect non-existent. So I don't know. There is no story or anything it wants to tell you. Shows some psychotic issues in the author but not the good / admirable ones.

It's not the 4 euros, but the 4 hours I would love to get back and watch a B-movie instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022670193', 'num_games_owned': 348, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1639456738}
review:
예전에 Halfquake에 영향받은 초현실주의 퍼즐 게임 찾다가 나온건데 확실히 초현실적 공간을 보는 맛이 있다. LSD랑 옛날 서브머신이란 플래시 게임 섞은거 같음. 그런데 퍼즐은 단순하고 직관적이면서도 힌트조차 불친절해서 개인적으로 추천하지 않는다. 무엇보다 스토리가 그냥 없어도 될 정도이며(그만큼 언어적 장벽은 없다), 배경과 상관없어 보이는 정체불명의 사진 등을 보면 종잡을 수 없다.

그리고 움직임이 너무 느려서 치트 엔진으로 2배속 키고 했음.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025212944', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1639394811}
review:
Kairo is the best game I have experienced in the "why are there Shapes everywhere, I don't understand what's going on" genre. You could also call it "abstract walking simulator" but what I really want is the melancholic lonesomeness and the sense of mystery that drips off 80s computer animation demos, 90s math textbook covers, and yeah, Myst also.

Kairo is mostly an aesthetic experience and the puzzles are more for pacing than a serious challenge, and the aesthetics are exactly what I'm all about. It's largely weird causeways of concrete cubes levitating in misty voids, with enough environmental storytelling that the ending provides closure instead of coming out of nowhere.

Play this game if you want to spend 3-4 hours wandering through hallways of levitating cubes and orbs. If that's not appealing to you, this isn't the game for you.

review:
Kairo is both a complicated, and a simple game at the same time. Primarily focusing on general exploration with puzzle solving to unlock the continuation of the game. Some of these puzzles are very simple, others might requires some looking around or trial and error, but overall it's a fairly great experience. One that for 5 bucks (at posting this review) is very much worth the money if you like atmospheric games.

The atmospheric part of the game is by far, the best aspect in my opinion. There are so many neat places and so many charming and sometimes off-putting things to see. It's classified as a horror game in the tags, but it's not an, in your face, type of horror, it's more psychological based if you actively choose to look for it. It's kind of brilliantly done.

Searching for some things, particularly the collectables can be tedious at times, but mostly, if you use some logic as to where you'd hide them, and keep a sharp eye out, you'll probably find most of them on your first pass through the game.

Plus, that secret ending. Didn't expect that!

author: {'steamid': '76561198219343843', 'num_games_owned': 16099, 'num_reviews': 311, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1634104689}
review:
[h3]Meander through massive, imposing architecture as you try to make sense of where you are and what to do in Kairo. For puzzle lovers, it will scratch a certain Myst-like itch, and does remarkably more than you'd expect with little more than walking and jumping. That said, its dated graphics, lack of a fleshed out narrative, and difficult secrets (one which requires collaboration to solve, unless spoiled) may frustrate some. If you're puzzle-oriented, patient, and go into it blind, it's fair to say you'll get your money's worth - especially when on sale.[/h3]

[i]This review will contain light spoilers[/i].

Named after the Japanese word for "circuit," [i]Kairo[/i] is an interactive walking sim that hurls you into its world without any training wheels. No tutorial, no opening cutscene. Rather, A vast white expanse and an ancient throne. Who are you, and what are you doing here? What are these buildings and dilapidated mechanisms? That's for you to figure out, all on your own.

Remarkably, the game manages to weave its puzzles, world, and narrative out of little more than low poly constructs shrouded in fog, low res textures, WASD + jump input, and an unsettling, foreboding soundtrack. Truly, a minimalist game if there ever was one. Yet it doesn't feel flimsy, unfinished, or rushed. If anything, the more you explore, the more it draws you in, as it teases new mysteries in succession. In its first area, you'll hear foreign language transmissions of numerical code and discover portraits of a ruined world. In the second, you'll find yourself under observation of a shadowy figure, whose static-filled visage appears everywhere. Further on, you'll find images of cultural and social significance, solidifying the link that this is somehow all tied to Earth, in a scenario reminiscent of Arthur C. Clarke's works.

[i]Kairo[/i] is not terribly long. Perhaps three hours, even when experienced without assistance. Thankfully, the game has built-in hints accessible from its ESC menu, specific to each challenge room. Its secrets, however, have no such clues, and may take hours to solve, unless you look up answers in player-made guides. These lead to a special developer room which gives a few insights as to its development and design, but falls short of filling in details of its largely silent plot.

As mentioned above, [i]Kairo[/i]'s most remarkable accomplishment is managing to do so much with so little. How do you create variety with controls limited to Dpad and jump? By utilizing mechanics centered around location, timing, and sequence. Some objects are triggered by your location in relationship to them, some need to be pushed (or toggled by touch), and others operate by how long you stand (or run) on them. You can no doubt think of many modern games that recycle a single mechanic throughout its run time, to serve as padding. [i]Kairo[/i] doesn't fall into this trap. Its handful of puzzle rooms feel mostly unique. When a mechanic does see reuse, it's either quick to pass or utilized for the purpose of data entry (drawing symbols, etc).

Given all the above, how does one go about appraising this game? It makes a number of polarizing design decisions, as indicated by the many existing reviews. Players looking for a meaty plot or clear objectives will be sorely disappointed, since [i]Kairo's[/i] primary focus is exploration, discovery, and reading between the lines. In fact, three of the most pivotal plot points are hidden in its secret rooms, one of which required outside help but makes no indication of this in-game, which understandably frustrated many (nothing about the game lends itself to multiplayer in theme or structure).

But credit is due the developer for choosing a risky path and sticking with it, and when considered from the confines it imposes on itself, it's an interesting study in game design. It provides a unique sense of accomplishment for players who stick with it, solving its puzzles via tinkering and experimentation. Although the garish color choices and claustrophobic view distance can be alienating, it comes together with an eerie and unnerving soundscape to give birth to an unquestionably tense atmosphere, one reminiscent of bygone first person adventure games. As for the plot? Whilst I agree that it tips into the "too little" category, the fact that it had me searching for answers, musing about its connections well after completion could also be considered a measure of success.

I recommend this title for aspiring game designers, puzzle fanatics, and fans of abstract, esoteric themes. I don't recommend this for people who crave closure and clear-cut objectives. If you're the latter, [url=https://www.myabandonware.com/game/rama-3p8]I highly recommend Rama[/url], a phenomenal 1996 adventure game based on the novels, that hits on many of the same themes.

[u]Achievement Hunters[/u]: Fully guided. If you spoil everything, than <2hr to 100%. Requires completion, finding all the runes for each area, and then reaching the easter egg "ending." Rest assured, you can safely finish the game on your own and load it back up to search for all the secrets - no replays required.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011250864', 'num_games_owned': 1883, 'num_reviews': 354, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1633267665}
review:
A first person atmospheric puzzle game.

Usually I try to give games a fair shake before giving them a verdict, even if they can be somewhat strange. I didnt play this one for long, but I think Ive played enough of it to understand what I can expect until the end.

This game doesnt have a story. At least not one you can see while going through this world. Maybe there is something towards the end, but until then you dont really have much. There are some screens that can appear with obscured images on them, but they dont tell you anything.
The world in itself is made up of abstract geometric shapes (basically what you see in the pictures). You go through different chambers via portals, solving puzzles to get parts of keys or sometimes just going through corridors. This is accompanied by eerie background music. The visuals arent that good. And its not like Im expecting anything major, its just some places have a grain filter that makes the already unimpressive visuals even more lackluster. Lighting often doesnt help either. Often it can feel difficult to navigate because of it. Some objects you can go through because they dont have collision.
And the puzzles. Most of them require you to do busywork. Trial and error, waiting for setup. They arent fun. Some of them can be rather vague in what they expect you to do. Ive heard there is even a puzzle, which requires you to talk to people from different playthroughs to get their piece of the puzzle hint. It wore my interest out pretty quick. Granted, there are hints for each puzzle chamber and their is a kind of level map in the pause menu, so you wont get lost. But with the lackluster visuals and story I just dont want to bother.

If you look at the achievements, less than a third got the first zone done. Even more dropped off before finishing the second. That should tell you something. I wanted to quit before finishing the first zone, but decided to put in some more effort to be sure I wasnt being too lazy to try and get it. But aside from an eerie mood, there really wasnt anything there from making me feel bored.

3.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198097438071', 'num_games_owned': 377, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1627378835}
review:
What a waste of time!
It is a puzzle game but all puzzles in it aren't really puzzles. 

Problem 1:
Most of the puzzles are like: "here are 4 buttons and here is the order that you need to press them in". It is just Simon says over and over again in 10 different ways

Problem 2:
On the contrary, there are a couple of puzzles that require you to make giant logic leaps. The game doesn't give you enough information to arrive to the solution on your own. Thee was a puzzle that asks you to assign values to shapes and rearrange those shapes to form first 4 digits of pi...??? 

Another (optional) puzzle required you to draw a shape with 4 lines but the game only gives you one of them. I assumed that I'll find the other lines when I play through the game. But I didn't. The other parts of the solution are only obtained by ASKING OTHER PLAYERS because all players have different parts of the solution.
Don't get me wrong, I think that it is actually kind of amazing. EXCEPT! There's nothing that indicates that the solution is outside the game. There's nothing that hints that I need to seek help online. If the game somehow told me that information, I would've gladly started asking other players for their parts. But it did not.

How do I know the soulutions than? 

Problem 3:
There's a hint system inside that game, that can give you the solution in plain text if you are stuck. And if you need WORDS to tell the player how to solve a puzzle, why make a game in the first place... go write a book. Telling the player what to do is easy, but directing the player's thought process so that they arrive to the solution "on their own" is much harder. 

Problem 4:
There are 18 tiny glyphs on the walls in each area of the game. If you want a true ending, you need to look around every single wall to find all of them. That's just tedious, like everything else in this game

Problem 5:
Reward for the struggle
There are 3 optional ""hard"" ""puzzles"" and a few other requirements to reach the true ending of the game. Look up "Kairo Secret Ending" on YouTube. This makes me mad... Trust me it will not spoil the game for you, but it will save you a lot of time. The developer is a massive troll. While the game's meaning is open to interpritation, the secret ending has NO meaning. It is desrespectfull to the amount of time you put into the game. 

This review only covers the puzzles of the game. There's a lot more that can be said but this is enough to get my point across. This is a fundamentally flawed game. Don't waste your time with this one

author: {'steamid': '76561198151383683', 'num_games_owned': 213, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 609, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 609, 'last_played': 1627662586}

author: {'steamid': '76561198015003424', 'num_games_owned': 1496, 'num_reviews': 256, 'playtime_forever': 462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1625493118}
review: Kairo is an interesting game, with mostly interesting, mostly easy puzzles. The game uses minimalist low polygon architecture and manages to create some interesting environments. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said about the particle effects which are outright janky. As are some of the rooms. An actual story, in place of the vague references to a dying world, would have made the whole thing more impactful as well. And speaking of janky, the secret ending is most certainly not worth unlocking - not even an ending really. Still, there is something rewarding about bringing a dead machine back to life, slowly peeling away the layers, one puzzle at a time. It would have been nice to have something a bit more meaningful waiting for the player at the end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198256088680', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 132, 'playtime_forever': 375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1624989375}

author: {'steamid': '76561198394732752', 'num_games_owned': 182, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1622614639}
review: This is one of those surreal first-person exploration games that I like so much, this one coming with a number of puzzles.  Nothing is really explained, but most of the puzzles are either intuitive or will click after you mess around with them long enough; if not, there are always guides.  What really sells this is the atmosphere: a pleasantly geometric landscape of abstract objects in monochrome, with that one color varying by room; the way that the visuals are put together also gives it a vibe similar to those FMV Adventures from the mid '90s.  The music is weird and ethereal, so it feels a bit like Yume Nikki, but much lonelier and more meditative.  I couldn't have asked for a lovelier world and experience, and there are plenty of well-hidden secrets to find.  Oh, and that secret ending is PERFECT.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137513791', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1616729272}
review:
Never played Kairo to its entirety, so maybe I cannot speak for the last area or two.

What I can say is that the game really nails the atmospherical part. It feels better than some walking simulators I've fiddled with, and it really feels that you're walking inside a puzzle itself. 

In terms of puzzles, I will say that the game suffers from this Legend of Zelda feeling,  where you're missing something, which in most cases is not intuitive, and you're going back and forth trying to figure out what you're missing, and that ends up being a little bit tedious in the end. 

Overall, glad I had the experience, and I know many people got much more out of the game than I did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198807207406', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1619107055}
review:
Je n'ai rien contre un jeu expérimental qui cherche à poser une ambiance et construire un monde abstrait, au contraire. Mais ici on ne voit pas un monde mais simplement une série de salles sans connexion spéciale les unes aux autres, avec parfois des petites énigmes qui parfois ne font aucun sens (vraiment aucun, il faut les faire soit à la chance soit à l'aide d'un guide). 
Pour moi la tentative d'établir une ambiance est un gros flop, en partie à cause de la musique en fond, désagréable et omniprésente; d'autre part les graphismes, qui selon moi ne sont pas d'un minimalisme épuré mais juste simples, sales et moches.
Le jeu n'est juste pas amusant. L'ambiance n'est pas là, les puzzles ne sont pas amusants. On s'ennuie.

Décevant.

Dans le même genre de jeu, je conseillerais plutôt NaissanceE.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104918316', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1604865246}
review:
The game definitely delivers for the price tag. It's worth trying out. It's not long or particularly hard, but it offers a really unique atmosphere.

The atmosphere of this game really matches the theme that runs through the game, of being alone and dealing with loss. The strange, abstract rooms feel very close to places I would normally see in my dreams and it makes the experience all the more eerie. The conclusion definitely has that wow factor, and while you won't find a huge compelling storyline, I think it does provide a really good emotional experience. There's no need for words, for characters, for a concrete backstory. You just kind of know what it's about as you go along.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076804276', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1650844314}
review:
I don't hate this game, it definitely makes me wish I could give mixed reviews on steam instead of an absolute yes or no recommendation. There were some pretty neat puzzles, the environments while simple I still found fairly charming and it has a nice semi-haunting atmosphere that I liked. 

The reason I can't recommend it is that I found quite a few of the puzzles to be completely unrewarding and frustrating. The frustration arose from there not really being a reason for why you're doing some of them or how to even solve them (the puzzles you have to solve for 100% completion are the worst and I have no idea how people figured out some of them, it must have just been a matter of dumb luck or a ton of trial and error)

If it's on sale for really cheap maybe pick it up

author: {'steamid': '76561198137524518', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1611874301}
review:
意味不明但冥冥中感觉充满哲思的步行模拟解谜游戏。有相当的难度，不是在于解谜本身，而是在于理解谜题。官方还比较贴心地在游戏中内置了提示（菜单 - Hint），社区也有还算详尽的英文攻略。游戏没有汉化，不过反正游戏内除了菜单也没有文字，所以算不上什么影响。音效和 bgm 都还挺有氛围的。建模设计有点意思。

缺点是优化做得挺烂，不知道为什么动不动就会出现 200-500 FPS 导致显卡咆哮。跑地图总是要跑很久。游玩时间超过 60 分钟必开始晕，可能和粗糙的材质有关。不过这个毕竟是美术 feature，所以也没什么好的解决办法。

author: {'steamid': '76561198024185123', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1605963576}
review:
First something good:
This game does have some interesting puzzles, which take some time to understand.

But overall it just can't get past the mark of what i would expect someone to make in a few months as a hobby project on the side, while playing around with an available engine.
Many puzzles are only hard, because you first need to actually visually identify all their elements and how to interact with them.
On top of that the visuals are unimpressive and the game suffers from useless long walking distances like they are currently popular with "atmospheric" games. They are just an annoying obstacle if there is nothing interesting to see along the way though. Without those the game would be at most half it's length.

Overall I would not recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198180783295', 'num_games_owned': 133, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1609777783}

author: {'steamid': '76561198010905516', 'num_games_owned': 835, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 254, 'last_played': 1609736422}
review: Kairo is a bite sized and obtuse puzzler set in an abstract setting. It took awhile for me to really get absorbed but the atmosphere and creepy ambiance hooked me after awhile. The puzzles were tough and decent if you like scrounging around for environmental clues in order to solve them. A solid 4 hours in my opinion, nothing I haven't seen before, but decently done and engrossing. Recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11095, 'playtime_forever': 1620, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1620, 'last_played': 1609649209}
review:
This is a simplistic low poly/minimalist 3D first person casual puzzle/platformer where you walk around an esoteric environment and step through various puzzle levels. 

It's ok but not amazing.  It would probably get better reviews if the puzzles were more engaging and interesting, instead the puzzles seem to be 80-90% working out where/what the puzzle is and then the rest solving it, which is not very satisfying.  It really wouldn't hurt for this to have better graphics, too, maybe some textures on the polygons?

author: {'steamid': '76561198122542514', 'num_games_owned': 424, 'num_reviews': 180, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1420414706}
review:
I recommend this game because the experience was good and the puzzles as well. I had a good time playing it.
Personally my eyes hurt a bit afterwards because of the frizzly look of the game.
This game is not for everyone. The atmosphere is an important point and shapes your experience with the game. you need to be open to something like that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198861829043', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1609424890}
review:
一款畫風詭異的解謎+步行模擬器。

勉强玩了20分鐘，感覺對遊戲的第一印象被破壞了。實際上就是一個意義不明的解謎遊戲。畫風詭異超現實，非常粗糙。畫面噪點，眼睛看一陣會不舒服。可能是故意給人營造出一種在噩夢中走路的氛圍。至於謎題也是讓人摸不到頭腦，就是一直開暗門走路。總而言之，完全不明白要傳達的意思。

還有就是在紅色房間，在激活機關之後會有一圈圖片出來，上面大概是地震過後的災害景象，配以字正腔圓的的中文女聲，前言不搭後語，就像評論裏所説的軍事廣播暗碼，真的不知道安插這一段是什麽用意，大晚上的感覺頭皮發麻。還有配樂非常蛋疼，有一陣沒一陣的，而且非常陰沉單調，聽起來像是哀樂似的。自認爲膽子不小，但是真的惡心壞了。

至於作者要傳達什麽？我是不想思考了，去他X的，誰愛領會誰領會去吧。已申請退款。

author: {'steamid': '76561198011781119', 'num_games_owned': 633, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1606514422}
review:
I found this game to be more frustrating than anything else. I got stuck on a puzzle for a long time until I found out that the games gives you a partial random solution, and that you have to ask others with game to give you the rest. Thankfully it turned out to be the only puzzle of that type, but that's not what I look for in a single-player puzzle game. 

A majority of the game is a walking art simulator, where you go to various locations and look at pretty but monochrome geometry. Most of the puzzles are straightforward, apart from the few (2-3)  for which you are given no clues. The sound design was poor, with the occasional tone to let you know you found the solution to a puzzle you didn't know you were doing, and many loud static sounds passing for background music. I was more or less enjoying the abstract nature of the game and the puzzles until it started introducing the background story.

I finished the game despite itself, and derive no real pleasure from having played it in its entirety.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079610188', 'num_games_owned': 621, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1604208104}
review:
cool little puzzle platformer, experiment in environmental storytelling, where you play as a slowly accelerating pill shape. takes maybe 4-5 hours to 100%.

the main draw is the graphics. the environments are abstract and beautiful. they have a cohesive style and personality, mostly of brutalist, monochrome architecture, and stylised, low-tech effects. completing puzzles also visibly changes the game world, which is nicely satisfying.
imagery of war is scattered throughout, but that theme never climaxes into a story.

the puzzles themselves are hit or miss. some are fun, others are so obtuse it's like they came out of a point and click. the main shortcoming here is that the puzzles are just that; there are some themes that appear in a few different puzzles, but for the most part, there's no cohesive element or theme that ties everything together. in many puzzle-platforming games, there's some sort of device the game is built around; portal has the portal gun, braid has time travel, and super mario sunshine has fludd. kairo does not have any sort of device, and puzzles range from connecting the dots, to drawing symbols, to correctly orienting dynamic objects; so this is where as a puzzle game it falls short.

also there's this one sound effect that's obscenely loud and it peaks and i hate it.

i still recommend it though, because of the beautiful environments, good soundtrack, and respectable level of polish. there's also a cool secret developer room, like the kind you find in old community tf2 maps that have development concept art and stuff. i just wish there was a disco room to match... maybe i haven't found it yet.

It's a surreal looking puzzle game with very vague hints towards how to solve them. The game is also very slow paced, especially with how slow your character is. author: {'steamid': '76561198045732011', 'num_games_owned': 1947, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1602941018}
review:
Kairo is an odd first person puzzle game with an interesting aesthetic and ambient soundtrack. When you get into the game, you have no idea what's going on. This is a feeling that will follow you through the game as you continue further and solve more puzzles. 

There's no real story going on and tbh, there's not much going on at all besides you and the puzzles. But with that said, it's not a bad thing. You walk around, solve puzzles and hoping that you'll manage to continue to the next area. Before you know it, it's over. You finished the game! There's some hidden areas, extra puzzles and even a secret ending for the person who wants to push in some extra time into the game as well.

I recommend this to people who are fans of first person puzzle games!

author: {'steamid': '76561198010112985', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1599767334}
review:
Right off the bat everything is so slow. The movement is floaty with your character carrying momentum from walking when you change directions. So much of this game is walking through literally nothing or landscapes made up of concrete texture cubes. Some areas are visually interesting but with the sole purpose of walking from one end to the other. Pushing objects takes ages for no real reason. Many of the puzzles in this game are trial and error, often revolving around pushing buttons with shapes on them. Others are incredibly straight forward.

The "vision puzzles" in the game are unlike anything else and are nearly impossible to solve. One of them actually is impossible to solve on your own in a single playthrough. You are given 1/4 of the solution to the puzzle (which is hidden in a completely separate area from where the puzzle is), requiring either multiple playthroughs and hoping you are given the other solutions over 4 playthroughs or by going online and getting the other 3 pieces. I've never encountered a puzzle game that requires you to essentially cheat to solve it. Someone serious about completing it on their own would look in every corner and behind every pillar and wall trying to find the other 3 pieces to the solution only to find nothing. In that way it's more of a big f you to someone taking the puzzle seriously.

I went into this game wanting to like it. Exploration games heavily rely on the visuals and I felt that for every interesting landscape there were two or three boring ones that were just rooms filled with a different colour with the same concrete wall and floor texture. Puzzle games obviously rely on good puzzles and too many of them seemed so poorly designed. Even without the impossible to solve puzzle I would in no way recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129113524', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1596408236}
review:
Like nothing else I've ever played - Kairo is one of the loneliest and most mysterious games you'll experience. Everything about it - its grainy visual style, abstract and monumental architecture, haunting soundtrack, and almost complete absence of words and dialogue - combines to make it a thrilling discovery. After seven hours with it I'm left still wondering what it's all about or what it's trying to say, yet still satisfied at what I'd just been through. Almost impenetrable yet also in its own way fascinating. 

So what do you do? Functionally it's a first-person exploration game with mostly mechanical puzzles, which involve pushing objects, turning valves, aligning things, that sort of stuff. These puzzles are pretty much the engine room of the game, serving as both a mental challenge and the way of breathing life back into this world that Kairo presents you. The playing areas are large and it's very impressive watching the whole area come back to life after you've completed the puzzle. Along the way you can collect hidden runes, hear bizarre echoes of human voices long gone, see broken images of places that seem to hint of a connection to more familiar settings. It's essentially environmental storytelling, but it's extremely fragmented and abstract, tantalising but keeping you guessing as to the true message of the game. 

There are also optional puzzles, which - for me, anyway - were much harder than the main ones. The only one I have managed to solve so far was music-based, so was very challenging for me as I've got a very bad ear for pitch or melody! They are interesting diversions, but the meat of the game is definitely in exploring all these surreal, interconnecting areas that lie relatively dormant before you've put everything back together. Kairo captures the sensation of being completely alone and lost, and while you may not fully understand it, you'll be quite reluctant to turn it off.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978347215', 'num_games_owned': 962, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1593491229}
review:
I can not in any way imagine how this game could have mostly positive reviews. There seems to be a story of some sort that maybe involves the world ending but they never give you any information you can use to piece it together. The puzzles range from "as simple as walking into a room and touching the one object that looks interactable" to "guess what shape we want you to draw with no hint of any sort" to "play a tune using these objects... we aren't going to tell you the tune".

There's not a lot of backwards progression so at least you don't have to worry about falling back too far when you die, though it seems ridiculous that they even allow you to get into a situation where you can fall since it adds nothing to the game. The visuals almost seem to be purposely simple geometry but in a lot of sections it seems like they tried their hardest to make something look interesting and it just boiled down to colored cubes floating around...

The sound design is awful, with very loud noises loading as you enter a room and ambient music disappearing when you touch a door so you can never trust that you aren't going to be jarred violently out of whatever mental state you're in.

I honestly have next to nothing good to say about this game and I have to believe the good ratings are bots. There is just no way this many people thought this game was good...

author: {'steamid': '76561198062623579', 'num_games_owned': 745, 'num_reviews': 234, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1654394331}
review:
Highly underrated minimalistic mystlike. It's very heavy with atmosphere despite it's simplistic visuals, and has a surprisingly cohesive and specific story to it, all told exclusively through environmental clues. Honestly I think the storytelling is it's most impressive attribute, you may not understand it by the end but the hints are there. Electron Dance wrote a great article explaining it all if you're interested, though of course be sure to only read it after having finished the game yourself. If after reading it you think i'm weird for thinking it's so neat, I'll clarify: The story itself isn't why I'm impressed, but mainly by the way it's told.

Story aside, it's environments are a lot of fun to explore, it genuinely feels alien and as if you're exploring something you weren't meant to find. (Especially with the game's 3 optional hidden puzzles, 2 of which are practically unfair) Pretty much everything is made of basic geometric shapes, yet it still manages to have quite a heavy atmosphere. It's really neat as it's exclusively through shape, color, and sound design that it builds it's atmosphere from. Yet it still manages to be quite dense in that regard. The dark synth-y soundtrack gives this feeling of being somewhere you're not supposed to, but there's little moments of levity in some areas which really makes them stand out. It's really well done.

On the topic of puzzles, they're decent. There's good ones but the bad ones definitely stick out, there's 1 that's quite boring and 2 that are so vague I honestly don't understand how they passed playtesting. Thankfully the game has a hint system in place that resolves this though. (though 1 puzzle near the end still required me to look up a walkthrough as the hints weren't helpful enough) The fact the puzzles are mainly about reviving large ancient machinery keeps them interesting, where they would otherwise be bland. But there are still a few that are just genuinely good puzzles on their own. Overall I'd say the puzzle design is the game's weakest link, but the presentation of them is what kept me from finding them boring. One final note i thought was interesting is that you only interact with stuff by touching it, you never click on anything. I thought it was kinda neat how that fits the minimalistic design of everything else.

Overall Kairo has a lot of brilliant ideas, sticking so heavily to a minimalist design philosophy that it manages to make some things out of it that I hadn't thought possible before, mainly with it's storytelling and atmosphere. It suffers from it's puzzle design but thankfully the presentation prevents them from feeling like a slog. I think $5 is a perfect price for it.

It's a rough gem, but it's still a gem. - 4/5

author: {'steamid': '76561197981390123', 'num_games_owned': 648, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 503, 'last_played': 1490667386}
review:
Kairo, where do I even begin? 

This is a pretty standard puzzle/walking simulator game, but I think this game came out long before the term walking simulator was a thing. The world is inventive, alien and haunting. The music was perfect and heightened the sense of atmosphere in the game. The game is almost Lovecraftian with it's design. There's a lot of interpretation that needs to go into the game's plot and setting, nothing is really told to the player bluntly. It's one of the games that can make a case for "games as art". 

This game isn't for everyone, there's no action, there are no characters to interact with, and there's no plot other than what the player interprets and perceives themselves. I normally don't play games like these, but the abstract nature of the game world and the overall atmosphere of the game really resonated with me. 

I'd give this game an 8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198914919471', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1586982578}

author: {'steamid': '76561198313765948', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1601494159}
review:
No story line. Zero. None. You keep thinking one is going to pop up. It isn't.
Puzzles are interesting and fun but I want a reason to be solving them. There is no reason without a story.
Not a spoiler because there is no story line: Halfway through the game you find a skeleton that has carved "I am alone here" into some maybe stone. That's as close to a story line as you are getting.
Graphics are super basic but I wouldn't care about that if there were a reason for it, like something that would be included IN A STORY LINE.
Yes I can imagine a story line into this game. No I don't want to do that.
Games with puzzles and good story lines:
Myst IV: Revelation (WHY IS THIS NOT YET AVAILABLE ON STEAM?)
Dreamfall Chapters
Really MOST puzzle games have at least some semblance of a story line to give you a reason for all you are doing. This is the first one I've had reason to complain about because IT HAS LITERALLY NO STORY LINE AT ALL. HOW do you immerse yourself in a game when the entire time you are all, "Okay, but what is this place? Why am I solving these puzzles? When is the reason going to present itself?" It isn't. Ever. Nothing. If my mind were entirely mechanical I would recommend this game. It may be fun for people who love logic puzzles but are not creative or emotionally inclined. Personally I want both.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108383681', 'num_games_owned': 875, 'num_reviews': 1050, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1586013776}
review:
This game looks exactly like my square-ish creatings in 3D MAX back when I was a child in 2006. You would say it is the developer's STYLE, but no, even for a square-ish style you have to add something and make it more eye-pleasant, this game is just lazy-made game. Puzzles weren't that bad though. The problem is that you can't die here. I was quite enjoying the game, despite of all of these flaw, until in Garden level I fell on the bench of the map and there is no way to go up, even if I die I immediately respawn at my last place - on the bench. And there is no save / load function to prevent this.

EDIT: Controls are terrible, too. It is really annoying to move, especially considering this game could be called Walking Simulator.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016478665', 'num_games_owned': 400, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1584996961}
review:
So, this review might be a bit weird because this game is trash, yet i recommend it
BECAUSE
the game itself is nice, you get

- you can walljump in some areas and on every slight slope (feels like a 89° wall would be possible to just jump up tbh)
- i got softlocked by the games reset function twice in 10 min (so far) (it places you where you had last contact with ground if you fall, means if you jump to a ledge where you cant get back from you are softlocked luckily a restart fixes this)

author: {'steamid': '76561198030856885', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1573338699}
review:
[h1]There is not much to this game.[/h1]

I had hopes for this game. It looked like one of those big, weird and mysterious atmospheric games. The sort of game that can absorb you into itself and keep you exploring and wondering what is this strange place and what is it about.
Unfortunately, instead of big, weird and mysterious, it turned out to be empty, same and arbitrary.
Game is full of the textures that look the same. Various objects and rooms seem rather arbitrary with no purpose or logic to them and most of the areas are really empty.
The wonder and mystery didn't really last long for me.

There are puzzles in this game, but they are really arbitrary as well. Some puzzles you can solve on your own, some puzzles just by stumbling around and some puzzles not at all. I got to a place where I couldn't progress. It appeared to be a puzzle, yet no matter what I did nothing would happen. So I back tracked to try and see if I could find anything really to help me progress, but I just ended up at the very beginning of the game.

Ultimately, I think the main issue is that spending more time than absolutely necessary in a room is what ruins the mystery and atmosphere. And if you like to explore, or if you get stuck in a puzzle, you'll start noticing the same repeating textures and the emptiness.
I think there's simply not enough in this game to make the atmosphere work. Every area looks like it's merely a bridge to the next area. It never really feels like I am exploring something, just going through a place with weird architecture and physics.

In terms of gameplay, it's a walking simulator with puzzle elements.

---In conclusion---
Kairo seems interesting, but when it comes to playing it, it loses it's charm rather quickly. Puzzles range from super simple to not being sure what the puzzle even is. With atmosphere that loses it's intrigue and no interesting gameplay, I can't recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992880692', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 239, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1581464663}
review:
Kairo is a first person exploration/puzzle game with an emphasis on figuring out what to do, exploration and a strange/alien atmosphere. I've played a bit more than steam shows because of offline play... but honestly not much more.

I would not call Kairo a pretty game, for the most part levels are made up out of simple geometric shapes, simple particle effects and simple lighting. Honestly, it reminds me of stuff I used to make myself in Milkshape. The atmosphere is overall well done though because the room layout and design feels "alien" and you often don't know what you are supposed to do, or why you are doing anything, or where you are supposed to go. You feel lost, the place looks out of this world, and you have the nagging feeling you are missing something important.

But that brings me to my biggest problem with the game. The "puzzles" are all pretty simple it just takes a while to figure out what you are supposed to do. Solving them didn't feel satisfying or challenging, but the puzzles that take a while are frustrating because you end up just going "what am I supposed to do? What can I even interact with?". This is made worse by rooms that have no puzzles and are functionally hallways. You can waste a substantial amount of time exploring a room (which is again, not usually much to look at) only to move on to the next room in frustration. There are collectibles but they reward you with nothing other than an achievement if you collect them all (or an alternate ending apparantly but I never got that far).

Also, there is no real story to speak off. I never made it to the end of the game, so they may explain it all right at the end, but leading up to it... there is little to nothing. It teases you with fuzzy pictures, with barely audible radio-like dialogue... but it amounts to nothing. There may be a deep mystery that is very hard to solve at the bottom of these bread crumbs but it is so obtuse, so removed from the regular game, only hardcore fans will really dig deep enough to enjoy it. And this game does nothing to earn such devotion.

Without satisfying puzzles, nothing interesting to look at or experience, and no story, I can't recommend this game. It got the atmosphere right but little else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118583236', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 359, 'last_played': 1579438004}
review:
クリアしたのでレビューをば。
ってかこのゲームにちゃんとしたエンディングがあったことに驚きですが。

まず、一見LSDのようなうろつきゲーに見えてその実MYSTという感覚です。
ゲーム内において一切の説明がありません。Escキーから開けるメニューに若干の操作説明と3段階ヒントがある程度です。
その肝心のヒントも「そこは分かってんだよ！」と思わず言いたくなるフワフワ感。
考えるな、感じろ、と言われているような錯覚さえあります。

メニュー画面ぐらいしか文字が無いので誰でもできる、という反面、抜群に不親切です。
いや、別に貶しているわけではありません。アンディーメンテ作品や初期のファミコンのような手探り感、もとい、プレイ方法すら試行錯誤して見つけるというところまでも"やりがい"としてカウントしている類の難解なパズルゲームです。

また、スクリーンショットでは実感できないぐらいにスケールが大きく、移動に結構な時間がかかります。一応、走ることはできますがちょっと速くなる程度なので、移動も楽しめる人でないとイライラするかもしれません。
そのスケールの大きさとボリュームを鑑みて520円は妥当だと思いますが、パズル大好きというほどでもなければセール時に何かとついでに買った方がお得だと思います。

廃墟が好き、遺跡が好き、うろつくのが好き、シンプルが好き、パズルが好き、多少難解でも根気よく取り組める、という人にはオススメできます。
逆に、探索は好きだけどパズルは苦手、短気、方向音痴、シンプル過ぎると飽きる、という人にはオススメできません。


以下、具体的なゲーム内容です。嫌な人は見ないように。


実態としては廃墟や遺跡のような無機質な建物内部に点在するパズルを解き明かして行く、というものです。
FPS視点、視界にプレイヤーの映り込み無し、WASD移動、マウス操作がカメラ、後はEscメニューで。

多分、全4ステージかな…？プレイ間隔が空いているのでうろ覚えですが…。
1ステージの中にパズルが幾つか存在し、それらを全て解くと次に進むことができます。
4つか。少ないな。と思うかもしれませんが一つ一つ規模がデカい上に、進むごとにさらにデカくなっていくので心配ご無用です。むしろ、もうお腹一杯まであります。
シンプルな地図がEscメニューで見れますが、部屋単位でしか見られないので方向感覚はある程度必要です。

パズルは直観的なものから覚えゲー、大掛かりな仕掛けを用いるものまで様々で、よくもまぁこんなに思いつくなぁと、この点に関しては感心するばかりでした。但し、全編通してパズルな分、幾らか理不尽なものもあり、youtubeに上がっている攻略動画をチラ見することも。
とはいえ、自分にとっては時間をおいて再プレイで解けるものがほとんどだったので、クリアまで漕ぎ付けられました。

また、各所に散らばっている白いシンボルを集めるという収集要素もあります。
自分は途中で気づいてクリアまでに半分ほど埋めてリタイヤしました。
クリア後は各ステージへと飛べるワープゾーンが解放されるので、収集要素はもう一度見まわる気力があるならクリア後でも良いでしょう。

もののついでで買ったゲームでしたが、パズルの難度を除けば自分は好きです。
好きな人は好き、という類のゲームだと思うので、うろうろとパズル好きな人は買ってみては？

author: {'steamid': '76561198853858420', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1575508113}
review: Kairo might be the most cryptic puzzle game I've ever played. There are no instructions, no in game text, and no voice overs. Puzzles are hinted at and solved exclusively through environmental cues, which can be subtle. Your enjoyment of it will depend heavily on whether it's core loop- stark polygon graphics, puzzles based on subtle environmental cues, and a tone that mixes wonder and dread- appealing. Give it a try if you want to see Portal or the Talos Principle striped down to their most minimal elements and given a uniquely mysterious atmosphere.

review: Kairo was a very abstract sort of game. The environments are very stark and bleak, but they are beautiful in their own way. For a game that seems so basic, it kept me playing without any boredom. It's not exactly exceptional, but I thought it was worth spending about 3 hours in its trance-like state. I wish a bit more was explained at the end, but that mystery is surely intended. Pick it up in a sale if you like "arty" games and/or walking simulators with some light puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031938583', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 293, 'last_played': 1648347762}
review:
Kairo is a world of surreal, foreboding architecture. Pillars rise from an infinite red mist, platforms interspersed between. A park of blocks in a black void, underlit by a green glow. Strange machinery that feels alien yet familiar. And behind it all, a purpose - obfuscated, hidden, but gradually revealed through the environment. Deeper secrets lie in the nooks and crannies of Kairo, revealed to prying eyes and inquisitive minds.

Play the demo on the developer's site for a taste of the experience. If you like the demo, you'll like the full game. And do yourself a favour - go in as blind as possible. Let Kairo surprise you.

Mysterious, awesome, and at times terrifying, Kairo is well worth the price for a tremendous atmospheric experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198184124650', 'num_games_owned': 65, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1573606849}
review:
Kairo is primarily a walking simulator with a few puzzles thrown in. There's nothing wrong with walking simulators or puzzle games, but this one was incredibly slow and tedious. Most of the game was just walking through corridors with nothing much interesting to look at. All geometric shapes, all factory-like. 

Puzzles were either far too easy or way too difficult (like, impossible without a walkthrough difficult.) Even after knowing the solutions to all the puzzles, I couldn't figure out where I was supposed to gain the information to solve the harder ones. 

Lots of backtracking too. Very maze-like. Wouldn't recommend unless you want to get frustrated.

review: I really love these surreal games with desolate, unexplainable environments. The sense of being alone and the aural music with the somewhat mystical devices and areas are fascinating. That being said, I've had this game since release, and it's still f%^&*ing confusing. I have no idea where to go after a certain point or really know how to figure some of the puzzles out. author: {'steamid': '76561198068512031', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1572998475}
review:
This game never really clicked for me. The puzzles left me with a kinda hollow feeling, I never had any of those ah-ha moments that makes puzzle games satisfying, it was more of the frustrating "I just don't know what this puzzle is trying to make me do". The ones that could be solved using logic and not random guess work were far too easy, consisting of "replicate this shape", "press the buttons in the order shown here" and "stand on this platform til the moving thing is in the right place".

The game wasn't as much challenging as it was nonsensical

author: {'steamid': '76561197995099615', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1321, 'last_played': 1572925766}
review:
Do I recommend this game? Yes and No.
Many of the puzzles in and of themselves, are challenging, but there are some just not fair. They break logical consistency with other puzzles. There are puzzles that actually misdirect you from the correct solution; a puzzle whose solution is not within the game itself; and red herrings galore.
But I was entertained and challenged. I recommend that after you're pulled your hair out over a puzzle, don't hesitate to look up the solution online because it is probably a puzzle you can't solve on your one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097998533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 974, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1644302589}
review: This is still one of my favorite puzzle games. With what little budget it has, it managed to make a chilling atmosphere, puzzles that range from just satisfying to really cool, one of the best ambient soundtracks I've heard from a game, and a neat story with a neat way of telling it too. I'm a sucker for brutalist and otherwise weird architecture and this game definitely scratches that itch too. There are no real traditional puzzles in the game and the variety keeps it really fresh. And contrary to what most think there actually is a story to unfold, it just never spells out anything. Honestly my only two criticisms are with the hint system, which goes from barely helpful to way too helpful, and the [spoiler]RNG puzzle, which is a lame excuse for a puzzle imo[/spoiler]. Other than that though, I can't recommend it enough, especially at it's price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002051803', 'num_games_owned': 201, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1569580209}
review:
Kairo is 3D platformer where you solve puzzles. The graphics are a little dated with the use of low quality textures and the film grain effect can be nauseating however thankfully you can turn that effect off.

This minimalist game uses a lot of Brutalistic-like architecture which can be polarising, and the puzzles aren't for everyone because they're very esoteric. You practically have to guess what to do or use the hints provided in the menu.

Furthermore, there is no real story to this game. Just a lot of walking and working out these surreal "puzzles" that make no sense and are completely arbitrary. There are some "implications" of a story, but it's mostly just fan theories taking advantage of some symbolism and implications. There's no narrator, characters or enemies - it's a very unusual game that may not suit everyone's tastes.

The ambient sounds give off this surreal, other-worldly atmosphere which I found interesting, but in the end I didn't feel very motivated in playing this game. It just felt utterly pointless and more like an art project.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988332522', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1419901072}

author: {'steamid': '76561198024242855', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1568134131}
review:
This plays like a game jam entry. The graphics have the effect of an unfinished greybox demo, there is little thought or effort put into narrative purpose to any element of the setting, and the puzzles are simplistic and tedious.

They put a film grain and some haunting music over it in an effort to make its bare-bones pointlessness feel like an intentional artistic choice instead of a failure of imagination and design.
