author: {'steamid': '76561198031670464', 'num_games_owned': 578, 'num_reviews': 485, 'playtime_forever': 16, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1562715599}
review:
Στα [+]
•  Εντυπωσιακή εμφάνιση, μέσα από μιά διαφορετική οπτική. 
•  Κάποιοι πρωτότυποι γρίφοι. 
•  Ανετος χειρισμός καί απρόσκοπτη κίνηση στό 3D περιβάλλον.

Στά [-]
•  Η βλακώδης χρήση ιστορικών στοιχείων σ' ένα εντελώς εκτός τόπου καί χρόνου περιβάλλον. "Enter the lost world of Kairo... Explore abandoned monuments..." γράφει ο κατασκευαστής, κι εντάξει, από τήν αρχή καταλαβαίνεις ότι ο σχεδιασμός τών κτιρίων καί τών χώρων γενικά, δέν έχει νά κάνει μέ τήν ιστορική πραγματικότητα αλλά μέ μιά φανταστική, εφφετζίδικη, minimalistική απεικόνισή τους. Κανένα πρόβλημα μέχρις εδώ. Τό κακό προκύπτει όταν τά λιγοστά διακοσμητικά στοιχεία πού θά συναντήσεις σ' αυτούς τούς φανταστικούς χώρους, όχι μόνο δέν έχουν καμιά σχέση μέ τό Κάιρο ή τήν Αίγυπτο, αλλά αντίθετα παραπέμπουν είτε στήν Αρχαία Ελλάδα (τοιχογραφίες καί παραστάσεις από αγγεία) είτε στήν Μεσαιωνική Κίνα (παγόδες)... Κι επειδή μού είναι λιγάκι δύσκολο νά πιστέψω ότι ο κύριος πώς-τόν-λένε δέν έχει κάποιες στοιχειώδεις ιστορικές γνώσεις, προκύπτει η εύλογη απορία, πρός τί ο τίτλος Kairo; 
•  Μερικές επαναλαμβανόμενες ιδέες στόν σχεδιασμό τών γρίφων. 

Συνοψίζοντας
•  Ανετος Τίτλος, χωρίς πολλούς προβληματισμούς αλλά μέ αρκετές ευχάριστες εκπλήξεις.

Βαθμολογία: 3/5

Παρεμφερείς Τίτλοι
FRACT OSC
LIGHT OF THE MOUNTAIN
MASTER REBOOT


http://adventures-index10.blogspot.com/2012/10/kairo.html

author: {'steamid': '76561198090054708', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1562447354}
review:
Kairo isn't much of a 'game' as it is just a series of puzzle rooms you need to walk to with a touch of exploration to find secrets. The areas are much bigger than they need to be, though I suppose that padding is there so the runes aren't so easily spotted without spending time scouring for them.

I enjoyed the puzzles. It's the same kinda deal as The Witness where you're just dropped in with no directions, no explanations, and no story. It is just puzzles for puzzles sake with some visual hints/scenes pointing to some kind of apocalypse. So if that's what you want then I can recommend this for you. 

It is a bit pretty at times despite only being boxy shapes awash in bright solid colors with a grain filter on, but can also be a bit nauseating.  When opened at full screen it moved all of my desktop icons to my secondary monitor but these were all fixed by just using a windowed mode. Overall I decided on a thumbs down just due to it feeling hugely unpolished, and while the puzzles were a bit enjoyable the only ones that were difficult seemed to be ones that didn't really make much sense to even those who've made walkthroughs; which isn't a good reason a puzzle is be hard.

review:
このゲームには1問、自力で解けないパズルがある。
夜空に星座を描くパズルがあるのだが、解くためには鍵が4つ必要なのに、ゲーム中に登場する鍵はランダムで1つだけ。残りの鍵は他のプレーヤーと情報共有することを前提にデザインされている。つまり、攻略動画を見ろということである。

私はこのパズルを解こうとして、無駄な時間と労力をつぎ込んだ。音がヒントなのか、オブジェが鍵なのかと散々悩んだ。あげくに自力攻略不可と知ったときの虚無感といったらなかった。

他にも、実際は図形が鍵なのに、ボタンごとに異なる音が鳴るから「音がヒントなのか」と勘違いさせる素敵ギミックがあったりなど（一方で音が鍵のパズルもある。紛らわしい）、パズルゲームとしてのデザインは褒められたものではない。

ただ、全てのパズルが悪いわけではない。謎の文字の意味を類推して解くパズルは総じてよくできていて、やり応えがあった。

パズルゲーとしてはやや難ありだが、謎の遺跡探索ゲーとしてはよくできている。一見無駄に広そうな空間が広がっているが、実際にはエリアが細かく区切られているから無駄に歩き回らさせれることはなく、次々と新しいエリアを見ることができて楽しい。収集系の隠し要素や、ちょっとしたイベントなども用意されている。
落下死したり、モンスターに襲われたりなどの余計な要素がないのもいい。

価格から考えれば充分楽しめるゲームだと思うが、星座パズルだけは注意。考えるだけ無駄なので。

author: {'steamid': '76561198068268909', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 578, 'last_played': 1450894667}
review:
An oddly suspenseful and very atmospheric, abstract puzzle game (bordering on walking simulator). It's not Myst or anything, and the story it tells (if it does tell one) is really hard to make any sense of, but it is a really interesting experience. The sound design and art are married together in a way which makes the minimalist presentation rather engrossing. Figuring things out still doesn't feel like an accomplishment, but the puzzles aren't unfair in terms of difficulty (I got stuck once or twice, eventually figuring things out after a bit of trial and error). The desire to see and know more about Kairo's setting is the main thing that will push you to keep going.
If you like puzzle games or walking simulators I'd suggest giving Kairo a shot, it doesn't really feel like a game in the traditional sense but it's interesting enough to warrant a playthrough. It won't appeal much to those who don't have at least a mild interest in puzzlers at the very least.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014907395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1558418569}
review:
Whoa. This has been sitting unplayed in my library for *years*, but, holy shit, what is this beautiful game I just finished playing?

I am so glad that I played Kairo after playing later, similar games (like NaissanceE and Fugue in Void) or meta-games *about* games like this (like The Beginner's Guide and The Magic Circle). Because playing this now is like going back in time to that moment when demoscene aesthetics were just beginning to coalesce into a new sub-genre ("brutalist-inspired 3D puzzle-adventure games"; wait, is that really a thing?). Or maybe it's more like playing the games made by the fictional designer in The Beginner's Guide. Kairo is wild. And, wow, does it have fantastic music and haunting ambient sound. Wear headphones, for sure.

The difficulty ramps up quickly, but fairly. My one complaint is that one of the solutions ended up being beyond merely challenging (the room with the [spoiler]two rotating gears with shapes in increasing numbers of sides; the fourth solution (pi) was just, ugh, seriously beyond me[/spoiler]), but the in-game hint system got me through it. And aside from that one problem room, I didn't need to use any other hints (or by the time I did try them, they weren't any use anyway) and I also avoided online guides. What I'm saying is that the puzzles were hard, but 
not at all impossible. The game's just about perfectly tuned so that puzzles feel inscrutable for *juuuuust* long enough to be really satisfying to figure out. 

When a game's solutions click into place like that, it really feels fantastic. It's the reason I love puzzle games, or even just puzzles *in* other kinds of games. And, for me, that was how I felt most of the time while playing Kairo. Great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011595325', 'num_games_owned': 2468, 'num_reviews': 928, 'playtime_forever': 173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 173, 'last_played': 1557023834}
review:
Não tenho nada contra jogos minimalistas, mas Kairo é tão minimalista que parece ser um projeto inacabado. Além de não ser nada intuitivo e não possuir historia o jogo meu deu tontura por algum motivo e isso é a segunda vez que isso acontece (segundo a comunidade steam não foi só eu). Gosto de resolver puzzles, mas aqui você têm que descobrir se algo é um puzzle ou não, resolver sem contexto praticamente na tentativa e erro. No valor do jogo têm muitas jogos neste estilo melhor.
------------------------------
I have nothing against minimalist games, but Kairo is so minimalistic that it seems to be an unfinished project. Besides being not intuitive at all and having no history, this game make me dizzy for some reason and this is the second time it happens (according to the steam community it was not just me). I like to solve puzzles, but here you have to find out if something is a puzzle or not, solve without context practically in the trial and error way. On this game price tag there are many better games in this style.

author: {'steamid': '76561198339490205', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1556729439}
review:
全く説明のないまま変な世界に放っぽりだされ、パズルを解きながら進んでいくゲーム。

説明が一切ないうえに、パズルのゲームデザインが直観的に分かりずらく、解けても「え、今ので良かったんだ･･･」と何となくモヤッと感が残りあまり達成感が感じられず。
建造物のデザインはかなりシンプルで、自分がsteamでプレイしたゲームではNaissanceEに近いと思ったが光の処理の違いだろうか、こちらはあまり美しいと思えなかった。部屋の色がやたらどぎつい赤や青だったりするのもあまり好きじゃない。

author: {'steamid': '76561198018893258', 'num_games_owned': 3721, 'num_reviews': 744, 'playtime_forever': 351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 351, 'last_played': 1556310634}
review:
ファーストパーソンパズルゲーム。
不思議な世界でギミックを動作させてパズルを解いていくゲームだ。特にパズルについての説明がないのでギミックを動かして変化を調べて解いていかなればならない。多くは直観的に解くことができるが一部は非常に分かりにくい。一応文章によるヒントがある。
シンプルな世界のデザインだが奇妙なオブジェクトがあったり部屋ごとに印象的な色付けがされていて雰囲気は良いが、やはり説明不足なところが目につく。部屋のパズルを解いてピースみたいなものを手に入れるなどパズルをクリアしたことを確認しないまま部屋を出ると、またその部屋のパズルをやり直しするはめになったりする。説明がないのはコンセプトのためと分からなくもないがその点だけは残念。
低価格であり抽象的なゲーム性ということを許容して、不思議な雰囲気のゲームをプレイしたいのならオススメだと思う。

review:
I liked [i]Kairo[/i], I enjoyed the puzzles, I enjoyed beating the game and I definitely feel like I got my $$$s worth -- but when you get to the ending, the game gets pretty disjointed. The tone of the ending really doesn't fit at all with the atmosphere of the rest of the entire game, and there's no resolution of anything at all.

So, if you like [b][u]very[/u][/b] abstract puzzley stuff with no narrative whatsoever and a deeply ominous atmosphere, jump in. But don't expect it to go anywhere beyond that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005431807', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1551012442}
review:
With Kairo, I have to say, narrative is minimal here. The story is told through the environment, and in particular, your changes to that environment when you succeed at the game's challenges. Instead of GLaDOS talking to you, you work on vision puzzles and machine puzzles and – if you're lucky – secrets scattered in the environment. But I mentioned the word 'minimal' already, and that one applies not just to the narrative, but to the audio, and to even the visuals as well. I think that there was intent there.

Kairo isn't a flashy, in-your-face experience. There is no combat, few puzzles are timed, and even if you fall off a cliff the game will silently and kindly put you back safe. It sits somewhere in-between games like Portal, Myst, Gone Home, Thomas Was Alone or … well, quite a few. The visuals are reminiscent of a minecraft world that's slowly being deleted, the narrative is subtle but keen, and the gameplay is really just a walking sim with some puzzles. The surreal is well and truly in place here, and so is the melancholy of being alone – though you never feel actively threatened in the moment. The atmosphere is occasionally very threatening, however, and I frankly think that that describes something more that Kairo could have been, something more fleshed out, more complete, and with more staying power. Sadly, this potential Kairo isn't what we got.

At the same time, it's not the most successful at what it actually does try to do. I believe it pulls in far too many directions, as alluded to above in the unfinished list. It's a very good experience, lengthened by puzzles more than anything, that you should be able to finish in a day, maybe two. And it's length, well, that's unfortunately a bit of a mark against it. So is the environmental storytelling – because in this case, this implementation of environmental storytelling, is a missed opportunity. Kairo could have been a Thomas Was Alone or a Gone Home, a game so good that it redefines the narrative potential of it's genre, a game that's powerful. Is Kairo powerful? No. Frankly, I came away with the impression of  'It was too late, but we did the thing we were supposed to anyway'. I won't say precisely why, but if the 'too late' wasn't so much a part of that, the game would have really spoken, I think.

As it stands, Kairo is a good experience that you should pick up for the five bucks or so it usually costs, if you enjoy puzzles and you don't have a longer experience on your list already.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995233257', 'num_games_owned': 1146, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1548128103}
review:
Great if you like obscure games that don't give you much direction. The atmosphere is perfect (I recommend turning off film grain). The puzzles make you think, all the information is there its just up to you to put it together. The is a hint option in the pause menu, used it once during my playthrough. Not a long game but I enjoyed every minute of it. For me it was 100% worth the $5, but I can understand how many people would disagree. The way I see it I got 3 hours of enjoyment for less than the cost of going to see a movie.

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198031617164', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 239, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1547471991}
review:
카이로

1인칭 퍼즐 게임.
배경과 음악이 매우 음침하고 어두움.
그래서 조금 몽환적인 느낌이 들기도 함.
퍼즐은 대부분 쉽지만, 어려운 것도 조금 있음.
얼탱이 없는 퍼즐도 많았음.
인디게임이라 그런지 그래픽, 퍼즐의 완성도가 낮은 듯.
퍼즐이 그리 재밌지는 않았음.

게임에 예술적인 시도를 하려고 했던 표시가 남.
무언가 메시지를 담으려고 한 것도 같고.
그런데 너무 추상적으로 만들어 놔서, 별로 와닿지는 않았음.
게임이 그렇게 친절하지도 않고.
무엇보다 게임이 전혀 매력적이지가 않았어서 별로 알아보고 싶다는 생각도 안 듦.

장점보다는 단점이 더 많이 보이는 게임임.
조작도 많이 엉성함.
움직이는데 관성이 붙어서 계속 얼음판 위에서 미끄러지는 듯한 느낌이 듦.
마우스로 보는 것도 마찬가지로 관성이 붙어서 느낌이 이상함.
하다 보면 적응하기는 하지만, 정말 매우 짜증나는 부분이었음.

또 하는 내내 멀미가 심했음. ㅠㅠ
내가 웬만하면 3D 멀미 걸린 적이 별로 없는데, 
큰 모니터로 해서 그런지 이 게임만큼은 하다가 토할뻔 했음.
머리가 아파서 플레이가 정말 힘들었음.

별로 마음에 드는 게임은 아니었음.
그렇지만 짧게 할만한 게임이긴 했음.
크게 추천하지는 않지만, 이런 종류를 매우 좋아하는 사람들은 괜찮을 듯.

진행도: 노말 엔딩 봄.
숨겨진 문양 다 안 모음. 시크릿 엔딩 안 봄.
도전과제 남음.

review:
A bit too abstract to suggest to anyone other then my game developer friends.  It truly feels like a game-maker's game.  No instructions, SFX are very horror-like without there ever being any horror.  

It's tough because I'm very curious about the ins and outs of this game, and what would happen if I completed every room, but it's not gripping enough to make me actually want to finish it.  I love the oldschool artstyle and doing as much as possible with very little actual programming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056873791', 'num_games_owned': 592, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1544373821}
review:
[h1]Kairo[/h1]

A journey of abandonment, heroin substitution and car sickness.
From the get go the way my eyes took to the screen, motion had me wondering if i needed the metaphorical paper bag as i flicked through the option settings like a frantic piano player short of keys.
I thought it was safe, i thought i would be ok now but all i did was trade my visual hijacking for an emotional influx of abstract solitude and a state of overwhelming helplessness.
If your looking for a witness or Talos Principle experience you wont find it here. What you will find however is its a game that plays you, not you it and on that note leave you to decide if its fate will coincide with your own.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073730003', 'num_games_owned': 175, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1543175496}

author: {'steamid': '76561198174279703', 'num_games_owned': 274, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1543422125}
review:
解密还是比较适中的，场景宏大，视角感很强，背景音乐诡异，建模有点粗糙。
到底讲了什么意思，以下纯属个人见解。
游戏中穿插了好多图片，数学，历史，科学，文明，物理，化学，生物。。。各种各样的图片
就是因为有这些东西这些事这些人，才有最后的那蓝天白云绿树草地。——新世界新纪元
而且游戏中间还有一段DNA基因排序和原子结构。
那个骷髅应该是上帝，而且有一个上帝视角 坐在几个监视器前。一些解密也可以看出一直为某种东西寻找能量提供能量。
可以说是创造灵魂或者是创造生灵吧 不一定局限为人类。。。
在灵魂的制作工厂完成制作之后 通过一种独特的方式来到了现实的美丽世界。

最后一段音乐还是非常棒的，和前段一直诡异的音乐有明显区别，让玩家觉得格外好听。
唯一遗憾的是有一个音乐谜题，外面柱子那有音乐提示。
按照顺序在上面输入 没有任何反应，不知道有什么特殊的解密方式。
尝试多次后还是没有任何结果。 

9/10 分

author: {'steamid': '76561198005004973', 'num_games_owned': 495, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1542725637}
review:
Une chose est claires dès les premières secondes du jeu : Kairo ne plaira qu'à très peu de joueurs. Certes, il a eu son petit succès ; mais même parmi ceux qui ont sorti la CB, une bonne partie s'en sont trouvé déçus. L'ennui et l'incompréhension sont les principaux reproches. Et on peut le comprendre.

Il faut dire que c'est un jeu très conceptuel, autant d'un point de vue graphique que sonore, que les couleurs vives et les sons étranges ne seront pas du goût de tout le monde. On commence près d'une structure grossière, perdue au milieu d'un vide blanc. Plus loin on aperçoit un bâtiment gris à l'intérieur duquel se rendre. On vogue alors de pièce en pièce en traversant des portails. Les salles sont souvent d'une taille colossale, chacune avec une teinte tranchée – vert, rouge, jaune, orange... Absence totale d'élément organique, aucun mobilier, juste du minéral ; des murs aux textures minimalistes, des angles aigus, des formes cubiques... et du vide. Le vide, d'ailleurs, on flirte souvent avec, mais heureusement la chute n'est pas punitive, et nous sommes aussitôt ramené sur le rebord.
Néanmoins, il faut dire que ces gigantesques espaces remplis de rien sont à mon sens bien plus perturbants que ne le serait un château perdu au fin fond de la Valachie.

Rapidement, l'on découvre certaines énigmes à résoudre. Aucun indice, aucune note, tout se fait par l'essai et les réactions sonores ou visuelles que nos gestes produisent. De ce point de vue, Kairo s'en tire très bien. La plupart des puzzles se comprennent vite, et pour ceux qui posent problème, le menu permet d'accéder à des astuces.

Au fur et à mesure de nos pérégrinations et du résultat de nos actions, l'on finit par se faire une idée de la raison de notre présence ici. On extrapole, on imagine... jusqu'à atteindre la fin qui nous donne une réponse satisfaisante, quoiqu'elle reste ouverte à interprétation selon le raisonnement de chacun.

Je ne sais pas pourquoi, cet univers froid et austère m'a fait penser aux BD d'Enki Bilal, donc si vous aimez l'un, vous devriez aimer l'autre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980033076', 'num_games_owned': 1016, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1538776269}
review:
I quite liked this game, all in all. It gives interesting puzzles, it does not punish you severely for mistakes, you can re-do anything you did wrong, or return to a missed puzzle later. Although there's no save-load mechanism, the game does not really need it. The autosave allows you to exit the game at any time to return to it later without losing progress, and since you are able to go back to any place you want, there's no need for reloading old saves. Gameplay is simple and effective, visual style, while a bit too simplistic for my liking, does not look too primitive like some modern games. The overall quality is very high, I've not seen a single serious issue, and only one minor visual glitch (a gap in the texture).

Still, there are some moments I didn't like.

First, some (not many) puzzles are way too hard. Mostly it concerns the optional or secret puzzles. On the one hand, they are supposed to be not too easy, that's the whole point. On the other hand, some of them are just absurdly difficult to solve without help (particularly, the so-called visual puzzles). But even in the main sequence there was one task I failed to solve and had to consult a walkthrough guide to beat it. Even after reading the solution, I didn't understand why it should work like that. I had to search for another guide with the actual explanation of the puzzle mechanics, and even that did not sound very reasonable to me. Maybe, it's just me, but all other main sequence tasks seemed way easier, this particular one was too out of balance.

Second, the colorful visuals has its problems. Having to work for considerable time in a fully-bright-red room was not friendly for my eyes at all! Others were not so bad, but still, some too-colorful rooms were not comfortable.

Third, might be a spoiler: [spoiler]there is a fake rune which I'm not sure whether it's a bug or a deliberate misleading feature, but it did cause me much pain, because it happened to be the first rune I've seen, and I couldn't do anything with it, so I thought all other runes were the same, and I didn't try to collect them even when I saw them. So after I found out about runes from the walkthrough, I had to backtrack to search and collect them.[/spoiler]

Forth, there is no way of disabling controller input which may be a problem for some. I have EDTracker attached; it is a head tracking device which represents itself as a joystick. So the game took that as a real joystick and started doing weird things (because obviously, the input sent by it is not anything meaningful). I had to physically unplug the tracker every time I played the game; there is no option to just clear the controller input in the options, the boxes are immediately filled in with whatever axis the tracker emulates.

Verdict: The listed problems are not critical, so I do recommend this game if that's your thing. Even if you get stuck there are helpful guides in the Internet and in the Steam Community hub (although I do recommend to try and solve the puzzles without help first, it's much more fun). I have no regrets with spending my money and time with Kairo, it's totally worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030946133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 383, 'last_played': 1543443979}
review:
Kairo es un juego de puzzle/exploración en primera persona, que se destaca más que nada por su atmósfera. Te hace sentir completamente solo en un mundo extraño.
Me recuerda un poco a un cuento de Borges llamado [b]El inmortal[/b], a la ciudad de los inmortales que describe allí:
[quote=J.L.Borges]Este palacio es fábrica de los dioses, pensé primeramente. Exploré los inhabitados recintos y corregí: Los dioses que lo edificaron han muerto. Noté sus peculiaridades y dije: Los dioses que lo edificaron estaban locos.[/quote]
Además, el precio, especialmente en las rebajas, ¡está muy bien!
Si no te incomoda la sensación de soledad en un juego, y te gustan los juegos como Antichamber, sin mucha historia, pero con mucha ambientación, este juego es recomendadísimo.
No tengo un set de VR, por lo que no sé cómo se comporte en VR.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032646584', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1588593776}
review:
Wahałem się pomiędzy TAK/NIE w wyobrze polecenia. Gra jest conajwyżej OK. W skali od 0/10 dałbym jakieś 5. 

Ogólnie gra była wciągająca dopóki miałem nadzieję, że zacznie się coś w niej wytłumaczać. Jak już doszedłem do wniosku, że ta gra to tylko coś w rodzaju zlepeki korytarzy i zagadek to zacząłem tracić zainteresowanie. Gra po prostu tak słabo nagradza gracza za postęp w grze, że po przejściu jej w niecałe 2h 30 min (tak, gre da się przejść szybiej niż czas który macie na zwrot gry) nie mam najmniejszego zamiaru łazić po mapie i szukać sekretów, które podobno tam są.

+ Niektóre lokacje robią wrażenie ogromem i atmosferą.
+ Ogólna atmosfera jest tajemnicza i ciekawa.
- Brak jakiegokolwiek wytłumaczenia czym jest Kairo, gdzie jesteśmy, kiedy jesteśmy a najważniejsze po co?
- Gra słabo nagradza gracza za postęp.
- Zagadki są często albo super proste albo wręcz nieintuicyjne i ciężkie do rozwiązania. Nie było chyba ani jednej zagdaki po której byłem zadowolony z siebie. Raczej takie, które były dziecinnie proste lub takie po których czułem się nieco zażenowany z racji niedopracowanej logiki lub po prostu nabiegałem się jak głupi bo przyciski rozrzucone były po ogromnych lokacjach. 
- Cena; podobno kiedyś ta gra była za 99c (4PLN). I za taką cenę bym nic nie mówił. €5 za 2h średniej rozrywki to moim zdaniem za dużo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130913911', 'num_games_owned': 123, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1540712805}
review:
It's a little sad that any reviews towards this game will only be seen by people who already have it. Personally, I liked the game so much, after I bought the version on the website (and beat it) I bought the steam edition (beat it again) and wrote this review (which I'm writing way after beating it the 2nd time)

Kairo is a simple, first-person, puzzle game. By simple I mean there are four controls, WASD to move, mouse to look, space to jump and shift to sprint. When you intereact with something in the enviroment, you push it or walk on it. It's a very atmospheric puzzle game, there is no ther person, creature, entity, thing in the world other than you. The game was a story, and it isn't super hidden, but if you speed run the game or don't pay attention to the world, you'll probably miss it.
Totally worth the money, you should absolutly get it if you havn't already.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031596248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1474016307}
review:
Ziemlich cooles Abandoned-world-spiel.
Futuristische Maschinen, seltsame Plätze und man fragt sich in der Einsamkeit: warum bin ich hier, was ist hier passiert und was sind das für seltsame versteckte Botschaften von Menschen oder Wesen die ebenfalls durch diese Welt gewandert sind.

Auch wenn die Grafik abstrakt bleibt, wird das "Allein in verlassener Welt" bzw "Ratte im Labyrinth" - Gefühl sehr gut eingefangen.
Es hat beinah meditativen Charakter zu erkunden, Rätsel zu lösen und meistens ganz in Ruhe bei der Entdeckung vorzugehen. Manche Räume strahlen bisweilen eine Bedrohlichkeit aus, das es Nachts gespielt, ganz ohne Jumpscares auch ein klein wenig zum Gruseln taugt. ( Gilt für ganz zart besaitete Zeitgenossen)

Wer Abandoned-World-Spiele mag kommt hier voll auf seine Kosten!

author: {'steamid': '76561197963491216', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1532547976}

author: {'steamid': '76561198063147588', 'num_games_owned': 347, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1532613726}
review: Would be alright if the camera and movement were not garbage. It actually made me feel sick from the slight delay between when you wanted the camera to move and when it actually would. The controls and movement feel just like the defult unity rigidbody and player movement scripts. author: {'steamid': '76561198271601800', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1529154354}
review:
In my opinion, the beginning of a game is the most important part of the experience. The intro defines the player's mood and perception of said game before any gameplay is introduced. It lets the player know that they are about to play a sad game, or a scary game, or a cutesy game. It pitches the whole idea of the game to the player, and they decide whether they like it or not. No matter what the game does right or wrong afterwards, the player will stick to the intro as a reference point for whether the game is good or not. The intro affects sales, it affects the community, it affects a company's future.

And this game screwed up, big-time.

After the Locked Door Puzzle logo is presented, the screen goes black for a few seconds, and then you are just there, in the ugliest environment imaginable. No explanation, just you, floating on unsightly grey blocks, with a simplistic, ugly room in front of you, and a slightly more complex, but still upsettingly ugly gazebo behind you. And all around you is a puke-colored void.

I don't know what the devs were thinking! Had they run out of ideas? Come to think of it, that's not a valid excuse, seeing as the game literally has no story or structure to it. It's like a Walking Simulator made by the Disney Channel. The movement is too slow, and many of the puzzles are so easy that you begin to wonder is maybe the devs have no faith in humanity whatsoever. Whatever, see if I care. Honestly, I don't know why I didn't refund this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110670256', 'num_games_owned': 333, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1638829424}
review:
This game is very mystic feeling. The graphics being so primitive help in my opinion, as they give me the same atmospheric vibes as the original deus ex, but it also comes from the scales of the rooms, the colors, and especially the soundtrack. Also, there's clearly some meaning to all of this, that make it more than wandering through random rooms solving random puzzles. It's an interesting, atmospheric diversion, complete with a built in hint guide for when you get really stuck. Which I did have to refer to sometimes because I'm lame as hell.

I will note that there was a bug for me, where I couldn't pick up a rune, and as a result, I can't get the secret ending. Also movement feels like you have butter on your feet, and some puzzles feel a little too obtuse.

review:
Для меня эта игра прежде всего о совершенном одиночестве.
Может я просто находился в таком состоянии при прохождении, но удивительно легко гемплей “вживил” в этого блуждающего человека по бесконечно пустому миру Каиро. Визуальное и - частично - музыкальное составляющее передает действительно какое-то новое впечатление от, казалось бы, очередного паззла.
Больше всего меня зацепило от рекурсии взглядов игрока в секретном зале - очень сюрреалистичный момент.

Из минусов только жутко надоедающий и совершенно не к месту звук гонга.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141299554', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 603, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1559754706}
review:
Ещё одна абстрактная игра. На этот раз с полной свободой перемещения - мы можем постоянно бегать по одним и тем же локациям. Да и, собственно, придётся бегать чтобы найти все спрятанные тайники и ключевые элементы. Даже после прохождения игры её можно продолжить, чтобы собрать недостающиеся элементы, попасть в ранее закрытые двери.

Начинаем игру странно: вокруг ничего нет кроме каких-то силуэтов в виде построек, парящих в "небытие", и мы вынуждены бродить от одной двери к другой (двери тут тоже весьма странные на вид). Чтобы разблокировать дополнительные проходы нужно разгадывать загадки. Некоторые из них довольно не сложные, например, составить иероглоф нарисованный на стене. Другие уже сложнее и лично я не понял их логику, например, "музыкальные кнопки".

Игра полностью немая, нет никаких реплик, никаких вздохов - только шаги. И кажется, что мы совсем одни. Кажется...

author: {'steamid': '76561197974430488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 556, 'last_played': 1516298727}
review:
Hmm, trippy.

This short indie game is very artsy. It manages to achieve a great arcane atmosphere with simple controls, a lack of plot, blocky graphics and eerie drone music. You can walk, jump & run – and that's it. Things are activated by approaching or stepping on them.

If only the game was more polished.

Moving around feels as sluggish as if every floor tile was a bit icy, and something as simple as turning while you have momentum can result in unexpected drifting. While walking! In fact, if you lose momentum while walking up stairs, you might get stuck a bit … Which is certainly no game-breaker, but it shows how unpolished some basic mechanics are.

I would say, the game design itself could have benefitted from some polish as well. See, you can solve a lot of the puzzles without understanding why that worked; and for some others, you might *never* get an answer to, as the puzzles just don't make any sense, or the solutions cannot be understood even in hindsight – even the person who wrote the (current) top Steam guide provides the solution for the clock puzzle but says they don't understand it.

There is one timed puzzle which you cannot solve unless you run – which the game never teaches you. Similarly (a minor nuisance), some other hints and collectible runes change the pre-established rules a bit (in the last world, nonetheless), and expect mechanics that have never been introduced.

I personally struggled with the "minigolf" puzzle where a ball bumps against Player-placed stone blocks and has to land in some hole. Why does the ball bounce off to the right?! Instead, marking the stone blocks with carved arrows could have easily conveyed to the Player that the direction cannot be changed; or better yet: the shape of the stone block could have been a right-turning tube block. Stuff like that could have helped, so that the majority of that puzzle solving attempt wouldn't have been wasted on trying to change the direction.

I personally didn't mind the monotonous music, but the simple graphics were in my case a bit too simple and too apalling in order to keep searching for the collectible runes without a walkthrough. It's just not fun to saunter through this place.

Kairo feels like a nearly-finished student project. I won't recommend it. It *can* be enjoyed, sure; the stuff I criticized isn't really *frustrating* … But honestly, there are better games out there that do the same.

[ 5.o / 1o.o ]

review:
This game is what I've been looking for from Puzzle Games, something that causes confusion, frustration, and then self-loathing for how dumb you must have looked for when you actually figure out the puzzle.

If I had to compare this game closest to any level of skill required, it'd be Myst Series of puzzle games.

Do you know of the Myst series? If you do, and you had enjoyed the games, I'm reccomending this game as it brings about the same level of difficulty of puzzles (With the exception that you do get 'Hints' towards solving the puzzles.)

Kairo gave me chills down to my very core, it preturbed me with its complex puzzles, and I enjoyed every single ounce of it. Best of luck with these puzzles, believe me, you'll need all you can get.

review: Kairo is the product of game dev practice, and imo not meant to be played by gamers. It feels like some of the environments from The Beginner's Guide, but without any of the context. There is a lack of direction and motivation to continue playing, puzzles are either too simple (like [spoiler]the triangle lights[/spoiler]) or unsolvable without a walkthrough (like [spoiler]the combination puzzle in the 'water' room[/spoiler]), and controller support is unpolished. Before these points are fixed, players can't focus on the intended unsettling experience.

review:
Got this after having finished QUBE, Naissancee, Antichamber and attempted Disoriented. I was not let down and I want more of the 'series', tho Antichamber seemed the best of its kind.
It's got small cons compared to all the pro points, only cus I can nitpick the shit out of everything: like being so cryptic and abstract and letting you walk through areas that are actually puzzles, not knowing you're supposed to solve stuff there. Without the hints telling me an Nth room is NOT part of the hub puzzles, I would've quit right there in the first hub, instead of going back to solve the transition room. And it's not that oh boi I had to go back, cus I did go back to places on my own accord after finishing the game, np. It's more about going 'Oh, this IS a puzzle!', in a frustrating way, instead of in a really happy, revelating way (like I experienced in Naissancee after finding the moving parts in a section).
But I got over it and was glad that there are more and better puzzles that were waiting for me.
Another small con is the feel of the game taken as a game like any other. It took me a while to get used to walking even, as you feel heavy and starting to move is like slowly accelerating from 0 to your normal walking speed, and actual movement is like sliding (like lowered friction and gravity), while running is not really a speed boost. Oh and some block collision pushes you backwards, making walking up certain stairs rather... funny. But no movement skill puzzles in the game, so this uncertainty of my position only added to 'oh no ima fall' when going towards an edge to look down. So this 'feature' worked out ok.
Which brings me to some other pros: Falling isn't punished, neither failing a puzzle. I mean sometimes you do need to fail as you first try out the room and see what it does, but I don't see it as a design mistake, specially if you're not punished and can start over or actually reset the room - neat feature!
The visuals have both pros and cons, the architecture overall is boxy but well planned and drawn out, with plenty of griebling and nice optical effects. Some structures/objects could've been made with custom models, like the made up coffins, which makes the game feel unfinished or poorly funded, but it really looked bug free (I couldn't pick up 1 of the beads on the string or w/e, and that's it, can't remember any other bug), which reveals a lasting, high quality finished product.
While the abstraction is used in telling the story and drawing a conclusion, to me it wasn't needed as a drive to move on, so I didn't complete all the hidden puzzles nor read the hidden meanings. For my soul it was enough to simply go from hub to hub and room to room, open area to another, solving them GOOD puzzles like a happy camper.

So yea, fkn play this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025540438', 'num_games_owned': 7101, 'num_reviews': 558, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1511994954}
review:
A solid mix between atmospheric exploration and some good room-based puzzle solving.

Puzzles do a good job of not delving into "Wait, what?" logic, though a few have issues with pretty much being guess-and-checking between 4-5 possible combinations until one works.

The story seemed practically nonpresent, maybe a bit -too- open to interpretation? Secret ending was absolutely fabulous though.

While the graphics are simple, the lighting, structures, and soundtrack combine into a wonderfully surreal experience.

8.7/10

review:
Kairo is a beautiful, totally abstract experience. I believe that I have never seen such a game in my life. What I liked most was absence of NPC's and even the player itself. I felt like I am the bodyless ghost who goes from location to location and solves riddles. There were no signs of human presence [spoiler] except for a sceleton and some pieces of art in the gallery [/spoiler].
By the way, riddles are nice. I liked the bits of a background story when solved some of the riddles.

Also the in-game ambient was quite good. It added to the feeling of abstractness and loneliness. 

Totally reccomended for everyone who is tired of game companies pursiung the pure realism in games. If you just want to wander and awe, then this game is for you.
All in all, it is 10 out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1506998068}
review:
Tags: Adventure - WS - Walking Sim
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Feels unfinished. Long list of outstanding issues.

Oustanding Issues:
+Movement inputs stay stuck for a perceptible window of time after letting go of keys making movements floaty
+Camera lags behind mouse cursor creating instant motion sickness and further imparting this input lag feeling to everything
+Environments float in black untextured space for no reason
+Environments are made of barely textured early3Dblocks composing small corridors. Easy to fall off the map
+Vew few assets per say, staircases, the occasional portal. Otherwise the 3Dblocks sometimes create little shapes, like a tree for example, but they are just clumsily stacked together as if made by a child
+Game involves reaching some kind of temple and exploring sublevels, presumably for a collectible but all I found was a different exit portals that returned me to the same portal I started at....
+Game has no narrative per say and just dumps you in
+Music is vaguely atmospheric but has some moments that perceptibly irritate the ear with buzzing background noises
+There is an annoying film grain to everything

Conclusion: This feels like a few test maps from someone learning an engine and not an actual game with design.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050488139', 'num_games_owned': 2858, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1503756832}
review:
Kairo (PC - Steam) - 3/10
Покупая эту игру на распродаже, я был готов к посредственной графике и прочим косякам, обусловленным бюджетностью продукта. Основной причиной покупки и вовсе послужил скриншот, напомнивший мне лестницы из "Мора" (до сих пор ловлю мурашки, при воспоминании о тамошних локациях), необычные цвета и надпись "exploration", которую разработчики поместили аж на первое место в списке ключевых особенностей (обожаю игры, в которых есть простор для исследований - от старомодных РПГ до относительно молодого жанра "симуляторов ходьбы"). И, конечно же, я ожидал, что в игре с упором на исследования, будет что исследовать. На деле же почти все локации примерно одинаковые (различаются лишь цветом фона) и совершенно пустые. Никаких необычных строений, никаких интересных предметов и символов - ничего, цепляющего глаз. Просто нагромождение различных геометрических фигур, в большинстве случаев лишь отдаленно напоминающее какие-то постройки. Во многих ревью и тегах мелькает слово "атмосфера", но особой атмосферы я тут так и не заметил. Дизайн локаций - незапоминающийся; сюжета вроде как нет; звуков почти нет, но некоторые эффекты режут слух своей громкостью; музыка совершенно не цепляет и не создает нужный настрой. Так что где люди находят эту самую атмосферу для меня осталось загадкой - игра банально пустая. Чего в ней много, так это паззлов. Порой банальных, а порой неинтуитивных и совершенно нелогичных - попадаются даже такие, которые можно решить только усилиями нескольких игроков (или прочитав гайд). Стоит отметить, что труднорешаемых и не поддающихся логике тут заметно больше, чем простых. Медленное перемещение, ограниченное взаимодействие с объектами, неудачная структура уровней (из-за которой не удается окинуть всю локацию взглядом) - все это делает процесс решения паззлов еще более раздражающим. Вроде бы расписано все красиво, да и отзывы с оценками как от игрожуров, так и от простых игроков очень хвалебные, но по факту Kairo очень нудная, скучная и кривая игра, в которой нет ни одного аспекта, стоящего внимания.

author: {'steamid': '76561198299077704', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1617156350}
review:
I'm gonna be the first to admit that I'm terrible at puzzles. I'm pretty sure that every puzzle game I've ever played had to be beaten using a guide. Therefore, I'm somewhat limited in what I have a right to say about Kairo. Which isn't all that bad, actually, because I still can't think of anything to say. I completed Kairo less than half an hour ago using a very well-written 100% guide here on Steam, and the experience has left me mostly speechless. So, what do I have to say about Kairo?

Well, I guess I can start by describing the game. Your protagonist is not technically a character, just a nameless, formless entity which serves as your window into the world. [spoiler] In fact, as revealed by end of the game's third part and by one of its final secrets, only two other characters even exist in this world, neither of whom are named, and only one of whom you will meet. [/spoiler] Kairo is not a game about characters. In the vein of a lot of walking simulators like Dear Esther, puzzle games like Submachine, and mixes of the two like The Witness, Kairo is a game about its world.

So, what is there to say about the world of Kairo? It's blocky, first off. The world is constructed primarily from stretched, stacked, and overlapping cubes, with the occasional sphere or disc thrown in, with colored fog fade-out in the distance. As for the world itself, I can only think to call it desolate. Kairo's environments are extremely varied, both in size and comprehensibility, but they all stand a chance of alienating you, which is something I found prevalent in Kairo: Alienation. The world around you is made from very simple shapes, but organized together into incredibly complex architecture. Often, you will find yourself on small islands of terrain within vast voids, which of course can make you feel very small in comparison to the world around you. Add to that the idea that you are the only entity occupying this world at the moment, and isolation combines with scale to create an impression that you are not just small within this world, but utterly insignificant within it.

That last part is a lie, however. You are not insignificant to this world. In fact, by solving its puzzles in some sort of ridiculous cosmic game, you will manipulate the great machines of Kairo to fulfill a purpose that may not actually seem clear until the very end. The puzzles in Kairo are, of course, the part I have the least right to comment on. As I am utterly terrible at puzzles, this really isn't a game I was able to play to its fullest. The game still does its best to make things accessible to people like me, however, through the hint system. In something like the style of the Professor Layton series, Kairo's puzzles operate on a three-hint system. The game menu provides a hint option, and in rooms containing a puzzle, that hint option offers you three click-to-reveal hints which progressively state what you're supposed to do in a certain room, and how to do it, more simply and directly with each hint. Of course, as most games of its type do, Kairo sometimes offers up puzzles so complex or esoteric that even the guide I followed could only describe the solutions to the puzzles, and not the logic they follow.

There are also secrets, of course. There are six runes within each of the three greater areas of the game, hidden in plain sight on the sides of columns or buildings so that you wouldn't ever see them by following the straight and narrow paths between portal doors and solving puzzles when you encounter them. Each greater area also contains a pedestal switch, which triggers a noticeable and often disorienting or unsettling shift in the immediate room, while also unlocking a very well-hidden door in a previous room in that greater area. Finally, each greater area has what's called a Vision Puzzle, which will not be solved through Hints and are most likely intended as a project for the player community to solve through examination and experimentation. Collecting all of these secrets in a single run of the game will unlock a small bonus area, containing few interesting easter eggs and a door leading to the secret ending, which is worth seeing for its sheer absurdity alone.


Everything I just said should be taken with a grain of salt, though, since I did just say a whole lot about a game that I don't actually think there's a whole lot to say about. At the end of the day, I loved Kairo mostly for the experience. The alienation and isolation of the game's vast world create a feeling I personally enjoyed, and the tiny puzzle pieces of a story the game gives you are interesting enough to keep the theorists guessing for a while. And finally, since this is a game I don't really know what to say about, even after saying so much, I want to express that I'm not recommending this game to anyone. If you disliked things like Dear Esther or The Witness, I don't think you'll enjoy Kairo. I'm reccommending this game to people who read this review and others, understand what people who like this game think about it and like about it, and then think, "Hey, I might like that too."

author: {'steamid': '76561198061833425', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1690646898}
review:
First off, this isn't a bad "game". Although calling it a game might be a stretch. The game tosses you into an open world without an direction or information. Kind of like Legend of Zelda which I like. But there are no enemies or NPCs to interact with. So I suppose it's more like Myst in that way. But there isn't any inventory or any objects to collect. Certain things you can press on with your character.  This is to solve simple yet baffling puzzles in the environment. I'd lean to calling it more of a visual novel, but then again there is no dialog. I've tried the game a couple times and just can't get into it. It feels more like an art installation than a game. Perhaps this is what the author was going for. 

From a technical standard point, it runs well even on a lower end laptop. There doesn't seem to be any glitches or crashes. If functions well, I just don't know if I'd call it a game per say.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026806776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 302, 'playtime_forever': 215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1501362197}
review:
So, graphically, [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/233230/]Kairo[/url] isn't much.  This sombre and moody atmosphere of monochromatic light and endless heavy stone-and-concrete textures with fog and film-grain effect isn't just part of some dark setpieces, it's a dreary and oppressive constant throughout the entire game.  The environments are not spooky-scary, just alien, megalithic and unwelcoming.  It makes the game a dark and tedious trudge through an uncaring place that's largely ambivalent to your presence.  You solve puzzle after puzzle to accomplish you're-not-sure-what just hoping that eventually you will emerge into sunshine and light, and it never really happens.

[i]Kairo[/i] is one of those mysterious games that screams questions: "Who am I? Where am I? What am I doing? Why am I here? What is the purpose of all this stuff?"  It never deigns to answer the question.  Thanks to some additional information from very well-hidden easter eggs and a second ending, fan forums have put together a reasonable theory that fits the observed facts, but it still has enormous gaps in it that have not and will never be answered.

[i]Kairo[/i] is similar to [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/210970/The_Witness/]The Witness[/url] in being an intelligent and mysterious puzzle-driven game that refuses to fully answer the questions it raises.  Quality-wise, [i]Kairo[/i] is significantly inferior to [i]The Witness[/i], of course, but it's accordingly priced a lot lower. This can be a great experience, for those who accept from the outset that the game will be surreal and joyless, full of questions for which the answers are forever withheld.  It's like the game equivalent of [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ingmar_Bergman]a Bergman film[/url].  If you aren't turned off by that kind of solemn artistry, then you'll enjoy it.  It's definitely not a game for everybody, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991477148', 'num_games_owned': 621, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1501951859}
review: Perhaps I wasn't the target audience for this game, but I generally found myself just trying to get through the different parts of the game instead of enjoying them. Some of the puzzles are interesting and make you think a little, but others are just "trial and error" until the solution works. I found the environment and overall atmosphere generally convoluted; I couldn't shake the feeling that I was walking through random level experiments. I suppose it makes sense for the price point, but if you enjoy a good puzzle game you can probably skip this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056857016', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1448378260}
review:
Несмотря на то, что в стиме наиграно часов 20, на самом деле за самой игрой провёл не больше трёх часов, остальное время ушло на поиск видеопрохождений. 

Игра - абстрактный симулятор ходьбы с порой слишком сложными загадками, что вынуждает бесцельно гулять по пустым локациям. Сделано, конечно, весьма талантливо, почерпнул для себя много визуальных графический решений. Отличный памятник абстракционизма с претензией на сюжет и гнетущей атмосферой.

К сожалению под конец становится ясно, что сюжет отсутствует и это самое большое разочарование. Kairo - это процесс, весьма занятный экспириенс, но лучше пройти его на ютубе.

review:
I was thinking if I would recomend it or not... I decided not. I didn't enjoy the game (even if I tried). 
I bought the game in sale, because from the pictures it reminded me of the Star Gate series. I was wondering what it would be aboout. But, it doesn't offer more than what you see in the pictures above. Well... maybe I am not part of the target group. I like interesting puzzles, which you are able to solve on your own, when you think (like Portal), or games where the puzzles are challenging, you see the guide and you get it,  but here... I just followed the guide first third of the game and didn't get a thing. 

I would recommend this game to someone who:
- likes to explore unnown territories - such as pyramids
- likes creepy music
- likes games with no clear story
- likes games without a word, spoken or written - (here I don't get why the game comes in 5 languages, to have options in five languages?)
- likes puzzles with difficult-to-read hints (like a real ancient machinery)
- doesn't mind that he/she cannot see his/her legs and hands

author: {'steamid': '76561198143034343', 'num_games_owned': 193, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1499886301}
review:
Kairo is an immersive walking, atmospheric puzzle game. I abandoned it early on because the experience was just too creepy for me. The atmosphere in the game is amazing because the creepiness is driven mostly by sound or the lack of sound. The visuals add to the mysteriousness of the world, and overall Kairo is very well-made. That said, I didn't meet any jumpscares except for when the invisible walls for the green maze suddenly emerged out of the ground in front of my face.

From what I can tell, the puzzles vary in difficulty, and you do not need to solve the hard ones to progress in the game. To discover the secrets, you do have to explore the world thoroughly and solve the difficult puzzles.

If you don't like the heebie-jeebies from walking alone in a forest, take a pass on this one. But it's a great game.

P.S. Also, people have complained about motion sickness in the game; just turn off Look Smoothing in the options, and it becomes much better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103858151', 'num_games_owned': 1743, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 455, 'last_played': 1499640633}
review:
Non so come ci sia finito nella mia libreria, nè perché l'ho avviato ieri, ma caz*o che bella perla nascosta avevo. È come Myst, ma disegnato da De Chirico, astratto ed alienante da far impressione e lasciarti con una sottile sensazione di angoscia. La mancanza di NPC e ovviamente di dialoghi aumenta considerevolmente questa sensazione. La storia quindi non viene raccontata direttamente dal gioco, ma sta al giocatore ricavarla area dopo area, puzzle dopo puzzle. Un'idea me la sono fatta, ma non voglio spoilerare... Ovviamente anche la OST catalizza la sensazione di tensione mentre si esplora questo niente a metà tra il minimalismo ed il cubismo.
Il gameplay è il classico puzzle game a stanze, con visuale in prima persona (suppongo sia dedicato per i VR): i puzzles alla fine sono abbondantemente risolvibili, ancor più facili con i suggerimenti in game. Le aree segrete invece richiedono molto più ingegno ed esplorazione, e difficilmente senza una guida si possono localizzare.
I controlli purtroppo sono molto imprecisi, inoltre la visuale "balla" troppo, quindi può essere anche fonte di chinetosi. Una brutta pecca.
Forse non vale 5 euro del prezzo pieno, ma in saldo è da provare assolutamente...

author: {'steamid': '76561198156965768', 'num_games_owned': 888, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1506005087}
review:
Kairo es... raro. Creo que me gustó. Y aún así, no lo recomiendo. No es para cualquiera, aún bajo el rótulo de ser un juego indie.
Kairo transmite desde el primer momento la sensación de que algo grande está por suceder. De que hay una metáfora detrás de todo lo que ocurre. De que el mundo onírico que presenta va a ganar coherencia con el tiempo. Y no. Y no. El juego avanza con puzzles que logran mantener el interés, aunque no abriguen casi ninguna lógica (la mayor parte de ellos son de prueba y error); lo terminarás y lo comenzarás de nuevo a ver si algo se entiende mejor, sacarás todos los logros (y los cromos!) y aún así no cobra sentido. Quizás esté más allá de mi comprensión. Hay detalles escondidos, imágenes de un tono post-apocalíptico, todos los escenarios parecen ruinas, se escuchan transmisiones de radio muy poco claras y un tanto angustiantes en varios puntos específicos del juego, y aún así... nada. Perdón si alguien se da por spoileado, pero en realidad es que el juego sólo crea más ambiente con eso; no es que lo use como pieza central. Tras cuatro horas y medias de juego, lo tengo al 100% y dudo seriamente volver a tocarlo alguna vez. Y no es eso lo malo, es que... simplemente deja una sensación de extrañamiento poco agradable. Quizás con el tiempo vuelva para cambiar esta nota, pero de momento es un no recomendado, aún cuando lo he disfrutado.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118392184', 'num_games_owned': 3465, 'num_reviews': 347, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1499193830}
review:
[i]Je me demande ce qu'il faut prendre pour comprendre les sens cachés du jeu. De ce type de jeux en général en fait.[/i]

[b]Kairo[/b], sorti en 2013, est un FPS d'exploration indépendant, où l'on incarne quelqu'un, qui explore les ruines de Kairo tout en résolvant ses énigmes.

[h1]Les plus :[/h1]

- Les énigmes sont sympas, sans être insurmontables. Par contre, je n'ai pas compris la logique de certaines, que j'ai un peu résolues par hasard.. (ou avec des guides, tant certaines sont... WTF ?)
- Possibilité d'avancer à son rythme, de passer d'une énigme à l'autre, sans se sentir bloqué.
- L'ambiance assez sombre, mêlé à la soltitude, est réussie.
- Une durée de vie respectable. Environ 3-4 heures pour finir le jeu. Rajouter 1-2h pour trouver tous les secrets.

[h1]Les moins :[/h1]

- Graphiquement vilain.
- Autant j'ai un esprit ouvert, mais là.. Je cherche toujours le sens caché du jeu, de son univers et de son histoire.
- Un gameplay un peu plus poussé aurait été sympa ? Car à part avancer sur des plateformes et sauter, c'est pauvre.

[h1]Conclusion :[/h1]

[b]Kairo[/b] n'est pas exceptionnel, mais n'en a pas la prétention. Ce petit jeu indé saura combler les fans du genre, à savoir, d'énigmes, et d'exploration. A prendre en solde.

_ _ _ _

[h1]Si vous avez trouvé cette évaluation utile, et que vous voulez en discuter autour d'un verre, venez rejoindre notre [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AlternaTyff#curation]page de curation et nos forums ![/url][/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198318976797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 664, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 664, 'last_played': 1499147434}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197992850864', 'num_games_owned': 1318, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1497624512}
review:
Kairo é um jogo de puzzle e exploração.

Você joga em cenários bem coloridos e com uma sensação de vazio. Alguns cenários são belos e outros um tanto arrepiantes.

Você deve avançar solucionando os quebra-cabeças para prosseguir ao próximo local. O jogo em si não é tão difícil de solucionar, exceto os puzzles secretos que sem a ajuda do guia eu não teria a mínima noção de como resolver.

Usei o guia também para encontrar as runas, que são marquinhas minúsculas em partes do cenário do jogo que são muito difíceis de visualizar.

Os gráficos são bem ruinzinhos, mas o jogo foi feito por uma única pessoa, acredito que na engine de Half Life (mas nao tenho certeza).

A trilha sonora é boa, mas nada muito espetacular, apenas combina com o jogo.

[b]PRÓS[/b]

1 – Ambientação Legal;
2 – Rápido de platinar;
3 – Puzzles são em sua maioria justos, não tendo muitos daqueles puzzles sem lógica alguma;
4 – Apesar de ser um jogo indie, não encontrei nenhum bug.

[b]CONTRAS[/b]

1 – Gráficos bem meia boca;
2 – O movimento do personagem é meio estranho (você parece que está patinando no gelo), morri algumas vezes por isso.

[b]NOTA FINAL[/b]

6,5/10

[i]Recomendo, mas nada muito especial.
Bom para quem gosta de platinar fácil. 
Pegue na promoção![/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198072033658', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1496777748}
review:
Bottomline: Minimalism does not and should not equal 'minimal effort'.

First of all, I am aware this is a four year old game. Also, it's pretty cheap to request a €0,99 refund, I obviously don't care about the money. The developer just didn't put the required effort into the game, and therefore I do not wish to support. 

I bought the game because I was interested in the minimalist, brutalist artstyle of the game and I also have a taste for mystery and environmental puzzles. The developer however, appears to use the word 'minimalism' as an excuse to deliver a rushed game that is, bluntly put, really bad. Incoherent and even nonsensical game design is accompanied by lazy art (for example: symbols are created using text parentheses.)

There are many high-quality minimalistic, abstract games out there in the world; Kairo isn't one of them. If you're going to make a minimalist, abstract 3D environment you should at least bother to do some proper lightbaking and do some research into light and space in general because this game was rife with visual artefacts.

I understand the amount of time and effort that goes into game development, but I recommend spending five bucks on beers instead of this game.

One positive point: I did like the atmospheric ambient music.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962365480', 'num_games_owned': 724, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1497249685}
review: For $5.00, Kairo seems alright. It has a few positives, but a few negatives as well, so I can see why some might not like it. It's weird, it's abstract, it's bright and colorful, and I generally enjoyed exploring the world. I play all the way through in one sitting and never had any motion sickness, but I believe I can see why some people do. There is a jitteriness to the movement, and if there was anything to make me sick, that'd be it. The controls are also kind of swimy, so it's kind of a sliding feeling which I wasn't much into. The visuals for some might seem a bit basic, and has the apperience of a mod for a game, but the music and audio seemed to be alright. Lastly, the puzzles were a bit ridiculous at times, but were all solved without consulting a guide, although the in game hints were used a couple times. Despite these few problems, I do think Kairo is an alright experience, and at a price point of $5.00, you might give it a go if you like weird puzzle games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994799155', 'num_games_owned': 1525, 'num_reviews': 307, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1497066277}

author: {'steamid': '76561198126246691', 'num_games_owned': 567, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1496481577}
review:
这绝对是我玩过得最恶心游戏之一，首先画面非常诡异；游玩过程中无处不在的噪点让人头疼；断断续续的背景音没有亮点；油腻的操作让人想摔鼠标。
我并不想强行拿别的解谜游戏来和Kairo做对比。毕竟我花了四个小时通关游戏，关掉游戏的那一刻，我仍没有理解这个游戏想传达什么理念给玩家。那些把我传送到各种莫名其妙场景的传送门是想告诉我什么？墙上挂满画作，只为藏一个解谜答案在里面？
解谜部分更是做得超级失败，解决一个问题并没有带给我多少快感，我只是在忍受异常恶心的画面和无聊的跑路。谜题没有学习过程，也没有循序渐进的难度系数，只是把一些看上去“好玩“的谜题摆在一起，把各种愚蠢的隐藏门放在玩家面前，让玩家来回跑路开门，这只是一个超级恶心的步行模拟游戏。

author: {'steamid': '76561198045663266', 'num_games_owned': 470, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1494158299}
review:
Hauntingly beautiful, Kairo stuns with it's surreal and brutalist concrete vision of...?

Others have remarked about a lack of meaning in this game, but I think it's there. It echoes through the vast alien chambers of this game, little glimpses of things recognisable. This feels like a monument to us, long after we're gone, made by *something* with a different kind of understanding of space.

The puzzles are satisfying, without being too obtuse. The hint system is welcome, which I only found necessary for one puzzle that required an unreasonable leap of logic. There are apparently deeper puzzles to solve once finished, and  a number of collectables to find. Sadly, I have the patience for neither, although I did my best to hunt round the levels all I could.

The visuals are striking in their simplicity, but are completely appropriate. The audio elevates the mood perfectly; it's utterly outstanding.

I found the end strangely affecting, and the developer's final credit especially so.

All in all, very much recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055517936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1490892417}
review: Kairo pales drastically in comparison to critically acclaimed success, Myst: a game of similar presentation and design caliber, created with a modest budget for its time, and which made a far greater impact on the gaming world. Kairo takes any and all reason that could (and frankly should) be percieved within a puzzle game, wipes its proverbial posterior with it, and readily hands it back to you with a childish snigger. What facets of Kairo that would seem to lead towards some sort of explanation is eerily creepy and unsatisfactory because it doesn't explain a single thing. I found it a disappointment and a borderline insult to the puzzle game genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075148650', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1482690019}
review:
Очень атмосферная бродилка с головоломками, которая казалось бы на первый взгяд из себя ничего особенного не представляет.
Только спустя некоторое время исследований, начинаешь вникать в смысл игры и смысл происходящего вокруг. 
Kairo - это игра абстракция, с интересными головоломками, которые бывают сложными, с хорошо передающей атмосферой таинственности, неизвестности, запоминающейся архитектурой и великолепным музыкыкальным сопровождением.
Но бывают такие моменты когда все происходящее вокруг давит и угнетает, а особенно это заметно в сопровождении каких-то звуков.
Игра не простая, а поэтому в ней нужно постоянно думать, иметь хорошее мышление и если вы обладаете этими качествами, то она определенно для вас, да и в целом для поклонников такого жанра.
Советую к приобретению этого продукта.

author: {'steamid': '76561198315655557', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1491587599}
review:
It's like Dark Souls if you took out the RPG stuff and replaced it with puzzles. Explore some sort of ruins, fix some machines and hope for the best, and hopefully figure out what's going on.

You get what you pay for, though, and this really is only worth about a tenth of a AAA title at best. There are similarly priced games that are more bang for your bulk, but there's something to be said for lighter fare. It's like getting a salad instead of a burger. Buy at your own discretion, but it would make a good thing to show someone not very into gaming, like a kid or a parent.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981426062', 'num_games_owned': 934, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1491521299}
review:
Even if the bland and desolate landscapes compliment the theme of the game, at some points it was taken too far and made some parts quite a chore. The storyline puzzles were of good difficulty, but for the hidden puzzles I had to consult a guide. Perhaps they would've been doable with careful note taking. The runes were of OK difficulty, although I only realized they existed at the end of the first area.

Ran smoothly on my 2955U (1.4 GHz dualcore) 2GB RAM machine using the PS3 SIXAXIS controller via xboxdrv. Controls were decent enough, although the character had quite a bit of momentum. In my opinion the run could've been used by default while holding a button had made the character walk.

TL;DR: A decent game if you like some FPS adventuring and puzzle solving. Bought at a discount, but even the asking price isn't bad for what the game offers.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197993459459', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1490775977}
review:
First room teaches you that you can fly (or rather, walk) over bottomless pits.  Then you get hit with invisible walls so you can't fall.  Then you fall.  Lesson learned: mechanics are meant to confuse you.

Level design looks like someone found the "cube" tool and said "this is everything I need".   Most rooms use symmetric architecture to disorient you.  Room are connected by portal-doors with unmemorable splashes of color to distinguish them (e.g. red portal vs. blue portal).  Lesson learned: basic navigation is meant to confuse you.

Puzzles are trivially easy, when they work at all.  There is no "use" button and so everything is activated by stepping on a specific piece of floor or pushing against a particular wall.  Anything more complex, such as pushing a handle on a rotating cylinder, is just as likely to not work as it is to work slowly.  Some rooms have no puzzle at all but things that you interact with like other puzzles.  Lesson learned: puzzle elements are meant to confuse you.

Normally I'd think such a consistent design of confusion was serving a larger theme.  It's not.  It's just a bad game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080661269', 'num_games_owned': 544, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1487557455}
review:
A decent lengthed puzzle game, not much else to say. The puzzles aren't easy but aren't difficult, and can usually be figured out without the hints in the pause menu. The soundtrack and atmosphere was eerie and the look of the game fit with it, regardless of being extremely undetailed. The simplicity isn't really that big of a deal, you can look past it and it's a good look for the game. The exploring was sort of linear, as I found every place I went to had a purpose and it wasn't so much of a "return here later because you didn't do something yet" which I personally like, as aimless wandering especially in puzzle games can be annoying. For an extremely indie game and for a very low price (I got it for like under a dollar), it's definitely worth your time. Achievements are fun to go back and get as well. For me personally optimization isn't all too good, I kept the detailing stuff off to make it run smooth (My setup can run GTA at Ultra, so take that how you will), but I can't complain as the dev is obviously not that experienced. I felt like the puzzles could've been a little more challenging and maybe the story actually developed into something (I felt like there was a story as to what the places you were at are, but nothing was ever explained), but regardless it was a good game and was definitely fun to play through.

Give it a try, it's worth it.

[b]7.5/10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198308250341', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1485357103}
review:
Imagine a walking simulator, except with all the interesting aspects of walking simulators (narrative, interesting environmental storytelling, etc.) removed, and replaced with some puzzles and nothing else. That's Kairo.

It's not a bad game; if all you're looking for is a slow paced, bare-bones puzzle game then you'll enjoy it. The puzzles can be a little on the punishing side, but in general they're reasonably well executed and somewhat engaging. 

In short, if you want a first-person puzzle game which includes puzzles, a first-person perspective, and absolutely nothinng else, then Kairo is for you. 

A good game is any game that hits the target it's aiming at, even if it's not necessarily the most interesting target in the world. Kairo is far from the most engaging game ever made, but it achieves what it set out to do competently, so it gets a recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971971180', 'num_games_owned': 458, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1486080231}
review:
Firstly, I had my eye on this game, I usually like puzzle games. So I bought it during a sale, for less than one euro. I've played it for a little more than an hour, I don't think I'll be coming back to it. 

I don't really know how to review this game. It's... a game, I guess. You walk around in large chambers, sometimes in the void. You solve puzzles that are not at all clear, and if you haven't played it for a while and try to pick it up again, you can easily start to backtrack without even realizing it. 

There is no story, no clear objective, and not anything that really should attract you to keep playing it. But it still has something that draws me too it. Something that makes me want to keep trying, something that wants me to spend a couple of more hours in its foggy empty void. 

The feeling is not enought to make me actually keep playing it, the environments are not captivating enough and the non-existant story/objective is certanily not enough. So I will uninstall it. But this game had some potential, and considering I spent next to nothing on it, got a few cents back from card drops and it has steam achievements I will still recommend it. 

Perhaps you will too feel this strange urge to keep playing, and just perhaps you will actually like it enough to keep on playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013746553', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 597, 'last_played': 1485446187}
review:
Explore a desolate world with empty & strange architecture & machinery, bring them back to life and solve it's mysteries.
This is my first escape in a "walking simulator" but I would call it more of an exploration game where you encounter puzzles to progress further. I enjoyed it immensly. I felt like some Indiana Jones exploring some eerie alien site.

What I liked:
- The simple but effective graphics and the architecture it's made of
- The "grain" effect (especially near some radioactive obelisks)
- The atmospheric music & sound effects
- As you progress, some past locations with no apparent purpose got a meaning and how to solve them
- Most puzzles are interesting, some fairly easy but most have a logical solution

What I didn't like:
- getting all those (some hard to find) achievements to get in the secret ending
- some puzzles with no (apparent) logic at all.

As I said, I enjoyed it immensly. It's like urban exploring (checking out abandoned buildings) 
Recommended for those who like to explore strange environments & solve some interesting puzzles along the way to activate mysterious machinery

author: {'steamid': '76561197986926648', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1490289267}
review:
Un très bon jeu, et ce à un prix très abordable. Les décors surréalistes et ennivrants absorbent complétement dans le jeu, alternants entre le grandiose et l'oppressant et leur côté abstrait les empêchent de vieillir.
Les énigmes, parfois tordues, c'est vrai, sont toutefois compréhensible sans la moindre explication car intuitives, et de toute manière, il y a des astuces claires dans le menu du jeu, dont la traduction est parfaite.
L'histoire est très floue, permettant de laisser vagabonder l'imagination et d'imaginer le sens du jeu.
Je vous le recommande, si vous êtes patient et rêveur. Par contre, si vous n'aimez pas l'ambiance sonore assez new-age et les décors simplistes et hallucinés, ou si les énigmes ont tendances à vous prendre la tête facilement, vous n'aimerez pas le jeu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198333753912', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 450, 'last_played': 1483589575}
review:
十分优秀的一款解密游戏。
基础内容解密难度中上，其实说难点高的多半都是被没用的场景混淆了，还有就是没有明确的提示。玩过几个场景后就知道过度场景没任何解密内容，直接忽略就好了。至于提示，仔细观察都会找到暗示，多尝试也会找到规律。
额外内容，彩蛋成就什么的还是比较费时间的，地图比较大，需要慢慢找，不看攻略真的需要把整个地图翻遍才行。很多场景都很有意思，能看出来作者花了很多心思，内容思想什么的因人而异。

折扣的时候价格便宜，喜欢解密的很适合入手。
