author: {'steamid': '76561197960881955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1448094860}
review:
Kairo is a deeply atmospheric puzzle/exploration game which tells its story only through clues. Thought provoking and simple with some really challenging puzzles. Definitely recommended if that sounds appealing to you.

One minor criticism: The work associated with the achievement 'A Problem Shared' is probably a bit too much to ask of players buying a single player offline game. It requires you to look outside the game for assistance, yet the game never flags this internally or sets a precedent of this occuring in any other puzzle. I genuinely don't understand how players are epxected to know this and I think it makes for a weak puzzle in the end. This is a lot of text to describe something minor easily resolved with a search though. I really enjoyed Kairo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995248114', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1448074579}
review:
I usually like walking simulators/puzzle games, but this one left me feeling like I missed something important.

I had no idea why I was walking around aimlessly solving puzzles in an abstract world. I couldn't figure out what the game was trying to convey, or even find my own meaning in it, and there was no closure. It just felt empty. There were no "ah ha!" moments, just "oh, ok. That's cool I guess."

The puzzles themselves ranged from trivial to extremely difficult. Don't get me started on the random "puzzle" that makes you press a button until something randomly happens after multiple tries... I was constantly at a loss of where to go/what to do I often had to resort to a playthrough.

This is just my experience with the game, your milegage may vary. If you like wandering aimlessly and solving meaningless puzzles, this may be fun. To me, it just lacked a lot of what makes walking simulators/puzzle games fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169763307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 434, 'last_played': 1558885058}

author: {'steamid': '76561198186126747', 'num_games_owned': 473, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1447976061}
review:
Довольно простая для прохождения игра, основанная на метахаосе и японском восприятии минимализма. С самого начала легко проходится и никаких сложных препятствий я пока не встретил. Однако, посмотреть на все это очень даже стоит! Расширяет восприятие и меняет взгляды на привычный мир. 
Не знаю, почему все жалуются на невероятную сложность. За полтора часа игры ни разу ни с одной сложностью не столкнулся и даже заработал ачивку :3
Однозначно скажу только, что обычная логика здесь не работает. Всё на уровне восприятия, всё очень абстрактно и не всегда логично. Просто делай что-нибудь! Можешь нажать эту хреновину - нажми и смотри, что будет!
А так, мозги больше закипают от дурки, которая там происходит. Холодный, сумасшедший мир метахаоса из бетона и камня. Нетворческим людям будет очень тяжело. А творческим - просто рай )
P.S. Прошел игру целиком. Ничего сложного. Простая головоломка с геометрией и интуицией. Но очень атмосферная! Я б там жил )

author: {'steamid': '76561198123138465', 'num_games_owned': 783, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1447876124}
review:
Kairo is a first-person puzzle game set in a minimalistic universe. 
The player journeys through the ruins of a civilization long departed, discovering artifacts and clues about the disappearance of its inhabitants along the way.

The puzzles in the game are not groundbreaking, but they are still enjoyable and somewhat challenging. 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=557747505

The 3D world of Kairo is made up of very basic geometrical shapes, usually being combined to almost give the appearance of a more complex structure.
The grittiness, sparseness and colors pervading each room is part of what I think, creates the game's strongest characteristic: its ambiance.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=557717729

The soundtrack can be eerie, futuristic, ethereal and unnerving and serves to both enhance the impact of the visuals as well as shape the emotional experience of the player.

I found myself enjoying the atmosphere more and caring less about the former inhabitants of the world and the overall message the game conveys. 
In overall, for a small, adventurous indie title like this, Kairo is still an experience worth having for fans of this sort of game. 

7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198027372201', 'num_games_owned': 1128, 'num_reviews': 214, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1445872494}
review:
First things first KAIRO is a straight up Puzzler.
It isn't really anything else, especially barely a game of exploration.
What i think is really good in that regard is that it doesn't seem to lock you into a puzzle.


There is somewhat of an part exploration in the gameplay but it doesn't really reward you for it.
Yes, i know you can find some kind of runes, however that isn't really what i want to be rewarded with when it comes to exploration.

What i want from exploring a world is interesting and inspiring sites and views and in that regard Kairo is rather weak.


One reason why i feel that way is simply taste. :-P
The overall world design is far to abstrcat for my taste, 
The structures in Kairo simply feel to artificial wich leads to me thinking "well, yes, intersting design dear gamedesigner" instead of loosing myself in the world and inspiring thougths like "what may have happened here" or "i wonder what this once was". 
On top of that many elements of the world look really rather unfitting in their surroundings instead of giving me the feeling that they are a naturall part of this structures., The design simply lacks a conclusive and whole overall direction.

The second reason is that Kairo is really rather crude and unpolished. 
Don't get too close to the walls becasue the camera will clip trough the walls.
Strange lighting effects that most likely weren't suppossed to be there or even look like the textures have been placed wrong are visible in the VERY FIRST rooms you will explore in the game.

But the worst are the textures overall. They look really, really HORRIBBLE!
It really pulls you out of the experience if you can count the pixels of what is suppossed to be cracks and holes in walls.

The second weakness is Kairos Sonddesign or rather the lack thereoff. There are sounds and noises but they are more annoying then enriching and in many places sounds simply a re missing where there should have been some noice.
If giant structures in the world are moving i shouldn't feel like they are made of Styrophor and have no weight to them. Wich is exactly what happens in Kairo.

Kairo wants to be a minimalist thing but minimalistic doesn't mean low quality of assets and i feel that is what has been confused here when Kairo was designed.

Would i recommend it?

Nah, not really.
There are several games on Steam right now that do what 
Kairo wants to achieve in a far better and much more polished way.

There are Portal and Portal 2 (of course), Mind - Path to Talamus (wich i have only watched and not played yet) and more.

And if you specifically look for a minimalist style there are NaissanceE, Antichamber and The Stanley Parabel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093220384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1444418668}
review:
The anatomy of a good puzzle can be a difficult thing to understand, and an even harder thing to manufacture. It can't be so easy that it feels like a pointless exercise used to fill otherwise empty space, but not so hard that it feels like it's actively fighting against you to get in your way and prevent you from moving forward. It should give you all the pieces of information you need in such a way that will allow you to naturally make the connection and reach its conclusion under your own enterprise. Ideally it will also have a specific purpose and serve a function within the game's world, if not its story. But most importantly, it has to be fun, to reward the player with a sense of satisfaction and accomplishment once they do put all the pieces together in their head and turn a creative thought into glorious action. Sadly, Kairo fails on most of these counts, and by some margin.

I'm a big fan of the first-person, puzzle exploration genre, so when I saw this being mentioned in the same breathe as games like Antichamber and The Stanley Parable, and especially seeing the art style in pictures and videos, I couldn't get my hands on it fast enough. Unfortunately, it probably has about as much in common with those games as Gran Turismo has with Mario Kart. Initial impressions were really good. You start off at the foot of a throne on a small slab of land seemingly floating in an endless, white void, the only other feature being a large, blocky structure floating a brief distance ahead of you. Some steps invite you down into the white where you find you can freely walk among the nothingness and make your way over to the other structure. So far, so good. It's set the tone with something unique and mind-bending. Everyone loves a good mystery, so already you're compelled to venture further and find out what this strange place is and discover your role among it all... Several hours later, after having unlocked and completed everything, I still feel none-the-wiser about any of it.

Having tried to read up on it on discussion boards and such, the prevailing theory seems to be something about mass  interstellar relocation and your janitor-like role of reawakening a ship on its approach to its new home and the hope of a new chance and fresh start for a dying species - possibly ancient aliens, possibly future humanity... the jury's still out on that one. But to be completely honest, the whole thing feels like pretentious art w*nk of the highest order either way. It smacks of The Emperor's New Clothes to some degree and like there's so much vagueness to everything that anyone can project their own meaning to whatever they like and make it infinitely more profound than it would be were it merely explained to us in any degree of detail. If you have a worthy story then tell it! Let it be known and understood so people can enjoy it and share it. Don't hide it behind walls of damn near impenetrable symbolism and open-ended hints. Rather than coming across as mysterious it just ends up feeling like it lacks any real substance, and were it not for reading all the wild conspiracies, any faint trace of a story would have been completely lost on me as a result.

What I did get was a series of unengaging puzzles in an array of strange environments where nothing seemed to make sense or have any reason. Some are simple switch-based affairs, others are more demanding and require some considered observation and noting, and none of them hit that sweet Goldilocks spot of being not too easy or not too hard. In fact, despite the generous, optional hint system, as time went on I found myself increasingly resenting their very existence in the game as they only seemed to hinder any sense of enjoyment or wonder at the spectacle of my surroundings. That's probably the one thing this does get right, as the stark, minimalist use of bold colour mixed with the challenging geometry of the architecture makes for a real marvel of design. But when that's the only real strength, it ultimately makes this feel like an interactive art installation more than a bona fide game.

So that's all you're really left with. When all you can do is walk, run and jump, with no actual option to manually interact with anything or make use of an inventory or even pick up any items, you just end up roaming around stepping on pressure pads or passing through beams of light until you're told you've completed the puzzle them move on to the next one. The game makes for some pretty pictures, but beyond that there's really nothing else I can recommend about it. In fact, while Steam tells me I spent 5 hours with this, it honestly felt like more than twice that, and I'm pretty sure that even counts all the Alt Tabbing I did as I needed to get away from the game's puzzles for a while. Whenever I was playing it I was thinking about other games I'd rather be experiencing instead, and when I wasn't playing it I dreaded the prospect of booting it up, eventually completing it only to get it over with so I'd never have to touch it or think about it again.

The only reason to have any interest in this game would be to go to its Store page, to scroll down, then to click on the list of similar (and no doubt far better) games in its genre then investigate those instead. Otherwise everything feels too much like art for art's sake and lacking in every other area. In short, avoid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128622576', 'num_games_owned': 769, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 569, 'last_played': 1437057706}
review:
Okay, let's get one thing out of the way first: this game does not look good. The trailer above kinda oversells the graphics — they're not [i]minimalistic[/i], they're [i]cheap[/i].
That being said, everything else about Kairo is great.

Distant cousin of Myst, this game is comprised mostly of puzzles. And there is a compelling diversity in these: some are very easy, some are very difficult; some totally straightforward, some mind-bendingly abstract; and of course everything in between. This makes the progression always enticing and never boring. 
The level design is very cool despite the poor graphics and each level has its own unique feel, the whole game being very "atmospheric". This is brilliantly reinforced by the marvelous sound design, with a really, really awesome music that transported me from puzzle to puzzle in a dream-like state.

Thanks to all these strenghts, Kairo manages to be at the same time fun and relaxing. It is a journey, really, in a land full of mysteries and secrets, where lots of questions are raised and no explanations given — you make your own conclusions from the scarce clues given along the path.

I have no idea how to grade it out of ten, but I am positive that I'd recommend it in a heartbeat to pretty much anyone. The only major flaw that I would point out is the absence of V-Sync which allows some MASSIVE tearing to occur. And the Field of View is rendered in layers, which looks kinda awful. But other than that, well... What's not to like? 

You like puzzles? Get it. Like "moody" games? It's a good one. Like quality OSTs? This one's perfect. You like Myst? Don't hesitate! 
There even is a skeleton hidden somewhere. Spooky!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970314107', 'num_games_owned': 2302, 'num_reviews': 917, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1415772179}
review:
If you have any kind of appreciation for grand, surrealist landscapes, Kairo will hit the right notes for you. Cubist swamps, gravity-defying mechanisms, distant stone cities, and forests of infinite pillars await. Fog and limited draw distance are used to great effect here, shrouding impossibly huge structures from you until you move close enough for them to emerge from the murk. The environments are colorful and unique and seem to tell a story by their very nature. There's no text or dialogue in Kairo, but it has hints of the Dark Souls storytelling-without-telling motif.

Gameplay is about as simple as it gets. You walk, you run, you jump. There's no key for using, holding, or interacting here. Everything you need to fiddle with is done by proximity. This often manifests as pressure plates or stones to push, but there are more creative applications like devices that only activate when you stand in a certain orientation with them. The puzzles get hard too, so be prepared for some serious experimenting and creativity to work out how some of them function. There are some secrets to find as well, which require combing every nook and cranny of the dreamlike architecture... which is something you'll want to do anyway.

The big knock I have against Kairo is that, as well-done as the atmosphere and design is, it still looks like a Half-Life 1 mod. All the shapes lack detail and there are only a few basic textures used throughout. However, the game makes the most of its minimalist presentation, and in the end it could be seen as more of an asset than a drawback if you can immerse yourself in it. Overall, this is a great game for the look and feel it conveys, and it's usually so cheap that there's no reason not to pick it up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142332218', 'num_games_owned': 382, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1442861223}
review:
Minimalist, abstract, and esoteric. I picked up a copy of Kairo because it was on sale and it looked interesting and played it through to completion (with the help of a guide to point me in the direction of my objectives, I admit. They're not that obvious some of the time).

Kairo manages to combine my two least favorite things in a game: slippery controls and almost required sprinting. In-game you can hear your footsteps so I know my feet weren't covered in oil... but it certainly felt like it. Many of the areas are expansive, which is cool, but if you want to try to complete the game the way I did [spoiler]you will need to backtrack through areas you've already visited.[/spoiler] At times like these I found myself holding down the sprint key just to get through these areas as fast as possible. After about an hour of this, my left hand is pretty sore.

On the positive side the environments were cool and my favorite puzzle mechanic- the block puzzles where you have to stand in a certain position in the room to solve them- didn't feel like it was used often enough. I think there's enough in that idea alone to make an entire game out of, should the developer give it a try.

That said I cannot, in good faith, recommend Kairo. Not at full price, anyway. Five bucks for a ~3 hour game that's uncomfortable to play during the second half isn't a great deal by any stretch of the imagination.

review:
В любой непонятной ситуации бейся головой об стены.

Нельзя сказать, что игра сложная. Скорее, нет четкой цели, и всегда не знаешь, что делать, и как делать правильно. Нужно обладать высокой внимательностью, чтобы решить некоторые задачи. Бывало, сделаешь что-то, а потом пытаешься понять, а что же изменилось. 
В некоторые моменты игра вызывает параною. Особенно эти картинки с помехами, на которых можно опознать силуэт человека. Всегда стараюсь уйти из этих комнат побыстрее.
Игра, к сожалению, не смогла подвинуть моего фаворита всех головоломок - submachine. Здесь нет как таковой предыстории, нет никаких намеков на сюжет. Но сама идея - создать мир из простых форм, приправив всё яркими цветами и правильным освещением, при котором не начинают литься слёзы из глаз на 10й минуте игры - вызывает уважение.
Есть один раздражающий момент - в некоторых комнатах фпс падает аж до 7, при том, что обычно держится 50-60. Видимо, это фишка игры наравне с помехами =\

author: {'steamid': '76561198020278853', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1555659818}
review:
I quite enjoyed this game. The atmosphere was great, and it looked really cool. However, some of the puzzles were a bit -too- abstract, and for some reason touching a wall caused my framerate to drop dramatically. This got annoying in some areas, espeically being that the controls in this game aren't very tight, even with the settings tweaked. 

Some areas a a bit bigger than they need to be, so there's a lot of walking to do. Thank goodness there's a sprint button, but it doesn't change your speed that much. 

This game has very little replay value, unless you're one of those people who want to painstakingly go through every nook and cranny to find these tiny symbols tucked in corners of the levels.

I think the game was trying to tell me a story, but I didn't get any sort of feeling of resolution at the end, unless I am supposed to find all those little symbols. That sounds absolutely miserable though. That would be like playing a 3d eye spy game. I have better things to do with my life.

Overall, I enjoyed the game. Puzzles were nice, except for a few, which were really stupidly hard. The game is not that long at all, so these few dark spots really put a dent in the overall experience.

I almost gave this a thumbs down, but at the end of the day, it did hold my attention, and I did say twice in this review that I enjoyed it, so it gets a thumbs up from me. But just barely.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063830022', 'num_games_owned': 207, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1440523920}
review:
If you're looking for a deep, challenging puzzle game with an ambiguous and surreal atmosphere, then have another go at using that search box because you seem to have mispelled Antichamber. I wouldn't mention it, except you can't seem to go 5 minutes of reading about this game without it being compared to Antichamber (indeed, this comparison is what brought me to the game in the first place), and I simply can't see why. Kairo is nothing like Antichamber, and if you're expecting it to be then you're about to be sorely disappointed. This is not to say that I didn't like Kairo, as you can presumably tell from the fact that this review is a recommendation. It's just that my initial view of it was tainted because I was constantly trying to compare it to Antichamber, and in that comparison it, like most games, falls very far short.

First, the bad. The "puzzles"  are probably the main thing here. Barring a few rather interesting ones, they can be solved with minimal effort as soon as you work out what each element of the environment actually is. The main problem, I feel is the lack of a central mechanic. With no way to interract with the environment besides standing on things, puzzle design is extremely limited. In the game's defense, it uses this limited capacity well and rarely repeates itself, but nonetheless you will likely find much of the game unchallenging. Furthermore, the much-touted atmosphere is... eh. It's not bad, but it tries too hard to be creepy, which simply doesn't work with the gameplay. There are a few very effective moments, but overall you'll probably find you just don't notice it.

However, the game just about makes up for these shortcomings with its stronger points. The environment design is excellent, using a rather minimalist block-based design for buildings which contrasts effectively with the more detailed decoration and interactable objects. Along with providing some spectacular views, this helps greatly with distinguishing puzzle piece from environment and the intuitive level design means you'll have little difficulty with finding your way around. Finally, the ending. Oh the ending. I strongly recommend playing through once to get the normal ending, then finding a guide online and playing through again for the hidden one. It won't have as much of an impact if you didn't play through once blind, but I honestly can't think of a way it could have ended better. Utterly unexpected yet actually carefully foreshadowed, it ties the game together and makes you look at the product as a whole from a completely different angle. 

Overall, I recommend Kairo, but only just. It makes up for its shortcomings in a number of ways, and it's certainly fairly unique. If you're looking for a challenge (or, like me, something Antichamber-esque), you won't find it. However, if you're looking for an unusual experience that effectively kills a few hours, you could do a lot worse. For only £4, I'd say it's worth the money.

review:
Minimaliste est un terme qui représente assez bien [i][b]Kairo[/b][/i].

Et ses qualités seront donc aussi des défauts, selon les exigences du joueur : 
> Ambiance complètement épurée, que ce soit au niveau sonore (quelques bruitages ou musiques très discrètes) ou graphique (formes très géométriques et décors vides).
> Le joueur n'est jamais pris par la main, que ce soit dans le cheminement, les énigmes ou... l'histoire (?). A lui de faire tout le travail d'imagination.

Bref, sans être extraordinaire, [i][b]Kairo[/b][/i] est puzzle-game tout à fait honnête, à l'image de son prix en fait.

[h1]Verdict : 3/5 - Ce qui est assez bien, mais pas top.[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198025675343', 'num_games_owned': 384, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1446532156}
review:
Kairo is a slow-paced puzzle game in a similar vein to Myst, if Myst didn't have all the annoying pixel-hunting and weren't a point and click game. Its atmosphere is surreal, strange, and overwhelmingly lonesome. That's the big word I think I'd use to describe this game - lonesome, and that lonesomeness becomes more and more eerie the further you go into the game. You are the only living thing in Kairo - everything else is a hollow, dead fascimile, with archetecture eerily reminiscent of human construction and yet alien enough you might think you woke up in R'lyeh. The world of Kairo is a small world that feels massive, alien, and completely dead... and I love it to pieces and back.

Wandering through the surreal and beautifully eerie world of Kairo is very relaxing, the puzzles are very intuitive and can easily be solved with a little thought, and the simple design really makes it feel like you're stranded. And yet, solving the puzzles is so satisfying, satisfying in that "I'm a goddamned genius!" sort of way. The range of feelings you get from Kairo goes from triumph, curiosity, and awe to fright, paranoia, and hopelessness - and what is art if not something that makes you feel deeply? Anyone who claims video games aren't art has never played this, and that's a damn shame. Did I mention that the music and the game's design is just so surrealistically gorgeous?

Seriously, BUY THIS GAME. It's maybe $5 for a wonderful little piece of surrealistic artwork that recaptures the eerie loneliness and thirst for adventure that Myst did so many years ago in 1992. Kairo is a gem of an indie puzzle game, and anyone who is a fan of surreal artwork, puzzle games, and games where you chill and wander for a bit will love this. You really do owe it to yourself to play it at least once. Who knows? It may become one of your favorite games, just like it has for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050384203', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 465, 'last_played': 1564946235}
review:
Чудесная летняя пора, зелень кругом, птички поют, распродажи в стиме.
В поисках интересного шарю по всему подряд, в том числе по играм без скидки.
Опаньки! Что тут у нас? Какие-то невероятные здания всех цветов радуги и больше, непонятные устройства, нагоняющие таинственность пометки "инди" и "головоломка" в жанрах... Почитаем-ка, как комментирует уважаемое сообщество. Сообщество рассыпается в похвалах, хвалит атмосферу и сложность головоломок. Отлично, беру!
Ну что же, это было предисловие, а теперь опишу свои впечатления. После запуска игры на меня тут же свалилась её неожиданная непонятность и, внезапно, страх больших пустых пространств. Куда бечь? Что делать? Справедливости ради, всё оказалось не так страшно как гласят коменты в отзывах, куда двигаться. становится ясно достаточно быстро, благо все группы локаций закольцованы и связаны между собой. Яркие цвета радуют глаз (кто сказал, что футуристичные интерьеры должны быть безлико-серыми?), архитектура с проегипетско-кубическими мотивами приятно задевает ситховские струнки в душе, а огромные подавляющие мегалиты кругом и ещё более огромные уводящие в никуда пространства внушают трепет и заставляют чувствовать себя не в своей тарелке. Сюжет в игре тоже есть, хотя он прост как три копейки и так же избит: человечество таки разнесло Землю в хлам, что нам кстати, доказывают картины, открывающиеся при решении трёх необязательных головоломок (весьма нечестных, кстати говоря), а мы путешествуем по огромному механизму, явно созданному людьми, и вновь заставляем его работать. Постепенно оживает причудливая машина, показывая своё истинное предназначение.
Итого: это действительно "симулятор египтолога под ЛСД", как высказались в комментариях. А ещё можно добавить "мечта кубиста" и "симулятор загробного мира". Даже если вас не поразит изощрённость головоломок (имхо, достаточно простых) или сюжетная драма (достаточно избитая, виденная в сотнях игр до того) визуальный стиль Кайро, архитектура и цветовая гамма игры точно оставят впечатления. Имхо, Кайро более чем стоит своей цены.

review: Kairo is certainly an odd game. Definitily not for everyone. However, if you are a fan of explorative puzzle games, I highly recommend it. It almost reminds me of the Myst series, in the sense that you are never given proper direction in how to solve the game, but each area is designed to keep the player interested and almost needing to solve the area. I will say that the feeling I get whenever I solve one of the puzzles is immensly satisfying. It brings me back to the roots of what made me love puzzle games to start with. Not to mention that the world you are given to explore is absolutly gorgeous.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141262666', 'num_games_owned': 873, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1038, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 785, 'last_played': 1683565690}
review:
Kairo-это очень интересная игра.
Плюсы-Малый размер игры
Наличие Oculus Rift режима
Очень интересная музыка.мистическая я бы сказал.завораживает.
Отличные загадки.необычные я бы сказал.
Отличное визуальное оформление.
интересная система чекпоинтов
А ТЕПЕРЬ ПРО СЮЖЕТ:ЕГО НЕТ И ОН ЕСТЬ.
В этой игре очень много ...........Масонской символики...  кто поиграет тот поймёт.там по сути все загадки основаны на физике.
Много философских намёков.Как пример там есть Храм Соломона.странные картины.масонские символы.и вообще по сути каждая комната-это 1 философская тема.трудно понять.тяжело.и есть очень страшные комнаты......как найдёте поймёте о чём я. в общем для понятия игры требуется знание масонских легенд,физика,топология,философия,геометрическое мышление.
Ставлю игре 10 из 10.
поиграйте.не пожалеете.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111413915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1438829228}
review:
IMPORTANT: When you hit the normal ending, wait for the credits to play out. They're not long.

Pros:
- Puzzles become interesting when you have no "hand" or "activate" controls. By limiting the player to mere movement controls, old puzzles feel fresh, and there's an extra sense of accomplishment with even fairly simple puzzles.
- The environment's minimalist polygon theme manages, surprisingly, to stay varied, interesting, and even evokative throughout the game, contributing to the theme of "strange and yet familiar" that pervades.
- Difficulty to normal end is low, difficulty to secret end is high.
- No penalty for exploration, experimentation, or taking your time.
- Overall, definitely enjoyable.

Cons:
- The "story" aspect is a little too vague. You paid $5, folks, this ain't Myst or Portal. While there are enough "clues" that a player can vaguely put together a plot (and considerably more blatant clues as rewards for solving secret puzzles), there's plenty that's just left to imagination.
- The mechanic that resets you to a safe ledge can glitch considerably, leaving you in a fall-to-your-death loop, though this can be solved by exiting the game and reloading.
- One of the final secret puzzles is actually impossible to solve on your own. Your game will have 1/5 of the solution, and which fifth is chosen at random. So you're either going to need lots of friends, or cheat and look at a walkthrough.

Final Note: Don't take my playtime as a good guide to the runthrough time of this game. I got irritated and consulted a walkthrough for two of the secret puzzles and half the rune locations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053565865', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 744, 'last_played': 1402110078}
review: I very much enjoyed this game.  There is not enough like this out there.  The game felt very personal, and there was something about the world that kept you exploring.  The atmosphere was wonderful, and it transports you away to this strange and bizarre world.  The conclusion of the game kept me thinking for a while as to the meaning of the game, and I came to a few conclusions.  That is what makes this a good game, it can be interpreted in many different ways.  I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys more atmospheric games with mild puzzle solving elements.  Some of the puzzles are very difficult, there is still one that I cannot solve.  The most difficult puzzles are the ones that really demand you to pay attention to your environment.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973207923', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1438235977}
review:
Kairo is... Interesting. The puzzles were pretty mild and hunting for the runes were an added incentive to explore the bizarre world. The ambient sounds/music added plenty of atmosphere (headphones a must!). Was there some deep meaning behind this game and the imagery/sounds in it? The game's description said there is, but it was beyond me. Though after completing, I don't feel very compelled to research the meaning either.

My two complaints was that I was holding sprint for pretty much the entire game, and I didn't have a Rift to get the full experience, haha!

For sub $5, I think this is worth checking out if you're in the mood for something different.

author: {'steamid': '76561198139919686', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1515069949}
review:
Un monde mystérieux de silence, abstrait et énigmatique. Chaque pièce renferme une énigme, souvent (très) simple et parfois trop dur (pas essentiel pour continuer le jeu) et il n'y a pas d'histoire ou d'intrigue, ce que je trouve déroutant car n'y étant pas habitué, mais ce n'est pas un problème.


Le style du jeu et l'esthétique est assez particulier, mais bon, chacun ses goûts.


Je trouve ce petit jeu très bon et recommandable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049904005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1437037757}
review:
3D - лабиринт с головоломками (после прохождения) 1го уровня можно сказать, что мы в лабиринте.

Атмосфера вокруг: Все в однотонном слабом свете и с каким-то зернистым шумом камеры. Но игрок - это же человек смотрит, а не камера, правильно? Зачем шум? Чтобы скрасить отсутствие разнообразия на голых повторяющихся стенах? Да, здесь нет никаких текстур или раскрасок на стенах, только однотонный свет вокруг, который показывает как бы сложность уровня чтоли или для определения где находишься.

Загадки: чтобы пройти дальше в двери, нужно отгадать загадку или загадки. А дверей этих закрытых несколько и не поймешь куда нужно идти, и где ты. После прохождения 1ых 2ух уровней за 5-10 минут, я попал в фиолетовый лабиринт с загадкой и не понял куда дальше идти. Затем попал в зеленый лабиринт, красный, белый. Куда идти и что делать с этими встречающимися закрытыми десятком дверей и непонятными загадками, и разноцветными лабиринтами?

Понравились только фоновые звуки и 3D атмосфера.

Поморочил себе голову минут 20 и выключил.

review:
本日ひとまずクリアしました。
不思議な世界で不思議なパズルを解いていくこのゲーム。
とても面白かったです。

498円と侮るなかれ。なかなかのゲームボリュームです。
また、パズルの難易度も序盤は簡単なモノから終盤は意味わからんレベルの難しいものまで揃っております。
ESCボタンを押すと今居るマップのパズルを解くヒントを３つまで得ることが出来るので、活用しましょう。
ただし英語です。マップにも直感的に理解できるヒントがあるのでゴーストの囁きに耳を傾けましょう！

最初は訳も分からずパズルを解くのも難しいと感じていた私ですが、
ゲームを進める内にだんだん脳みそがゲーム用に慣れて来て、中盤はパズルを解く快感にドップリ浸かれました。
パズルゲームが好きなら是非一度プレイをオススメしたいゲームです。
ゲームとしてのパズルを解きながら、世界観の謎も解いていく……あなたの脳みそに、きっと楽しい驚きと発見を齎してくれることでしょう。

author: {'steamid': '76561198114665760', 'num_games_owned': 386, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1437356081}
review:
This is a game I desperately wanted to like.  At first I did, it was surreal and interesting to explore and wander.  Then the puzzles came.  Dear god, the puzzles.  Everything outside of the game made it seem as though the puzzles would be short and scarce throughout the game...  That is a lie!  The puzzles make about as much sense as something from a point-and-click adventure game.  The puzzle is nearly always figuring out the mechanics of the puzzle, rather than what to do, which is horribly frustrating.  I never thought it possible to rage quit a first person exploration game.  Then I did the impossible, and did just that.

The enviroments themselves are nice, usually only using one or two colors per room.  The only problem I really have with the world is that it's incredibly inconsistant.  The world is obviously not made to feel like it has rules, which I normally wouldn't have a problem with.  It's just some sort of strange, lawless purgatory type setting, right?  I wish.  It's actually supposed to be an alien planet.  It just doesn't work at all.

TL;DR:  I desperately wanted to like this game a lot, but it left a lot to be desired with terrible puzzles EVERYWHERE and and inconsistant world.

4/10  Don't buy this game.  Just don't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095917598', 'num_games_owned': 497, 'num_reviews': 1793, 'playtime_forever': 3763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 848, 'last_played': 1633050837}
review:
Nao entendi muito o jogo, mas ele é bem brisante, pra quem quer algo um pouco sombrio para passar o tempo esse jogo é bom, graficos bem simples, jogabilidade e td mais. :D

I picked up this game on a whim when it went on sale some time ago, and while it's not very long (I completed it in three hours) it's unique enough to where I consider it merits a review of its own. 

First off, let me nerd out at how good the ambiance is for a couple of paragraphs. The visuals are given sense by an excellent sound design, which kept me on edge for the duration of my playthrough; an achievement, considering the fundamentally abstract and calming nature of the setting. I didn't ever not feel like I was in an old, abandoned, alien place which might fall apart at any second, except when I finished the puzzle in the area and the whole place lighted up and started functioning again, but even then, the sense of foreboding was ever-present. Wide open areas get floaty synths that lurk just outside your hearing, punctuated by the slight pat pat pat of the character's walking, and inside areas each have a soundtrack that fits in well with what's around you. Going in blind, I half-expected the game to throw in some jumpscares at me at some point or another, but the actual gameplay was very deliberate and focused around the "narrative". 

The game also shines in its visuals. You might be thinking, "Well, yeah, the game markets itself as a puzzle/exploration game, it's bound to have some nice environments", but some areas are unique enough to actually merit a "Holly ♥♥♥♥, this is amazing". This makes the actual gameplay suffer at times, though, as you're made to slowly walk up and down a ramp to press at buttons to try to figure the room's huge puzzle in an epic journey that was evidently designed to show off every possible angle of the room with no regards to how long it might take to get from one place to another.

The actual puzzles themselves, the main focus of the game, is where it's a bit lacking. For all the praise I might sing of its visuals and environments, it's a bit hard to justify some of the choices regarding their design. I found myself having to constantly check at the in-game hints and a guide I kept handy to figure out the worst of them. There's a special variety that I particularly loathed, which are the kind of puzzle that required you to move against a timer over pressure pads on the floor in a particular pattern, which was made very infuriating with the character's tendency to slide around as if the floor was iced over. I'd say this is the area of the game where it's at its weakest.

I mentioned the game's narrative with quotation marks earlier on in this review, and that is because it's entirely possible to ignore it and never know anything about it, as it's never actually presented to you. It's just "there", and it doesn't care if you pick up on it or not. It's perfectly fine with sitting alone above the dusty door-frame of the room you just dismissed as pure eye candy and never having anything to do with you. It's not terribly complicated or unique, but it gives a sense to your running around, so I do recommend you take the time to trying to figure it out. 

Should you buy this game? If you can overlook that it's quite average as puzzle games go, and instead want to be awed by the amazing environments and architecture that it provides, sure, go for it. If not, you'll probably be wasting your money. 

I should also mention that it runs excellently in lower-end computers. So there's that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995664657', 'num_games_owned': 1021, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 2844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2844, 'last_played': 1437182466}
review:
If you have ever went on a walk, in an empty gymnasium with your eyes closed, you probably would find Kairo boring in comparison. In Kairo you get to do a lot of walking. I think. Actually I have no idea what this game actually IS.... When I am playing it, I feel as though I'm stuck in Half Life's tram car, able to look around, move a little, but nothing actually happens.
Actually that's a bit generous. It's more like waiting for your girlfriend to come downstairs for your date - you can walk around, check out the books on her book shelf, look at the dirt on the floor... all with an anticipation that she would be coming down stairs ANY minute,., She never does - and THAT's Kairo's entire gameplay model.
Did I like it? I can't say, I never actually DID anything. Oh sure, doors opened, things clicked, but unless I'm missing the point, the entire purpose of this game is to show how nicely you can make big ugly square blocks look sometimes.
I'd like to see what the developer actually intended, some day.

review:
I played lots of puzzles and walking simulators, and this one differs from the others for having a good variety of simple challenges in an atmospheric desert world mostly made of stone with some hidden and strange stuff along the way.the idea is good and the visual is pretty well done. The only flaw of Kairo's devs is the lack meaning in the game progress. There's no concrete story (at least untill the part of the game i'm in), only randon pictures in some places and visions that only appear if you solve optional puzzles that won't explain much. But I recommend this game if you like the genre and if it's on sale, of course.

PS: This game is definitely an Illuminati admission test, I can feel it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198089419763', 'num_games_owned': 194, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1435911551}
review:
Take a 90's shooter, skip on plot, guns and enemies. What you're left with is a bunch of unengaging puzzles which are only worthy of changing the pace between other gameplay elements, of which there are none now. Such puzzles consist of stepping on floor buttons in the correct order, shown on a wall in front of you. Levels are extremely low-poly and have single featureless texture tiled over most surfaces. Monochromatic environments, while making up for an appealing screenshot gallery, can be really nauseating.

In order to have a minimalist aesthetic appeal Kairo strives for, it would have to do all those small things right, like making footstep sounds actually match your walking speed, or not having them at all. Instead, its one of those games where you feel like you're stuck crouching constantly so you hit the crouch button to untoggle it, but the camera drops even lower.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049684319', 'num_games_owned': 198, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1551892557}
review: Своеобразная бродилка-головоломка от первого лица. Музыка, графика, символы, все это создает определенную атмосферу kairo. Ходишь по абстрактным локациям, думаешь - что же здесь к чему и как? И радость, когда решил задачу, когда механизм запущен, потоки пошли, завел очередную деталь какого-то незаурядного механизма. Кто этот человек, который смотрит на нас с экранов? Что значат эти символы? Почему здесь в экране то, что вижу я, а в том какие-то панели управления? А в остальных гробиках с экранами - в экранах помехи? Может это космический корабль, а коридор с гробиками - это своего рода кладбище? Тогда почему я жив, и жив ли тот, кто сидит за приборами? И вообще - человек ли я, или это галлюцинации привидения, а может быть я бортовой робот, каким-то чудом обредший сознание? Такая вот своеобразная игра.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082580213', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 275, 'last_played': 1435284675}
review:
Overall, a very interesting game with a perplexing, dream-like setting and nice mid-level puzzles.  But there is no concrete story or true gameplay beyond the puzzle solving, so if that turns you off, this title is not for you.  

In the current gaming setting of triple A titles with increasingly beautiful and realistic graphics, I was a bit off-put by the blocky, grainy architecture of the game.  At first.  Then I realized how brilliantly atmospheric it was.  Lonely and creepy, Kairo is very reminiscent of the first Myst game: a solo protagonist working their way through a mysterious world, piecing the story together as you go, never quite sure if you've gotten it right.  

If you're a completionist, prepare for a lot of backtracking, as some things are only activated after you get all the way through an area.  If you're not, don't worry about missing out on anything more than full exploration of the environment.  The final secret is funny but not story-related.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000824354', 'num_games_owned': 1300, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1435712000}
review:
It's very easy to walk away from Kairo feeling as though it was just a light puzzle game with a bunch of stuff happening for no discernable reason. Unless you are willing to make a degree of meaning for the game for yourself, interpret some of it as art, or spend some time unraveling the abstract references and hidden meaning, you'll probably have a boring time with an average 3D exploration puzzle game. But for those who spend some time unraveling those clues, thinking about those references, and connecting the abstract together, there are interesting layers of story and meaning.

[h1]Highlights[/h1]
As stated above, the main problems people have with Kairo, and the thing most people praise about Kairo stem from the same issue; the lack of direct or game-fed meaning, story and explanation. If you invest the time, Kairo becomes something much more, but it's always going to be subtle. For some, spending the time soaking in environment simply isn't worth the mild reward, and there are other games which do a much better job, and for others it will act as casual slow-paced art. In short, it's probably a game you'll either love or hate.

* Extremely subtle designs in everything from lighting, shapes, distances and more add to the concept or image being conveyed in each section
* Particularly good on VR platforms, mainly the Oculus Rift, though there are problems here

[h1]Mistakes[/h1]
Many people have a problem with Kairo, or don't see any value in it against other games in its genre. In the end, it comes down to whether traditional gameplay elements and story are required to make this game fun for you or whether light and often frustrating-to-figure-out puzzles are enough reason for you to explore a strange environment.

* The first sections have clearly been structured to convey tutorial elements while remaining non-obvious and ambiguous, but the problem many people have with this game is its lack of story, explanation or meaning and while that's not necessarily a mistake, it's subjective, and worth bearing in mind
* The difficulty and nature of puzzles is erratic, which is understandable, but it would've benefited the game to make, at least some puzzle elementst more fluid and understandable
* The bobby weaving motions when moving help add a subtle dreamlike feel, but may induce motion sickness or mild nausea and should've at least been given adjustable options

[h1]Recommendations[/h1]
At just £3.99/4.99€/$4.99, Kairo is fairly priced and clocks in at 3-4 hours play time. Due to the mysterious or ambiguous nature of Kairo, some may find themselves spending much, much longer on this title, exploring the secrets or potential elements of meaning, whereas others will move on after an hour or less. Either way, it's definitely worth a buy for anyone looking for something with a different approach, and shouldn't be missed when on sale.

* There are some fantastic player interpretations of the story elements and reading them in itself is fun [spoiler][url=http://www.electrondance.com/the-secret-of-kairo/]The Secret of Kairo[/url][/spoiler]
* A headset is recommended as it make the experience stronger, a VR headset is even better
* Kairo (回路) is the Japanese word for "circuit" [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/233230/discussions/0/617336568071589929/]which lends to elements of the story[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198083714959', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1445394616}
review:
Kairo is seriously a fantastic experience. It seems people are complaining about the following:

[i]"kept waiting for something interesting to happen, some secret to uncover, some story to unfold"[/i]
Kairo is something of an atmopsheric puzzle game. That being said, it's really full of "AHA" moments. In every area, there's something interesting and beautiful.

[i]"The puzzles are a little too abstract"[/i]
I don't know about this. Yeah, the puzzles are quite difficult, but isn't that, you know, the point?

[i]"First of all I expected a little more story. Sadly there is absolutely none."[/i]
I played through the entire game, and never once expected a story. Do not go in expecting one. This is not a bad thing. This is a game where you need to appreciate the world at face value.

[i]"Graphics: 5.7/10"[/i]
People seem to be hating on the graphics. I think they really add to the atmosphere, which is, to be honest, what Kairo is half about.

Overall, I'd say this game is a 7.5/10, it's [i]almost[/i] there, but is too abstract for many. The price is fair for a game like this. I'd say overall, a reccomend.

review: I normally have a lot of patience for exploration games, happily slogging through gorgeous scenery to solve puzzles now and then and hopefully get bits of story here and there. But I just couldn't get into this game. The art is not that great, the ambience isn't drawing me in, and the puzzles are more annoying than challenging. There are hints at a story, but I just can't be bothered to stick around and find out, wandering around bland stone mazes that occasionally change color. Maybe I'll get bored enough in the future and try again, but I doubt it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005148877', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1425751277}
review:
Kairo is a puzzle exploration game. You travel the world of Kairo, trying to move forward and get to the next door… and the next… and the next.

The graphics are simple – smooth and coloured walls will keep you company. It gives the game a cold and sinister feel. I felt small and lost, running around in large buildings, trying to get out.


You have no inventory, no set of tools to help you out. Instead you unlock your surroundings by how and where you move and what you do. It’s a very unnerving and immersive experience.

It is difficult to explain this game without saying too much. But playing Kairo, I felt like I was the last person in the world, trying desperately to find my way out of a complex I was not meant to be in. If you like first-person explorations games, you should play this one.

[b]7/10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198131209127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1460290150}
review:
[h1]Прекрасное рядом[/h1]

[b]У маленькой и мало кому известной игры Kairo получается выполнять сразу несколько ролей. Это не только интерактивный памятник рассказывающий нам историю о жизни, смерти и перерождении – это еще и очень удачная проба разработчика в дизайне уровней. Это даже игрой не назовешь, это скорее произведение искусства.  Игра, бесспорно, по времени, идеально вписывается в картину этого времени – но и 10 лет назад она бы была на своем месте.[/b]

Но все эти философские рассуждения стоит оставить на потом. Сейчас, запустив игру, мы стоим в залитой красным цветом комнате и объяснение того, как и почему Kairo достигает своих целей придет гораздо позже. Главное в данный момент – время и настроение.  Осмотревшись можно заметить некий кубический узор и механизм, о предназначении которого уже давно все забыли. 
Игра не даст вам никаких ответов. Большую часть игрового процесса вы просто занимаетесь ее изучением и пребываете в восторге от тонкости этого мира. Тут все очень красиво: от нескончаемой череды комнат, коридоров и залов, где все имеет свой цвет и характер и до комнат с непонятными механизмами. Шаг за шагом вы подходите все ближе к ответу на вопрос, который наверняка задали себе еще в начале игры: что же все это значит?

В самом начале игра может показаться немножко страшной. Ее мир покрыт мертвыми тенями, лестницы ведут в мрачные подземелья; гигантские комнаты тут не поддаются никакой логике; чертовски запутанные лабиринты абсолютно непредсказуемы и вырастают прямо перед вами. У создателя (единственного разработчика) была тысяча возможностей увести Kairo в сторону страха и запугивания игроков. Но зачем это? Ведь если бы он "налил" ужаса в тени, то это бы испортило идеальный баланс игрового мира. Игра лучше всего работает именно так: не страшная, но и не спокойная, не жуткая, но и не благоговейная. Она такая, какая есть. И в этом ее плюс. 
Вопрос баланса необычайно важен для этой игры, так как в ней кроме этого больше ничего то и нету. В центре рассказывающейся нам истории – Машина. Она огромная, загадочная и крайне непонятная. Через образ этой самой машины Kairo передает игроку саму себя, изливается. В шестернях ее механизма скрыт не только баланс между жизнью и смертью, красотой и уродством, ошибками и вторым шансом. Помимо этого нам рассказывают о балансе между игровым процессом и историей, между тем, что может игрок и на что у него нет права. 

Хотя Kairo и кажется чем-то непонятным, участком "игры, но не игры", на самом деле добрая ее половина состоит из привычных загадок и головоломок. Для того, чтобы постановить работу машины игроку потребуется  путешествовать по ее внутренностям и "оживлять" ее систему одну за другой. Загадки эти скорее приятные, чем сложные, ведь они не требуют от игрока жесткой логики. Они лишь просят чуточку творческого мышления. К тому же, побоявшись завести игрока в тупик автор добавил спасательные круги: в меню всегда можно найти три подсказки по решению той или иной головоломки, а комнаты доступны в абсолютно любом порядке. 
Ах да, комнаты. Каждая из них состоит исключительно из одного цвета. И думаете, что это все? Нет. Есть тут и коридоры с шипящими экранами, и острова серой архитектуры в белой бесконечности. И различного рода шестеренки, трубы, колонны и монументы, которым логического объяснения дать просто нельзя. Со всем этим надо экспериментировать. Не стоит ничего боятся: за попытку никто не накажет.

Kairo необычная игра. В ней нет ни единой строчки текста, но она переполнена метафорами и аллегориями. Для того, чтобы решить загадки вам не нужен инвентарь или еще что-то, ведь все необходимое всегда при вас – ваше творческой мышление и нестандартный подход. Игра бывает страшной, хотя тут нечего боятся. Kairo – это своего рода инструкция правильного минимализма в бесконечных потоках громких проектов. Эту игру нельзя рекомендовать всем и каждому. Из 100 поигравших в нее она придется по душе максимум двоим. Ведь это даже не игра. Это способ отдохнуть от всего. Просто зайти и улететь в этот неизвестный и загадочный мир цветов и необычайных конструкций. 
Если вы ни строчки не поняли из того, что я написал выше, то вам, скорее всего, не стоит даже заходить в Kairo. Ну а если для вас тут все было понятно как божий день, то милости прошу – игра очарует вас.

[h1]Общая оценка: 5/10[/h1]

Специально для [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/steamorators]Ораторы Ste@m[/url]

review:
Самая сложная, непонятная, загадочная головоломка на моей памяти.

Не знаю кем надо быть что б пройти ее самому. Я уже не говорю о рунах и прочих загадках. Дичайший хардкор. Первое впечатление от игры было странное. Ну появился, ну хожу-брожу как аутист, и шо?  Ничего не ясно, никаких целей, ничего. Симулятор несности. Но взяв под руки гайды дело сдвинулось с мертвой точки, чему я очень рад. 

Местами стремно, местами чересчур сложно, местами скучновато, но в целом неплохо. Очень атмосферно. За фоновые звуки отдельное спасибо.

7.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197993055223', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1432101090}
review:
I'm not sure what to think of this game.  What I am sure of is that this game is not for me.  This game should feel open, mysterious, provoke exploration and thought.  That is not what I got.  What I encountered was hazy polluted visuals, vague aimless concepts, a feeling of hemmed in oppression and a headache.  I felt trapped in an environment that was hot, dry and without purpose, bombarding my senses with noise and unclear locals. 
I am surprised to say this but this game has projected an image of what could be my own personal hell.  
I can see that there are a lot of people who love this game, but I didn't find it enjoyable, and couldn't even stand an hour of it.  Look to others if you want a positive side of this game, but I can't recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198190380543', 'num_games_owned': 613, 'num_reviews': 602, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1491115710}
review: An unique exploration game. There are no tutorials. Just explore. Find things. Solve puzzles. And gradually, you will start to understand the beautiful world of Kairo. But the game is kinda hardcore, and maybe you will need a guide in order to discover everything. But if you're struck, don't give up! Because this world is so rewarding. But to new players, it's sink or swim. Let's hope it's the latter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084674862', 'num_games_owned': 1182, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1430593072}
review:
To czym mnie najbardziej urzekło Kairo, to fakt, że potrafi opowiedzieć niezwykłą historię bez narracji. Same niezwykłe lokacje i kilka rozsianych wskazówek dają pole do własnej interpretacji, gdzie jesteśmy i co robimy. Dzięki nie wykładaniu kawy na ławę gra pozwala nam na immersję. Możemy poczuć się zagubionymi podróżnikami, którzy pewnego dnia budzą się bez wspomnień w tajemniczym miejscu. Czy to ruiny wymarłej cywilizacji? Twór kosmitów? A może jesteśmy w rzeczywistości wirtualnej? 
(Dla osób, które już przeszły grę: pod tym linkiem znajduje się najbardziej drobiazgowa (i pełna spojlerów) interpretacja gry, która zrobiła na mnie niemałe wrażenie: http://www.electrondance.com/the-secret-of-kairo/ )

Zagadki nie są zbyt trudne (prócz tej z geometrycznym zegarem - ta jest złośliwa :P ) i grę przejdziemy spokojnie przez 5 godzin. Naszym celem jest uruchamianie kolejnych maszyn Kairo zwykle wciskając odpowiednią sekwencję przycisków, czasem przesuwając element otoczenia - wobec tego minimalizmu niesamowite jest to jak zróżnicowane są wyzwania, a przy tym dalekie są od przekombinowania - ich cudowna logika przypomina mi mój romans z serią Myst. Czasem w otoczeniu znajdują się wskazówki w formie symboli i obrazków - warto się rozejrzeć. 

Grafika jest tu bardzo ważna, ponieważ to ona zapewnia niesamowity klimat. Dziwne kanciaste twory, architektura na poły futurystyczna na poły monumentalna w stylu egipskich katakumb oraz kolorowe światło zalewające pomieszczenia i ziarnisty filtr sprawiają, że czujemy nastrój tajmnicy i alienacji. Nie raz poczujemy dreszczyk od muzyki Bartosza Szturgiewicza, która mogłaby służyć za soundtrack horroru sf. (Nie, to nie horror, potworów ani innej makabry nie będzie :D ).

Polecam wszystkim fanom łamigłówek i eksploracji oraz niesztampowych światów.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037253388', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 599, 'last_played': 1560184938}
review:
kairo is one of those games that plays with your mind...

it's not like those other games that call themselves "art" and "deep," kairo is humble and one of the games that turns walking simulators into a fantastic puzzle game. to start, you are given nothing. you move with wasd, you look with mouse, that's it. have fun. while kairo lacks in narrative and the story is like some small dots on a large canvas, the game uses your mind like a playground. if you plan on just going the linear path (which i do not recommend,) you are going to think the puzzles a just below portal 2 level. look a little deeper and lose your mind find your way through a level. since the game lacks characters and is like one of those cheap strange games on steam, you'd expect a more philisophical purpose. from my standards, i see no philisophical meaning. though you may think it's a simple puzzle game, the worlds and visuals look astounding and the ambient music(ish) really gives you a feeling of lonliness. a feeling of complete solitude in a world where machines can mold the landscape.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051782095', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 134, 'last_played': 1517935772}
review:
[b]Una fiaba fantascientifica...che non tutti apprezzeranno.[/b]
Purtroppo si è costretti a sconsigliare questo gioco. E non perché non sia bello. Tutt'altro. L'astrattezza del gioco e la storia impercettibile (che c'è eccome, ma non tutti la trovano), porta a dubitare del fatto che Kairo possa essere apprezzato da tutti coloro che prendano in mano un qualsiasi videogioco (e difatti la maggioranza delle recensioni sono negative). Sarà così anche la mia per i motivi sopra citati.


Per chi volesse comunque saperne qualcosa:
in Kairo il giocatore si trova in ambienti vuoti e minimalisti, attorno ai quali aleggia una colonna sonora strana (strana in senso positivo, e comunque, non poteva essere altrimenti). Il gioco è in prima persona e consiste nella risoluzione di "circuiti". La possibilità di essere meritevoli o meno dipende dalle proprie abilità. 
Essere meritevoli di che cosa? Giocateci e lo scoprirete...

author: {'steamid': '76561198128246602', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1429453526}
review:
It tries to be Myst.
and it isn't; the premise of this game is to open possible and ambiguity of story for intrepretation by the players, narration is being pushed to extreme minimum and almost non-existence, relying in "dumb dog puzzles" as the core mechanic of this game. the devs tries to be as minimalist as possible and resulting in being incredibly slow and boring, even when you do (and could) running in-game. the art design seems to unsure whether it want's to be in voxel or high res textured, even though there's almost nothing to show due to heavy emphasis on surreal atmospheric term (in this case, its kinda work... sort of).
It could be great, short game but somehow ended up being stretch beyond what is necessary. what could be 30 minutes game with more replayability and more variety of ending turns up as overly long walking simulator with very little redeeming value of gameplay and non-rewarding short ending (and that "ending") gets a barely thumbs down. good discount will help decided people to buy this game though.
(5.4/10) could be better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007688772', 'num_games_owned': 1260, 'num_reviews': 643, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1429392988}
review:
Kairo je abstraktní logická hra z vlastního pohledu, hodně podobná známějšímu Antichamber. Hádanky jsou pestré, obtížnost je vyvážená tak akorát, navíc hra obsahuje i zabudovanou nápovědu, dostupnou přes hlavní menu položkou Hints (snadno ji lze přehlédnout).
Extrémně jednoduchá grafika a primitivní 3D engine se spoustou nedokonalostí by u většiny současných her byly naprosto neomluvitelné, ale v případě Kaira se jim z toho povedlo udělat naopak stylovou přednost.

Podobná hra: NaissanceE

author: {'steamid': '76561198005686739', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1455675618}
review:
Ahhh, Kairo. Another atmospheric, minimalistic, exploration, puzzle game and an amazing one at that. At some points it was very relaxing, other's very tense, but mostly edgy. "This is a pretty sweet temple in here." "Oooh, what is this cool machinery?" "WHY ARE THERE STATICY SCREENS WITH THE OUTLINE OF A FACE SURROUNDING ME" These are some of the thoughts that came to my head and probably yours if you should choose to get this game.

"Hey look it's the Earth! And the Moon! Wait theres another Moon? Does Earth have a phantom Moon?"

I've been at the edge of my seat waiting to see what puzzle next, see how complicated it looks, then proceed to facepalm when I see it was simpler than that.

"The Earth and Moons look like a hollogram... can I jump into it?" (Jumps) "OUCH. Wait, if it's solid then HOW IS IT LEVETATING?"

If I were to make a movie trailer for this it would probably be something like this: " Kairo, a strange dreamlike world filled with temples, dungeons, palaces and strange alien like machinery. A man wakes up, alone and scared with no memery of what happened to get him there. When he looks on and braves this strange new land he uncoveres many things, puzzles to solve, and sights to behold. He set's forth to solve the mystery, of Kairo. In theaters now for $13.37"

The bottom line is this: Kairo is a very great surreal minimalistic puzzle solving that I solely recomend you should get. 
My favorite part was the buetifull, touching, serious ending.








(sees secret ending)

I TRUSTED YOU

author: {'steamid': '76561198088783978', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1428625595}
review:
A very dry game. 

The puzzles aren't very rewarding, they leave you with a feeling 'of oh thank god thats over' when you complete them which only leads you into a new 'oh fuck this thing' situation.

The atmosphere is . . . geometrical. I think they were trying for a mysterious egypt alien feel or something with the constant boxes etherial sounds though it overstays it's welcome very quickly and you are then left with a textureless environment with backround noise switching from ambient to blairing speaker feedback depending on where you are. 

There is no story and I couldn't force myself to finish the game after the first hour and a half so I will never know if there is a reason I was even doing these almost mindless tasks. But as far as I played there wasn't a single semblence of dialouge or story.

Overall, for a game produced by one man it isn't the worst thing to ever come out, but the fact that it WAS entirely coded by one person should key you in on the quality of the product. Compare it to any other game and it is terrible.

You will not be happy if you spend money on this game, don't buy . . . seriously, just don't.

review:
Очередной пример геймдизайнерской импотенции. Казалось бы игра должена мотивировать продвигаться по сюжету (каким бы он ни был). Не мотивирует. Казалось бы у подобной игры должен быть интересный визуальный стиль для создания атмосферы. Но его тут нет и всё выглядит как недельный эксперемент в Юнити по туториалам. Казалось бы должны быть хотя бы интересные головоломки, но и этого тут нет. Так ради чего игроку проходить эту игру? Возможно в игре и есть очень сильная философская сюжетная линия (в чём лично я не уверен), да вот только атмосфера, что создали разработчики, совершенно не стимулирует в чём либо разбираться и куда-то двигаться.
Бесплатно посмотреть можно. Покупать — нет.

review: Kairo is... odd. Everything about this game seems like it's working towards something genuinely fun and interesting but it never came together for me.  The puzzles are a little too abstract (any puzzle where figuring out the goal of the puzzle is the actual puzzle isn't a great puzzle, and there are plenty of those), the graphics are almost cool but are a little too simple to hold my attention, and while the minimalistic soundtrack works for the game, it's by no means a draw to it.  Maybe if you have an Oculus or something this game is for you, but on just a plain old 2D monitor, I'm not really feeling it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084475551', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1450447448}
review:
Very enjoyable, atmospheric and impressive environments.  Interesting puzzles, only one of which I had to look up.  Nice spooky atmosphere and music.  Great experience for a low price (especially as I got it for 80% off).  The screenshots say it all really.  The puzzles were not too difficult but certainly felt quite different to the usual ones I find in games, and fit in nicely with the atmosphere.

Does not work well with 3D Vision unfortunately, which would have been great for immersion into this sort of game.  Still looks very nice in 2D, I took at least 200 screenshots.

Definitely recommend this game if the look of the images on the store page, and the prospect of puzzles in this sort of environment inspire any interest.

Have found what seems to be one of the endings, but looks like there may yet be several puzzles to find and complete.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055690415', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1426786573}
review:
I'm nothing if not a fan of ambiguity to such an extreme that I can interpret something as a commentary on whatever I dern well please, and Kairo is an experience that excels in creating a blank slate open to any and pretty much all interpretations. This game is simplicity in action, and as I delved deeply into the carved blocks of granite/obsidian/stone/randomness to discern some hidden meaning behind it all, I found myself continually following my own line of thought, like a dog trailing after the scent of a long lost bone he buried somewhere deep in the earth.

I honestly attempted to like this game, but sometimes a little concrete meaning is required after a jumble of meaningless gravel. What I mean is that Kairo is far too ambiguous; I can wander aimlessly through this game and decide what it means for myself until, quite literally, the very end, at which point Kairo finally decides to give me something solid - not okay, guys, not okay.

Kairo is a game that lets you wander through a child's block fort, occasionally posing *cough cough* "puzzles" that briefly halt your progress through the maze of nothingness. I felt as though the developers had a clear idea as to what they wanted to say, sat down in a conference room and said "Hey guys, woudn't it be really cool if we..." and then glued together a jumbled mess of a game.... Sorry, 'experience'. I received conflicting feelings of paranoia and comfort throughout the game, feeling at one time as though I were being watched and at another time as though I were revolting against an omnitient, though not omnipotent, regime, slowly tearing it down brick by ambiguous brick. I think each *cough cough* "puzzle" in this 'experience' was arbitrarily assigned some deeper 'meaning' after the story-board team smoked an acre of some illegal substance. That doesn't fly with me. I am certainly not saying I don't LOVE pushing my smug nose up and saying "Oh yesh, I am a very smart man and love interpreting games and books and movies because I am so deep and insightful" because I do love to say that. I am a smarmy head-up-my-ahem turd; Kairo is a jumbled mess of obfuscated meaning with an alternate ending (oh joy) to encourage further 'experiencing'. That's cheap, guys.

IN BRIEF (he said ironically): Kairo is a block fort, glued together by a toddler hyped up on three gallons of coffee. Then a guy walked by and glued a tagline onto it that belongs at the bottom of an inspirational cat poster. If you have something to say, then say it. If you believe in what you're saying, then you want people to agree with you: make sure they know what you believe.

10/10
