author: {'steamid': '76561198127646290', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1427138897}
review:
Let me first say that if you are expecting Kairo to be something along the lines of Myst, Riven or, for that matter, any challenging puzzler, do not buy. The puzzles lack depth, complexity, and do not require deep thinking in order to discover the solution. They feel like an afterthought and I think the developer intentionally designed them so to make the experience in Kairo more fluid. 

As you may have read, Kairo is a minimalist exploration game (though it's more of an abstract art gallery simulator). Meaning you can only walk, run, and jump. Your interaction with machines is restricted thus partially explaining the lack of depth in some of the puzzles. No in game button prompts. Nothing out of the Kairo's context distracts you, save the notification that informs you've solved a puzzle. It's all for the purpose of pulling you deep into Kairo's world full of abstract architecture and objects with strange behavior that apparently defies physics. The fine grain filter and errie soundtrack assist in attempting to build an absorbing atmosphere.

Except I felt a disconnect for some reason. None of the abstract architectures (nor the atmosphere) evoked any feelings. No texts located anywhere to provide some backstory. Perhaps (and I'm not sure) some story could be deciphered (or interpreted) but the game gave me no reason or motivation to invest the effort into it. Even during the conclusion when Kairo's purpose was hinted at, no tingle of emotion. 

In my opinion, you can approach this game like you approach a strange dream right after waking up, either invest the energy to interpret it and derive personal meaning or instantly forget about all the vague disjointed images. If you're the former or if the idea of an abstract art gallery simulator sounds appealing, then maybe Kairo might be for you. 

However, if you are looking for something with cohesion and a game that gradually unfolds a story with clarity (or a challenging puzzler as talked about in first paragraph) then I would defintely pass this one up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075624664', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1423616606}
review:
I picked up this game on a whim when it went on sale some time ago, and while it's not very long (I completed it in three hours) it's unique enough to where I consider it merits a review of its own. 

First off, let me nerd out at how good the ambiance is for a couple of paragraphs. The visuals are given sense by an excellent sound design, which kept me on edge for the duration of my playthrough; an achievement, considering the fundamentally abstract and calming nature of the setting. I didn't ever not feel like I was in an old, abandoned, alien place which might fall apart at any second, except when I finished the puzzle in the area and the whole place lighted up and started functioning again, but even then, the sense of foreboding was ever-present. Wide open areas get floaty synths that lurk just outside your hearing, punctuated by the slight [i] pat pat pat [/i] of the character's walking, and inside areas each have a soundtrack that fits in well with what's around you. Going in blind, I half-expected the game to throw in some jumpscares at me at some point or another, but the actual gameplay was very deliberate and focused around the "narrative". 

The game also shines in its visuals. You might be thinking, "Well, yeah, the game markets itself as a puzzle/exploration game, it's bound to have some nice environments", but some areas are unique enough to actually merit a "Holly shit, this is amazing". This makes the actual gameplay suffer at times, though, as you're made to slowly walk up and down a ramp to press at buttons to try to figure the room's huge puzzle in an epic journey that was evidently designed to show off every possible angle of the room with no regards to how long it might take to get from one place to another.

The actual puzzles themselves, the main focus of the game, is where it's a bit lacking. For all the praise I might sing of its visuals and environments, it's a bit hard to justify some of the choices regarding their design. I found myself having to constantly check at the in-game hints and a guide I kept handy to figure out the worst of them. There's a special variety that I particularly loathed, which are the kind of puzzle that required you to move against a timer over pressure pads on the floor in a particular pattern, which was made very infuriating with the character's tendency to slide around as if the floor was iced over. I'd say this is the area of the game where it's at its weakest.

I mentioned the game's narrative with quotation marks earlier on in this review, and that is because it's entirely possible to ignore it and never know anything about it, as it's never actually presented to you. It's just "there", and it doesn't care if you pick up on it or not. It's perfectly fine with sitting alone above the dusty door-frame of the room you just dismissed as pure eye candy and never having anything to do with you. It's not terribly complicated or unique, but it gives a sense to your running around, so I do recommend you take the time to trying to figure it out. 

Should you buy this game? If you can overlook that it's quite average as puzzle games go, and instead want to be awed by the amazing environments and architecture that it provides, sure, go for it. If not, you'll probably be wasting your money. 

I should also mention that it runs excellently in lower-end computers. So there's that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971109813', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1426650214}
review:
Achei Kairo um jogo estranho.

Ele é bem intencionado e normalmente aprecio obras autorais e pessoais (Foi feito por um cara apenas), mas fiquei insatisfeito com o resultado. O jogo é hermético demais, os puzzles nem sempre fazem sentido (por mais de uma vez eu cheguei à solução sem nem saber porque), e os gráficos, que desejam muito ser minimalistas, me passam em muitos momentos por tosqueira. A *ambiência* é boa, mas os detalhes são toscos e amadores.

Enfim, não quero bombar o jogo como absolutamente ruim. Teve muita gente elogiando aqui, e eu vi bons momentos nele. Mas se você procura exploração e surrealismo, com sabores minimalistas e melancólicos, acho que existem outras opções melhores.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021790030', 'num_games_owned': 513, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 481, 'last_played': 1452584265}
review:
[i]NOTE: Somehow, the most recent updates to the game have made it incredibly buggy. In the stable release the main menu stays onscreen the entire time and I can't look left or right. In the DK2 Beta things are much more polished, but there are some sequencing glitches where I can reach the Garden without having completed a single puzzle. It's still worth a try if you can get it to work.[/i]

Kairo is not exactly the most complex game, but it gives you enough mental stimulation. Since it's only $6 right now, either go ahead and get it or wait for a sale. If you're on the fence about this one, I encourage you to read on fully.

[h1]FIRST OFF[/h1]
Kairo is made in Unity, and if you've experienced a game in Unity you know that slowdowns are extremely common. Prepare to wade through the settings several times deciding what slows you down and what doesn't, maximizing appearance with playability, especially when most defaults are selected with high-speed computers in mind.

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
The puzzles in Kairo are particularly easy by minimalistic adventure standards, but the developers have definitely squared down exactly what kind of puzzles they need. Rather than blatantly giving you instructions or commentary to push you in the right direction, they require you to work out exactly what's going on to figure out the solution, very similar to Myst. Puzzles are isolated to their own special room, but sadly this means most of the time you'll be walking through a room that's more for sightseeing than for puzzlesolving. For the casual gamer, Kairo features a hint system that can assist in solving puzzles. There's no penalty, and it doesn't resolve if they're used or not. All in all, [b]Kairo is a solid puzzle game[/b].

[h1]VISUALS[/h1]
The minimalistic visuals of Kairo are absolutely breathtaking. The wonderfully crafted levels are absolutely gorgeous to look at, and unlike many games, the additions of things like film grain only serve to add to the visuals, rather than give a false impression of visuals. Of particular note are areas of the game where the film grain is programmatically [i]increased[/i] to add effect as you look around and wander. There is (as it first seems) only one texture that Kairo has: a concrete/stone texture kind of thing. This sort of forces you to look at the architecture as the art. And boy, is the architecture ever art. [b]Stunning and functional, the deliberate monochrome of Kairo's architecture make it one of the most gorgeous games I have ever played[/b].

[h1]STORY[/h1]
...Well, here's where the negatives come up. Kairo's story is one that you have to infer, but the structure of the gameplay kind of causes whatever the story would possibly be to get... jumbled. I'm not sure how to describe this without giving much away, but Andrew Plotkin has a wonderful quote that hits this nail right on the head.

[i]"If I were to level a charge, it would be that the game world never really coheres, beyond the visual level. An adventure can set up its narrative drive through discovered texts and journals (old gag though that is). Or it can build a narrative out of its artistic details, the discovered connections and implications hidden in the visual world. Or this structure can come from the gameplay itself -- the connections you discover between the puzzles and mechanisms that make up the game. By solving, you learn what it's for.

Kairo disavows each of these strategies: it chooses minimalist artwork, (nearly) textless presentation, and modular puzzles. They're separate design decisions, but together they more or less rule out the sense of a coherent narrative world. It's not a flaw in the game, but a missed opportunity, I guess."[/i]
[url=http://gameshelf.jmac.org/2012/10/kairo-quick-comments/]~Andrew Plotkin[/url]

[h1]THE SECRET[/h1]
There are a set number of secrets to the game, but Jesus Christ do NOT even try going for that shit. Just look up a walkthrough. Kairo's secret ending (yes, it does exist) is a joke. I have to give that away. It's not really funny, and the solution to get to it is completely obscure to get to. It was painful to read how people figured out how to get to the secret rooms, they reminded me of classic Sierra game solutions, it was that bad. Not to mention the secret ending in the dev room (after I even managed to get to it) made me question the validity of all the other secret rooms regarding any sort of story Kairo has. My verdict? Kairo has no story, and that's the worst thing I could possibly say for this genre of games. I'm all for a game with no story (DOOM is one of my favorite games, for God's sake!) but that's a philosophy that needs to be considered on a game-per-game basis, and Kairo's the kind of game that can't handle that shit.

[h1]OVERALL[/h1]
Kairo's a game that promises too much at the start of the game and delivers too little at BOTH of it's endings. However, if you're more here to solve some puzzles and get beautiful visuals, then by all means, $6 isn't all that much. Go ahead and grab it if you're into art games, or if it's on sale. You'll get more out of this than Dear Esther in terms of fun. (imo)

Oh, also check out Antichamber if you're all for atmospheric avant-garde first-person puzzle games with no true plot! THAT'S how to do that shit right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013488135', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 594, 'last_played': 1629942086}
review:
This game is so, so unique and beautiful.

I have always had a fetish for architecture and minimalism, so I was eating my heart out with these striking sceneries and giant, monolithic buildings. (I can only imagine what it would look like on the Oculus; probably overwhelming. In a good way.) 

But what added a poignant thrill to this game was the constant drive to keep going deeper in this "civilization." If you get bored easily or have a curiosity that fades quickly, then this game is probably not for you. Especially since some of these puzzles take a lot of patience and/or trial-and-error.

I played through the whole game with only needing some help on two puzzles (both of which I still don't quite understand because blind luck got me through), so they're not ridiculously hard if you pay attention to all the details as you move forward. (Again, this game is about discovery, so it emphasizes exploration.)

It's a surreal, beautiful game that is meant to be savored. Personally, I think it was worth every cent and more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133077076', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 110, 'last_played': 1421373179}
review:
Kairo is a beautiful and at times, mildly unnerving experience.  Exploring unnaturally simplistic, geometric landscapes that feel eerie and somewhat alien seems to make the skin crawl a little.  

There are times while wandering, I'm made to feel the same way I felt while reading passages of House of Leaves where the author described rooms and corridors larger than the house that contained them.  There's a sense of unease from the environments and sound design that make for an entertaining experience.  

May not be the right cup of tea for the metrics obsessed, goal collecting gamers out there, but was well worth it for me, especially at the sale price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042986114', 'num_games_owned': 444, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1479927519}
review:
[b]Что же такое Kairo, спросите вы?[/b]

На этот вопрос, мне кажется, нельзя ответить просто. Это не игра, это явление. Kairo была  придумана одним очень талантливым человеком и реализована его командой разработчиков.

[h1]Kairo:[/h1] это нагнетающая своей атмосферой бродилка, которая на первый взгляд покажется "бессмысленной". Зайдя в игру, вы ничего вначале не поймёте: - Что это за непонятные построения? Почему я хожу по воздуху? Текстуры не прогрузились? Почему я бегаю по одной и той же локации кругами, всё циклично повторяется! *закрываю игру*

Это были мои первые вопросы, после которых, я закрыл игру и отложил её в долгий ящик. Спустя некоторое время я всё же дал игре второй шанс и зашёл в неё.. Я начал всё тщательно исследовать, вникать в скрытый смысл игры, хоть как-то логически строить цепочку игровых действий. И, могу я вам сказать, я просто проникся этой игрой полностью. Kairo оказалась ошеломительной игрой, с очень интересными головоломками, с нагнетающей атмосферой неизвестности и незабываемой игровой архитектурой! Вы перемещаетесь с одной локации на другую, выполняя квесты, ища подсказки и ключ к разгадке.. но что мы ищем? Зачем мы здесь? Кто это всё возвёл?
В кульминационной части нам открываются все двери, тоесть под конец игры нет неясностей, если конечно немного поднапрячь извилины.

В игре скрыт глубокий смысл. Вы должны сами понять это. 

[h1]Плюсы:[/h1]
+ Оригинальная идея.
+ Превосходная реализация идеи.
+ Тяжёлые головоломки.
+ Графический стиль.

[h1]Минусы:[/h1]
- Инертное управление в этой игре не очень приятное.

9,8/10 кароч

author: {'steamid': '76561198030968100', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1425177788}
review:
[h1]Summary:[/h1]  Interesting indie first-person puzzle game with terrible mechanics, its only redeeming quality is its unique atmosphere that is breathtaking modern art at times, but can be grating at others.

[b]Pros:[/b][list]
[*]Unique and thought provoking styling and ambiance
[*]Unique puzzles (some hard, others stupid easy)
[*]Minimalist
[*]Grand and wide open environments
[*]Nostalgic 90s feel (at least to me)[/list]
[b]Cons:[/b][list]
[*]The intense color palette, sharp and grating sound effects, and an overall feeling of confusion makes the game interesting at first and then unpleasant 
[*]Many of the puzzles are either confusing, super easy, or boring
[*]Terrible game engine (slow, buggy, see though walls and objects)
[*]Because the game is so grand and wide open you zoom around at 100mph across vast areas which is annoying at times
[*]Very unpolished
[*]Fairly short 
[/list]
[h1]Detailed review:[/h1]  I played this game almost back-to-back with [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/252550/]Qbeh-1[/url], a first-person puzzle game in the same vein. It was a funny coincidence because, in juxtaposition, these games couldn’t be further opposites. Qbeh-1 fosters a zen relaxed feeling with blue skies, cool water, open spaces, majestic buildings, relaxing ambient music, and a feeling of smooth progression using hands-on puzzles with standard building blocks. Kairo on the other hand is a strange game with a surreal, Stonehenge, modern abstract, [url=http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/collections/collection-online/artwork/3955] David Smith [i]Cubi[/i] [/url] feeling with graphics reminiscent of the 90s era (reminded me of an old dos game called S.C.A.R.A.B.). It has an environment that is discomforting and disconcerting, trapping the player in dark psychedelic tombs and inorganic voids. The game uses harsh grating sound effects and music and surrounds the player with static filled screens, sharp abstract constructions, and bizarre features. There are no controls beyond the basic movement controls; every “action” is performed by stepping on tiles or otherwise bumping into the various features found within the giant rooms. Perfecting the feeling of being lost in an abstract void is a complete lack of storyline or instruction beyond a list of puzzle hints that can be found in the menu. In short, the game makes you feel like you’re traveling through the monolith from 2001: A Space Odyssey. It’s not bad, but I wouldn’t recommend it to just anyone as it would offend all but those who can appreciate a game that is little more than a virtual modern art gallery with simple puzzles separating each exhibit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032075825', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1424982307}
review:
Wyłączam zanim dostanę ataku paniki.
To nie jest gra dla osób o słabych nerwach. W Kairo nie powinno się grać w ciemnym, pustym pokoju.
Prosta grafika. Lokacje - z nieograniczonych przestrzeni umykajacych oku i katedr jakby zbudowanych przez bogów zmieniajace sie w klaustrofobiczne korytarze - opierające się znanym nam zasadom i wprawiane w ruch niewidzialną ręką - wyludnione, opuszczone. Muzyka bardziej niepokojąca niż kroki w pustym mieszkaniu. Wszystko to tworzy nastrój samotności, pustki i niepokoju. Na początku gry jest tylko tyle: nastrój. Wydaje się, że na tym ma polegać cała gra - nie ma prowadzić do celu tylko wywoływać emocje. 
To gra dla ciekawskich i wytrwałych. W całej tej pustce w pewnym momencie zaczyna się za wszelką cenę szukać celu - czegoś do zrobienia, zasad, którymi kieruje się ten świat. Tu trzeba wypróbować granice tego, co wolno, żeby dowiedzieć się, co należy. Ciekawość przyćmiewa narastające emocje, aż w nagłym przebłysku zrozumie się, że coś się osiągnęło.
Na chwilę obecną trudno mi określić co osiągnęłam, ale to nie jest tutaj ważne - wrócę tu: w jasny, słoneczny dzień; i dowiem się, jaki jest cel.
Wyłączam zanim dostanę ataku paniki i natychmiast chcę jeszcze raz włączyć i iść dalej.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987411178', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1424630123}
review:
Well, that was dissapointing.

To summarize: The game is too much walking, and too little to do. The graphic style becomes boring too soon. That would not matter if you had plenty of things to do on every level, but you don't. It's as simple as that: you'll spend too much time walking and too little time doing real stuff.

Besides that, the game shows poor coding. The mouse and keyboard movement don't feel smooth, and such minimalistic graphics should be piece of cake for my computer, but no matter how much I lower the resolution, the framerate is never as high as the one I get on Mass Effect of FEAR 2. There's clearly something wrong in a game with such simple graphics if Mass Effect runs better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044078749', 'num_games_owned': 422, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1424444047}
review: La verdad es que en cuanto entras a Kairo te das cuenta del tipo de juego con el que te encontrarás. Posee unas gráficas simples, una música bien lograda que acompaña de manera perfecta el ambiente que te presentan. Los puzzles son ingeniosos y ni muy complejos ni muy fáciles. El sistema de pistas que te van guiando y que puedes ir despejando de a poco en caso de que quedes atorado en alguna parte son realmente útiles. Totalmente cómodo de jugar (puedes realizar todas las acciones del juego con el mouse solamente). Recomendado si te gustan este tipo de juegos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077760322', 'num_games_owned': 1036, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1423943492}
review:
Kairo wirkt leider ein wenig wie gewollt und nicht gekonnt.

"Slowly uncover the true purpose of Kairo", verspricht der Text auf der Shopseite. Die Wahrheit ist, dass ich nach dem Spielen von Kairo genauso schlau bin, wie vorher.

Ihr erscheint in einer abstrakten Welt und es liegt an euch, diese zu erkunden und die dabei auftauchenden Rätsel zu lösen.
Der Verlauf des Spiels lässt sich grob in drei Areale unterteilen, in denen es jeweils eine Reihe von Rätseln zu lösen gibt, welche jeweils einen Teil einer "Maschinerie" wieder in Betrieb bringen.
Was sich hier recht überschaubar anhört, wird gegen Mitte / Ende des Spiels schnell frustrierend, da man sich durch die eintönige Gestaltung der Umgebung und zum Teil unnötig großen Räume / Gänge schwer orientieren kann. Zwar gibt es eine Minikarte, aber diese ist nur bedingt hilfreich, da die Abbildingen der Räume zum Teil stark von ihrer eigentlichen Form abweichen. Außerdem lässt sich lediglich ablesen [i]ob[/i] man sich in einem bestimmten Raum befindet, nicht [i]wo[/i] man im aktuellen Raum steht.
Auch hat man sich sehr schnell an der Würfelwelt mit den immer gleichen Texturen sattgesehen. Das Erkunden außerhalb der "notwendigen" Bereiche wird, wenn man von den Achievement-relevanten versteckten Runen absieht, weder objektiv noch subjektiv belohnt.

Die eigentlichen Rätsel sind größtenteils relativ schwach. Fast nie gab mir das Lösen eines Rätsels ein Gefühl des Erfolgs. Das hat je nach Rätsel unterschiedliche Gründe.
Manche sind so einfach, dass man kaum seinen Verstand bemühen muss (Schema "Finde die Stelle im Raum, an der die komplette Lösung abgebildet ist und wende diese entsprechend an").
Andere können dagegen so abstrus konstruiert sein, dass man durch stumpfes Herumprobieren am besten zum Ziel kommt.
Dass das Lösen eines bestimmten Rätsels wortwörtlich vom Zufall abhängt grenzt in diesem Zusammenhang schon fast an Hohn. In einem Spiel, das sich selbst nicht allzu Ernst nimmt, wäre dies vielleicht eine lustige Abwechslung, aber Kairo nimmt sich, soweit ich das beurteilen kann, todernst.
Spontan würden mir zwei, drei Räume einfallen, die ich positiv in Erinnerung habe, aber das Gesamtbild bleibt bestenfalls durchwachsen.

Die Musik hat zwar keine bleibenden Eindrücke bei mir hinterlassen, aber sie ist stimmig und hilft dabei, dass ab und zu durchaus so etwas wie Atmosphäre aufkommt.
Der Rest der Soundabteilung hinkt dagegen etwas hinterher. Viele der Soundeffekte empfand ich als nervig und die schlecht geloopten Effekte wirken unprofessionell.

Angeblich soll während des Spielens eine Handlung kommuniziert werden. Diese ist aber entweder nicht vorhanden, oder erschloss sich mir nicht.
Es gab eine Entdeckung, die ich als plotrelevant einschätzen würde, aber ohne einen Kontext oder Bezugspunkte davor oder danach ließ mich das ganze eher kalt.
In der Welt verstreut finden sich Bezüge zu unserer Welt (Fotos, historische Illustrationen), jedoch wirken diese willkürlich und, in Verbindung mit der Spielwelt, zusammenhangslos.
Der Abspann deutet an, dass der Entwickler mit diesem Spiel einen höchstwahrscheinlich unangenehmen oder schweren Lebensabschnitt bzw. ein Erlebnis verarbeitet hat. Wäre dies etwas nachvollziehbarer eingebunden, hätte Kairo vielleicht zumindest auf einer emotionalen Ebene eindrucksstärker sein können.

Wer auf surreale Trips steht kann hier, vorzugsweise im Sale, zugreifen. Aber ich empfehle, die Erwartungen in Grenzen zu halten.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012652839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1451910024}
review:
밝고 몽환적인 느낌을 기대했던거와는 달리, 플레이하는동안 상당히 오싹한 기분이 들었다
배경음은 굉장히 어둡고, 곳곳에 알수없는 tv화면에서 폐허라던가, 검은 물체가 쳐다보고있다

여러개의 방에있는 퍼즐을 풀면 무언가가 작동되서 다음으로 넘어가는 형식.
모든 퍼즐에 힌트를 주기 때문에 푸는게 어려운건 아니지만, 배경 전체의 색이 똑같아서 이게 버튼인지 그냥 장식인지 구별하기 어려웠고, 밟는다던가 밀면서 푸는게 대부분이라 하나푸는데 시간이 좀 걸리는 편

새로운 곳을 탐험하면서 비밀을 밝혀내는 게임을 원했다면 비추천 하고싶다.

개인적으론 이게임하면서 크옵피보다 더한 공포를 느낌..퍼즐은 독창적이고 질리지 않았지만 분위기가 무거운것은 감안해야 할듯하다.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062937414', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1487939670}
review:
Добрый вечер всем.
Итак, что же нам подарила игра kairo?

В целом получилось всё в соответствии с большинством положительных отзывов.
- Игра, в самом, деле увлекательная.
- В самом деле, много головоломок.
- В самом деле, красивая архитектура, даже невзирая на примитивность.
- В самом деле, приятное звуковое сопровождение.
Вывод: с учётом стоимости по акции в 26р., игра,конечно же, стоит потраченных денег.

Из минусов:
- Вынужден констатировать, что большинство "головоломок" достаточно просты (не согласен с предыдущими ораторами в "мозгодробительности", сложности и многообразии этих головоломок. Почти все они проходятся либо интуитивно, либо «методом тыка», либо немного нудно, лишь одна-две на всю игру оказались в самом деле интересными).
- На мой взгляд, к серьёзному минусу игры можно отнести некоторую "мёртвость", ни о каком сравнении с Mist идти речь не может. Всё дело в очень завуалированном (практически отсутствующим) сюжете. На самом деле сюжет есть, но додумать его всецело придётся самостоятельно. Игра в плане сюжета эдакие кубики для младенца, который сам строит из них "нечто". Ввиду этого игра постепенно утомляет. Без сюжетности игра превращается в обычную красивенькую бродилку-пазл.
- Никакого ощущения таинственности или мистичности или минимальных элементов хоррора (как кто-то тут писал) в игре нет. Слегка гнетут тёмные интерьеры и пейзажи, но не из-за своей мрачности, а скорее из-за примитивности исполнения.
- Согласен, что со временем начинают уставать глаза из-за частой смены ярких интерьеров.

Из важного:
- Кто-то поставил kairo в один ряд с Antichamber. Совершенно напрасно. Antichamber игра более высокого уровня, и, в сравнении с ней, kairo просто меркнет.
- В kairo определенно стоит поиграть любителям жанра «ходи-броди-тыкай-угадывай», но ДО того, как играть в Antichamber. Если вы уже играли в Antichamber, рекомендую обойти kairo стороной, дабы потом не получить небольшую разочарованность.

Technické spracovanie hry na slabej úrovni, ale dokáže zaujať svojim utilitaristickým dizajnom a ambient hudbou. V hre nenájdete žiaden príbeh, jedná sa o surové riešenie hlavolamov. Najväčším negatívom hry je jej herná doba, pretože na jej dokončenie je potrebné vyriešiť iba zopár hlavných hlavolamov. Kairo celkovo pôsobí ako zaujímavý projekt, ale pre svoje nedostatky môže odradiť od kúpi a hrania viacero hráčov.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128287463', 'num_games_owned': 619, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1499806115}
review:
It's been a long time since I 100% completed Kairo, so I thought I'd come back for a bit and just do some exploring and really see whether Kairo deserved the review I gave it. I've read a lot of the negative reviews and I was really wondering whether I had this mistaken view of how good Kairo is. Kairo is a lot like Myst with a minimalism twist. Some may gasp or think I'm nuts for comparing Kairo to the masterpiece that is Myst. However, Kairo, at its core, is [i]very much[/i] like Myst. There is more story direction in Myst, and the puzzles are more direct, but this is where Kairo becomes a little more abstract and like a modern art piece.

In Myst, the story is [i]told[/i] to you (with a little twist), while in Kairo you are uncovering a story long forgotten. I know to some this may be dissatisfying, because it feels like you're not taking part in a current story. For me though, I don't mind one bit. I enjoy unraveling stories like a long weaved thread. When you reach the end too, there is a lot left to decide for yourself. It's not so different from Myst, but this subtle difference is critical to Kairo's feel. As opposed to Myst where you know exactly what happens at the end, Kairo leaves you to wonder.

As far as the gameplay goes, Kairo sometimes presents puzzles which are a little hard to grasp. They're not difficult by any means, but sometimes it's hard to understand the kind of thinking Kairo wants you to do. However, overall the puzzles aren't a problem and are satisfying to complete. The game also gives you the ability to explore freely. Despite this, Kairo gives you just the [i]little bit[/i] of direction you need to know where to go next. However, the movement feels absurdly sluggish. I don't know why the character's movement is so heavy and slow. It's not a major concern, though.

It is important to note, that the aspect of exploration allows Kairo to sometimes feel more like a walking simulator than a puzzle game. This will turn away many onlookers. In my mind though, this isn't an entirely bad thing. I enjoy that aspect. Classic, hardcore puzzle game fans will likely get bored and quit. Those of you who are more into exploration games and walking simulators will be in awe at the haunting atmosphere that Kairo creates, and you will be rewarded with an ending that allows you to ponder and sum up all you've experienced. The soundscapes and the minimalist art give the game a unique feel I haven't experienced in a game prior to this one.

In short, Kairo is an exploration puzzle game with walking simulator elements. Hardcore puzzle game fans will likely dislike the artistic nature of Kairo, whereas exploration game fans will find it a refreshing touch. It's no Antichamber, The Witness, or Cypher, but it's not bad either. No matter what you look for in a game though, what Kairo tries to do I personally believe it does well, so it gets a recommendation from me.

[b]Overall, I'd give Kairo a 5.5/10.[/b] That being said, I definitely don't recommend this to hardcore puzzle game fans, though. This isn't what you're looking for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010112719', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 293, 'last_played': 1589947968}
review:
I got this game for $1. And I'm glad I scooped it up! A great puzzle/exploration game with enigmas abound.

GAMEPLAY: Consists of walking, jumping, and looking around. It's straightforward exploration with minor platforming. Puzzles round out the play, which you complete by stepping on platforms and bumping into objects to trigger them.

PUZZLES: They're pretty intuitive for the most part, but there were a few I had to consult the helpfully provided "hints" option for (one in particular was hair rippingly frustrating because I'm terrible at math). Be prepared to comb areas carefully for clues, and draw out some diagrams here and there. It's quite satisfying to solve these puzzles, as they're fairly challenging, and it's made clear when you have activated a piece of machinery or opened a pathway by way of flashing lights, thunderous tumults, or loud gong strikes. It all amounts to a feeling of progress and getting one step closer to solving the mystery.

VISUALS: Very minimalistic. Oftentimes, you wander through barren corridors or empty voids, with sparsely a decoration to look at. What there is to look at, though, serves to deepen the mystery. It feels like everything being presented - from images of Earth to the DNA double helix - has some type of underlying meaning. Otherwise, lighting and colouring is used to differentiate rooms, creating a very surreal effect. There's also some use of moving objects - floating, spinning globes, for example - that add some variance. In all, it's simplistic, but only where it needs to be.

AUDIO: The highlight of the game for me. Again, simplicity is the standard here - a haunting, ambient soundtrack makes the place feel mysterious, dangerous, and cozy all at once. It's a strange effect, but it keeps the player guessing as to what, exactly, these structures are. As mentioned before, loud, sudden bells and gongs are used to indicate that the player has completed a puzzle, which is pretty satisfying. Radio static in certain locations and chimes during object interaction round out the auditory experience. Like the graphics, it feels like the sounds of the game highlight what's important.

STORY: Ostensibly, there isn't much of one. There is virtually no dialogue or cutscenes, and there are no NPCs present. Only environmental clues, mainly through recurring motifs, give rise to some semblance of a plot. I enjoyed wondering what Kairo could be about, and reading theories about it afterward.

Overall, a great experience, which is even nicer considering I got this game for $1. It reminded me a lot of Myst (and Penumbra, somehow). There are mysteries to be unravelled for those willing to search for them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061294312', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1422315758}
review:
I just finished the game Kairo and I must say that I am disappointed. Let me tell you why:
(Caution: minor spoilers ahead)

First of all I expected a little more story. Sadly there is absolutely none. Before playing it I also thought that there's maybe a connection to the city Cairo in Egypt, but there is no connection at all (as far as I experienced it). The only "clues" you get in the game are some blurry pictures and unrecognizable audio tunes which serves no purpose. A deeper meaning? I doubt it. And for an art-project this seems all too random and poorly conceived. When I finished the game I was as smart as before. Mostly I didn't even know, what I was doing and for what purpose. Who build these puzzles and why? And why do I have to solve them? But that's my second point of criticism: the riddles.

The riddles are sometimes too simple, and sometimes you don't have a clue what you should be doing and the game doesn't give you any hints regarding the puzzle. Some of these riddles I solved by pure luck, bashing buttons and trying it over and over again. Even after I finished some of these, I couldn't tell you how I solved it. But most of the riddles based just on pushing the right button at the right time. Not much fun and also not very clever for a puzzle game...
And there are also rooms without any importance to the main riddle, but you can't recognize, which rooms are important and which are just "corridors" to other rooms. There is no clear path in this game. Some may call this "concept" or "open world", but I think the developers just had not enough time (or talent) to generate a clear guideline for the player. And that is my third point of criticism: the level design.

All you do in this game is walk. And walk. And walk. After playing it a few hours, I constatly use the "sprint"-key, just to get where I want to, faster. Because every room is enormous and vast. At first this is actually cool, but after a few riddles it is just annoying. Yeah, I understand - big landscapes: cool! But the levels don't include too many details and it's getting boring. concrete wall on concrete wall. So here's my final point of criticism: the look of the game.

Sure, this is not a AAA-game by some major game developer, but the game looks like it's from 1995. The rooms and places look too clean and dull, there's no life or fun in these corridors and halls. So the walking gets very frustrating, because you walk through dull rooms all the time, solving very easy (or "what-the-hell-do-I-have-to-do") puzzles without even knowing what purpose for... And the end screen (which appears very soon) gives you no solution what you just accomplished.
One good thing in Kairo is the soundtrack. It is deep and athmospheric and it prevents the game to get even more boring.

So all in all I was disappointed. The game was indeed too short (6 hours), but because I got sick of running around in circles I was happy when the end screen appeared. 
The game would surely be better, if there actually was a story or maybe even a connection to the city of Cairo. I could even imagine a game about the political / social struggle in Egypt and the history and the culture of Cairo. Unfortunate, Kairo had potental, but the poor game design and the absence of story just killed the whole game.

review:
Too blocky, chunky and minimal for me. Has potential, but after 10 min I knew I'd had enough.

That's not to say it's terrible. I don't want to "not recommend it". There needs to be a middle ground where you neither recommend for or against. It depends what sort of games you like and what mood you're in. Sometimes a basic and minimal game is exactly the thing to get into. Right now I'm distracted by The Talos Principle... expensive but good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047420246', 'num_games_owned': 140, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1438060943}
review:
Really creepy puzzle game! There are in-game hints for the puzzles, which I thought was nice (there's a hint section in the menu that only gives hints for puzzles). The story is really well done and subtle enough to not get in the way for people more interested in the puzzle aspect.

Only 2 gripes: the game's pretty linear/straightforward so IDK how much replay value there is to get the achievements, and there's a puzzle where for me the in-game hint system was completely unhelpful, so I had to just mess around until it solved

It's a cheap, short, interesting game that you can beat in a few hours, so I'd rec it

author: {'steamid': '76561198064527406', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1421777443}
review: This game wasn't really one of my favorites. There was a sizeable portion where I just wanted it to end. The puzzles were interesting and fun to complete. Everything in between kind of just blurred together into a multi-colored swatch of concrete. This game is not pretty. A sizeable portion of it I couldn't even enjoy artisticly. It felt like I was walking through some one's grad school project. The symbols throughout the game felt forced. It all just felt a little bit too obvious to me. Maybe that's just me. I just didn't like it. I appreciate what the game is trying to do, and I can tell a lot of love went into this. I just don't think I was the right audience for this one. I will say the secret ending was awesome. That quite possibly was worth going through the game to get. If stark modern art is your kind of thing then this game is right up your alley. If you aren't into that kind of thing you might want to try something else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016342006', 'num_games_owned': 415, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1640437618}
review:
Ein wahres Meisterwerk!

Ich bin was Spiele angeht eher skeptisch, besonders da ich normalerweiße nicht für Spiele mit etwas dunkler Atmosphäre zu begeistern bin.

Kairo überzeugt mich aber auf ganzer Linie! Man wird in das Spiel reingeworfen ohne eine Information wo man ist. Die Geschichte erzählt sich trotzdem irgendwie von selbst, auch ganz ohne Worte. Durch die Musik wird das ganze perfekt abgerundet. Ich bin leicht erschreckbar und das Spiel scheint damit zu spielen. Ich muss sagen das gefällt mir.

Ich möchte garnicht zuviel verraten, ein blick in das Spiel lohnt sich auf jedenfall!

author: {'steamid': '76561197986997483', 'num_games_owned': 846, 'num_reviews': 314, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1413155429}
review:
This is a somewhat hesitating recommendation.  This is very much the kind of thing that I like, exploring old ruins and solving puzzles.  It's very beautiful, and has a nice aural landscape too, I suppose the aspect I don't like is that you have to explore every inch of the thing.  There are tiny runes etched into the rock in hidden areas that you must find, and it gets boring before then end.

But it is good, just maybe don't try to play it all at once or everything will start blending together.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131632892', 'num_games_owned': 534, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 1686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1448, 'last_played': 1576663307}
review:
Mittlerweile glaube ich den Hintergrund des Spiels zu verstehen. Ich glaube hier geht es bei den Rätzeln um fundamentale Fragen der Menschen und Menschlichkeit. Es wird das negative der Menschen gezeigt und gleichzeitig (tote oder gerade entstehende) Natur. Die Rätzel bauen alle auf Mechanik/Technik auf und sollen (glaube ich) den Menschen bewusst machen, wie hilfreich Technik sein kann aber eben auch wie gefährlich!

Selbst jetzt nach ein paar Tagen finde ich das Spiel noch unglaublich Genial! Das ist eindeutig etwas Wert (zumal das auch für Kinder [im Beisein der Eltern!] geeignet ist, da kein Blut, keine Schlachterei und keine pornografischen Inhalte vorhanden sind (y) ). Wenn man's nicht kennt und das erste mal sieht oder anspielt, ist's mir klar das man selbst 1 Euro als teuer ansehen würde, aber ab dem dritten Raum (wenn man's grundlegend verstanden hat) will man gar nicht mehr aufhören. Für eine weitere Version würde ich deutlich viel mehr Zahlen!

author: {'steamid': '76561198099356013', 'num_games_owned': 438, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1421619415}
review:
Kairo es uno de esos juegos que me encantaría que me gustasen... pero no.

Es básicamente un juego de puzzles con pocas posibilidades. Construido sobre espacios abstractos y geométricos, en él todo consiste en ir solventando las distintas pruebas para ir pasando a las siguientes salas. El problema es que estos puzzles son por lo general muy poco gratificantes, siendo bastante irracionales y carentes de todo sentido lógico: empiezas probando unas pocas combinaciones para intentar averiguar la dinámica del juego, pero al final todo consiste en descubrirlo de chiripa. Jeroglíficos, runas y símbolos están inscritos en las paredes del juego, cuyo significado nunca se nos va a explicar, sumado a una especie de "cuadros" enmarcados en las paredes de los que tampoco tenemos ni idea de por qué están ahí.

Para resolver los enigmas contamos con movernos con WASD y saltar... y ya está. Entiendo que el juego pretende ser minimal, pero siendo tan abstractos los acertijos que propone es muy fácil perder el interés ante la falta de opciones.

Y es una pena, porque en estos ambientes abstractos y geométricos el juego logra algo poético, especialmente gracias a la banda sonora que es envolvente y misteriosa. Además, bastantes de los puzzles implican tonalidades y ciertos sonidos pero de manera muy tibia, lo cuál deja mucha sensación de potencial desaprovechado.

Así, en general Kairo es bonito a pesar de su simpleza, pero dándose el caso que jugablemente no da mucho de sí, se hacen todavía más notorios los numerosos problemas de tearing y popping. Si tuviera una buena jugabilidad o supusiera un reto satisfactorio probablemente lo pasaría por alto, pero no siendo así lo cierto es que los problemas gráficos no ayudan nada.

Puede que me haya dejado bastantes cosas, el juego me ha durado más bien poco (he tenido que mirar una guía en un par de ocasiones porque desesperaba, y realmente esos puzzles no los hubiera adivinado jamás de tan rara que era la mecánica para resolverlos). Veo que hay varios logros que no he obtenido, pero viendo lo poco gratificante que me ha resultado, dudo que resolver las pruebas restantes me supongan una alegría.

En resumen: Kairo, una pena porque la sombra de "podría haber sido un buen juego" planea en todo momento sobre él.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087951038', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1432449127}
review:
Ever since I started playing this game, I have been plagued by unspeakable nightmares. Such horrific phantasms that cannot be adequately described by human beings have ravished my every sleeping moment. I can't fully describe the horror, but I will do my best.

My dreams all start with me standing on a throne pedestal, overseeing nothing but a building off to the left and a tall tower to the right. As i enter the building, it plays the beginning of the game through my head, sometimes doing puzzles out of order, finding odd things wrong with them, like looking behind a pillar for the symbols and finding Trollfaces there instead. But all my dreams end the same way. Everything starts turning all grainy and fuzzy, and suddenly I can't move, and a giant red rhombus starts licking the right side of my nose and I can't get away.

Damn that red rhombus.

Then I'm being chased  through something like a chinese restaurant except everything is blue and on the ceiling, and nothing's chasing me, but a waterfall of chicken noodle soup keeps raining down from the sky, except its not chicken noodle soop. I don't know. And then, God starts slapping me back and forth across the face, yelling some bizarre phrase over and over that seems to make a lot of sense but i can never remember what he said.

Then I fall back into the game, and the red rhombus (damn that red rhombus), starts chasing me while punching a pair of my old tennis shoes, or some other object from my house. Sometimes i wake up at that point, but other times I end up in what could only be described as cowboy hell where I'm tormented by something like Johnny Cash and yodelling cacti for a while, and then right before the earth-sized cake from Portal is about to crush me, I wake up.

The full horror of these dreams cannot be expressed fully through these feeble attempts.

∞/√-3 would walk lonely and blindly through an abandoned ghost world again

author: {'steamid': '76561197969948149', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1421447877}
review:
[h1]One Sentence[/h1]
Atmospherically interesting and surreal puzzle game with some glaring flaws.

[h1]A Bit More[/h1]
Let me first say I got this game for the fair price of 0.74$ and I think paying full price may also be a fair deal, depending on where your video game preferences lie.
Kairo sets the mood pretty early with it's ominous soundtrack and stark visuals. I found the grain effect and mouse smoothing (default settings) annoying so I had to turn them off straight away. I had extremely choppy/laggy mouse and keyboard movement which might be due to my weak computer but this game should not as demanding on the cpu as it is. Despite all that Kairo's atmosphere is enjoyable and the much needed hint system helps in teaching you what the level design won't. Towards the later segments of the game the puzzles lose some of their quality and the map design will leave most players wondering around without much enjoyment.  

[h1]Bottom Line[/h1]
If you enjoy difficult puzzles and open ended mysteries Kairo will give you your money's worth

Follow http://steamcommunity.com/groups/West7 for more game reviews

author: {'steamid': '76561198093538696', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1421728580}
review: This is a pretty interesting game. Though oftentimes it suffers from the same problem as similar indie titles. It'll forget it's an abstract first person puzzle game and become Sculpture Garden Simulator 2015. Yes game, when walk through your rooms I appreciate your post-modernist, minimalist design that recalls Egyptian, Chinese and Classical art. But when you place these puzzle-less rooms in between the puzzles, you're really hurting the pacing. Though for $0.74 (as of this writing) , I definitely recommend picking it up. The puzzles are just challenging enough and if you have trouble the game has a pretty generous hint system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049061232', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1421203359}
review:
Very cryptic game. You will feel like a fine craftsman trying to repair an immense mechanism of which you can't grasp the entire dimension and function, and yet, each part of it it's so beautiful in its minimalistic design.

The puzzles aren't hard to solve and it won't take you a lot of time to travel through the entire world. For that matter, someone will probably call this game more of a "walking simulator", but maybe in this case a "vision" simulator label could be appropriate.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084110829', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1421256447}
review: Игра просто охрененная! Захватывающий гемплей заставит окунуться в прохождение игры с самого начала и до самого конца. Да, погибнуть нельзя. Никак. При всем желании. Игра страдает прямо-таки толстовским всепрощением. Обрушат на голову крышу, устроят ядерную бомбардировку, из разверстой бездны прискачут Всадники Апокалипсиса — истошный вопль «Элика!!!» автоматически оживит героя и вернет его на ближайшую надежную опору. Бесполезную в таких условиях «полоску здоровья» убрали, заменив двумя состояниями: «здоров» и «ранен». Статуса «R.I.P.» нет, даже в бою за гибелью следует мгновенное воскрешение. В качестве компенсации противника слегка подлечивают. Подобное упрощение раздражает бывалых геймеров и заставляет чувствовать себя читером, но, с другой стороны, избавляет от рутинного «save/load». В сказке ему не место... Да, именно в сказке. Сказка — в работе художников, которые при помощи акварельной графики и cel-shading легко и артистично компенсировали нехватку полигонов. В отсутствии инвентаря (мы ничего не копим и не храним). В несложных, но симпатичных логических загадках. Наконец, в тихой мелодичной музыке

review:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a some kind of a puzzle walk simulator game.


[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]

The game will only ask you for the language once. There are 5 different languages.
There are many different resolution sizes available.
There is a volume slidebar available.
There is a look sensitivty available.
You can play with a xbox controller.

[h1]About the game.[/h1]

So you are dropped into this game and you will have no clue what it is about or what to do. Most of the puzzles are pretty annoying and the game feel really bland. Even if you have manage to complete a puzzle, you will not feel that you will get rewarded for it. You will feel that you are just playing a boring walking simulator game with no impacts and progression at all.

Graphics are not catchy and boring.
Sound is minimalistic.
Clunky control movement.
Character is "sliding" and not walking.
There are hints available.
Feels really bland/empty.

[h1]Other things.[/h1]

None.

-------------------

I Give this game a 2/10

review:
Kairo has absolutely no character in its' visual design and atmosphere. I wandered the halls looking for some storyline or meaning to my progress, yet there's absolutely nothing to keep your interest for longer than 10 minutes (except possibly for the achievements). Not even Kairo's architecture is interesting, resembling the surreal cubic design of Assassin's Creed's Animus with all the life sucked out of them.

The game doesn't even redeem itself on its' puzzles, which are ridiculously simple and generic, and yet are still explained in full within the game's hint menu.

I only spent $0.82, and yet I still feel like I wasted my money. Save up and buy a better puzzle/platformer instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992536847', 'num_games_owned': 1969, 'num_reviews': 187, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1421004393}
review:
Kairo is an abstract first person puzzle/exploration game where you work your way through a geometric world to complete what are initially seemingly arbitrary tasks to accomplish a goal which is not immediately apparent. It is obtuse, but stylistically so, and easy to get lost in. I recommend walking around and exploring before diving in too deep, but when stuck in any given room, you can go into the menu and choose up to three Hints to help point you in the right direction - this is the saving grace of the game, as they progressively give more direction without telling you what exactly to do, so you're never actually LOST, it can just feel like it at times.

The controls are a little "floaty" - they don't feel as tight as most other first person games, but due to a lack of combat that's not necessarily a problem, just takes some getting used to. The graphics are simple, but very effective - the spectacle is quite impressive. 

In addition to the normal gameplay goals, there are a series of 18 runes to find hidden about the game, one "go back and find later" puzzle where, after you exit an area, something secret opens up which you can find, and three exceptionally hard "did you notice that one little thing elsewhere? Interpret it in this abstract way here!" puzzles which you might need to look for external guides for.

The game doesn't take too long (aside from those harder puzzles) - 3-4 hours should probably be enough to get through it.

I had a good time with it. It's probably not up everyone's alley, but if the above sounds interesting, check it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068958789', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1524638784}
review:
I wanted to like Kairo. I really tried.

But i can't. It really just comes down to the fact that even as an "explore and wonderment" game, it's very...dull. The atmosphere is great and a lot of the areas (Especially the famous "red pylon" room) are fantastic looking, but...The puzzles feel bland and useless, like they were taked on to give the game uneeded "difficulty" (of which there is none even with puzzles), the music can be grating at times, and some of the stuff, like the static, screens, or door effects, feel a bit out of place.

I can definitely respect what the game was trying to do, and in terms of being a "wow look at this giant otherworldly thing" game it succeeds, but i think that adding ridiculously easy puzzles and the sort actually took away from the game rather than added to it. If the whole game was just walking through progressively grander rooms (with the occasional ACTUAL jumping puzzle, the only puzzle that i think could fit in this game), i'd like it a lot more, but it just was a bit too tedious for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002522468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1420282540}
review:
レベルエディタで適当に作った感が溢れるMAPを走り回り、随所の部屋でパズルを解いて先に進むゲームだ。
世界観等の説明は一切無く、物語性も皆無である。
随所にちりばめられた演出からある程度の事を汲み取ることは可能かも知れないが、学も無ければ感受性も無い私では理解することは出来なかった。
哲学的な内容なので評価は分かれると思う。雰囲気で似た作品では「ゆめにっき」が近いのかも知れないが、あそこまでゲーム性は無いので期待はしないように。

パズルとしての難易度は低い。分かり難いがMAP自体にヒントがあるし、メニュー画面にもヒントという項目がある。

気に入らない部分としてエリア外に落下した際に最後に立っていた場所に復帰する仕様なのだが、復帰した場所が脱出不可能な場所がいくつかある。ゲームを再起動すればAutoSaveによりエリアの入口から再開できるため進行不能にはならないが再起動は少々面倒くさい。
他にはMAPのライティングがおかしい部分があったりと作り込みも少々荒い。

あと3D酔いしやすい人は注意が必要。
オプションで視野角（FOV）等を弄ることで私は多少改善することが出来た。

セールにより99円で購入し、払った代金以上には遊べたと思うが、フルプライスの価値があるかは正直疑問である。
買ってまでやる物ではないと思う。

author: {'steamid': '76561198025423629', 'num_games_owned': 63, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 949, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 927, 'last_played': 1479230076}
review:
A very atmospheric game both visually and audibly, making for a pleasurable journey to the end. Although puzzle based the puzzles are not so hard (or just guesswork based) as to be annoying. With a little thought all but a couple of the puzzles can be solved in reasonable amount of time (and those that can't belong to the 'achievements' section, so they do not hinder you from completing the game).   

I loved the pace of this game, the feeling of being somewhere that matters, perhaps because the game hints through its imagery that the place is somehow significant and that you aren't just wandering around without meaning. There was no rush, no one chasing and it was easy to get from point to point without a lot of walking.  

Kairo is a relaxing game to play. Enjoyable too.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974593679', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1420181721}
review:
To put this as bluntly as possible, so as to save people a bit of time, since there's a rant coming shortly:  I don't like this game.  It's not clever, it's not intuitive, it's just very, very marginally "artsy", so everyone will be drawn into what is otherwise a shallow and uninteresting experience.

[b][i]The Rant Begins[/i][/b]

I've had my eye on this game for a very long time, and I'd been intentionally avoiding the reviews to the best of my ability, because I felt as though this was the sort of game you wouldn't want to spoil by having any prior knowledge of any aspect of it.  The reviews looked positive, and that was the important part, in my eyes.  Naturally, once it finally went on sale I wasn't the least bit hesitant to snatch it up and install it as quickly as could be, because games like this (I thought.) always fascinate me and never fail to entertain.

I [i]love[/i] the "off-kilter" genre, and I don't at all mind when a game wants to sit down and just walk me through a story.  Visceral Clean-up Detail, Dear Esther, Tiny & Big, Gone Home, these are games I've played more than once, or a dozen times over, just because I [i]love[/i] it when a studio or an individual sits down and tries to defy a genre, because if no one ever did, we'd end up with a terribly stagnant market practically bereft of originality.

I've also never been one to shy away from a solidly-constructed puzzle game.  Portal needs no introduction, Braid--although overhyped--made you plan ahead so far that it occasionally became a little brain-bending. The Bridge, Antichamber, Myst, Kill the Bad Guy, FEZ, all of these came at the puzzle genre with something unique, and often very atmospheric.  They made you rack your brain to see a puzzle in a light it had never quite been presented in before, and you would walk away feeling accomplished when you'd finally figured out that one, little trick to cinching it all together.

Kairo does none of these things.  It attempts to paint a unique world full of mystery that begs to be explored, but in those rare instances where it rewards exploration, you get such a small, nonsensical snippet of the 'lore' that you're just left with more questions, or a flimsy little "piece" of the puzzle in the form of a slight JPG-artifacted "rune".  Often times Kairo will have entire rooms, entire cement-slathered, sprawling 'scapes to explore that serve [i]absolutely no purpose at all[/i].

Kairo also does not approach the puzzle genre in any [i]meaningful[/i] way.  I know this is a matter of contention, because there are those that think the puzzles are just blatantly impossible, and then those that insist Kairo is brilliant because it [i]does[/i] offer some semblances of clues in the form of pattern recognition, or subtle sound cues, but both of these trains of thought are ultimately flawed, because Kairo, to me, suffers from a cardinal sin when you examine its puzzles more closely:  Kairo's puzzles are [b][i]boring[/i][/b].

Once you've managed to work out exactly what it is that the game is expecting of you, you don't have one of those, "Oh God, really?!" moments that you'd have in Portal, you don't see all the little nuanced motions that you'll need to pull off to navigate through the level in The Bridge; in Kairo, once you've seen the puzzle for what it is, it is always something [b][i]excruciatingly simple[/i][/b].  Many of these puzzles--[i]far[/i] too many of them--simply involve a trial-and-error style rote memorization of a keypad-like button press sequence.  One of them involves shuffling yourself into the right place until all the blocks line up with the other blocks.  I hope you enjoy this one, because you'll be doing it a [i]lot[/i].  

One of the "core" puzzles for the secret ending involves scouring this desolate, barren expanse of cement into every nook and cranny, until you find all 15 of the JPG artifacts, and the worst one of all?  Backtracking.  The last of the core puzzles involves a nearly-nonsensical amount of backtracking to accomplish.  Yes, you are given a very mild hint concerning what to do and where to go, but the fact of the matter is the game is shoving you ten to fifteen minutes out of your way, through uninteresting environments you've already seen, to do virtually nothing except headbutt a statue.

Clearly this is a game that's garnered an impressive following, and I've no doubt that there are plenty of people out there who enjoy this sort of game for what it is, but I came into this expecting a refreshingly-interesting story at best, a unique puzzle in the very least, and at the worst: An interesting world I could explore.  I found myself being offered none of these things. 

In short:  In Kairo, I do not feel alone.  I feel [i][b]bored[/i][/b].

review:
If you are prone to motion sickness, skip this game. I played it for an hour, and spent almost an hour recovering from the nausea it induced. While more 3D games never bother me, something about the scale, the coloring, the atmosphere, and the movement combined to trigger motion sickness pretty badly for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972995911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1419792322}
review:
Kairo is a beautifully eerie shapescape that combines original style with familiar puzzle questing.  It is a simple yet aw- filled atmospheric journey that takes place in this supernatural-like world you've stumbled upon. 

Pros: 
+ Increadible atmosphere.  Sometimes even daunting to look at with the great depth of field use by the dev.   
+ Music is more like a drone in various keys and melodies.  It's unique and quite pleasing to listen to.
+ There is no linearity to it, well there is but you're free to tackle various areas at your leisure.
+ Puzzles are both easy and incredibly challenging.  
+ Sandbox style freedom to explore the world.  It's not very large but the amount of rooms can make you forget where to go or where you've been.

Cons:
- There is very little if any backstory but some may say none is needed with just how odd and abstract the setting is.
- Some puzzles are a little too tough because they go completely unexplained or not elluded to.

Overall I would rate this game a solid 8/10.  If you're into puzzles and don't mind exploring abstract scenery with no AI interaction then this game is 100% worth it at it's price.  On sale even better.  I highly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028570547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2558, 'playtime_forever': 503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 503, 'last_played': 1419880920}
review:
"Kairo" ist vor allem eines: stilsicher.

In einer archaisch-monumentalen Welt gilt es, aus der First-Person-Perspektive verschiedenste Rätsel zu lösen. Man entdeckt Raum für Raum, sucht nach Hinweisen und versucht, Rätselstrukturen zu verstehen. Die mysteriöse Spielwelt entfaltet dabei durch oft synchrone Farbgebung und die meist reduzierte aber gekonnte Soundkulisse ihre eigene faszinierende Atmosphäre. 

Die Rätsel erweisen sich als mal einfach, mal knifflig, Hinweise werden stets subkutan gegeben, teils durch visuelle, teils durch akustische Elemente. Dabei ist aber stets nicht die Lösung des Rätsels das eigentlich spannende, sondern das Entdecken des Lösungsweges.

"Kairo" entfaltet seine eigene Welt, seine eigene Ästhetik, seinen eigenen Reiz. Ein Indie-Game wie es sein sollte, da es nicht durch Effekte oder eine aufwändige Engine glänzt, sondern durch Charme und Intelligenz.

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
8/10 Atmosphäre
7/10 Grafik
6/10 Sound
7/10 Spielmechanik
7/10 Balancing
7/10 Spieltiefe 
8/10 Spielspaß

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Souveräner und atmosphärischer Ambient First-Person Exploration Puzzler. 

[h1][b]7/10 Gesamtwertung

author: {'steamid': '76561198070305576', 'num_games_owned': 428, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1640965422}
review:
"For everyone who nedeed a second chance"

Загадочность на загадочности загадочностью погоняет.(4) Игра очень странная и порой пугает своей гнетущей атмосферой. То около около радиовышек слышны голоса, говорящие на русском, то начерченные на монументах послания, то на экранах за тобой наблюдает силуэт человека, то на тех же экранах показывают фотографии катастроф и последствия каких-то бедствий, то просто дают загадки без решения... просто так. Множества разных картин с изображениями формул, древних надписей, знаменитых картин и людей и др. Суть и мораль всей игры к концу становится довольна ясна, но для любителей произносить во время игры фразу: "Что это б...ть за х...ня?" - эта игра в самый раз. (5)

author: {'steamid': '76561198041694909', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1419858956}
review:
I bought this on sale for less than 1€, but I'd happily have paid the full price for it. it's an extremely minimalistic game, don't buy it if you absolutely need captivating plots, high-end graphics and complex gameplay or you'd be disappointed. the game is a fascinating journey through a beautifully designed surrealistic world. a really fitting ambient soundtrack adds a lot to the experience. if you've ever played Hiversaires and enjoyed it you'll really like this game as well (if you haven't go and play it). despite the 90s-like 3d graphics I was more than once amazed by the haunting and eerie scenarios and architecture of the game. along the journey you have to solve puzzles to proceed, which are decent, full of satisfying eureka-moments and quite never frustrating. it's a pretty short game tho, it took me less than 3 hours to get to the final credits, but still there were a couple of optional puzzles I didn't solve and some secrets I discovered that suggest there is something more if you find them all, so I might get back to it one day. one last note: most of the negative reviews complain about the lack of a plot and clear instructions. well I liked that instead, it's a plot device itself that adds to the unsettling feel of the game. you're thrown in without any explanation and are left with more questions than answers. picture it as a dream, no one is there to tell you where you are, what is happening and what you have to do, you just accept it and go on, and it's beautiful that way.

overall solid 7.5/10, would play again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046807512', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 161, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1417831309}
review:
Dal trailer e dalle immagini, così come da altri commenti, mi aveva intrigato parecchio.
Speravo di trovare un gioco capace di stupirmi coi suoi enigmi e con la bellezza degli ambienti.
Peccato che nè gli uni nè gli altri siano veramente esaltanti.
Gli ambienti troppo vasti, si cammina tanto senza avere sempre un'idea di dove andare, nè di dove si trovino le stanze con gli enigmi.
Gli enigmi poi sono la parte più deludente: un gioco a puzzle dovrebbe dare soddisfazione, anche farti scervellare magari, ma farti sentire intelligente quando trovi una soluzione. Peccato che qui gli enigmi siano o troppo semplici o troppo... vaghi.
Mi sono ritrovato a risolvere una stanza senza nemmeno capire perchè, o lasciare una stanza convinto di aver trovato la soluzione  e doverci ritornare perchè non era così.

E' un gioco confuso in cui l'astrazione, che doveva essere il punto di forza, risulta essere una debolezza.

I suoni d'atmosfera (non si può parlare proprio di musiche) sono gradevoli, il level design poteva essere interessante se meno grossolano e con ambienti più ristretti.

Deludente.

(p.s. io ho adorato Antichamber e qui  al confronto siamo lontanissimi da enigmi stimolanti in ambienti creativi)

author: {'steamid': '76561197966720521', 'num_games_owned': 3407, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 500, 'last_played': 1419094353}
review:
Uno de los juegos más raros y abstractos que he probado, prueba viviente de lo que ocurre cuando la narrativa visual basada en el entorno se lleva hasta el extremo.

Kairo nos lanza a un escenario en el que no sabemos qué somos ni dónde estamos, extrañas y a menudo colosales estructuras se muestran ante nuestros ojos. Con movimientos básicos deberemos resolver los puzzles que se nos vayan presentando según avancemos por una especie de portales, la mayoría de estos puzzles se basan en la lógica y la observación y, aunque al principio pueden ser bastante fáciles, en determinados puntos pueden llegar a complicarse.

La cuestión es que gracias a ciertos detalles sabemos que lo que hacemos parece tener un propósito, pero se hace muy difícil deducir cual es por nuestra cuenta o al menos a mí me lo pareció. Dicen que es mucho más fácil de entender jugando una vez más o incluso varias, pero lamentablemente es un lujo del que no dispongo así que tras completarlo tuve que buscar teorías fuera del juego (y una de ellas parecía muy razonable). Esto es algo que puede ser tanto positivo como negativo según el cristal con el que se mire, personalmente me pareció muy curioso.

En la parte técnica no es un juego que destaque visualmente, de hecho se nota a simple vista lo cuadriculado que es todo, aunque eso es parte de su encanto y estilo visual. Es incluso más importante la ambientación en su conjunto, que juega un papel importantísimo y cubre de un halo de misterio a todas y cada una de las localizaciones.

En esencia es una experiencia diferente, así que si te lanzas a ella procura mentalizarte en consecuencia.

review:

Biegając po nie istniejących lokacjach, które zaistnieć po prostu nie mogą, rozwiązując zagadki i uruchamiając tajemnicze machiny i urządzenia, człowiek zaczyna czuć się samotny, wyobcowany. Prócz tego zwiedzając świat gry, zaczynasz odczywać niepokój, fascynację, ale i obawy przed nieznanym, a każde kolejne pomieszczenie budzi w człowieku jeszcze większą ciekawość.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053170892', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1642544733}
review:
Хорошая, годная, глубокая игра с великолепной атмосферой и интересными головоломками.

У игры необычный язык — она разговаривает образами. В игре нет слов, нет букв, нет предложений — она использует символы, которые сама придумывает и наделяет смыслом. Вместе с минималистичным миром, примитивной графикой, необычными (и сильно отличающимися друг от друга) уровнями, это создаёт [b]уникальную игровую атмосферу.[/b] Напоминает хороший триллер

Другие плюсы и минусы, одной строкой:
[list]
[*] + Сложность головоломок — в самый раз. Достаточно сложные и не скучные.
[*] + Несколько уровней прохождения — есть основная сюжетная линия, и есть дополнительные задания.
[*] - Некоторые из доп. заданий чересчур и бессмысленно сложные ([spoiler]мелодия, звёздное небо[/spoiler]). Впрочем, можно их не проходить, спасибо хоть за это.
[*] - Зачем-то показывают в начале кучу букв и выбор языка, хотя в игре оно не нужно вообще.
[/list]

Из похожих игр отмечу [b]Antichamber[/b].

author: {'steamid': '76561197981124799', 'num_games_owned': 760, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1419237645}
review:
If you want a tl;dr of my review, it's basically just "If you like atmospheric exploration games, buy it".

My ACTUAL review is:


Kairo is an interesting game to say the least, I feel like there was an actual vision behind the developer and for the most part I think his vision came through, however the limited resources he had are fatally apparent. The film grain effect is just a static overlay that feels more distracting than stylistic, and while early areas of the game are very visually engaging and seem like they have a plan and purpose behind their layout, later areas just feel slapped together, using almost random geometric shapes and often just feel like the design had little to no thought at all. A fair amount of rooms have a purposefully grand scale, which is usually unnessicary considering you have to run back and forth in them to solve a puzzle. Of course this might be a purposeful choice to evoke a specific emotion from that level, I just felt pulled out of the experience. 

Now obviously I can't review a game without discussing how it plays and the mechanics, which also sadly fall flat. The game only gives you three commands, the ability to look, jump, and sprint. Nothing else. This is sometimes problematic to solving puzzles as you need to physically touch certain objects in order to "activate" them. While feeling awkward by itself, the player has a sort of floaty momentum to them that is accentuated by the fact you need to ram into objects to solve puzzles, which are also obtuse. There are different symbols used to differentiate switches, but the logic behind them often changes. Sometimes they're supposed to be literal, as in you have to activate the exact sime switch, but sometimes they're representations of numbers, which is confusing when the rest of the game had been using a literal interpretation. Luckily there is a hint system built in, which solves most of my gripes with the presentation not being very clear.

All in all, I feel like this game needs a lot of polish, but is still worth the price, especially if it's on sale.

review:
It's hard to decide whether to give this game a recommendation or not. I liked it, but this game is absolutely not for everyone. Its very artsy, which will be a turnoff for some. There are environmental type puzzles to solve -- and sometimes it is not at all clear what to do. The graphics don't get any better than the screenshots.  The game has a science fiction vibe, but it's more of an atmospheric game; not a lot of plot as such.

If you like exploring, and like a sci-fi type atomosphere, and don't mind a game that is artistic rather than traditionally fun, you might enjoy the game. I did. But that was a long list of qualifiers.
