author: {'steamid': '76561197970507922', 'num_games_owned': 1272, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1475039630}
review:
This has been quite an experience.  I wasn't expecting nearly so much out of a little game I picked up on a whim.  

According to walkthroughs, Kairo can be finished in just a half an hour if you know what you're doing, but I spent hours going through it.  The puzzles are indeed difficult at times, but what slowed me down the most was just stopping to gawk at the architecture.  It's just simple geometry and the textures are concrete, concrete and more concrete, yet somehow it's really amazing to look at.  The intense colored lighting and sheer emptiness of the massive, enigmatic spaces you get to wander through really hit with impact.  What really makes the environment pull you in though is the music.  Kairo has by far some of the best ambient background music I've ever heard.  Definitely play with good headphones if you've get 'em.  I'm officially starting my Steam category of games to go back and play again when the Oculus Rift comes out.  

It's really difficult to describe the unique feeling and atmosphere of Kairo's world, but here's the best I can do:  Does anyone remember the bizarre, abstract and often borderline incoherent art-house style computer animation that occasionally showed up on TV in the late 80s and early 90s?  It's like that, but with more thinking.

Gameplay consists mostly of puzzles and exploration, and both are quite rewarding.  A lot of the puzzle give that sort of Myst vibe at first glance (ie. "here are some random shapes and levers, have fun and see you in a couple hours")  but I found all of them to be fair and some were even a bit intuitive.  There were several that seemed totally abstract like they should have been frustrating to figure out, and I'm not sure if I just got lucky but the answers always clicked in my head after a bit of twiddling.  With so many puzzle types being redone to death in adventure games, it's good to see some totally new concepts that work.  My only real gripe with the puzzles are the fake ones.  Or at least apparently fake ones; I'm really not sure.  There were several rooms I faffed about in for ages before pulling up the in-game hint system to find out the room was just "here to play around with, mostly."  Mostly?  That's just lovely.  There were two places I recall getting this "hint", and they were the only two places I had to resort to using the hint system.  And then the hint is basically "this room is just here to waste your time. OR IS IT?"  Oh just piss off and tell me, is it or is it not a room with no purpose?  Again, just a minor gripe since I moved on when I got the aforementioned hint.

There were a few other minor nitpicks I had after finishing the game, but nothing major.  There were some pretty glaring geometry glitches like hairline cracks, overlapping brushwork, misaligned textures, missing faces, and gaps that looked like they weren't supposed to be there.  Higher resolution textures could have really improved the look of a few areas too in my opinion.  Finally, while I loved the music throughout the game itself, the ending theme just didn't fit.  It's not bad or anything, but it was jarringly different from everything heard up to that point which I think detracted a bit from the final sequence.  Just my opinion.  Again, all minor things not worth too much thought.

All in all, Kairo is a unique concept with some changelling puzzles and a fun bit of easter egg hunting, but it was also an unforgettable and immersive experience I won't soon forget.  It might be a bit obtuse at times for some, but if you're up for some creative problem solving in a fascinating setting, you can't do much better than this.  Hope there's more like it someday soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046059706', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 78, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1416076225}
review:
I don't think I've ever regretted spending $5.

I put a little under an hour and a half into this game before I made the decision to uninstall it.

Here is my reasoning.

I bought the game because some reviewers touted its similarity to Antichamber, a game that is very near and dear to my heart. The trailer for the game made it appear tantalizing and intriguing and, most of all, fun. 

Unfortunately, it didn't take me twenty minutes to regret this small purchase.

Kairo has, I've found, missed the mark on one of the most fundamental gaming concepts; not just in video games, but in the entire realm of playing a game for fun. I call this "carrot-and-stick". Other people call this other things. But essentially, in nearly every game you can think of, there's the metaphorical carrot, your objective, and the metaphorical stick, what keeps you from your objective. I could cite endless games, card games, board games, arcade games, games of make-believe played in the backyard of my friends' houses when we were five, and, yes, video games that keep/kept me latched onto the idea, entertained, and engaged in the gameplay.

One thing I quickly learned in Kairo is that there's not much of a carrot.

I'm going to take this discussion back to Antichamber, for those who have played it. I'd hypothesize that the two are compared often for the similar concept of working through puzzles in complete solitude. But in the Hub of Antichamber, you can see a door marked Exit, though you cannot reach it. In one of the first spawn points, you can see a door behind a barrier marked "The End". There's even the Black Ghost, dancing just out of your reach on certain puzzles. These are all suitable carrots. 

Kairo is designed in such a way that I have yet to see the carrot; there's not much more than an endless stick. And after almost an hour and a half of playing for no apparent reason, I tired of the game.

On one last note, for all the endless puzzles in Kairo, there are worlds you walk through that have no puzzles at all. The game has a hint feature, but if you are not so inclined to use it, it's incredibly difficult to discern a puzzle world from a world that's apparently there for your exhaustive visual pleasure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046257051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1418221024}
review:
Just a simple review for this game.


Kairo is a very good example of a game that is about puzzles, and about logical thinking.   This game does not beat around the bush in trying to add other things alongside the puzzles.   It is very much focused on puzzles that force a person to really think, or to be patient and wait til an answer appears.    The game can be frustrating because often times, you will come across a puzzle in which doing things in the wrong order, will lead to various issues, or puzzles where an answer is not possible to find until a later time.    I knw that it was annoying trying to figure out a few of the puzzles, and eventually used a hint guide to figure it out.



Graphics:   Very basic graphics, low res textures and stuff.   But like I said before, this game focuses on the puzzle aspect, not the pretty visuals.   Also, there are a nice color theme that can be seen so that is enjoyable.


Audio:   Very minimal muisc because it focuses on the puzzle, not the other things.

Game Mechnics:    The controls are very simple.  You move, you jump, you run.   Nothing more, nothing less.   You solve puzzles by moving in certain areas, moving objects to certain areas, and standing in certain places.


Story:   None that I could see, but thats possibly due to it focusing on the puzzles, rather than the story.



Overall, this is a very enjoyable  game that can be frustrating at times, due to the challenging aspect of it, but since there is a 100% guide on Steam, you will always have a way to make it through IF, key word is if, you need it.   If you are not that good with puzzles or logical thinking, then I would not recommend this because it will easily frustate you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969615096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1416630892}
review:
NaissanceE and Kairo share many stylistic and gameplay similarities.  Both prominently feature first-person exploration of vast, compelling brutalist architecture, monochromatic visuals (frequently, but not always greyscale), a profound sense of isolation, a deliberately ambiguous plot and practically-undefined protagonist, as well as an overarching dreamlike quality to the entire experience.
Where NaissanceE is primarily exploration and platforming with some occasional light puzzle-solving, Kairo is primarily exploration and puzzle-solving with some occasional light platforming.
Most of Kairo's puzzles are thoughtful and reveal their answers with observation and consideration.  There were certainly a few that were much less complicated than I made them out to be, some that felt like simple trial and error, but a couple were obscure enough that I eventually resorted to searching out the answer.  (Ugh, the wheels of shapes!)  Fortunately, you're usually given a few puzzles at a time to work on in whatever order you choose.  There are also some extra-credit puzzles that unlock the super-secret ending that lays bare the true meaning of the bizarre mechanisms you set in motion throughout the game.
While NaissanceE has a handful of video-game and pop-culture references, Kairo isn't afraid to give a nod and a wink to other games.
Steam says I've got about 5 hours into Kairo, and I feel like I was able to explore the gameworld pretty thorougly in that time.  Since I got it on sale for less than $1.50, I'd say that was easily worth the price of admission.

review:
Si te gustan los juegos de aventura de exploración como Aura, Myst o Lighthouse, recomiendo que jueguen Kairo.

Es muy minimalista en su presentación, mayormente con figuras geométricas y texturas con poco detalle, pero es acorde a la temática que intenta exponernos a lo largo del juego.

La mayoría de los puzzles son de una dificultad media, requiriendo recorrer una habitación por completo antes de proceder a resolverlo. En algunos casos se requieren volver a zonas anteriores para poder encontrar las soluciones, pero de ninguna manera esto se vuelve tedioso. 

La música crea un ambiente que va junto con la presentación, sonidos de electrónico profundos y ominosos pero llenos de emisión.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041271552', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1417869564}
review: Honestly this game had potential, but it really feels like the developer said "let's try making something deep because why not."  I'd recommend it, except there are only a few actual puzzles.  Most of the time you walk back and forth and stare at objects in the game until something happens, or run through trial and error.  There were two areas that looked like really creative and challenging puzzles which was great, and I was stumped for a while and had to check the in game hints, only to be told the rooms didn't do anything and you should move on to the next one.  But wait, there's a secret ending gotten by collecting 18 glyphs throughout the game!  Maybe there is something more to this, maybe a better ending than floating into the sky with no resolution! Nope, don't waste your time, it's just a troll room.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006077632', 'num_games_owned': 295, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1417582685}
review:
Kairo is worth your time and money, but only because it requires minute amounts of both. I recommend it in all its lukewarm glory.

It's a puzzle-game with platforming elements - unlike its contemporaries Kairo gives you a full range of movement that helps avoid the monotony of more "walking simulator"-esque games, though it rarely expects you to actually platform. There's something to be said for bunnyhopping your way through the environment, and there's even some collectables that take advantage of the movement system. 

Kairo ran well enough, though I did have some minor troubles getting stuck on the geometry and consistently had clipping issues with the camera edges while running it at a 1920x1080 resolution, which I don't particularly hold against the game. 

It bills itself as an exploration game, but the progression is still largely straightforward - you travel from hub to hub solving puzzles in siderooms accessible via portals. Your exploration is largely limited to the next area the game wants you to go. I didn't think this was a negative aspect in the slightest, as I've personally no interest in wandering around some landscape with no idea where to go, but unless you figure exploration to mean "looking at the game as you progress through it" then it does stand out.

The puzzles are simple and easy to figure out, rarely requiring more than a few minutes of experimentation to figure out each ones internal logic structure (outside of one frustratingly weird gear puzzle that I'm still not sure how I managed to solve). You're never outright told what to do, but given your simple moveset and means of interaction - mostly pushing blocks or activating buttons - it's not hard to figure out, though there's a hint system anyway. If you've ever played a puzzle game before, you'll just be going through the motions.

Throughout the game, there's a consistent rate of highly unique rooms to traverse as you solve the puzzles presented. These rooms are sadly marred by their low budget - the massive structures are simplistic, and empty, mostly relying on the novelty of the colour schemes and their sheer vastness to hold your attention. Given the short amount of time you spend in each area, it works, though if/when you backtrack to pick up collectables you've missed and solve optional puzzles you'll the novelty wears off. 

Story is there, but it's completely ambiguous, mostly symbolic and only really lends itself to the game through some notable imagery. It's not really worth "figuring out", I didn't bother with it and I doubt it's meant to be a part of the "experience", but the flavour it lends to the puzzles is appreciated nonetheless.

The advantages of Kairo lie in how casual a game it is. It's a game to wind down with, cool off and a have a cup of joe while adjusting to the game's own wavelength. It was obviously a labour of love, but there's not much more to the game than that. There's nothing wrong with that. There's just nothing memorable about it either.

review:
Kairo is really one of a kind game. It takes a little time to absorb you into its world, but once it does it never lets you leave it. It's an adventure/puzzle game which is kind of easy to finish but extremely hard to master. 

There is so much hidden stuff in this game that you'll want to play it again and again. Yet, none of its puzzles is obvious or easy to be seen. 

Kairo's alien world is extrordinary unique and beautiful on its own and feels like it came out from 2001's monolith.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054848644', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1592120684}
review:
Kairo isn't a game for everybody.  In fact, I wouldn't even say it was a game for most people.  It's the type of game that takes a lot of patience to enjoy.  You've got to really put yourself into the game, imagine that you're really in this place, seeing these things.  The atmosphere and mystery are everything, and if that isn't your bag then you won't find enough to enjoy here when it comes to pure gameplay.

There are indeed puzzles to be solved, but most of them are quite simple.  There are no controls beyond moving around and jumping, and there's no text or story to speak of beyond what you're observing of your environment.  As is to be expected with these types of games, a lot of it is open for interpretation, including the ending.  The graphics are solid, but quite simple and low-budget; most of the architecture is made up of blocks and flat planes.

If any of those things are deal-breakers, then don't even bother.  But if you're into the pure sense of discovery that games can offer then I can't possibly recommend it enough.  The term gets tossed around a lot, but it truly is more of an experience than a game.  You've got to like abstraction, simplicity, and rich atmosphere (thanks in large part to the excellent sound design).  You've got to be the type of person who gets a thrill from the simple act of booting up a game and not knowing exactly what to expect--of heading through a door and not having the foggiest idea of what you'll see.

There isn't much more to say about the game.  If it's not your cup of tea, nothing else here will be relevant to you.  If it is, then there's no need for me to explain what was great about it with more detail, because it's already obvious that you should play it.  I mean hey, it's five bucks, and as I type this it's on sale for one whole dollar.  Even if the story only lasts a few hours, that's a stupidly good deal for such an experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075868257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1417137933}
review:
Very strange, very mysterious, but also incredibly beatiful.

There is no introduction, no talking, nobody to hold your hand.
There are no tools and no weapons.
There is nothing but your natural human ability to walk, jump, push things and think.
And yet you almost always know what to do.
The world is silently guiding you through its majesty and testing your lateral thinking as you go.

The charm of this game comes from the simplicity of the controls, the great design of the environment and the sheer amount of mystery flowing through every room.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971316390', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1417284707}
review:
When I saw the screenshots and such for Kairo I presumed that Kairo may not be the most visually appealing game but sometimes, while such games may not always put their best screenshots on display, they do usually have some redeeming charm. The various positive reviews and an endorsement from RPS also seemed to indicate that this was a diamond in the rough. However as it turned out, it is actually a mouldy chunk of food in the dust. How on earth this game achieved anywhere near a positive status on Steam I have no idea, but I suspect foul play. Allow me to explain why you need to avoid Kairo like the plague.

Plain textures can sometimes be compensated for by some impressively detailed architecture or environments which hold intrigue. Kairo simply does not have any of that. The environments look like they were made by someone experimenting with mapping and decided to package everything together to make it seem like a game. The designer has some strange idea that throwing tons of fog into every section of the game is a substitute for creating atmospheric lighting or using the environment itself to influence the players' state of mind. As such every part of the game I saw felt lifeless, unfinished and bland. I have honestly seen maps from the original Quake with more atmosphere, style and imagination.

The 'puzzles' are so dull that I literally gave up after playing the game for half an hour. They consist of running into invisible triggers or standing on trigger brushes to cause something to happen. One of the things the designer forgot to actually do is clearly indicate when a puzzle is solved and what the point of solving it was. In one area I found 4 platforms which turned on a bunch of particle effects on a rotating central disc. Visually quite interesting and clearly the puzzle was solved because all of the triggers stopped working, but it did not appear to have any effect upon the game. The lack of direction here is astounding as the designer chooses to leave you completely in the dark as to what you should be doing and gives no context or sense of progress to what you manage to figure out on your own. Someone needs to sit this person down with games like Myst, the Longest Journey, Master Reboot or even The Room so they can understand the difference between an enjoyable mystery and aimless activity.

Kairo is unpleasant to look at, boring to explore, devoid of any sense of achievement or purpose and ultimately one of the worst games I have had the misfortune to mistake for a worthwhile investment of money or time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043516018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1417152165}
review:
As an abstract puzzle game, Kairo is great.  The gameplay is simple yet challenging, and the built-in hint system is helpful enough to point you in the right direction when you're stuck without outright spoiling the puzzle.  However, I think the abstract design makes the story hard to follow (and leaves the player to guess); after finishing the game, I wasn't really sure what it was all about.  Still, that doesn't detract from the gameplay.  If you enjoy puzzle games and want something a little different, I would definitely recommend Kairo.

Pros:
- Otherworldly/alien environment.
- Engaging, abstract, and unique puzzles.
- Good music, which helps set a somewhat ominous and somber tone.

Cons:
- The story was a little *too* abstract.
- Keyboard controls are not remappable, or even listed in full.  For example, the "R" key resets you to the room entrance, but I found that completely by accident.
- There is no way to see your progress on collecting the hidden glyphs, except by collecting more of the glyphs.  I would like to have seen my current progress when the game is paused (such as how the map is displayed).

author: {'steamid': '76561197985363409', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1416687708}
review:
Поиграли немного. Графика для такого рода проектов конечно не нужна какая-то сильно навороченая, однако здесь она уж слишком угловатая, сглаживания практически нет, ощущение будто вернулся в 2003-ий. В трейлере музыка шикарная, в игре же попроще, она там не так сильно цепляет. Ещё управление в игре со странностями. Предполагаю, что автор делал упор на управление через Oculus Rift, а о более популярной клаво-мыши почти не думал. Но там не сказать, что всё прям так печально. Привыкнуть можно, хотя, то, что можно двигаться лишь вперёд-назад (влево-вправо нельзя) создаёт определённый дискомфорт.

В целом эта игра - психодел (или наркоманский бред? Называйте как удобнее). Ничего непонятно, ничего не ясно, всё очень странное и причудливое. Атмосфера немного есть и более-менее адекватное звуковое сопровождение тоже. Игра не из тех, которые затягивают и не отпускают, однако пребывать в ней, лично мне, интересно. Рад покупке и буду ждать новинок от автора.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030606382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 385, 'last_played': 1675325506}
review: This is a "boring" game, and I liked it. It is essentially a puzzle/exploration game where you have the most minimalistic controls. The puzzles are challenging, but more than that this game is more of an "experience" than a challenge. The ominous and almost spiritual music gives this game a kind of mesmerizing, depressing, uplifting, and unsettling feeling. A very surreal game to be sure, and one that I keep thinking about from time to time. Since the game is running so cheap as of the writing of this review I encourage anyone who says to themselves now and then "I wanna play a game where I don't kill something", just go ahead and give this a shot, even for an hour. Monument Valley meets Yume Nikki, this is one boring game I recommend, yes yes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111811696', 'num_games_owned': 1567, 'num_reviews': 179, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1412021004}
review: Очень рекомендую эту игру любителям Myst-подобного жанра. К тому же на момент написания обзора она на распродаже и бывает там довольно часто. Судя по всему, игра делалась для Oculus Rift или с заделом под него, отсюда минималистичная графика и управление. Собственно, всё управление состоит из одного лишь перемещения и вращения головой - нет даже кнопки действия. Сюжет из разряда тех, которые игрок должен домыслить сам из аллегорических обрывков, но атмосфера выстроена мощно, а также в отличие от многих подобных игр - всё кончается хорошо. Игра не очень длинная, но с другой стороны - за такую цену (100 рублей обычно и 24 рубля на распродажах) я бы ожидала игры длиной всего в час. Почти не случалось застревать и подсматривать в прохождения при том, что загадки всё же весьма сложные, требуя внимания и аналитических способностей.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079017859', 'num_games_owned': 1172, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1437996002}
review:
I have enjoyed every moment with this game. I haven't quite finished it yet, but I'm confident in recommending it. To be clear, if you're looking for a fast-paced game with all the latest bells and whistles, this is not the one for you. The graphics and music are quite simple, and gameplay is as slow-paced as you'd like it to be. However, I disagree with those who call this a "walking simulator." It is very much a game. There are puzzles to solve as well as a story to uncover.

The puzzles are very well-designed. There is no dialogue and no text, yet somehow it's always clear what you're expected to do. Some of the puzzles are quite simple, while others are much more complex, but I haven't found a single one I couldn't solve with a little patience and logical thought. It's not too easy, but it's not too difficult, either. There was only one puzzle I needed hints for - and those hints are provided in the game menu. There are three hints for each puzzle, starting out vague and growing more specific, so you can get exactly the amount of help you need if you ever get stuck.

The story is revealed entirely through gameplay. When I first started playing, I didn't expect there to be much of a story. I was satisfied with the beautiful abandoned abstract architecture and puzzles. The first time I uncovered an unexpected plot twist, my heart skipped a beat, and every one I've found after that has led to even more amazed moments. I'm very picky about storytelling, and this is one game that does it perfectly without ever resorting to dialogue or verbal exposition.

Overall, it's a well-crafted game. Everything in it functions well and it all comes together to form a beautiful whole. It's not for everyone, but I think most people will find it enjoyable and well worth buying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037005915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1415700915}
review:
Kairo is one of thise gems amongst the steam garbage I seem to keep running into. After playing antichamber, I absoultely had to play Kairo.

Kairo is a game in which you appear to be embarking into the depths of an ancient egypt-like machine that either uses magic or technology too far beyond you to understand. Either way, Kairo is one of those games that doesn't explain anything to you (though you have the option of hints, which don't help much) so it requires a lot of problem solving and logistics on your part. 
Most of the puzzles are self-explanitory, and the ones that aren't normally are supplied with a stone or wall you have to look at. Once you find those, you then proceed to facepalm realizing how simple the complex-looking puzzle really is.  Even so, the puzzles really are challanging, to the point where I actually had to look up a walkthrough for one of them because it didn't seem to be based on any rhyme or reason (and that I couldn't find any stones or walls to explain it) I'm sure you'll identify the one I'm talking about if you play this game.
The story is widely open to interpretation though. There were points in the story that sent a legit chill down my spine. Other moments had me scratching my head wondering what just happened. In order to understand it, you're required to fill in a lot of blanks.
Overall, despite it's cheap graphics and oddly slippery controls, Kairo is a game that you'll enjoy figuring out for yourself, and then be proud to finish.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990036156', 'num_games_owned': 538, 'num_reviews': 501, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1415960435}
review:
As someone who used to work with mapping for garry's mod I can clearly see that the mapping in this game is terrible. Another problem is that the controls are inexplicably sluggish and you feel as if you're on ice skates while you walk. I thought it might be because of my computer but the framerate is very good and there is no mouse lag so the problem has to be related to the game. 
Now, I understand that this game is inspired by yume nikki, but that is no excuse to make the puzzles so obscure without a hint on how to solve them. yume nikki itself was not a finished game you know. All in all, I want to get immersed into the game but the lack of polish and sluggish controls make it impossible to do so.

Until this game is properly polished I can't recommend it.

If the dev wants help with mapping, I would be willing to help if I can, for a small fee of course.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011478921', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1414841251}
review:
Beware: don't enter this world or its mysteries will haunt you. 

You're dropped alone in a wonderful world, where nothing seems to live or work. Your duty here is to bring this world back to life by solving puzzles, discovering new areas, and making some machines work properly.

Some places are really huge (the gardens for example can make you wander here for hours), and colors, geometric shapes and music are really immersive.

You'll need a lot of patience, observations and concentration to move ahead. Visual and audio clues indicate when you completed a puzzle. It's up to you then to know its purpose....

There's two endings to this game. The normal one can be completed *quite* easily once you begin to understand how the game works, and you only need three achievements to finish the game that way.

But the secret ending requires you to grab *all* the achievements - and some are really very, very tricky to get. It took me 10h of gameplay to complete the game.

Overall, and for the price of it, Kairo is a good game to buy, once you accept to spend a lot of time wondering what you're doing here and how to move on...

review:

각 방에 위치한 퍼즐을 풀고, 다음 방으로 넘어가 해당 건물의 필요한 큰 장치를 작동시키는 방식. 

게임 자체는 그냥 무난한 1인칭 시점 어드벤처 게임이다. 큰 줄거리보단 퍼즐을 푸는 것이 위주가 되는 게임으로, 게임은 그다지 어려운 편이 아니고, 플레이타임도 조금 짧은 편이다. 여러모로 정말 무난한 게임이라 사실 할 말이 별로 없는 게임이다.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024993029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 10382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9970, 'last_played': 1614001579}
review:
There are many, many able reviews of this game so I'll just add some short remarks. 

I find Kairo haunting and beautiful. Every time I reach the final goal, and the credits roll, and the music plays I think of creator Richard Perrin and his father — and the loss of my own — but it’s hopeful and optimistic. Still the entire experience exhibits a sense of loss and recapitulates same. For me the game is an expression that I enjoy somewhat plaintively in its context. 

I play it often enough at my three-year-old's insistent request. He has none of this context! But he still wants to come back again and again. He finds it mesmerizing as he instructs me where to go and what to inspect next — the first time, his eyes wide in amazement. I think at his age he's captivated by the geometry and the color (children's entertainment is generally far from this). “Go see where the blocks are painted!”, “Go to the black moon!”, “Go in the elevator!”, “Show me the dinosaur!”, “Fly into the sky!” He’s still surprised when the environment springs to life. I’m surprised to see we’ve wandered around Kairo for over 150 hours in the last year or so. 

In short, a moving experience for a parent, and a curious adventure for a child. Play it together. Appreciate the time you have together.

So really, this is a thank you note. Thank you, Richard Perrin and the rest that made Kairo possible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081703567', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1688400931}
review:
С детства меня завораживала монументальная архитектура.Величественные башни и неприступные стены всем своим видом кричат о том, что они не могут быть творениями рук человека, они есть существа из плоти и крови.Верите ли вы в то, что у таких замков есть своя душа, характер?Разработчики Kairo заставят вас поверить.

Сады наполняются скульптурными обитателями, старинные механизмы приходят в движение и космические просторы разворачиваются прямо за следующей дверью.Все это результат решенных вами задач.Таинственный город тяжело и шумно дышит, наполняя свои узкие улочки солнечным светом...Однако солнце ли это?

Ищите ли вы выхода, спасения?Пытаетесь ли вы помочь?Есть ли вам дело до серого и строгого камня города Каиро, изрядно потрепанного войной?

Найдете ли вывсе спрятанные печати, вернете ли к жизни тронные залы, осветите ли старые храмы, спасете ли сады?Заведите старые часы и раскройте самые страшные тайны самобытного места, которого нет ни на одной карте мира.Сделайте это...

И проснитесь.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982572424', 'num_games_owned': 1384, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1412592270}
review:
I'm not a huge fan of Kairo. It's a puzzle game, but you never get those satisfying "ah-ha!"moments from a puzzle successfully solved. The puzzles are often frustrating, esoteric and are rarely particularly logical. There's thankfully a built-in hint system, but that doesn't really make it any more satisfying. You end up with a more "Oh, that's what they wanted me to do? Huh, okay." than anything. The (very) minimal graphics, sound and story don't do much to entice you to slog through the rest of the game.

If you want a surreal, minimalist walking simulator, [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/265690/]NaissencE[/url] is a much better game. If you want surreal first-person puzzling in a clean white-washed environment, go for [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/219890/]Antichamber[/url] or even something like [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/239430/]QUBE[/url]. 

I enjoy surreal/minimalist walking simulators and first-person puzzlers, but this game just doesn't do it for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996899722', 'num_games_owned': 1436, 'num_reviews': 265, 'playtime_forever': 698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1412551353}
review:
Well, that was probably the most engrossed I've been in a game for a while.  It takes me right back to "Driller" or its sequel "Far Side" which, used "Freescape", an early 3D, to evoke alien and unusual environments.   Unlike those two early games, Kairo gives no backstory, and lets you attempt to figure it out for yourself. I love it...

The whole game is extremely minimalist in its level design, but extremely evocative of space and alienness.  The aesthetics are a mix of old and new:  blocky, simplistic but with texture mapping, reflections, fog, flames and more.  The overly simplistic design may deter some who would dismiss the game as dated, but anything more complex would start to get in the way of the narrative.

It may not have been the designer's "point", but the simplicity of the environment allows you to completely ignore it, and focus more on playing the game.  And playing may not be the best definition either:  experience, discover, enjoy are also great definitions for this.

The beginning makes it look like you'll be exploring ancient egyptian ruins (albeit in a dreamy world of whiteness), before  abruptly turning grey and industrial-feeling.  The game continues to take turns and each area feels and plays a lot different.

The only time that the simplicity works against the game is when an area is more complex than it looks. After traversing a dozen empty corridors, and passing stray cubes, you may not realise that another grey unmarked stray cube is, in fact, a trigger for some action, and be left puzzling for a while.  Such "difficulty through obscurity" is a hard one to balance right, to be honest, so I'll let it off, mostly.

I think the thing I enjoy most about Kairo is that it really plays with our preconceptions of what a 3d puzzle game is.  They jokingly call one of their achievements "Locked Door Puzzle" as a nod to other more mainstream games.

I really enjoyed playing Kairo, and then with the help of a cheat to find all the secrets.. A great minimal game.  If you do decide to play it, don't try and speed-run it.  although it looks shallow and simplistic, there are a lot of hidden (or just obscure) tidbits for the explorer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026192485', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 475, 'last_played': 1436421558}
review:
The world of [i]Kairo[/i] may be unsettling for some. I found a sort of, unclear affection to it. Not quite a "game" in the traditional sense, not quite an art experiment. [i]Kairo[/i] falls deep within harmony of those two descriptions, offering a very reflective, interactive experience that very rarely seen in this age. Despite the frequent use of a single color palette per area, each environment is unique and will stay in your mind hours after leaving them. The simple yet gratifying gameplay will leave a lasting impression even after you finish this interactive poem.

But for me personally, the pure yet intricate sound design and tranquil soundtrack still peer into my thoughts daily. This piece of art will always stand out for me as one of the most surreal and hypnagogic experiences I encountered in any medium. I cannot recommend [i]Kairo[/i] enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992169556', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1412050838}
review: Enigmatic and atmospheric. I really found myself enjoying this game. What Kairo lacks in graphical fidelity it makes up in sound design. The soundtrack meshes with the stark and rigidly geometric envirnment to convey a sense of place and meaning. The "story" of the game is very much open to interpretation but I thought it was poignant and dramatic. Pushing through the games puzzles - which, admittedly, at times were a little needlessly opaque - nevertheless gave me a real sense of purpose. It's wonderful that a game like this can be created through crowdfunding, and deliver such a hefty emotional punch despite such a small budget.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061647423', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 1197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1676631064}
review:
Very fun atmospheric puzzle game, in the same vein as Myst.  Puzzles are abstract and often require a flash of insight, but never feel nonsensical.  Environments are monochromatic and bleak, but in a way that comes off as ominous instead of bland.  The backstory is told in only a few scattered pieces of scenery, and left to interpretation.

The main game can be reasonably completed without ever looking at a guide, but you'll have to in order to 100% (one of the puzzles gives each player only one part of the solution and is intended to be shared on the internet to assemble the full solution).

author: {'steamid': '76561198057575588', 'num_games_owned': 218, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 571, 'last_played': 1550386822}
review:
Kairo is a game about exploration and puzzle-solving, but it is also much more than that. Kairo is something that demands your full attention. It is a game that you play in the dark, all alone. You won't be killing zombies or assassinating kings in Kairo, but you will be exploring a strange, impossible world filled with perplexing architecture.

The ambiance is unsettling, and even threatening at times. The music (written by Wounds) is alienating and absolutely beautiful. The graphics are simple, but this simplicity fits in perfectly in making you feel that you are truly in a foreign world; a place you do not understand. For those of us with low end computers, you'll find this to be a pleasantly smooth running game.

At its core Kairo is a puzzle game. Some puzzles are easy and won't strain you too badly, but others are so hard it's almost unrealistic to think any player could solve them on their own (looking at you, Clock Room). Each puzzle is intuitive though, and they always make sense after you solve them (even you, Clock Room).
Luckily if you get hopelessly stuck, each puzzle has three hints and the solution to help you along. 

The story is what really ties the elements of Kairo together. From the start you'll have many questions: Where am I? Why am I here? WHO am I? Will these questions be answered? Well, that depends on you. There is little to no dialogue in Kairo. The story is expressed entirely through the environment and the things that you see. If you want to understand this place you're in, then you must actively think about the actions you take, and how they're affecting the world around you. There are answers to your questions, but Kairo leaves it entirely up to you to find them. If you take the time to uncover the mystery, you'll be glad that you did.

Kairo is a game that not everyone will love. But for those who do, it is a masterpiece. It is the kind of game that sticks with you long after you finish it. I wholeheartedly recommend Kairo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979146340', 'num_games_owned': 4768, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1403285624}

author: {'steamid': '76561198012786076', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1411718653}
review:
This is more of an "ehhh..." than a strict Thumbs Down- Kairo offers a sort of first person linked-chamber exploration game with simple puzzles unlocking further exploration. Lacking mechanical depth or logical difficulty (there's a lot of obvious "stand here, then touch there" stuff, though perhaps more lurking beneath the surface beyond my grasp), the puzzles generally feel like a bit of vestigial interactivty left there to regulate progression through the game's strengths of envrionment and atmosphere. Each area proffers a unique bit of architecture, either a room or  monument suspended in the void; In tandem with the monochromatic color scheme and sound design, the effect is rather evocative, but of nothing more particular than the tingly excitement of meandering through an abandoned alien kinetic sculpture garden.

Kairo exhausted my patience due to the tedium of its puzzling elements, but it could be worth exploring if you dont mind and find the screenshots compelling (if you do mind, I suggest Kairo's obverse, Antichamber- its world isn't exactly poetic, but does have a practical charm in service of the brain-bending environmental puzzling Kairo lacks.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197979487649', 'num_games_owned': 1296, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1546017071}
review:
The approach to wether to buy this game is fairly simple: Look at the screenshots. State how they breathe with atmosphere and probably form something like a desolate first person puzzle exploration game filled with mysteries. Play the video and confirm that assumption. 
Well, I was sold and Kairo didn't disappoint at all. It's not a long game but then again it's not an expensive game either. If you enjoy the kind of mystical immersement games like Myst or Antichamber convey you will enjoy Kairo as much as I do. You get dropped in the game world with not a single clue whatsoever on where you are, why you're there or what you should do. It's up to your creativity and will to explore to find every secret this place has got to offer. Great music, great graphics and logical puzzlesolving.
A mild spoiler but also a fair warning: [spoiler]There's just that one puzzle that's really annoying and obtuse compared to the rest of the game (almost at Fez-proportions) and you'll probably just have to google that one or try to solve it at random. So if you stumble upon a yellow chamber with clocks, don't despair. Things will become better afterwards.[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198153034035', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1451908678}

author: {'steamid': '76561197987722190', 'num_games_owned': 378, 'num_reviews': 185, 'playtime_forever': 332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1653662335}
review: Kairo est un petit jeu d'exploration et d'énigmes en vue à la première personne. Nettement moins déroutant qu'un Antichamber, il utilise des énigmes à base de logique et d'associations de symboles. Une série d'astuces livrées avec chaque niveau permettra également aux joueurs moins observateurs de trouver sans peine les solutions. Constitué de décors très abstraits, le monde de Kairo alterne les ambiances apaisantes et inquiétantes et se révèle agréable à parcourir. Cependant on regrette que les graphismes n'aient pas été plus travaillés : sous couvert de simplicité et d'abstraction, les environnements apparaissent souvents trop dépouillés et très pauvres en textures. Malgré ce léger reproche, ce jeu reste une expérience à tenter (à petit prix) pour les amateurs d'exploration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028212667', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1433065903}
review:
There are two ways to approach Kairo. The first is to view it as a meditative experience in an open world with many soothing  environments and lots of exploration. The second view is to see it as a string of puzzles that need to be solved to complete and beat the game.

You'll enjoy it either way you view it. If you decide to explore, you will see many different areas, and come to love the fact that you can hide away in the world of Kairo and relax after a long day. Walk around in the Park, look at the alien structures, and relax to the calm sounds of water rushing, or birds chirping.


And if you take it as a string of puzzles, you will be challenged with a system with no interaction button, with clues to guide you when you are lost. You will push things, pull things, and eventually get the machines that govern the world of Kairo running.

And be treated to a delightful and uplifting ending.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081002780', 'num_games_owned': 152, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1570448057}
review:
Clairement suffoquant. 
Le jeu propose une suite de puzzle, plus qu'une prétendu exploration, avec une musique d'ambiance digne de celui fait par votre micro-onde. Le vrai problème de ce jeu, c'est qu'aucune explication n'est donner ! Vous serez jeter dans la fosse au puzzle/exploration. Dans un univers qui rappelle celui d'un temple alien où le non-sens et l'illogisme domine. Personne ne vous dira pourquoi vous-êtes ici ou bien là. L'ambiance est stressante, suffoquante et angoissant. Alors qu'il s'agit d'un jeu de puzzle !
Le temps de jeu est honnête, le jeu est long. Même si vous comprenez en 2minutes les puzzles, le jeu reste long...Les niveaux et décors sont caractériser par une couleur dominante bien affirmé, voir trop. 
Niveau performance, le jeu n'est en lui-même pas trop gourmand. La prise en main est rapide. Le jeu est comptable avec les logiciels et lunettes de réalité-virtuel. 
On regrettera surtout le manque d'explication et la bande-son, tous simplement attroce. Pour un puzzle tranquille, je pense qu'un bon Portal suffit. Si je devais lui donner une note, ce serait un 8/20...

review:
I loved the fact that you don't have an action button it's just good old fashion pushing or jumping on. It's a small detail, but still, it's not usual and I think it brings something unique to this game.

Also the visuals, I loved them, but I also loved the images in the steam store page, here's a tip: the visuals are right there, you don't get a LOT more than that, it's all squares and different colors, if you don't like the images you might not like the visuals in the game.

Highly recommended if you are into Adventure genre. This is for Myst what "Guernica" is for "Mona Lisa"

NOTE: THIS ISN'T A WALKING SIM, this is an adventure game (a very original one btw) i say that based on the fact that it ACTUALLY HAS PUZZLES IN IT.
This, like most of the adventures out there, you don't get 3 different shotguns and 5 different assault rifles, no, this is a kind of game you play with your brain instead of your mouse.

review:

review: I think I've finally achieved Nirvana...either that or my mind has just been completely blown. Kairo is jaw dropping immense game of abstract exploration. It's easy to just stop and gaze upon the minimalistic visuals and animations because they are so moving and powerful. As you solve puzzles the world around you changes to reveal things that are impossible to describe in words. The sounds and music are ominous and dramatic, yet they do not frighten and somehow even offer comfort. The puzzles provide a perfect equilibrium of not being overly complicated without solving themselves. Kairo is truly a work of art on so many levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027737162', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1410582949}
review:
This game didn't take too long to finish, but somehow I managed to wait for months in between sessions and forget what was going on.  So I would NOT do that, were I to live life a second time.

This game has a few REALLY killer puzzles, and I am a snob about puzzles, so that is saying something.  I think the number one thing that made this game work is it's utter abstractness.  Many of the best puzzles were fairly simple tasks, but understanding how the mechanisms worked was a challending and engaging task, simply because of the lack of context.

One of the most interesting and unique things about this game is the cool control scheme in which the position where you are standing affects the state of the world.  This is used in a variety of ways, and it somehow manages to make very simple puzzles a lot more engaging.

On the down side, this game was definitely lacking in polish.  Movement was slightly glitchy - especially going up stairs and jumping off walls (which I'm not sure you were supposed to be able to do at all).  There were often cheap looking cracks between blocks that didn't quite touch.  Some icons looked like poorly clipped .pngs.  Just a little rough around the edges.

Also the "story" kept getting devastatingly interesting, and then leaving you hanging.  Ending was super weird (secret ending was even weirder.  But no, I didn't get it, I watched it on youtube :P)

author: {'steamid': '76561198134009318', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 231, 'last_played': 1410289510}
review: Что я могу сказать после прохождения этой игры? Какая-то она мрачная. Играл в неё на работе, подошёл коллега и спросил: "Это чё СЛЭНДЕР??" Я конечно прошёл её всю, но не сказать что получил удовольствие. Некоторые головоломки просто нелогичные, а получение ачивок с поиском всех рун и т.п. вовсе превращается в рутину и не обходится без подглядывания в прохождение. И это при том, что я люблю головоломки. Но к примеру Antichamber доставила мне гораздо больше. В целом идея неплохая. Бродилка непонятно где будучи непонятно кем. Этим она мне очень напомнила игру Тургор. Но здесь сюжета нет. Вы просто ходите в каком то мире состоящем из предметов и фигур. Разгадыванием головоломок приводите что-либо в действие при этом поэтапно оживляя всё вокруг. Каких-либо ещё живых персонажей в игре нет. Есть непонятные голоса, картинки и вставки, так сказать, из нашего мира. author: {'steamid': '76561198088033314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1410448342}
review:
[h1][b]Abstract Theory[/b][/h1]

[h1][b]Full Review at [url=http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=121]GameDragons.Net[/url][/b][/h1]

[b]Presentation[/b]
Kairo is a game of exploration and mystery, putting a whole world of differently coloured rooms ahead of you, each with its own intrigues and puzzles; the design of those rooms is simplistic, each following a precise theme and colour, without adding too much detail on the ambient, but that's part of what makes Kairo's mystery so great, leaving you with questions about a certain object that you encountered and what useful information that object might have for you. 

While some of those questions will be answered by the end of the game, most of them won't, leaving you more confused than you were when you first started the game, and as great as that is from the mysterious perspective of the game, it somehow feels disappointing at the same time, as you probably were expecting at least some of the bigger mysteries to be answered in a way or another, but on the bright side that leaves a lot of room for interpretation, allowing each one of us to have our own verdict on what Kairo wanted to tell us. 

The greatest part about this game however, is the way it manages to shape its universe around you, constantly surprising you with what lies ahead in the next room and leaving you in doubt on how you should react to what you see before your eyes, but at the same time giving you complete freedom to move around and see what you can discover to help you solve that room's puzzle and move forward just to have the same thing happen to you all over again. In the end, judging by the amount of hours you've spent in Kairo it won't add up to more than a few hours, but really digging into the experience and enjoying the mysteries it has to tell, it will seem a lot longer while you're inside and exploring at will, even though for most times, the more you explore, the more unanswered questions you'll have at the end.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Every once in a while, you run into those type of games that offer a unique and thrilling experience without focusing too much on the gameplay, but rather on the experience you have by simply being a part of that game and uncovering its mysteries; Kairo is exactly that type of game, delivering a simplistic mechanic of navigating through its universe and clever ways to solve its puzzles by using nothing else besides the basic movements and the environment around you.

 This game is all about exploration and uncovering the numerous mysteries that lie ahead, using the things you've seen before and the things you see in that very moment to help you solve different puzzles that stand in the way of your progression, something that works wonderful in Kairo, following a logical way of seeing things and even though the solution might not be that obvious at first, exploring the environment around you will eventually give you the information you need. 

Most areas follow the same pattern, requiring you to enter all the side rooms, observe what you can do in there and get things moving again until each and every one of the required steps has been completed and the core of that area is up and running, allowing you to move forward on to the next one. By putting some of the information you need to unlock various secrets in the rooms ahead of you, Kairo requires you to return to previously visited areas without feeling repetitive or boring, as there will always be something new to uncover that you might have missed on your first visit, and with the information from the rooms ahead of you in mind, you will for most of the times, know what you're looking for already. Even with the usage of the movements keys only, some of the mechanics such as pushing objects around feel like they haven't reached their full potential, as such simple things could've expanded the way in which puzzles are treated in various ways, making the game longer and adding that extra gameplay portion that's missing.

[b]Graphics[/b]
It's hard not to appreciate the unique art style of Kairo and the wonderful and sometimes spooky environments it delivers, but even in all the simplicity of shapes and precise objects you can clearly see the outdated engine on which the game was built. There are an almost infinite number of ways in which this game could have been improved by using the latest game engines, especially in the lighting area, where the latest engines would've made a huge difference on how that room is viewed and the exact experience the game wanted to deliver.

[b]Audio[/b]
There's always a great tune playing in the background to add to the feel of a certain room, sometimes adding to the feeling of joy and liberty, while other times cornering you in a small room with little light and a spooky theme to add to the mystery effect. The sound effects as low quality as they are do their job well enough, but there was room for a little more variety and a few more touches here and there to make you hear the world moving around you when it does visually happen on the screen.

[b]Extras[/b]
It takes around four hours to complete Kairo, add an extra hour or two if you're looking to get the most out of it and collect all the glyphs, monoliths and solve all the secret puzzles, but also note that this is a game priced at 3.99€, so for that amount of money, it does more than enough to please. With the amount of mystery and out of place objects you can find in this game there was room for a lot more, as some of the areas are not used to their fullest and areas that seem to have some sort of puzzle attached to them at first, are just there to give the impression of having more to see.

[b]Verdict[/b]
Kairo isn't much of a game, but it's one great experience, especially if you're into the abstract puzzle genre, as its unique design and way of saying things make it a must play for any enthusiast of the genre. As in most cases, there was room for more in some areas and modern graphics would've made a huge difference in the way the game unveils to you, but considering the fact that this is an indie game, it did a great job delivering a worthy experience from a low budget production.

[u]Rating: 7.4[/u]

author: {'steamid': '76561198025454883', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1448626351}
review:
I am alone.

As with most places in this desolate world I find myself in, the room is almost entirely monochromatic. Green, but not a green like living plants, but a green like something sickly and dying. Rotten. Slimy. It is a long corridor, and unlike the other places I have visited, it is somewhat claustrophobic. Large caskets line the sides of the corridor, and as I walk slowly along, looking for something I am expected to do, I stop and investigate one.

There is a monitor on each casket. Some are broken, some flicker with static, but this one shows an image, though of what, I cannot see. I stand there for awhile, longer maybe than I should, waiting for something to appear on that monitor, but if the image changes, it is perhaps only my imagination. Or my reflection.

Kairo is a strange, ominous world. There are great monoliths to explore, machines that reach up to the heavens, and cramped corridors to wander through. Some rooms have puzzles, some are just desolate walkways, hanging out over an abyss.

I feel I am in purgatory. The very first action this game asks you to take is a leap of faith. This is what the game expects of you- perhaps not to understand, but to experience.

Visually, this game is a treat of abstract, bold art. Simple, yes, but the limited pallette serves to build the abandoned atmosphere of the game, and Kairo is more than capable of providing small details mixed in amongst the enormous structures. The appearance of the game almost looks somewhat grainy, like an old photograph. 

The sound is just the howl of empty wind in enormous rooms. Rocks grind and scrape over surfaces as you move puzzles into place. There is some music, but it did not stand out to me in comparison to the rooms that whistle with loneliness. 

Kairo is, for the most part, a puzzle game. You manipulate these great structures, these old, broken runes, to find your way through. Some of the puzzles are simple, some of them seem to make little sense, requiring simple trial and error. Kairo does provide 'hints' for each level, but they are otiose at best, perhaps deliberately. Still, there is a sense of accomplishment at defeating these particular puzzles, and a continual drive to see what might be next keeps you going.

Do I understand what is going on? I feel I do. But at the same time, I feel that there are many right answers.

So, come. Walk with me for awhile.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995465397', 'num_games_owned': 2322, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1410297646}
review:
While Kario has some interesting puzzles, visuals, and architecture, it failed to keep me as an "explorer". After several minutes of "where do I go next" frustration while rerunning through bland empty corridors, I turned to a guide.

The pacing feels awkward/slow (even with Shift/Sprint held down), the scattered collectables are unnecessary, and puzzle satisfaction is quickly tarnished as you trudge forward (or even worse - backtrack) down long corridors to the next puzzle.  Kario could still be complex and grand without the stairs, paths, and extra large rooms. The only thing which drove me to continue was my stubbornness to complete the game.

"Kairo" - ja, was soll man dazu sagen?

Es mag im ersten Moment interessant wirken. Dieser erste Eindruck täuscht allerdings, da zuallererst keine direkte Story erkennbar ist. Man wird einfach in eine bizarre Welt hineingeworfen, in der man sich erst zurecht finden muss. Aber das kann sich als schwierig erweisen, da keinerlei Erklärungen zu den Rätseln gegeben werden.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989591969', 'num_games_owned': 4088, 'num_reviews': 271, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1409777888}
review:
Fantastic stuff. Kind of reminds me of the sort of game Antichamber wishes it was. Both are exploration-puzzle style games with few (if any) clues as to what is going on, whereas that game is just plain frustrating, Kairo is thoroughly engaging.

It's difficult to give atmosphere to a game that looks like it was made in 3D Construction Kit, but Kairo manages it. The sheer bleakness and huge open areas give a sense of loneliness and futility, but these are fleetingly overcome when you manage to solve one of the game's many puzzles.

The puzzles themselves have plenty of variety, despite not having an inventory. There are "arranging object" puzzles, "standing in the right place" puzzles and "working out the right order" puzzles just to get you started.

I would like to have had a little more exposition, as even after finishing the game you're still not very clear on what exactly is going on, but it doesn't matter.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994894769', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1408294357}
review:
Kairo is a game about exploration and puzzle solving. If Myst had been made in this generation, I think Kairo is a pretty good representation of what it would play like (though Kairo chose a much more abstract blocky appearance in many areas).

One of the really cool things about this game is that there is really no dependence on language. There are no conversations and no written or spoken instructions or clues in-game. Aside from the menu and the credits, you don't even need to be literate. The only "reading" deals with symbol-matching and it's in the context of numbers, not words.

I jumped right into Kairo without researching it at all, and honestly that's what I'd recommend everybody do. Seriously, if it sounds at all like something you might like, stop reading and jump in without any more context.



I will, however, continue typing for those who prefer to keep reading.

The game is all first-person exploration. Just move and jump. There is no combat, there is no inventory, there is no picking-up-and-carrying-and-putting-down of items. All your interaction is in where you walk, what you stand on, and what you bump into or push.

There are three major areas, referred to as the Lighthouse, the Tower, and the Garden. Each area contains hubs with several adjoining puzzle rooms. Complete puzzle rooms around a hub to unlock additional puzzle rooms and advance to the next area.

There's no substantial danger. If you fall, the game is pretty generous about spawning you quickly and very near, so you don't really risk losing progress.

While I do recommend this game overall, I do have a couple of warnings:
-There are little rune symbols scattered around the world. Most of them are in areas that are easy to get to but that you just wouldn't see unless you were specifically seeking them out. They're not required in order to finish the game, but you might find yourself backtracking if you decide to look for them all. There is one false rune in a hub room. I don't know if this was a mistake but you just can't get that one, and it's not accounted for in the "list" of found runes.

-There is a faint grainy overlay filter on pretty much everything, and combined with the occasional (and sometimes kinda loud) radio static noise, I started to get a headache after a while. If you play with headphones on, keep your volume comfortably low.

-There are three rooms that don't have an obvious purpose. Checking the hints for these rooms won't help, as the hints suggest that the rooms are there just for fun. All three of them are basically different kinds of geometric combination locks, so it's possible to brute-force the solutions, but there are so many possibilities that it's really not a reasonable method. One requires an audio clue from elsewhere in the game, one requires an extremely well-hidden visual clue from elsewhere in the game, and one actually requires collaboration with other people who have played (or are playing). There is sort of a code, and each player only gets one of the four parts of the code, so you would ideally need to exchange clues with at least 3 other people who got a different part of the solution. This is actually a cool concept, but since the whole game presents this atmosphere of isolation, the notion of communicating with other people out-of-game to trade codes is really counterintuitive. Then again, maybe it's a puzzle to try to find 3+ other people who would rather exchange guesses than just web search for the solution (which, admittedly, is how I reached the solution).

author: {'steamid': '76561198046610363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1389091150}
review:
Kairo tries to be this atmospheric, mysterious puzzle/adventure game.  It partially succeeds, but is definitely not up to the standard of games from other series.  
The environments are fairy well done, and the static-y atmospheric effects make them feel appropriately ominous.  The trouble is, all these spooky monuments and inscrutable features seem mostly just thrown together.  I rarely got any sort of sense as to what they were supposed to have been.  The single biggest thing contributing to the lack of connection to the locations (aside from how sterile they all are) is the fact that all the doors connecting areas are teleporters.  You step through one and you're in an environment that looks nothing like the one you left; could be on the other side of the planet for all you know.  Most of these are just connecting corridors, with no purpose but to create a buffer between puzzle rooms.
Nearly all the puzzles themselves were quite simple and solved quickly, save one which was very obtuse.  Some of them are supposed to be reactivating dormant machinery (except that the stuff is so abstract you have no idea what it's supposed to [i]do[/i]), while others feel like puzzles for the sake of puzzles.
You can breeze through the main sections in just a few hours.  Once you do, there are a couple of tougher puzzles that require hunting around for the proper code.  There's also this scavenger hunt thing where you try to find all the hidden glyphs around the rooms.  Neither feels all that interesting to me, since you're just going back over areas you've already visited and solved with a fine-tooth comb.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044602606', 'num_games_owned': 7477, 'num_reviews': 542, 'playtime_forever': 257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1408144294}
review:
This was an interesting game. I got this one in a bundle at some point and decided to play it today. I will say this...the game is incredibly difficult. There is a good chance you will wander without any idea what the hell you are doing and may quit as a result. That is actually a knock on this game. There is no such thing as obvious, with a couple exceptions. The game doesn't teach you anything really, and you are left to your own devices to sort out what you are supposed to do and the proper order in which to do so.
So....use a guide. This is one game where a guide is almost a necessity. You may be the sort of person who can figure out a game like this, but most people who play this wont finish it without the help of a guide. However, if you do, it doesn't detract from the experience at all, and the experience is really what this game is all about. For all that puzzles are the biggest challenge in this game, the sense of exploration and the different scenery is what makes this game stand out. I didnt get the sense of an overall story except:

SPOILERS

That this is maybe a galactic museum of sorts, or a museum at the end of the world, or something like that, and the last curator died, after which it fell into disrepair. You are basically fixing it and getting it up and running again.

SPOILER END

So, points off for not being very accessible at all, but points in its favor for being pretty unique and uniquely challenging. Pus, that secret ending was pretty funny when taking the rest of the game into consideration.

All in all, a 3 out of 10 for lack of accessibility and the (IMO) necessity of using a guide, but 8 out of 10 for everything else. Try it out. See what you think of it. I think it is a relevant game that will capture your imagination.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082489809', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1695495152}
review:
Astonishingly aesthetic. I can't say 'beautiful', but aesthetic it is. Grotesque and gigantic scale, rough surfaces and brilliant presentation of empty space. This is pure art - you getting concrete feeling of empty space (pun intended), visualization of nothingness and monolithness.

Sound environment and indirect interactions make it bewitching and slightly frightening, like you suddenly got eye-to-eye with something which is too big to grasp.

Puzzles are not 'puzzles' in terms of 'solving', but in terms of 'finding the puzzle'. Understand the rules of interaction, find patterns in that interaction, and only after that solve it. Solving is not main part, recognition is.

The best game without human narrative I ever saw.

review: Visually sparse and eerily empty, Kairo delivers an immense atmosphere and story to discover by yourself, one single movement in these empty and endless buildings would be enough to scare the shit out of me but luckily Kargo is a subversive and very intruiging puzzle game in which the simple gameplay wthout combination of items or common rules like other games once set em up, are of no priority anymore. I never play puzzle games but this one is really woth your time and, once again, the achievements are pretty easy to get as well. Just be sure that you like the aesthetics before you play it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198015863346', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1407032200}
review: I was honestly surprised by this game. I tend to have a love for indie exploration games, but this turned out to be so much better than that. You know that feeling, when you just want to keep playing to see what's next? Well I haven't felt this in a long time, but I certainly did with Kairo. What is it? It's a first person puzzle game, with an amazing narrative, that is told without a single word spoken. I don't want to spoil it, but the game really turns out to be much, much more than you expected. The mechanics work pretty well, some puzzles are easy, some are hard as hell (the ones you need for a secret ending for example). Kudos to the developer, this is truly an amazing work of art. Would I recommend it? Definitely. I really didn't expect myself to love this game so much. But I did. And so should you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069371185', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1407028864}
review:
Más que un juego, es una experiencia. Se trata de un indie de exploración en primera persona y puzles en el que toda acción que realices se lleva a cabo con tu cuerpo. Lo único que puedes hacer es moverte y saltar, y esto último está casi de relleno para dar sensación de libertad, porque no sirve para avanzar en ningún momento. Eres soltado en mitad de un mundo cubista/futurista aparentemente en ruinas y lo que hagas a partir de ahí es asunto tuyo. Para lograr avanzar, tendrás que resolver puzles, alguno que otro algo enrevesado.
La trama en este juego es prácticamente inexistente. De vez en cuando se da alguna pincelada que puede darte a entender algo, y he aquí lo mejor: ni se te muestra explicitamente ni eres capaz de sacar nada en claro de los detalles que se te ofrecen, por lo que cuando termines, lo que tú concluyas en tu cerebro será tu historia, tan válida como cualquier otra teoría argumental que se te ocurra (yo tengo un par, y cualquiera sería verdadera), ya que la trama ni es un punto importante ni lo pretende ser en ningún momento. Este es un juego puramente creado para aportar una experiencia y una inmersión en un mundo completamente abstracto. Los puzles están para que pueda ser considerado juego y darle algo que hacer al jugador, creo, pero lo que me parece que el creador pretende es sumergirte en un mindfuck hecho entorno explorable. Las cosas pueden parecer algo y resultar no ser lo que crees, obligándote a replantearte el modo de avance o incluso hacerte sentir ridículo en algún que otro momento (si lo jugáis me entenderéis), los escenarios no dejan de sorprender, y a todo esto se le añade un apartado sonoro que encaja completamente en las ambientaciones, consiguiendo producirte sensaciones de lo más variadas (desde tranquilidad hasta inquietud sin ninguna amenaza aparente a la vista).

Recomendable. Mucho.

review:
Muy chulo, una atmósfera envolvente aunque es un juego "de libre albedrío", osea que la mayoría de las veces vas a lo loco.

Es cierto que el control es un poquitín malo y a veces nos topamos con fealdades gráficas como malas colisiones y tal, pero eso no le quita encanto. La idea es bastante buena y acabas por cogerle el truco, muchos lugares por explorar y un entorno cambiante que hace que quieras seguir jugando a ver con quié te encuentras.

Además de coleccionables hay un final extra absurdo pero merece la pena verlo. Quizás lo único que estás bastante perdido y acabarás por mirar una guía o te durará un porrón de horas más.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970672461', 'num_games_owned': 2234, 'num_reviews': 195, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1403036249}
review:
Kairo is a rather atmospheric abstract exploration/puzzle game.  I think a game like this could work well if there were interesting things to find, but Kairo doesn't have any.  The game just ends up being boring from start to finish with a pretty poor and confusing ending to top it off.  There are a few pretty creative puzzles throughout but many of the others make no sense and even seem like they deliberately try to confuse you.  That's not good puzzle design if you ask me.  Replay value seems to rely on annoyingly-hidden secrets, some of which require a lot of slow backtracking.

So if you feel like walking around slowly, staring at confusing puzzles in differently colored rooms with nothing remarkable in them, this is the game for you.
