author: {'steamid': '76561198061028678', 'num_games_owned': 205, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1395293359}
review:
総合評価　６／１０

良い所
	ヒントの殆ど無いパズル要素
	謎解きはプレーヤー次第

悪い所
	酔う
	結局、謎は明かされない

FP視点でのパズルゲーム。

現代アートやビデオアートなどに興味があり、かつそういったものが好きで波長が合うなら楽しめるかと。

クリアーするだけならさほど難しくはないが、（オブジェクトの動かし方などに気づけるかそうでないかで難易度が変わる類のパズル）真のエンディングがあるような気がする。

これはプレイしなければわからないのだが、収集要素と隠し部屋、それと音の鳴る遊び部屋が謎のまま残る。

パズルを解くのは楽しいのだが、こういった雰囲気のゲームは最後になにか大きな秘密が紐解けると期待してしまう。そして期待は裏切られる。

因みに酔います。所謂、３Ｄ酔ですね。モーションブラー、フレームレート、フィルムグレイン、フィルターカラー・・・色々混ざってそうなっているのだろうか。

author: {'steamid': '76561197991019754', 'num_games_owned': 394, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1679700588}
review: Few games I have played have captured that original sense of discovery I felt back in 1993 when I played Myst for the first time.  This game abandons you, in the most compelling way, and you are left alone with only your thoughts.  These are sometimes filled with curiosity, sometime awe, and sometime a tingling sense of dread.  Few game are willing to take the risk on having no dialogue, minimal sounds, and just leave the player with their own minds.

review:
This is the most interesting time I've had playing a game that I totally didn't understand once it was finished. Granted, the theme is subtle and I *think* I get what the story was saying but there's not a lot there for clarity.

Fortunately, the game is highly engaging and very entertaining. The puzzles were unique and at times exasperating but well worth it. I probably logged 6-8 hours into the game and it was a lot of fun. If you like puzzles, this is the game for you. Just don't expect your hand to be held anywhere!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993492300', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1405481509}
review: Kairo is a beautiful game. It stands right up there with best artistic endeavors in gaming in the last ten years, and its tone is perfectly executed. Do not play this game in a room full of housemates screaming at League of Legends (as I did in my first attempt); in order to appreciate the mood, you should be alone and open to anything. Because, thought the game does not literally deliver EVERYTHING, it conveys the feeling that it COULD, and that is a mostly lost art in gaming, as well as literature and film. After fully completing every aspect of the game, I still am not entirely sure of the exact story narrative, and the writer in me hates that, but that same writer also appreciates it. How easy would it have been for the developer to just give us computer terminals and characters to explain everything? But that's why this is so great. It felt like I was really there, really trying to piece together something entirely on my own. If I were actually there, I doubt there'd be notes scattered about just telling me every detail about what happened. But the story, while integral to the setting in design, is not essential to experiencing the setting. I highly recommend this to people who loved Myst back in the day; who enjoy newer exploration-based environmental games like FEZ and Gone Home; those of you who have to be driven by saving the princess and killing the bad guys, however, might want to sit this one out. But I enjoyed this game immensely. Thumbs way up!

author: {'steamid': '76561198020576431', 'num_games_owned': 684, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1405088771}
review:
Bir arkadaşımın "Antichamber'a benzer oyunlar" önerisiyle satın aldığım bir oyun ve çok memnun kaldığımı söylemeliyim. Oyun en basidinden puzzle çözme oyunu olarak geçiyor. O şekilde ilerlenen bir sisteme sahip. En büyük özelliği ise, mistik olması.

Artı Yönleri:
*En başta oyunun atmosferi: İlginç bir şekilde oyunu gergin oynamanızı sağlayan bir uğultu var arkada, onun yanı sıra oyununun oynanabilirliği sizi direk atmosferine alacak şekilde tasarlanmış. Daha iyi bir atmosfere girmek için gece kulaklıkla oynamanızı tavsiye ederim.
*İlginç görsellere sahip. Verilmek istenen bazı mesajlar var.
*Hikaye işleyişinin orijinal olması. Kayıp bir dünya gibi düşünün.
*Oyunda güzel yerlerde gizli kapı var ve bunun için dikkatli bir şekilde oyunu oynamanız gerekmekte.
*Puzzle zorluğu orta seviyede.
*Çok fazla gizemli bir tarzının olması ve insanda merak duygusunu uyandırması.
*Oyunun çok uzun sürmemesi: Bu da insanı sıkmıyor. 

Eksi Yönleri:
*Oynadığınız alan fazla büyük. Bayağı bir yürümeniz gerekiyor. Büyük bir ortam olması için uğraşmışlar ama bir süre sonra insanı bayıyor fazla yürümek.

Açıkçası çok fazla eksi bi özellik bulamadım. 5 Doları hak eden bir oyun. Ben oynarken çok keyif aldım. Zeka oyunlarını seven herkese tavsiye ediyorum.
80/100

author: {'steamid': '76561198000607180', 'num_games_owned': 375, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1406569906}
review: Jeu indé' de puzzling/exploration à la première personne dans un monde déformé, figé et a priori postdiluvien, Kairo nous propose une aventure certes courtes, mais unique et dépaysante. Là encore, les mécaniques de jeu à proprement parler sont mises de côté au profit de l'ambiance, qui se veut de son côté très travaillée et redoutablement efficace. Tantôt pesante, tantôt reposante, si elle rechigne déjà à lâcher le joueur, elle semble encore moins encline à le laisser de marbre. Production indé' "artsy-fartsy" oblige, on s'autorise à casser quelques codes. La narration ne se fait par exemple que par le biais de l'environnement, que le joueur sera libre d'interpréter comme bon lui semble. En ce sens, Kairo est de ces jeux qui se ressentent plus qu'ils ne s'expliquent, une de ces productions qui osent s'écarter des sentiers archi-battus de l'industrie pour proposer au joueur non pas qu'un simple divertissement, mais bel et bien une expérience à part entière. Les curieux apprécieront surement, pour peu qu'ils se laissent aller au voyage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107503346', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1436221807}
review:
Kairo - проект крайне специфический, и непросто принять решение - рекомендовать данную игру к покупке или нет. Любителей спинномозговых шутеров, фанатов "графона как в Crysis", либо просто нетерпеливых игроков я призываю немедленно закрыть эту страницу, запустить любимый CoD или Battlefield и забыть о Kairo как о страшном сне.

Дело в том, что это инди в квадрате, это одна большая метафора, выполненная в простом, но в то же время завораживающем стиле. Здесь отсутствует сюжет в привычном понимании - суть происходящего преподносится в виде небольших "флешбеков", если хотите, после прохождения группы комнат. По большому счёту, сюжет здесь и не важен - он добавлен лишь для создания определённого настроения при прохождении. Не буду спойлерить, это нужно увидеть собственными глазами в определённые моменты.

Геймплей представляет собой игру от первого лица, основанную на решении пазлов. Последние, в свою очередь, иногда обескураживают своей алогичностью, и чем дальше по ходу игры, тем чаще. Мне сложно понять, чем руководствовались и вдохновлялись разработчики и левел-дизайнеры при их создании, но периодически возникает ощущение, будто нас специально задерживают в прохождении. Данный факт раздражает, поэтому я рекомендую найти прохождение на YouTube, открыть в фоне и время от времени сверяться с ним. Тем более, что в конце игры есть замечательная комната-пасхалка, выполнить условия для попадания в которую при обычном прохождении решительно невозможно.

review:
Kairo is a game for people who like museums and art galleries.

This is definitely a style of indie game that I would like to see more of in mainstream production.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983548320', 'num_games_owned': 3594, 'num_reviews': 180, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1404099664}
review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z1kmUrQUPac

Kairo is one of the most uniquely atmospheric game I've played. It's visuals are simple, but expertly crafted, both eerie and gorgeous at the same time. To say the least, the game is surreal in it's aesthetics. While the environment is some thing to take in, it's not just about looking at pretty set pieces, the game features mind bending puzzles as it's main motivator.

Though the game is incredibly enjoyable, and wonderfully put together, it does have some minor flaws. The movements feel rather sluggish, and at best, floaty, and there isn't much incentive to replay the game once completed. Not to sound cliche, but Kairo really is about the journey and not the destination.

For $5.00 at it's full price, you are getting a quality product. I can not recommend this game enough, especially at it's low price point. 

Pros:
- Excellent aesthetics
- Surreal and eerie atmosphere
- Interesting puzzles
- A very unique game overall
- $5.00 is unreasonably cheap. This is a good thing for the consumer (I personally think it's worth more than just $5.00)

Cons:
- Floaty controls
- Not a lot of replay incentives

author: {'steamid': '76561198009383930', 'num_games_owned': 615, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1451706140}
review:
Kairo. Ein Spiel, ...
...dass ohne viel Story trotzdem recht fesselnd ist.
...dass durch sein bizzares Setting überzeuget.
...dass mit gut ausgewogenen und zum größten Teil fairen Rätseln aufwartet.

Allerdings muss ich zugeben, dass es mir auf Dauer etwas zu linear und unübersichtlich wurde. 
Linear deshalb, da es permanent das selbe ist: Ich komme in einen Raum, rätsle etwas rum, löse das Rätsel und kann zum nächsten Rätsel weiter, zudem ich jedoch erstmal laufen muss. Nicht, dass mich jemand falsch versteht, die Rätsel machen Spaß, aber dieses Laufen ging mir mit der Zeit tierisch gegen den Strich (vor allem, wenn man ALLES im Spiel entdecken will. Hat hier jemand Achievment Jäger gesagt?). Und genau beim "alles entdecken wollen" wird es dann auch noch unübersichtlich, woraus ein öfteres Verlaufen bzw. "Verlorengehen" resultiert (war zumindest bei mir der Fall). Zum einfach mal "durchrushen" eignet sich dieses Spiel also eher weniger.

Das waren aber auch die einzigen zwei Negativpunkte. Wer gerne erkundet, sich nicht ständig fragt, wann die Story endlich anfängt, gerne länger in einem Spiel verweilt und auf eine komplett abstrakte und abgedrehte Spielwelt steht, sollte sich dieses Spiel unbedingt mal genauer anschauen.
Und für Indie-Fans eh ein Muss! 
Daumen hoch!

review: Really good game, fellas. The atmosphere is fantastically mysterious, the puzzles are just the right difficulty, the whole world is wonderful to look at, the music fits perfectly and the subtlety of the story telling is very welcome. Those who like exploring, puzzle-solving and generally getting immersed in an interesting, strange world of its own will love this. And no violence!

author: {'steamid': '76561198058254204', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1691346099}
review: Посмотрев видео и прочитав описание, мне представилась экая идеальная бродилка: ходишь и наслаждаешься видами неких "покинутых монументов". Запустив игру я было обрадовался - ура, можно бродить и ничего не делать, наслаждась левел-архитектурным дизайном. Увы, игра оказалась набором довольно стандартных квестов, половина из которых видены в различных играх и фильмах. Соответственно, другая половина оказалась весма труднорешаема, если не сказать "нерешаема". Из пройденных мною локаций некоторые действительно интересны по дизайну, а другие весьма слабы и списаны с других источников. Также присутствует ощущение каких-то филосовско-сакральных смыслов, но это можно списать и на фантазию автора, оградив себя от лишних измышлений. общая оценка "плюс", поиграть (за 40р) час-другой можно.

review: A quietly unnerving game filled with interesting and rewarding puzzles. Secrets are scattered throughout the game, but the secret ending is a joke that's not really worth the work unless you love 100% completing games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986202316', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 732, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1456275257}
review:
This game was very good.  The combination of the eerie scapes {can't say landscapes because there was no land} the enigmatic puzzles and the atmospheric sound track make for a sort of bizarre and fun experience.  

The puzzles were fun and not too hard, although, I did have to refer to the hint system in the game a couple of the times.  There are areas along the main path but there are also areas that may be just for fun and it is hinted at that there might be something more there.  A secret perhaps.

It took me about 5 or 6 hours to finish the game.  Don't get me wrong, this game may not be for everyone.  If your looking for Call Of Duty,  Speelunky, or The Witcher, this is not the game.  Its a little more like Myst but without the story and far more surreal, but for $1.99 it was great!  Grab it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198139457913', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1406354674}
review:
Kairo - Review

Gameplay:  7/10
Delivering a new and fun approach to puzzle gaming, Kairo give hours of fun with an ancient twist. The gameplay is simple yet effective, it delivers a challenging balance between the need to use logic and intuition.

Game ambiance: 6/10
There is little in the way of graphic ambiance in Kiro; odd geometries floating about with an abundance of fog. This is exemplified by the subtle use of sound and music. What it does have is a creative and well blended atmosphere between these elements to give a relaxing sense of space and mystery.

Reliability/Stability: 10/10
The game has had no issues to report.

Story/Plot: n/a


Concept: 6/10
The idea of using ancient Egypt in the puzzle genre of gaming has been around for a while. But it's never been done in this way.

Concept execution: 7/10
Creative, original, simple and effective; the execution of this game is almost dream-like. Unlike other puzzle games Kairo enables a challenging, stress-free, fun and relaxed problem solving platform to explore.

Textures: 2/10
Nothing special, but then nothing special is needed.

Modelling: 4/10
Just the bare minimum modeling has been done. Don't let this deter you though, any more would spoil the effect.

Graphics: 5/10
Overall the graphics are average, but still effective. The creative use of perspective goes a long way in this game.

Sound: 4/10
The sound is simple and only added where needed. This also adds to the whole feel and concept execution of this game.

Music: 7/10
Well written ambiance that is a magical match to the visuals.

Adjustable shadow mapping: No
Bonus/Extras: none

author: {'steamid': '76561198013469422', 'num_games_owned': 577, 'num_reviews': 163, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1404733603}
review:
공포게임인줄 알았습니다.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999563951', 'num_games_owned': 794, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1625052140}
review:
I love this game so much you have no idea. This game, to me, perfects the feeling of loneliness (related spoilers in brackets below)
This feeling of loneliness was so present and so overwhelming to me, and I kept moving on wondering what was next. As time went on and things started being revealed to me, the things which were revealed only made that feeling of loneliness grow. There were some points at which I also felt fear, the sort of fear you feel when you want to get out of a room and you don't know quite why, so you run out and slam the door behind you.
The game itself is pretty solid. You have no inventory and no buttons with which you can use to interact with things. You walk jump and look around and those are the only controls. The variety of puzzles despite this is amazing, and most of them make perfect sense (there was one where you rotate two gears to match symbols in some weird arbitrary manner and I never actually figured out what the connection was. Had to use a guide for that part)
If I didn't have the emotional capacity of a potato I would have cried at the end, I swear to god, it just HIT ME RIGHT THERE, RIGHT IN THE WEAK POINT. So please please PLEASE BUY THIS GAME.

[there's a moment in the game where you walk into a room and press a button. TV screens turn on around you, showing a humanlike figure behind static. As you solve the puzzles around this point in the game, this figure pops up on more TV screens as you complete puzzles. As I played through I thought to myself, "Is that another human? If I meet them what will happen? Who are they?" At some point you find yourself in a green tinted room with another TV, only larger and in front of a table. When you walk around the table, you find a skeleton on a chair with monitors examining puzzles you've completed in front of it. There is a message scratched onto the arm of the chair. "I AM ALONE HERE."]

author: {'steamid': '76561198130424055', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1404751663}
review:
This is one of those puzzle games that is very difficult. It's llike taking a pretzel, placing it in a room with two torches and asking someone to figure out the puzzle. The puzzles in this game tend to range from "Oh wow, the answer is simple" to "how does this even result in THAT kind of answer?!"

The graphics remind me a lot of older Playstation games which is alright in this case. This isn't meant to be a masterpiece, it's more of an art style game, it takes a good eye to enjoy this and the puzzles that lie inside. As for those little out of spot marks you see here and there in each part of the game, let's just say it results in getting the best ending ever (coffee is great indeed).

The sounds are something else and just sound so lively in a place that is almost entirely desolate. Find a certain thing or two in the game can be equally heartbreaking and allows you to come to your own conclusion on what you think led to the events in this game.

9.5/10 Would recommend to friends. The achievments are a bit difficult but fun to get. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197988857583', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1409866556}
review:
The lighting and sound of Kairo creates a daunting atmosphere: Not 'Scary', but it could be described as 'Eerie' and 'Ominous'.
The level design is quite Agoraphobic: The wide open spaces make you feel very exposed and the sharp blind corners make you feel very uneasy.
You're always convinced you're in danger and that something will jump out at you, but nothing ever does.

In terms of actual gameplay - Its a simplistic puzzle game; your only control is wasd movement and jumping.
If you do decide to play, I recommend the following options:
1. Turning the mouse option sensitiving to about 10%
2. Turning Grain off
3. Turning the Motion Smoother off

author: {'steamid': '76561198006557991', 'num_games_owned': 1601, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1404512343}
review:
Единственная игра, играя в которую меня в первый раз через некоторое время подташнивало глядя, к примеру, на движущиеся розовые объекты на черном фоне, или находясь в потоке движущихся прямоугольных линий и всматриваясь во все ЭТО :) Да и есть напрягающие в таком же плане палитры, бледно-зеленые, бледно-красные... В общем за мою тошноту игре отдельный лойс :D

А если серьезно, то игра имеет весьма неплохой стиль, этакий минимализм (правда не такой отшлифованный как хотелось...), отличное музыкальное сопровождение (добротный эмбиент под стать игре), а как головоломка, она среднячок. Умственно напрягаться особо не пришлось... Да и всё наглядно видно что к чему и почему =)

В общем, игра определенно заслуживает свои 76 по Metascore. С чем я и поздравляю автора сего творения, Ричарда Перрина :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198090080625', 'num_games_owned': 485, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1412593388}
review: 这是一款恐怖解密游戏吧，最大的特点就是各种几何体和单色调的场景组成的魔幻视界，并且配合诡异玄幻的BGM有一种沉闷压抑的气氛，解密大多不是很难，注意那些符号和可操控单位被触碰时发出的声音就可以了，整个解密也没有什么故事性的剧情，就是一步步去发现更多的新奇事物，但是这种未知的处境和被团团的色块、几何体包围，时不时还会出现故意挡住你去路的“智能”墙、封锁你前进的冰冷的石块，都会让人有一种莫名的恐惧感，当我第一次跟那个走哪挡哪的墙纠结了一会以后..关掉了游戏。

author: {'steamid': '76561198042103424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1584938727}
review: Kairo is actually one of the better puzzle games that I've played, blending atmosphere with mystery and tossing a few challenging puzzles in between. Many of the early puzzles are not particularly challenging, mostly consisting of pushing a chair or something, but they do gradually get more challenging. The atmosphere is great, always slightly creepy but not scary. the graphics aren't exactly next gen, but in a manner similar to minecraft, the game itself makes the grainy, blocky, dream world all the more special. Overall, I enjoyed Kairo immensely. I would recommend this to anybody who likes a good puzzle and a good atmosphere (basically, if you liked Portal, you will probably like this too). Totally worth it for the 2 bucks I paid for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045639343', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1425752978}
review:
Enjoyed this experience so much that I bought the soundtrack during fall/winter of last year and would walk around my college campus listening to droning ambience from this game in my earbuds, gazing at the architecture and sculptures of campus, sort of a walking meditation thing inspired by the feeling of the game itself.

Overall it's a great game, but the developer's emotional attachment/struggle with the making of Kairo has created a sort of disconnect between himself and it. This is a shame, since add-on material, a sequel, or even just more frequent support/bug fixes for the pc and mobile versions of this game would really help this game's staying power as similar games/clones are released all around it, with greater developer involvement and newer more exciting takes on this newly emerging "minimalist foreign exploration puzzler" niche.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974281429', 'num_games_owned': 707, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 892, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 892, 'last_played': 1404122999}
review:
It's a neat little game for what it is.  Some of the puzzles are really difficult and non-intuitive.  We're all used to games holding our hands in the beginning, training us for a little while until things progress in difficulty, but this game doesn't do that.  The puzzles aren't connected in any kind of order.  The level design is minimalistic, serving only to host the puzzles for the most part, more like a tech demo you'd see for a kickstarter project to entice fans.  

The "story" is purposefully left widely open to player interpretation but it won't blow your mind in any real way.  You can tell the concept that inspired the designer to create the game is there but probably fell short of what he really wanted to do in the final product we're getting.  I could see him making a sequel and really fleshing out something from this game.

The game is more artsy and vague than a flowing linear story.  It reminded me of playing Myst back in the day.  You'll find puzzles with solutions located in completely different unrelated areas.  Everything you need to solve the puzzles are located in the game for the most part, but for those of us going into this as a casual time sink just wanting to blast through it will need to look up some solutions to get all the achievements for sure.  If you get it on sale for a couple of dollars it's worth it.  It took longer than I thought it would to complete the game in its entirety, but not in an overly frustrating way.  It was a pleasant surprise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014662768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 406, 'last_played': 1405870455}
review:
Kairo isn't your standard issue game; it's more of a playable piece of digital art really.

It is a world abstracted into basic geometric shapes, drenched in monotone hues, and brought with eerily alien music.  It doesn't contain the usual button mashing or killing stuff, but instead is about exploration and solving puzzles (nothing hard really).  It's fairly short, but will offer a unique experience you won't find anywhere else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069302012', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1439455541}
review:
If you like me have fallen in love with Antichamber and now are looking for something similar, Kairo is a good choice.
It has similar mesmerizing atmosphere of strange empty rooms, simple geometrical shapes and ambient music. This world is somewhat between ancient tomb and alien spaceship, but sometimes you'll find something weirdly realistic.

It is gloomy and meditative but in the end you getting deep and pleasant experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979912242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1404099596}
review: While very simple graphically (which it tries to hide with an awful noise filter that fortunately can be turned off), this is one of the most evocative games I've ever played. It reminds me of Rendezvous with Rama: you wander around huge, lifeless environments with inscrutable machines with no idea what you're doing until the end, and even then it's unclear. But take a lunch break and watch the cubes float by.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014932334', 'num_games_owned': 2697, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1411773561}

author: {'steamid': '76561198031108102', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1414818213}

author: {'steamid': '76561197991527477', 'num_games_owned': 280, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1404053713}
review:
Kairo is a very peculiar indie game with interesting puzzles that focus on visual cues (next to nothing audibly). If you have a decent computer and own FRAPS, then you should have no problem (REQUIRES FRAMELOCK), but for those of you who do not, I would be weary. My setup was running Kairo at 300+ FPS and quickly became dizzy and nauseated which lasted longer than it should have. 

Requiring a framelocking software in order to experience the game as it was meant to be is a turn off. Not to mention most won't know what framelocking is or how to do it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019288141', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1404012783}
review:
What has happened and why is the world so empty..? That is the main question that you have to ask yourself as disturbing images and realizations are made clear the deeper to delve into this world. If you love puzzle games that make you think and give you a good challenge, then you're going to love Kairo~! 

The game is hauntingly beautiful, in a simplistic way and I love all the different types of puzzles they incorporated into the game. And I’ll give you a hint… don’t miss a step in looking around, you could miss something very important~!

I bought on sale for 1.49$ and I don’t regret it. Actually, I feel like I got a great deal for such an interesting game~! I’d pick it up if this type of game is your cup of tea.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052277399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1403970455}
review:
Ein Spiel im luftleeren Raum - was das Spielerlebnis angeht...

Kairo ist bemüht eine düstere mystische Amtosphäre zu erzeugen, durch z.B. übereinander schwebende Ringe, die nach Lösen eines Rätsels einen Strahl erzeugen, oder durch Herumfliegen von Quadern um einen herum, sobald man geradeaus läuft. Warum das geschieht, erfährt man jedoch nie, weder durch eine Erklärung, noch durch Andeutungen (vllt am Ende des Spiels, die Motivation das herauszufinden wurde bei mir jed. nicht geweckt). Somit entsteht nicht einmal ein Gefühl dafür, wo man ist und was das ganze überhaupt soll. Grafik-Stil und die Architektur der Bauten wirken minimalistisch und gezielt generisch, auf mich persönlich allerdings irgendwie noch zu undefiniert und unfertig, als dass ich sie als charakteristisch und außergewöhnlich empfände. Die Rätsel sind ok, ihren Sinn / Notwendigkeit erkennt man jedoch nicht.

Somit mMn nur empfehlenswert, wenn man grundsätlich auf mystische und atmosphärische Spiele abfährt. Wie gesagt, Atmosphäre ist vorhanden, die im Ansatz interessant ist und ja auch dem ein oder anderen hier gefällt, mir persönlich war das jedoch zu wenig.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078788850', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1388874374}
review:
The atmosphere of this game is amazing - the strange world of Kairo is very enticing. The puzzles are odd, slightly-difficult, but captivating. It's a game suited to long, slow playthroughs where you delve into all the details.

However, I must warn you that it triggered migraines in my case. I can't give the game the full attention (or play time) that it deserves. It's a major problem for me, but maybe not for others - so I suggest you try before you buy if at all possible.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995555431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1403943710}
review:
I actually had no idea what I was getting into when I got this game, but I am so glad I did. From the very moment I set foot in its loenly and yawning halls I knew it would be an interesting experience. The aesthetic nature of the game is so beautifully executed, it gives you this perfect mix of uneasy tension and soothing zen-like atmosphere. You get the feeling you arent the only person to have wandered these lonely halls, and that the place you find your self in has been waiting for you all along. 

I loved pondering the nature of the structures you find in this game as much as I did solving the puzzles all the way through. It was definitely worth the time and money, a contained experience that leaves you with an unexpected feeling of wonder. Just get this game to see what Im talking about. Truly a hidden gem on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971629679', 'num_games_owned': 825, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1403809296}
review:
La déception qui me fut causée par Kairo est grandement de ma faute : j'ai acheté ce jeu car il est signé Richard Perrin, dont j'avais adoré l'excellent point-and-click d'horreur The White Chamber. 

Las ! Kairo n'est qu'un clone de Myst aux graphismes et énigmes simplement frustrantes et/ou simplistes, car il arrive parfois qu'on ait compris la solution, mais qu'elle soit simplement gonflante à mettre en pratique. 

Donc, je ne peux recommander Kairo, mais encore une fois, c'est un peu de ma faute, car je ne m'attendais pas à tomber sur un Myst-like, un genre que je n'aime pas, et parce que je m'attendais bêtement à ce qu'un auteur me ressorte une recette que j'avais aimé. Et après, on ose se plaindre des suites à répétition dans l'industrie du jeu vidéo...

author: {'steamid': '76561198019923591', 'num_games_owned': 965, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1403804290}
review:
What the hell did I just play?  Equal parts weirdness, exploration and creepy atmosphere.  My first attempt at playing this was about 10 minutes of wandering around aimlessly thinking, "Huh?"  Then I realized there was some structure to the game and I attempted to figure it all out.

I failed.

So I played again, with a guide.  Even though I didn't necessarily play it entirely by myself I still appreciated the ambiance of the finished product.  

If you bought it for the Cards, you might as well play for the achievements too.  They're pretty easy and the game is worth the run through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025902178', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1403744810}
review:
The concept is interesting, but the graphics are crude. The atmosphere is immersing, but the controls are not. The architecture makes you wonder, but the puzzles and scenery progression tell no story whatsoever.

There is no coherence or flow; some puzzles are BAD (looking at you, Pi), the hints are abrupt and without any subtlety. The interaction is poor. Walking up stairways gives headaches from the camera motion; too close to walls and you see through them. Strange things in the scenery prompt questions, but nothing around intends to answer them.

There is a mystery surrounding Kairo, and it is: "why am I still playing?"

author: {'steamid': '76561197995766941', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1403828294}
review: At first I thought this was another weird artsy fartsy game, but man, was I proved wrong. It's a semi-complex first person puzzle game that boasts a stylish yet minimalistic design that keeps you intrigued. Albeit, at times, the graphics can look a bit bland or bad, I overlook the aforementioned flaws because of how interesting the game is. A few of the puzzles actually require a bit of thinking as opposed to just flat out putting pieces wherever you feel they go. Luckily, there is a hint option in the pause screen. I had been eyeing this game for a while and saw it go on sale a couple of days ago. I highly recommend this game if you are intrigued by visual puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006464255', 'num_games_owned': 265, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1400350023}
review:
Before I begin, I have played for more than 0.3 hours, but I played in offline mod. Not very much though, this game made me bored faster than a math lesson can do.


Positives:

- Decent scripting I guess

Negatives:

- Pretty much everything
- Boring gameplay
- No storyline


You spawn in a world with absoutely no clue how you got there. You don't have a name, you don't have a goal, you don't have anything to find. The story is non existing.

Some games can be good even without a clear goal or a background story, but not in this case.

Not only do you have no goal, enemies or purpose in Kairo whatsoever, the puzzles are also simple but yet confusing. You can not interact with anything and you don't have an inventory, meaning that all you can do is move objects by walking towards them, or jump on random platforms in hope that something will happen. Really, really simple puzzles. And when I say it's also confusing, what I mean is, you don't really know why you are doing what you are doing due to the non existing story and the few hints you get doesn't really help that much at all.


Do I recommend this game? No. I don't recommend it to anyone.

People that love adventures, no. The game is as simple as it can be (including the soundtracks and gameplay in general) with nothing to explore or discover at all. You don't even have a purpose or anything to lose. Not even health (no, you can't even die in this game).

People that like puzzle games, no. Again, the puzzles are basic, yet confusing, and you don't really know why you are doing them.

People that love a good storyline, no. There is no story in this game at all.

-------------------

Why people like this is beyond me. I have played many bad games, but this without doubt in my top 5 most boring games ever.

2/10 - Really bad

author: {'steamid': '76561198025025928', 'num_games_owned': 1095, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 533, 'last_played': 1376977955}
review: What is Kairo? A mystery? A haven? A weapon? Drawn to a truly awing series of subdimensional rooms set throughout different sacred ruined structures and glimpsing dozens of different ages and stages of Earthen architecture, you must discover the truth that lies within. Only by reactivating each mechanism and bringing life back to these ruins will you find the answers you seek. What is Kairo? Is it a beginning? Is it an end? Each room is its own purpose, its own meaning, its own separate, desperate secret. The shattered memories of a whole culture, a vast race locked with each carved rock and echoed through each signal that reaches up from the deepest void. Kairo has a calling, Kairo has a need. Bring Kairo back to the light, clear the dust off this great ancient machine, and resuscitate this sleeping monolith. What is Kairo? The past? The present? The future? Kairo is life. Kairo is death. Kairo is rebirth. Yet, most of all, Kairo...is waiting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012905156', 'num_games_owned': 653, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 184, 'last_played': 1403460817}
review:
Imagine you wake up on a stone platform. You havce no idea who or where you are, or even what's happening. Pushing a button on the wall causes a chime to go off and suddenly blocks of "water" are flowing up a cliff...

Welcome to every second of gameplay in Kairo, a first-person puzzle game somewhat akin to the "closed-room" Flash games you got so furious at as a child. There is no menu to speak of. No dialogue. No explanations. If you want to degrade yourself by using the "hints" provided, then you might have some idea of what needs to happen. Otherwise? Well...maybe if you hop backwards on one leg the door will open.

Don't get me wrong, the puzzles in Kairo are great! They twist and bend your mind in ways that few activities do. Sadly, this is somewhat diminished by the monotonous tone of walking through nothingness hitting the Escape key for your next clue. It looks like someone wanted to make a game of random puzzles, but felt the need to incorporate a storyline. This is fine, of course, unless you refuse to use any words at all - written or spoken. As the player, you end up with a small hint as to anything that did happen/will happen/is happening....then the game ends. Congratulations! You've solved 3 hours worth of puzzle game!

All-in-all, it was a good bit of fun. I bought it for $1.50, so it's hard to complain. But if you find yourself having to pay any more than that for it, I'd say take a pass.

- Mr. Talidar

author: {'steamid': '76561198031757552', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1051, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1402551951}
review:
[b]In Brief[/b]
[b]Kairo[/b] is a narrative without words painting a picture of aloneness on a canvas made of staggeringly large geometry.

[b]Most valuable resource:[/b] The art.
[b]Of interest to:[/b] people who appreciate geometric abstraction, and like deeply mysterious Myst-style puzzlers.

I have never before played a game with such an incredible feeling of scale.  The place is enigmatic, it is stunning but, more than anything else, it is *overpoweringly huge*.  Figuring out what you are supposed to be doing is part of the experience of this game, so don't be put off by what appears at the outset to be random acts of geometry.  There is meaning and purpose to this place; it just takes some time to start to piece it together.  This is a different kind of narrative.

For me the strangest part of the experience of Kairo is that at the outset you are in a place of geometry and void, with no personality or sense of place; you are cast adrift with no instructions whatsoever, completely alone in a place which amplifies aloneness.  You aren't even sure what the game is, let alone what the game world is all about.  But by the end you feel like you know this place, you understand it, it is familiar and you are at home here - which, given the way the game ends, is the ultimate irony.

There is a story here, but one told without words, and it is a magnificent story of great scale and great aloneness, and it is masterfully told.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027900724', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1403408117}
review:
This game is pretty crazy. Somewhere between fascinating and terrifying, wondrous and foreboding. There are no monsters or even imminent threats really, but still your entire surroundings feel so ancient and so much grander than you that it creates an incredibly ominous feeling that never quite goes away.

As you interact with the world, huge abandoned structures come to life, and though the scenery changes and the paths are made clear, you never really know what’s going on under the surface. What do these huge contraptions actually do? Where is it leading? And how did all of it (and you for that matter) end up here? You get the sense that you’ll never really know, because it’s all just too ancient, too alien for your understanding.

The entire experience is rather chilling, and if you let yourself really become immersed in this world, you’ll probably find yourself making some pretty strange sounds, like I was, and laughing at points about just how uncomfortable it actually makes you.

The game isn’t perfect. There are bugs, but those tend to add to the strangeness of the environment in a way. One noticeable fault I had was that the footstep sounds are the exact same no matter what your pace is. This may sound minor, but it is rather noticeable at times when you are really taking it slow to take in your surroundings, which you will probably do quite a lot. Still a minor complaint in face of everything that’s really on display in this one.

I bought it during a Summer Sale at $1.50, and I would probably recommend it at a fairly higher price-tag even still.

MY SCORE - 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198071611866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1403270626}
review:
Kairo game has really poor level design. It's not minimalism or something. It's just ugly. Levels have all common mapper's mistakes like bad lights and incorrectly aligned textures. Although I saw it from video and screenshots, I still hoped that Kairo has interesting puzzles and enthralling atmosphere, but it does not. Puzzles are just random or inane and your character's physics make their solving even worse. Player movements are slow and clunky. 
It looks like first project of author and the main problem is that the game is sold for money. Seriously, I would forgive the most flaws if game was free. Most, but still not all. I played many free games/mods/mappacks created by enthusiasts that have much better level design, atmosphere, storyline, puzzles, etc. And all they look like authors actually endeavored to make their creations better. I can't say same about Kairo. 
If you still bought this game, don't forget to change settings: remove this waste "grained effect" and unacceptable "look smoothing". Also don't forget to increase FOV (Field Of View), it seems like author does not know that many players feel sickness and headache because of small FOV.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028118165', 'num_games_owned': 939, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1389679306}
review:
Playing the game actually reminds me of "Excerpts from Expert Judgement on Markers to Deter Inadvertent Human Intrusion into the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant", which you can google and peruse at your leisure. What they talk about on the site is: after we dump a bunch of nuclear waste somewhere and seal it off, how do we signal to future generations that they should stay away? Given that the half-life of the waste in question is 10,000 years, about as long as recorded history, this poses a significant problem: how do we communicate with people who will likely be nothing like us, and have a very limited understanding of our language, society and history; how do we tell them that they should not hang out in or excavate this nuclear waste dump? The expert judgers come up with a series of sculptural and architectural edifices, things that imply danger and will last millennia, and each one is more bizarre, desolate and brutal than the last. 

A lot of what I see and do in Kairo feels like I'm interacting with someone's answer to that kind of question (although not about nuclear waste, specifically), which is extremely cool. 

It doesn't hurt that the puzzles are very good. Gameplay is mostly about observation, testing interactions and figuring out how things work. It's kind of like Riven in that regard, and so far I haven't run up against any versions of classically lazy puzzles. Which is to say: no sliding tile puzzles, no finding the bauble and sticking it into the mcdooly, no one-on/one-off puzzles where you try to get everything to sync up as on or off. The first step of every puzzle is figuring out its rules and its pieces, and then trying to understand what the end goal is. It's all very seamless, very understated, and very rewarding.

Highest recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064350349', 'num_games_owned': 767, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 603, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 603, 'last_played': 1402473522}
review:
Я неравнодушна ко всякого рода художественным эксперементам в играх. Огромные локации, поражающие масштабностью, довольно-таки жуткая атмосфера и на удивление логичные головоломки. Первые десять минут игры я не понимала, где я и что вообще происходит. Но после первой головомки все встает на место, потихоньку осознаешь происходящее, больше даже в воображении, потому что игра лишь намекает, немного приоткрывает завесу реальности. И вот кажется, что ты уже все более или менее понял, выстроил теорию... но открыв все двери, не покидает чувство, что ты смотришь в замочную скважину.
Здесь действительно нет никого, уже никого. Отличное место, чтобы вспомнить себя. И не спишите пользоваться прохождением. Все проще, чем кажется.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091891742', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 808, 'last_played': 1393443831}
review:
Kairo - проект крайне специфический, и непросто принять решение - рекомендовать данную игру к покупке или нет. Любителей спинномозговых шутеров, фанатов "графона как в Crysis", либо просто нетерпеливых игроков я призываю немедленно закрыть эту страницу, запустить любимый CoD или Battlefield и забыть о Kairo как о страшном сне.

Дело в том, что это [b]инди в квадрате[/b], это одна большая метафора, выполненная в простом, но в то же время завораживающем стиле. Здесь отсутствует сюжет в привычном понимании - суть происходящего преподносится в виде небольших "флешбеков", если хотите, после прохождения группы комнат. По большому счёту, сюжет здесь и не важен - он добавлен лишь для создания определённого настроения при прохождении. Не буду спойлерить, это нужно увидеть собственными глазами в определённые моменты.

Геймплей представляет собой игру от первого лица, основанную на решении пазлов. Последние, в свою очередь, иногда обескураживают своей алогичностью, и чем дальше по ходу игры, тем чаще. Мне сложно понять, чем руководствовались и вдохновлялись разработчики и левел-дизайнеры при их создании, но периодически возникает ощущение, будто нас специально задерживают в прохождении. Данный факт раздражает, поэтому я рекомендую найти прохождение на YouTube, открыть в фоне и время от времени сверяться с ним. Тем более, что в конце игры есть замечательная комната-пасхалка, выполнить условия для попадания в которую при обычном прохождении решительно невозможно.

От плохого к хорошему - звуковое сопровождение [b][i]великолепное[/i][/b]. Я прошёл Kairo уже очень давно, но некоторые фоновые треки прочно запали в душу, и я время от времени их переслушиваю. Медитативный эмбиент грамотно подобран к каждому помещению, он ненавязчивый, но в то же время составляет единое целое с самой архитектурой. Ни разу и нигде не возникло желания убавить/выключить звук, а это очень хороший показатель для игры.

Графическая составляющая, как сказано выше, простая, можно сказать, "рубленая". У каждой комнаты есть свой цвет и "настроение". Внутри обычно всё составлено из примитивных угловатых форм, но в сочетании с хорошим светом и музыкой, запоминается и выглядит законченно.

[i]Резюме: Kairo - игра на противоречиях. С одной стороны, мы имеем невзрачную графическую составляющую (с технической точки зрения), невнятные пазлы и отсутствие нормального разъяснения, что собственно тут происходит - всё это в совокупности может оттолкнуть многих игроков. С другой стороны, перед нами предстают интересные дизайнерские решения, действительно красивая, запоминающаяся музыка, и та самая потайная комната.
С какой стороны смотреть на Kairo - решать только вам. Мой стакан всегда наполовину полон :)[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561197998116681', 'num_games_owned': 3140, 'num_reviews': 597, 'playtime_forever': 1367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1367, 'last_played': 1401760225}
review:
Очередная претенциозная минималистичная туристическо-исследовательская головоломка про G.E.C.K. с redemption story. Половина задачек элементарна, другая подчиняется нечеловеческой логике, третья половина (потому что секретная) напоминает аналогичные задачки из FEZ, только здесь намного меньше мягких подсказок и целостности мира, чтобы их понять.

Внешне игра пытается быть стильно минималистичной, но больше похожа на неаккуратную и грязную. Тем более автор и сам это понимает, раз использовал эффект убитой плёнки по умолчанию. Текстуры очень тухлые и режущие глаз, постоянно видны места заполнения, да и общая гамма как-то не слишком приятна. По общей стилистике и качеству исполнения, на фоне этой игры даже первый Quake кажется царством радости, веселья и высокополигональя. А символы выполненные с помощью стандартных шрифтовых круглых скобок ")(" - вообще убожественны.
Внешний вид уровней так же безыдеен и угловат. Да и нельзя сказать что он стилистически выдержан. Он постоянно использует некоторые элементы оформления один раз и больше никогда не возвращается к ним. Некоторые комнаты выглядят аккуратно и вполне со вкусом, в то время другие наслаждаются откровенным супрематизмом, третьи пытаются выглядеть нормально, а четвёртые, пытаясь выглядеть нормально - радостно проваливают это и выглядят запредельно низкокачественно. Да и повсеместные следы разрушения и сколы больше относятся к реальному миру физических материалов, что очень контрастирует с местной сверхнизкополигональной абстракцией. В одном месте игра использует старую концепцию "дорога возникает под шагами идущего", в то время как хорошая игра из неё одной может построить всю стилистику целиком (Bastion).

История у игры про всякую типичную метафорическую хpень о падении человечества и всепрощении, но лучше бы игра оставалась абстрактной, так как всякие стандартные образы древних цивилизаций, дезоксирибонуклеиновой кислоты, химические схемы и фотографии Эйнштейна заезженны до смерти и, кроме того, совершенно не вписываются в окружение.

Достижения рабочие, картиночки - в одном стиле, с названиями авторы тоже поигрались. На прохождение и на сбор всех секретов. Достижение на поиск всех символов на стенах (исследовательское) находится в довольно странном положении. В нормальных играх такие обычно используют, чтобы игрок не пропускал особенно удачные места созданные планировщиками уровней и художниками: красивый вид, трагический элемент повествования вроде обнимающихся скелетов и прочее. Однако здесь не только смотреть особо нечего, так как всё одинаково нищенское и квадратное, но и сами символы зачастую спрятаны в самых дальних и пустых, унылых уголках. Так обычно делают не очень хорошие игры, чтобы: растянуть время игры и накрутить часы на тех, кто любит собирать все достижения; растянуть время игры и накрутить часы для тех, кто хочет поиграть подольше и ищет после прохождения дополнительных трудностей; или просто засунуть достижение ради достижения, так как это одна из самых нетребовательных для разработчика разновидностей в плане умственных затрат. Но в то же время можно сказать, что поиск символов помогает обнаружить тайные двери, которые подсказывают о дополнительных комнатах и "секретной концовке".

В целом игру можно порекомендовать только неприхотливым любителям туристическо-исследовательских игр, не гнушающихся супрематизма или неприхотливым любителям простеньких головоломок. Для остальных игроков: какое-то впечатление огромные размеры и псевдо-странные сцены могут и оставить, но нельзя сказать чтобы играть было прямо настолько уж интересно. Тем более на фоне Antichamber и прочих.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072118811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1383193852}
review: As much as I wanted to enjoy Kairo, I simply could not. There is nothing redeeming about it, in my opinion. The puzzles require extreme moon logic to figure out, and I managed to get through the game with no real understanding of what I was doing. I blindly stumbled through, hoping against hope that at some point, the confusion would clear up. It did not. I ended the game more confused than I started it, with a healthy helping of disappointment and bitterness to boot. Some may call the graphics abstract, unique, or elegantly minimalist; I call them lazy. They look unfinished and bland, as if the developers simply couldn't be bothered to polish them, and tried to pass this off as artistic choice. There are tantalizing hints of a story that never emerges, only a few little morsels here and there which, like a can containing only three potato chips, provides just enough taste to make you want more, only to be disappointed that you can't have any more. And no, the ending doesn't make anything clearer, or anything of that nature. If anything it'll just confuse you more. I sincerely regret spending my time and money on this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129275854', 'num_games_owned': 429, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1401062662}
review:
Kairo is an interesting, if ultimately slight, atmospheric puzzle game.  The artwork is all rectangles and circles and simple geometric shapes.  The music exists simply to generate atmosphere.  There is no "plot," but rather a series of puzzles that are to be completed simply because they exist.  The puzzles are generally fairly easy, although there are no real instructions and most of the puzzles require you to use your surroundings to figure out what to do.  In addition the "secret" puzzles are a pretty big step up in difficulty and will likely resort to the user having to consult a guide.

All of that said, the game succeeds with what it's trying to do.  The atmosphere is engrossing and engaging and the game is neither too easy or too difficult.  It's really a shame it was only 3-4 hours long, 'cause I think it could have been twice as long and not worn out its welcome.

Rating: 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198002391387', 'num_games_owned': 806, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1393194170}
review: I wanted a peaceful exploration/puzzle-solving game, and that's what Kairo gave me. Unfortunately I found the graphics extremely hard on my eyes - it triggered a lot of motion sickness and headaches for me. I also found some of the puzzles to be really, really obtuse and frustrating. There's also a total lack of a story, which was fine for me but might not be for you. If you're a genre fan, definitely give this a shot. If you're looking for something fast-paced and action-packed, look elsewhere

author: {'steamid': '76561198041020327', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1400860095}
review:
An absolutely incredible game... i loved it all the way through <3

Kairo is quiet and surreal, has incredible timing and pace, and constantly tickles your curiosity in order to compell you forward from each puzzle to the next. When the game is strange and alien, it is fascinating, but when it begins to hint at things familiar it turns creepy. The plot is revealed without ever resorting to the use of writing or words; a story told entirely through shapes, colors, and meaningfull images.

I cant believe this is only five dollars. I'll be watching these devolopers in the future to see what they come out with next... I will remember this game for awhile :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198096079278', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 158, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1400884035}
review: Wow! This game has me enthralled. Eerie, beautiful, mysterious, atmospheric; these are all words I would use to describe this game. I can't tell you how many times I had tingles go up and down my spine while playing. The sense of awe, dread, mystery, and alienation are all invoked and maintained by the environments and the soundtrack. This game is very heavy on the exploration and the puzzles are just about right in terms of difficulty. This game reminds me of the final sequence of 2001:A Space Odyssey when astronaut Dave Bowman went Beyond the Infinite. The landscapes you explore in this game seem like the sorts of experiences Dave might have had before becoming the Star Child. If you like exploring and figuring out puzzles based on strange alien technology, getting disoriented and unnerved by the overwhelming sense that perhaps you are not meant to be in the vast, stark spaces you find yourself in, then you should definitely get this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983722524', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1403250489}
review:
Un jeu d'énigmes en 3d assez doux avec son ambiance chill-out.
Tout architecte, étudiant en architecture ou simplement amateur par ex, de civilisation ancienne, peut chopper ce jeu;
ça lui fera une alternative psychédélique à son boulot...
Peut convenir aussi à des personnes peu habituées à jouer ou débutantes, c'est pas un jeu très compliqué et l'atmosphère y est paisible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032289388', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1398018848}
review: I played this for a while and... while there's nothing really WRONG with it, I've seen the same kind of concept done much better. The gameplay, for example, is much the same as Naissance - wander a mysterious environment, the purpose of which is unknown, solving abstract logic puzzles. But compared to the elegant beauty of that game, Kairo seems crude, and in some areas not even properly finished. Kairo is kinder to your wallet, but Naissance is a much more worthy investment of time.

review:
This will be my first game review ever. And I think this is the first game I aver played that is worth writhing a review about.

Long story short; dham this game is awsome.

I never played a game that is so simple and has so much impact on everything. It is the first game that realy make you feal lost, alone and tiny. No game has ever done that for me.
The graphics are not realy advanced but the atmosphere makes up for that. The "music", but maybe you should call it back ground noises, give you the impression that you are on an alian planet.

If you ever have seen the movie "cube" and liked it, then you also should like this game (minus the horror part). You are just left alone in an environment that you can not understand. By solving puzels je make your progress trough the levels, but you just don't know where you are going or why you are here.

My verdict 10 out of 10 and realy worth the money

author: {'steamid': '76561198041984970', 'num_games_owned': 1266, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1399807574}
review:
As far as abstract-puzzle-FPS go, it is a great game. You truly feel like being in a dreamlike world (or a nightmarish one if you are scared of loneliness and desolation) where you even lose track of time. Sure the whole thing looks bleak and unfriendly but you are drawn into it with a deep sense of serenity. Such titles (with the likes of Dear Esther) are rare and valuable for it.

The sound design is excellent and the ideas are great. The vast and empty landscapes are sometimes a bit overwhelming at first but it is part of the experience. The puzzles are never frustrating thanks to the tips that are hidden away in the menu.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987093311', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1400550033}
review: This is the sort of atmospheric adventuring I love. Massive, enigmatic structures filled with challenging (but not too frustrating) puzzles. Awakening new areas, adding their energies and mechanics to the overall world as it all comes alive. A simple map develops along the way, and the game has a 3-tiered hint system for each puzzle area, just in case a nudge in the right direction is needed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026669780', 'num_games_owned': 846, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1399631790}
review:
На первый взгляд незамысловатый Каир не такой замысловатый, как кажется. Его невозможно понять, не имея и малейшего общего представления о нити развития науки о жизни, отражающей мысли и идеи разных времён и народов, тенденции развития нашей расы. Вместе с историей, Каир показывает вероятное развитие будущих событий. Это то, о чём знает любой фантаст. Это то, чего боится любой геополитик. Но это тут. И нам дан шанс всё исправить.

Каир - атмосферная бродилка с головоломками и сюжетом, передаваемым только символически. В нём также отличная визуальная и звуковая составляющие, но вам не придётся делать ничего, кроме как ходить, прыгать и думать. Постоянно думать.

Низкая цена не означает, что можно броситься за покупкой прямо сейчас, потому что хочется попробовать. Вы, возможно, обрадуете разработчика, но разочаруетесь сами, если поймёте, что игра не для вас.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002360985', 'num_games_owned': 1180, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 869, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 829, 'last_played': 1503210940}
review:
ゲームを始めると、無機質で幻想的な映像の世界にいきなり放り投げられて、どこに行くべきか、何をするかさえ分からないが、実はパズル主体のゲーム。
各部屋は一体どういうパズルかすら一切伝えられないが、移動したり何かを動かして反応するものをヒントにすると見えてくる。
だが救済処置として、ポーズ画面のメニューでも各部屋のヒントが文章で出るし、読んでも特にペナルティは無い。

私は始めてから2日目でエンディングにたどり着いたが、その時点でまだ解いてないパズルや実績も残っていた。
そのヒントはどこにあるか、今度は今まで歩いてきた全マップのどこかにあり、それを探さないといけない。言ってみれば、一度クリアしてからが本番。

ゲームとしては徹底して突き放しているが、その中での見せ方、伝え方、パズルもクリアまでは難しすぎず、クリア後は徹底して考えさせる。その考えさせ方、楽しませ方が絶妙。

author: {'steamid': '76561198082868163', 'num_games_owned': 940, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1399525134}
review:
Monoliths, glyphs, runes, buttons to step on... Kairo.

For every step you take in this lonely world, you find yourself seemingly stuck and lost within yourself as well. Film grain covers your field of vision as you navigate the towers, solving a wide plethora of puzzles, from simple navigation of a simple maze to interpreting a star map just to open a door to running on treadmills, Kairo does the puzzle genre justice by infusing complex and mind-boggling puzzles towards a simplistic, minimalist world. The colours are beautiful, the gameplay is relatively solid (although I personally find the movement a little too sensitive) and this is really immersive by itself (if you play in a dark room with headphones).

A drawback for me personally was that I found myself getting lost most of the time, that I was unable to have a good view of the puzzle I'm trying to solve. Like a rat in a maze, I could not see the big picture of the puzzle and I had to keep walking in circles trying to figure out what I've done, even resorting to sketching out some rooms on a piece of paper and drawing the various interactive elements on the paper so I can figure out what in the world is going on. It does interrupt the flow of the game for me sometimes and it was a little distracting to the overall feel of the game.

In short, despite the few rough edges of this work of art, Kairo is really a beautiful gameset (with its fair share of really, really creepy elements and depictions here and there), really meant for the casual player to play and enjoy this surreal world, while unraveling a terrible tale that led to this place. If you're a puzzle nut and you enjoy creepy, lonely worlds, Kairo really is the place for you to be.

Eurogamer has succiently highlighted the deep spine of Kairo. "Kairo is mysterious and elegant and powerfully distinct. Like Fez and Minecraft, it will work your way into your dreams if you're not careful."

Play at your own risk, because Kairo does leave impressions in your mind as you play it, with the wide rooms and chilling images (when you stumble upon some seemingly "dead ends") and huge, huge glyphs.

To this casual gamer's opinion:
Kairo: 7.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198082574081', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 631, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 545, 'last_played': 1400213132}
review: The prime description of this game says it’s a minimalistic puzzle game yet I find the so called minimalistic environments rich. The spaces between rooms and puzzles are huge as if done with a XYZ co-ordinate modeller on steroids, the actual puzzles themselves more artifact than steam punk but richer in detail than the beautiful rooms travelled to get to them. Great art and even better music are at play in this game as well as symbols and language. Portal players used to traversing a room by entering one portal and exiting another already across the room may at find the game at time a bit walk intensive but the journey is the thing. Has some non-Euclidean feel as in Antechamber and a discovery feel as in Riven. For the current price of just ~$5 get and play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012363945', 'num_games_owned': 2117, 'num_reviews': 404, 'playtime_forever': 1114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1517160767}
review:
A real brain teaser this one. Does not tell you anything - you are not even sure who you are and if it's all just some weird dream. No dialogue anywhere in the game and the first character you encounter is not in the shape to tell much stories.  

'Minimalistic explorer' is what i have heard this being called and it's pretty accurate. Games like this dont really exist and nobody makes them yet i think this one was fun right of the bat and it was able to steer clear of the X-files/lost type of cliffhanger and then nothing -type of clichees that i was expecting to pop-up at some point. so i'll give this one 9/10 - As a minimalistic explorer w/puzzles to solve.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061689411', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1402159127}
review:
So, yeah, how do I describe Kairo?
First, the puzzles. While they start out easy, later in the game, they are really counter intuitive(At least the devs had the idea of including hints).
I was stuck on the last "world", not even because I was stuck on a puzzle, but I simply didn't knew what puzzle was left to do.
Not to mention the optional puzzles that lead to the secret ending(which is just stupid and feel more like a filler than rewarding) are even harder and are simply undo-able without a guide. Also, they require backtracking.

The graphics are both basic and good, and the game run very well on low end computers(Even with shaders on). Though the environments are sometimes too lazy and blocky. The ambient music is also great, and give a mood to each "room".

The "story"... Okay, I just don't get it. Kairo use a lot of morbid symbols, post-apocalyptic pictures, etc, but it never feel more than an assemblage of tropes("Oh, look how creepy is this place! So creppy, huh???") rather than a mysterious story. So don't buy this game for the story.

In short, if you are okay with using a guide/the hints for the puzzles, then you could buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005648447', 'num_games_owned': 5285, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1398378787}
review:
Kairo propose une aventure par l'exploration et la résolution de puzzles à la première personne. À travers des environnements abstraits et visuellement dépouillés, par l'exploration de salles reliées autour de plusieurs hubs - certaines salles sont justes là pour faire la transition entre les autres, quand elles ne proposent pas d'énigmes. Les énigmes sont visuelles, mémorielles et résolubles en se déplaçant uniquement ou en observant, puisqu'il n'y a pas de touches d'action. En soi ce n'est pas un problème, et c'est tout de suite rafraichissant, après-tout, exit les guns et les puzzles-jump (clin d'oeil à la série Portal), voilà bien un concept sympa, si l'on attend un level design qui suit.

Or la principale difficulté reviendra à chercher ce que la salle nous demande de faire, et s'il existe bien une interaction tangible. En effet, dans la première catégorie de puzzles du jeu les énigmes sont extrêmement simplistes une fois que l'on a compris ce qui nous a été demandé : on mémorise des symboles et on marche dessus, on marche sur d'autres dans ordre particulier ou l'on circule dans un espace labyrinthique, etc. Pour la deuxième catégorie de puzzle (facultatifs pour la plupart), ils sont impossibles sans un guide, puisqu'il n'existe aucun indice dans le jeu indiquant les patterns nécessaires à la résolution des puzzles, si ce n'est de tatonner parmis une pléthore d'essais. À dire vrai, j'ai commencé à regarder dans un guide car j'étais bloqué dans une de ses fameuses salles (2 sont nécessaires tout de même pour atteindre la fin du jeu). Et vous savez ce qui est drôle ? C'est que l'auteur du guide n'y voit lui-même aucune logique derrière l'explication de ces puzzles contre-intuitifs et abstraits à souhait. Oui oui, les développeurs ont donc visuellement cherché à rendre difficile artificiellement la résolution de problèmes par les difficultés à l'esprit humain de distinguer des cohérences et des indices parmi un dédale de zones abstraites et confuses et dont la direction artistique - qui pourquoi pas, propose un cadre psychédélique amusant - ne sert parfois ni le gameplay, ni le propos, voire, n'y proposent pas de solutions.

Et en parlant de propos et de direction artistique, on a l'impression de se balader dans un musée d'art contemporain dont l'architecte aurait auparavant absorbé de nombreuses substances illicites. On affiche des images post-apocalyptiques par ci, des architectures improbables branlette-arty et une ambiance sonore et visuelle "creepy" qui cherche à mettre particulièrement mal à l'aise ("tu as vu les cercueils sans nom ? et la salle des caméras et ce squelette qui te regardait depuis le début ? tr0p d4rk"). Trop de symbolisme tue le symbolisme, surtout si ce pot-pourri de références (animaux pour l'arche de Noé ? un phare pour quoi faire ?) n'amène à aucune conclusion que ce soit, nous laissant de marbre devant un néant absolu de signification et un degré d'abstraction brûlant ce qui nous reste de neurones. Ha, et je n'ai même pas parlé des mécanismes cachés obscurs amenant à une fin secrète dans une salle des développeurs, nous suggérant leur travail ou probablement pour afficher un poème nébuleux et un au final un gag qui dure deux secondes. Heureusement, tout ça ne dure pas bien longtemps puisqu'il faudra une poignée d'heures pour finir le jeu à 100%.

Non vraiment, ce jeu doit trop être intellectuel et arty pour moi, je n'ai pas du avoir saisi tout le talent de nos amis les développeurs ...

author: {'steamid': '76561198077223900', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 518, 'last_played': 1402527612}
review:
Gra bardzo intrygująca. Oszczędna w grafice i dźwiękach, ale tworzy niesamowity klimat i daje odczucie osamotnienia.
Wędrujemy po dziwnej pustej krainie. Są w niej tylko budynki-wyspy, w których poprzez rozwiązywanie zagadek logicznych uzyskujemy dostęp do kolejnych obszarów.
Wędrując po tych odosobnionych budynkach-wyspach odkrywamy mroczne tajemnice tego pustego świata, zdobywamy osiągnięcia i odnajdujemy ukryte symbole i monolity.
Gra jest godna polecenia.

Very intriguing game. Creators spared various graphics and sounds, but the title creates an amazing atmosphere and gives the feeling of loneliness.
We are wandering on strange empty land. There are only "the island-buildings", on which by solving puzzles, we gain access to new areas.
While great adventure we are discovering the dark secrets of this world, gaining achievements and also finding hidden symbols and monoliths.
Game is totally worth recommending.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002139609', 'num_games_owned': 508, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1398192122}
review:
An experience I'd recommend everyone trying.
Put aside thoughts of '2deep4me' when looking at this game because the challenging puzzles and the game's many secrets are the main attraction.
Kairo's atmosphere is perfectly crafted. Despite not being a horror game, you can expect to get shivers down your spine when coming across new areas and interacting with the many objects within the game's world.
Speaking of Kairo's world, as you solve more puzzles and discover hidden secrets the world around you evolves to further signify what you've achieved. 
This is truely a wonderful puzzle game.
Many thanks to Sorun for sharing the steam key to this game. I probably would have never came across Kairo otherwise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068254230', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1398101518}
review:
I wouldn't call it exactly a game. Yet it's not just a 3d-puzzle. It's more like a piece of meditative experience offered to a player. Strongly reminds me of some other studios' works which seem to be half-games and half-art objects: Tale of Tales and their Fatale, Ice-Pick Lodge and their Tension, and so on. 
Some could find Kairo's atmosphere uncomfortable or even creepy, but for me it worked quite alright. The sound suits really well to grim and lonely landscapes. The puzzles aren't too... puzzling, but are sometimes really fun to solve. 
Secret rooms and hidden bonuses included.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035285721', 'num_games_owned': 5109, 'num_reviews': 1098, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1397774102}
review: Alltogether Kairo isn't seriously a real game. It's more like a playable art project. And it supports as one of the first demos OR, but what doesn't count anymore (FB fucked that up). Even without OR you become sick of this weird spinning graphics in fisheye optic. It seems they used somekind of Doom1 engine to render all the pseudo 3D objects. Minecraft has more details than this. The psychadelic colors in each room doesn't make it better. You begin this game and have no plan what to do. No instructions, no hints. Just get lost in the labrinth of colored rooms and corridors. The hidden multimedia clips are creepy also the threaten atmosphere. But why asking of any sense? Art is as better as more senseless it is. Don't buy it directly. If it's in a bundle added, it's OK.
