author: {'steamid': '76561198046139420', 'num_games_owned': 248, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1026, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 708, 'last_played': 1399808634}
review:
殺風景だけど不思議な世界を歩いてパズルを解いていくゲームです。
LSDっぽいという噂をきいて購入しました。残念ながらLSDのように愉快な感じではないですが、雰囲気はとてもよいです。
単純なボリューム的には値段相応といった感じです。

はじめは全くなにも情報もないまま異世界に放り出された気分になりますが、よく探索すれば必要な情報はきちんと与えられており、詰まってもヒントが用意されている親切設計です。
大掛かりな仕掛けが動くパズルは見ていてロマンを感じます。

音楽も本体の倍するサントラにちょっと興味が沸くぐらいにはよいです。
ただ、全体的に鬱々とした感じなので合わない人もいるかもしれません。

author: {'steamid': '76561198045796166', 'num_games_owned': 1054, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1397037828}
review:
This game makes me feel like I was inside the dreams of a weird engineer/architect. It is great how it can give you so much with so bare materials. You walk around huge constructions, trying to make sense of it. And then you realize you are the life inside these dead empty endless halls.

Kairo begins with a throne in the middle of nowhere. You're alone, there's nothing. But "nothing" becomes something tangible, you begin to think about nothingness. You enter this nothingness, this void, and find many things there. Things buried, forgotten. Other thrones, kings, or perhaps other times of the same reign. But you are the king of a dead and empty realm. Are you alone. There is a world out there and you do not have access to it. There is life, and all you see are images, codes, machines, mementos.

Could the machines drive you back to life? Where does this light leads? Where does this flow leads? Where will you go? Who built it? For what purpose? Where are you really? Maybe in a hospital bed, waiting to wake up. I enjoyed every minute of this trip. I did not understand almost anything, but what I did was enough to make the trip worthwhile.

This game is about second chances. You move from a lifeless place to a garden with flowing life. It is really about coming back to life, so it is another game that helped me recover. It is amazing how this message is there without the need of any word. It is a memorable experience.

Positive points
* A very trippy and weird experience.
* Logical puzzles that you solve without any instruction.

Negative points
* Very easy to get lost.
* Looks empty and random.
* The above are all part of the experience...

author: {'steamid': '76561197981180878', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1396801328}
review:
Kairo is a first person puzzle-game that made me go "Where the heck am I supposed to go?"

It's a cryptic game, really is. There are secrets runes hidden all over the game along the road of its many puzzles.
There is no way to die in the game besides falling off, but you don't really die - it just sends you back from where you fell.

It's a lonely experience with its ambience and ..if you can even call it music.
There are weird things happening here and there...

...but the game has the best coffee ad you'll ever see.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086151669', 'num_games_owned': 438, 'num_reviews': 181, 'playtime_forever': 83, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1374521370}
review:
Si tiramos de retórica sofista, y ya saben ustedes lo que me gusta a mi tirar de retórica sofista, Kairos representa “el momento adecuado para hacer algo”. Aristóteles lo llevaría a su terreno y lo encajó dentro de la oratoria política como el “momento y el contexto adecuado en el que la prueba debe entregarse”. Aristóteles no era un mal tipo del todo, y lo que él definía como prueba de ese argumento irrefutable que dicho en el contexto y momento adecuado dejaba a tu adversario con el culo torcido y sin saber qué decir, Kairo, el Kairo de Richard Perrin, lo desarrolla como discurso, añadiendo un tercer elemento que he decidido llamar “el yo argumental” PORQUE TENGO ESTUDIOS. Vale, esta crítica no va ser sencilla, pero es que telita con Kairo.

Ante tanta vacuidad en el primer párrafo, sentemos un par bases para que ustedes y yo tengamos claro de lo que estamos hablando: Kairo es bonito, tiene puzles y es un juego. No estamos ante una propuesta narrativa y sensorial como podría ser Dear Esther.

Perrin nos muestra un mundo donde hay elementos con los que interactuar, acertijos que resolver y algo parecido a un avance, lo cual encaja bastante bien en la definición de “juego”. Otra cosa es que todo lo que nos presente tenga tantas lecturas que pueda joderle la cabeza.

Siguiendo con la representación simple de su planteamiento, podríamos decir que Kairo nos presenta una serie de salas de distinta arquitectura en las que tendremos que resolver rompecabezas no demasiado claros, pero tampoco demasiado complejos. Entender el que hay que hacer nos llevará más tiempo que hacerlo, lo cual supongo que podría definirse como una suerte de pre-rompecabezas. Estas salas no se representan bajo un tratamiento lineal, y tendremos a nuestra disposición todas o la mayoría de ellas al comienzo de cada nivel (y eso de decir nivel aquí sí que es ambiguo). El tratamiento de estas salas está realizado desde un tratamiento arquitectónico sencillo, pero con una identificación de cada una de las estancias muy marcada, utilizando una gama de colores básicos diferente en cada una de ellas. Si hablamos de su diseño nos encontramos con un diseño limpio de geometrías sencillas que ayudan a dar fuerza al elemento de manipulación del “yo tangible”, y toca explicarlo.


Todo lo que podamos hacer en una sala es sencillo de hacer. Los botones son grandes, los elementos a pulsar, a arrastrar o colocar son perfectamente identificables en una primera observación. Kairo usa estos elementos para evitar la sensación de irrealidad que emana el título y trasladarnos a un “yo físico” dentro de su realidad. Algunos puzles se resuelven simplemente con nuestro movimiento, como esos totems que se separan o juntan de sí mismos según la dirección en la que estemos caminando. Kairo recalca que nuestra presencia en ese universo es necesaria para el funcionamiento del mismo. Nunca sabremos donde nos encontramos o quién o qué construyó esas salas.

Kairo renuncia al concepto Portal de “pruebas diseñadas para usted” abrazando el “usted está aquí y por eso esto existe”

El conjunto artístico de Kairo quedaría incompleto si no reservamos un espacio para su sonido, el cual sirve tanto para ambientar como para la resolución de puzles. Su elaboración sigue las pautas de su arquitectura, siendo en la mayoría de los casos sonidos de corte sencillo y si me apuran “tecnológico”. En un juego que basa su discurso en el poder de comprensión del jugador, el sonido ha de tener un papel narrativo y Kairo juega con ese papel dando pistas constantes de si lo que estamos haciendo está bien o no. Su integración con los demás elementos se produce a base de mensajes estáticos o voces lejanas incompresibles que nunca llegamos a escuchar correctamente, componiendo una banda sonora tan singular como el resto del título.

Richard Perrin ha creado una experiencia única en la que un servidor se lamenta de su pobre conocimiento arquitectónico y maldice no entender el significado conceptual de las cadenas de ADN que sobrevuelan alguna sala. La sensación de que no estaba a la altura de lo que Perrin pretendía contarme me acompañó durante todo mi viaje, y sin embargo he disfrutado mucho con Kairo. Mucho más una vez han pasado un par de días desde que lo acabé. Quizá nunca llegue a entender lo que Perrin quiso decirme, pero me gustó cómo lo dijo. Quizá haya que aceptar esta rara avis como lo que es: un extraño universo explorable al que llegas en el momento adecuado para hacer algo.

review:
First off: huge problem with Kairo is that all the architecture is basically straight lines, sharp corners, everything looked the same, really boring for a game that kinda relies on its aesthetics.

I got this in a bundle, and that's how much I think it's really worth. It's a pretty game, but not pretty enough for a game whose merit at first glance is just that - being pretty. Numerous graphical glitches, the far-from-smooth movement and controls made for a miserable experience for me. It is very atmospheric I'll give it that, but apart from that the clunky movement, okay-ish design and graphics, and inconsistent puzzles really killed this game for me.

Added: Followed a guide to get the final achievements, now I realize why I found it not pretty at all for this kind of slow paced atmospheric game! The architecture is all really blocky, sharp edges throughout the [u]whole[/u] game. Realized after completing the game why I got tired of it so fast.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078378071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1644979124}
review: If you're a myst fan then this will be right up your alley. Stepping out into to the monolithic environments of Kairo is akin to stepping out onto that dock in myst for the first time. Kairo is able to conjur up an atmosphere of loneliness and mystery that really sticks with you the whole game. While basically a walking simulator, there where times that I was simply awestruck by the towering structures and deep shadows the dominate its barren landscape. Aparrently it has oculus support as well, which put this first on the list of things i'm going to play when I finally have the funds to join the VR club. Kairo is also a very decent puzzler, requiring you to pay close attencion to your surroundings in order to peice everything together. While a few of the puzzles can get rather abstract, I never found myself stuck becuase of a handy hint system you can use to cheat if ever need be. For the price you can get it at, this game delivers a unique experience that you won't find anywhere else. I'd highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys atmosphere and immersion, and doesn't mind being stumped by a puzzle from time to time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042053286', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 587, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 587, 'last_played': 1394067120}
review:
From the moment the game begins to the ending sequence, Kairo's atmosphere remains powerful and unique. The world feels vast and lonely, but far from empty. The world is strange and yet eerily familiar, and the puzzles keep you involved in the goal. You can spend hours exploring the numerous rooms, each with its own atmosphere and function.
     Very simple controls stop you from playing the guessing game on how to interact with things, so that the focus can be on the environment and puzzles that surround you. The music and atmospheric sounds add to the vast and lonely feeling of the world, and some elements you come across can send shivers down your spine.
     If you're one for getting lost in an atmosphere, this is a game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041550021', 'num_games_owned': 1585, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1393887571}
review:
I really wanted to like this game. I absolutely love "artsy" games like this. However, there were several problems that tainted the experience for me.

Puzzles - They are counter-intuitive. While some puzzles make sense and are easy to figure out, others don't. For example, the puzzle at the back of the light house where you step on certain blocks seemed entirely random.

Movement, view, and mouse control - The extremely smooth movement in combination with narrow point of view made me feel sick to my stomach within 10 minutes. The lag between when I moved my mouse in comparison to when the character moved certainly didn't help, but that may have just been caused by my machine.

Broken pause menu - Again, this may have just been my machine, but during the pause menu, there was no way to select any options. I could only exit the pause menu by hitting escape. When I wanted to quit the game, I had to alt-tab and force close it. Being able to access the options may have been able to fix my previous complaint.

Empty textures - Textures and objects seemed empty and incomplete. I know that is the art style this game is going for, but it still seems very unpolished.

Sound - In games like this, sound effects and music need to take advantage of the atmosphere. I found most of the sound effects were cheesy and took away from the experience. For example, the cheap MIDI gong sound whenever you made progress in a puzzle is just awful. A lot of the time, there was too much silence, or just unvarying static, that could have benefited greatly with ambient music. During the few moments that ambient music was present, it seemed immaturely written and distracting.

I think that covers about everything I found poorly done in this game. Luckily, I bought it on sale and obtained a foil card so I have already made my money back. I really do want to enjoy this game and am disappointed that I didn't, since it seems like an interesting idea and I liked the lonely atmosphere. I will try it again if/when there is ever an update to see if any of these issues were fixed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971877162', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 310, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1395396174}
review:
I don't normally play exploration games.  Kairo is probably the closest thing to immersion that I wanted from a puzzle/exploration game besides the Myst series.  The music is the most immersive aspect of Kairo. It will bring you into this world.  

It should be noted that there is no spoken dialogue or text to read. You start off in this world and have to figure out where to go and what to do. The puzzles aren't terribly difficult. The hardest one for me so far only took 20 minutes to solve.  

I'm still playing this pretty awesome game for 5 bucks but I can already say it's worth a buy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025844122', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 656, 'last_played': 1393133973}
review: I have to write a review for this game while it's fresh in my mind.  Kairo is every bit as fun and eerie as you would want a 3D puzzle game to be.  Do yourself a favor and play this game alone and uninterrupted for a full immersive feel.  There are no verbal cues - as in you will never have another character speak to you, and you will never hear your own character talk.  There aren't any written cues or instructions beyond symbols you find (and of course the gentle hints in your menu screen, should you need them).  It's all about using the landscape and the machines and puzzles to your advantage - to a visual person like me, this was a wonderful experience.  Each different area in the game has its own color scheme and chosen background music and sounds from one of the game's tracks (the music is great for the game and ranges from "Fairly soothing and enlightening", to "I feel like someone just shoved ice down the back of my shirt").  In terms of graphics, it's not exactly, say, "Skyrim" in terms of detail or texture - but that honestly works well for the game.  The maker of this game knew what he was doing and while it's a little rough around the edges in some regards (I guess) the game is -solid- in the graphics department to me.  It feels like the great machines are actually working next to you.  That you're standing next to sources of great power, or that you're standing next to a row of...  Well you'll see (I really do love the architecture in some parts).  I completed the main storyline and some of the extra content without any help, but admit that I did need some help from the Steam Community to unlock the rest (there is one particular "bonus" puzzle that actually demands that you seek outside help in order to solve it).  Lastly I want to talk about the storyline - There is a lump that forms in the pit of your stomach once you start realizing where this game is going and the gravity of what has already happened and the gravity of what you might actually be doing.  It was mentioned already, but once you're done with the game (as it contains heavy spoilers), check out "The Secret of Kairo" on Electron Dance's blog if you want to read into some good theories behind the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027883639', 'num_games_owned': 2517, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1393098314}
review:
Meh. Non avevo grandi aspettative, ma fa abbastanza schifo sinceramente. Dovrebbe essere un puzzle game, ma gl'ambienti sono davvero troppo minimali con una grafica molto datata, i puzzle dal canto loro sono complicati, spesso non si capisce neanche bene che bisogna fare (non esistono dialoghi o istruzioni), si va un po' a casaccio per tutto il tempo. 
Ci sono i collezionabili, sotto forma di rune, ma anche questi sono nascostissimi e occorre una vita per trovarne uno.
Non sono riuscito ad apprezzarlo mi sono fermato verso la decima stanza, sinceramente a me sembra una alpha di un gioco del 2000, con qualche enigma.

VOTO: 3/10

review:
[b]Honiric 3D Puzzle Adventure! [KAMGUSTA's REVIEW][/b]

I must say I am torn in calling it a "game": it is more like a tech demo for Oculus Rift rather than a full fledged game. Or maybe you can consider it a piece of art thanks to his honiric atmosphere made of abstract buildings, strange obelisks, floating stairways and often one-colour tinted rooms. I am also torn in recommending it.

Aim of the game? You start outside a strange building and you have to find the secrets it hides inside... There is no inventory, no weapons, no HUD, no text, no help, only you. Music is relaxing and puzzles do not require a lot of thinking, letting you progress nicely in the game (unfortunately not very long: about 4 hours).

I think it is an awesome experience with Oculus Rift, but on PC it didn't catch me at all. Boring!

[b]Best played with Keyboard and Mouse (and Oculus Rift)
Recommended Buy Price < 3$
Score 6/10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198057682951', 'num_games_owned': 513, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1449736002}
review:
There are no enemies
There are no upgrades
There is no crosshair
There is no quest
There is nothing to guide you but the map in the pause screen

The atmosphere created is 10/10, very sureal and unsettling at times. Like other top reviews say, this reminds me of a weird M.C. Esther-esque Gone Home/Myst/Antichamber. The exploration is unforced, the puzzles are challenging and they require thought. The player instantly understands what a puzzle is about when they start trying to solve it. The game has a certain charm about it that I love.

Also the default controls are shit, make sure the sensitivity is waaaaay down. Even if it is, expect major frame rate drops during puzzle rooms and ESSPECIALLY in the Lighthouse Hub (the 2nd picture), It wasn't even over 30 fps at times in that room.

Great game, 8.5/10, needs better controls and better performance. Gameplay is flawless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022220032', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1390268908}
review:
This is a small, excelent exploration game. The art is very minimalist and surreal, very blocky in a braod sense, on purpose, and each screen or level is dominated by a color, which permeates everything in said level.

The puzzles are mostly "positioning" puzzles, in which you solve them by standing in a specific position or having to take certain path (but they are very logic and easy to understand), by having to push here and there some objects, just moving against them (there is no "action/manipulate" button), or by pressing some buttons in certain order. The atmosphere is mostly relaxing, but there are a few spooky or strange moments as well.

There is no rush, no sense of urgency, so you can stroll at your leisure through the many blocky landscapes. If you try to solve all puzzles by yourself, it could take about 6+ hours of game. If you follow a walkthrough, you could rush through it in a couple hours, but it would be a shame. There is also no manual save, but the game saves often as you reach a new area or solve some puzzle or find something noteworthy.

This game is ideal to relax or slow down a bit. Higly recommended

review: An extremely underrated game -- period. This game boasts a power to enthrall and captivate you, without needing an actual story the game almost speaks to you on a mystical level. The puzzles aren't easy but not too difficult, and there are very creative ideas put into it. The game also has intresting architecture and mysterious entities. It is a game that pulls you out of reality and puts you into this weird, but neat sublime world. I would say that this game is kinda like a more linear based LSD: Dream Simulator for the PS1 with puzzles. They both provoke unique mystery in an intresting and meaningful way. author: {'steamid': '76561198089817884', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1691456915}
review:
Kairo just seems like it was made for VR. The best way to describe is it is a Myst like experience where you travel through enormous rooms and areas that are large puzzles to figure out. There's no weaponry, no enemies unless you count the puzzles and you pretty much cannot die (falling off ledges just puts you back on the ledge). Each room is dominated by a simple color scheme and the architecture is large and blocky as giving the environment an ancient feel.

When played on a normal monitor, the simple graphics and plain architecture might seem like a negative. However, you activate VR, put on the Rift and you realize these graphics are now a strength. Just as Valve Steam Dev Days demo showed, so long as you keep latency low and frame rate high even a simple environment will seem real. Kairo delivers on this concept in spades. The large throne rooms, invisible maze arena, hollow pyramids, giant light orb and many other breathtaking sites fill this game. The slow pace and not too mind bending puzzles mean you're seeing new areas yet have plenty of time to appreciate each one. The sounds are different for each location and all are relaxing and never seem to be over bearing or painfully loud. There are a few cases where the sudden movement of the environment surprised me, but never did I feel the need to pull out of the game. The presence is strong and even with lengthy gameplay I did not notice much if any in the way of nausea. The frame rate seems great throughout with only one room (the one with four treadmills) showing lag.

Like Dear Esther, I play this game standing up and do the fake foot walk to aid in my immersion. The look is not tied to the control movement so it's easy to look around and enjoy the environment as you travel through. Its very easy to get drawn into the game and forget that you're in your room playing a game.

People probably have missed that this is a VR game as it does not seem to have the "VR Support" tag in the Steam search function. I've written the author and asked if he can get that added. As I said, for only $5 you're getting several hours of a great VR experience. A perfect game for those that prefer relaxed gameplay over the horror or shooter style games currently listed with VR support.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012748296', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1390065677}
review:
Need a break?

Welcome to the strange, yet simple and relaxing world of Kairo. It's a world filled with many ambiances, many puzzles, and many secrets.
The gameplay is that simple, reduced to only movements, triggers activating by just pushing or walking passed them. Most of the puzzles also aren't difficult, with hints provided in the menu if you need some help. Though, some secrets are pretty hard to find or solve, and you might want to pass them if you don't want to spend a lot of time on them.
But what makes Kairo different is the collection of ambiances and places, some people might see them like poetry, despite the lack of plot. Of course you will have a hard time enjoying this if you seek action.

Overall, its a nice, short, but most importantly relaxing game.
Be careful though, despite the quite simple graphics, it seems the game needs quite the resource, and you don't have many graphic options to help it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118131858', 'num_games_owned': 871, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 594, 'last_played': 1390324804}
review:
J'ai un avis mitigé sur ce jeu.
D'un côté, j'ai trouvé le concept original, c'est un alien comparé aux autres jeux d'aventure que je connais.

Graphismes cubiques et épurés, atmosphère sonore qui donne à ce monde une ambiance mystérieuse et parfois angoissante.
Difficile de commenter l'histoire ou le "but" général du jeu, c’est aussi bizarre que tout le reste.

Par contre, premier point négatif : à mes yeux, il est quasiment impossible de terminer ce jeu sans utiliser des aides extérieures (tels des guides/walkthrough) rien que pour trouver toutes les runes par exemple. A moins qu'on veuille y passer des heures et explorer chaque pièce en long, en large et en travers. En clair, faire preuve d'une patience que je n'ai, je l'avoue, pas eu.
Heureusement, les énigmes principales sont un peu plus simples si on arrive à en comprendre le but et les astuces, ce qui nous permet dans ce cas d'avancer dans le jeu. 

Deuxième point négatif : qu'est-ce qu'on peut marcher... Certes, c'est un jeu d'exploration mais même si la possibilité de "courir" nous est offerte, la vitesse n'est pas forcément grandiose et le temps peut souvent paraître très long. 

Troisième point semi-négatif : on ne peut pas enregistrer nous-même la partie au cours du jeu. C'est le jeu qui le fait automatiquement mais pas forcément au moment où on le désire. Mieux vaut finir une énigme avant de quitter si on ne veut pas avoir de mauvaise surprise.

Au final, je ne me suis pas beaucoup amusée en jouant à ce jeu donc je ne lui mettrai pas une note positive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080061662', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1390755886}
review: Possibly the weirdest thing I've come across. That's no bad thing. The level design is stunning and often makes you feel insignificant, the puzzles are challenging and require a decent amount of thought, but also aren't impossibly hard. But above all, the mystery in this game is it's strong point. It leaves you to think about what it could possibly be trying to show you, and never explains anything. That's why it's so interesting. For the price, this game is definitely worth your attention.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034312565', 'num_games_owned': 379, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1388995026}
review:
Interesting little game. It walks a bit of a line between games like Antichamber, Myst and Fez, where the environment is all you have to direct you through the puzzles and the world. While the visuals and puzzles are interesting, I don't think they match up to the standard of those three titles. There are a few great ones scattered and some secret content hidden throughout, bringing a game that is overall pretty fulfilling for a puzzle gamer. The later optional puzzles in particular are really quite difficult and I was unable to complete most of them without external help, speaking as somebody who completed Antichamber and all but two puzzles in Fez without needing to do so.

The sound and visuals work well together to build a nice atmosphere; the screenshots on the steam store speak for themselves. The mystery in the game starts to build up quite nicely as the game goes on, although I felt left wanting more of a final payoff. 

A decent title for 4 hours or so, but only worth getting if you have already played and enjoyed both Antichamber and Fez, as I would say they are better games with similar audiences. It is not easy to find competent examples of freeform world puzzlers like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993044303', 'num_games_owned': 1364, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1388770972}
review: If exploration and atmosphere dont matter to you much you can stop reading here and ignore the game completely. If you are like me and appreciate that kind of game Kairo is certainly worth buying. Atmosphere is superb, with every location being unique in its own right yet fitting overall alien feel of this world. Exploration is rewarded with lots of easy to miss details hidden around most locations. To me weakest part of the game were puzzles, while most of them fit perfectly into the theme of each room they were too easy. All in all if you like exploration based games it is great game if you dont like this kind of thing avoid it like plague.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062269122', 'num_games_owned': 1154, 'num_reviews': 290, 'playtime_forever': 349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1377067890}
review:
Al segundo 1 de empezar a jugar desconcierta bastante. Al segundo 2 la intuición me dijo que probablemente hubiera tirado el dinero. Cuando acabé el juego, me lo confirmó.
A ver, no quiero ser desagradable con el juego. Es una especie de mundo extraño donde nos iremos encontrando puzzles de diversos tipos en los que su elemento principal son las extrañas construcciones por las que nos movemos. Algunos son complicados y probablemente te ocupen horas, lo cual es peligroso porque en un juego con tan pocos alicientes y tan tranquilón como éste, puedes acabar dormido encima del teclado babeando o desinstalando el juego.
Como elemento principal del juego destacaría la rara arquitectura que hay por todos lados sin saber si es otro mundo o qué demonios está pasando, relegando los puzzles a un plano secundario. El problema es que sí, todo muy rarito y tal, las construcciones y eso... vale, bonitas, pero en treinta minutos el riesgo de cansancio es DEFCON 3.
Para enfrentarnos a todo esto estaremos solos. No hay nadie más en ningún lado. Poneos hasta las cejas de cafeína para jugar.

[b]Osea, de aventura, ¿qué tiene?[/b] Poco. Los puzzles son mover palancas para mover mecanismos, imitar sonidos, activar símbolos, etc...
[b]Pues en las fotos parece bonito.[/b] Sí, bonito sí es...
[b]Y la historia, ¿qué tal?[/b] ¿Historia? ¿Qué historia?

review:
This is, by far, my favourite mystery/puzzle game. The music and the atmosphere and even the way the levels are set out makes you feel scared and alone, just like your character.
One thing I love is the great feeling of achievment you get when you figure out a puzzle! It's amazing.

One thing I recommend for this game is wear headphones when you play it. The music completes the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044340549', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1388437115}
review: I really wanted to like Kairo but there is too much wrong with it for me to enjoy. The game doesn't make it clear when it saves and it doesn't give you the option to save whenever you want. This resulted in me completing major puzzles of the game and then leaving only to come back days later and realize that twenty minutes of work was gone. The player also moves to slow for some of the larger room puzzles which means correcting mistakes is a pain and bother. The only thing I really liked about the game was the lack of a HUD although at times this meant that I had no idea what to do since there was never any instructions. Honestly, a quick save feature would have made me love this game or at the very least an icon that shows when the game is saving but with neither of those things, I would highly recommend you avoid this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987001733', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1386892647}
review: Kairo is an experience game, likely to be lumbered in the Dear Esther, Gone Home, etc crowd, but despite this it's a really unique experience, and one definitely not to pass up. It's ethereal, ambient, and deserted, yet unnerving and alien. A good late night game lasting a few hours. There are puzzles each step of the exploration, and you can just do these and get the impression you're contributing to a much larger puzzle you eventually solve, or you can read into things much further. You're not given too much to go on, but you can surmise a few things. I completed it and then read a guide that showed how to solve the three non-essential puzzles which give strong indications of a deeper underlying narrative. These puzzles are a huge qualitative step up in difficulty. The main puzzles are fairly straightforward enough to not even need the hint system, but these are fiendish and involve getting hints from places well outside of the puzzle rooms and even needing the assistance of other Kairo players. I wasn't prepared to spend the time I'd spent doing the main game just hunting for ways to get these last bits, so I used a guide. If you don't have time either, I really recommend doing the same to get these last titbits as they firmly solidify hints you may have picked up throughout the main journey as to the meaning and purpose of Kairo, which is a really excellent thing. A good interpretation is here, which the creator has said is 'about 80% correct', but beware huge spoilers! Come back to this when you're done! http://www.electrondance.com/the-secret-of-kairo/

author: {'steamid': '76561198001716361', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1386921152}
review: It's like video games meeting modern art. I'd recommend this for game designers and architectural students to play at least once. At the low price for what it's worth, it's almost like experiencing a one time movie, so it's well worth the money for those that like art. As a video game, it's a very zen-like experience, all you really do is walk and solve puzzles with the walking controls. I do not recommend this for gamers that expect this to be a horror game or an action paced game, it's more of a world to just experience and watch the changes happen before and after you solve puzzles. So if you liked Myst or games like it, sure, this game plays well right in that area, puzzles are a lot easier compared to Myst.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022259960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1386873846}
review:
Amazingly minimalist puzzle game that looks like it was pulled out of cubist art? Yes please! Bonus points for having been made by the same man who did "The Binding of Isaac".

Kairo is what happens when Myst meets Mincraft and sprinkled with Shadow of the Colossus. The atmosphere is spooky, complemented by dissonant and etherial soundtrack, and punctuated by the sheer sense of scale and isolation. The machine, tower, and everything else is abandonned, and needs to be restarted. This requires you to solve a series of inventive, if no-nonsense puzzles in order to proceed.

The puzzles are somewhat challenging. I say this because the musical score alerts you when you're on the right track, or are doing something incorrectly. This can lead to simply listening to cues in order to proceed with the game.

All in all, it's a fun game that hooks you for a bit and doesn't let go. Also: if anyone dares go near the stele at the apex of that exterior spiral staircase, let me know what happens. The screen statics up and I've played enough "Slender" to have the "Ohhellnaw" muscle reaction to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979991373', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 295, 'last_played': 1385596052}
review:
Kairo is as different from any mainstream games as can be, and reminds me the most of the very first Myst, which did not in any way indicate what exactly the player is supposed to do. There is no hand-holding, and as such, the entire world of Kairo feels very different, more relaxed and engaging, than you regular game of today.

The art direction is minimalist, but a lot of thought went into creating the environments. Ultimately, it is a game of exploration and contemplation. Be warned!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044600422', 'num_games_owned': 624, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1420156554}
review:
I was completely blown away by this game given it's price and the fact that it appears, from the screenshots, to be something created in a few hours, but don't let that fool you, this game is one of the best examples of game design I've ever seen.

Atmosphere/Story/Game World I can honestly say I don't think I've ever played a game with half as much atmosphere as Kairo, and the fact that it does it with the most basic of graphics, no voice acting, no back story, no cinematics, and no supporting characters is astounding. Everything, the soundtrack, the mysterious, blocky architecture, the vast empty spaces, the grain filter over everything, even the floaty controls, all of it feels deliberate and just drips with atmosphere and conveys the story in a way that is far more compelling than any amount exposition ever could be. It is so immersive, if you allow it to be, that it will actually make the hair on your neck and arms stand on end and your skin crawl, in a good way, even for someone who dislikes the entire horror genera. You know you're alone but you just can't shake the feeling that something is off, that you're being watched. I imagine this is exactly how you'd feel if you were exploring an empty, foreign world in real life. It taps straight into your human nature, you have this creepy feeling but you have to keep going, you have to learn more about this world and what happened. Truly amazing.

There are some bugs or places where it isn't as polished as some titles. The biggest issue is that can see through geometry when you stand right next to it. There were also some places that I wasn't sure if there was a graphical error or just a design choice. Mainly places that seemed like there was a floor, I could walk and jump, but I appeared to be walking in space. Overall pretty polished.

Puzzles/Exploration Yet another place where Kairo shines. None of the main puzzles are that hard, you may need the hints in the menu for one or two, but the way that they are presented is the epitome of good puzzle design. The full extent of each puzzle is usually not fully apparent when you enter a room but the game does a brilliant job of "teaching" you the rules as you try and solve it. You probably won't solve it the first time but the penalty for failing is very small, basically just starting over, a few seconds lost at most, but you should have learned something new about the puzzle and will do better the next time. Sometimes you need to explore to find a hint in the environment, other times you just have to start interacting and see what happens. Besides the puzzles used to advance through the world there are a number of optional puzzles and objectives that you can choose to complete. There are 18 hidden glyphs, your basic exploration collectables, 4 seals in hidden rooms, and 3 extra puzzles, much harder, with clues scattered across the world but aren't explained. From what I've heard these puzzles were designed as sort of community puzzles, where players collaborated and shared findings to discover the answers together. It was probably pretty fun after launch but at this point you may need to look up the old threads to solve them, or at least get some hints. Theses extras aren't needed to complete the game but some of them can add a little (vague) context to the story.

Summery Kairo is a buy, no questions asked. It's the perfect length, the puzzles are intuitive and fun to solve, and the world and atmosphere are something every gamer should experience, doubly so if you are, or are interested in becoming, a game developer.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u-EeWrlfYvI

author: {'steamid': '76561197971251537', 'num_games_owned': 993, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1386255053}
review: Kairo is a game of exploration in a strange and unsettling world, one built of geometric structures in a stark monochromatic setting. Alien-looking monoliths loom out of the colour haze, blocks shift as you move, it's unnerving and there's an overwhelming feeling of being watched and isolated at the same time. The soundscape is dominated by an unearthly ambient score, with various musical notes and effects cues when appropriate; it generates a lonely atmosphere, and Kairo never forgets that you're there to experience its world. There are three main hub areas, each containing a handful of modest puzzles, and there are several secrets and hidden glyphs to find. It shouldn't take you longer than 5 hours to finish the three main hubs, but it's worth every minute that you spend in its unique world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003726789', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1386037141}

author: {'steamid': '76561198032788858', 'num_games_owned': 1105, 'num_reviews': 678, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1385985590}
review:
Крайне атмосферная бродилка от первого лица с элементами головоломки. 

С самого начала и до самого конца вы практически ничего так и не узнаете обо всем, что вас окружает, и до самого конца будете задавать себе основные вопросы - почему? когда? где?. Начинаете вы в непонятной локации, где нет никого, вообще мир вокруг вас пустой. Скажу больше куда бы вы не пришли, сколько бы локаций не сменили вы никого не встретите. Сюжета здесь нет никакого, исследование окружающего мира идет чисто интуитивно, ибо нет никаких рамок. Со временем так или иначе вы поймете, что находитесь на Земле, которая стала такой пустой после какого-то происшествия. Атмосфера настолько реальная, что порой щемит сердце от осознания того, что вы совсем один и огромные пространства мира абсолютно мертвы. Головоломки, которые вам встретятся основаны лишь на использовании логики, никаких предметов, лишь интуиция. Иногда стоит прилагать немалое внимание, чтобы заметить тут или иную подсказку. 

Стань одиноким! 7 из 10 :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198069918221', 'num_games_owned': 106, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1370375156}
review:
I personally love games that are about exploration and  open to interpretation. When I found Kairo and read that it advertised both aspects within its experience, I was instantly bought.

Kairo doesn't offer much in explanation. Every where you go is pretty much bathed in a single chromatic color with plain textures adorning every strange shape of your enviroment. This strangeness is accentuated even more with its plain droning music that is more akin to white noise. There is no death in Kairo either. There is no way to fail in Kairo. In Kairo it is just you, your mind and Kairo.

Now, what exactly is Kairo and why are you there? To understand these things you must venture into your new world. Kairo is seperated into hubs, within in those hubs are different rooms that contain a puzzle. Solve the puzzles and move on to the next hub until you reach the end. That's your goal. The puzzles themselves are not the most complicated thing to accomplish, pull a switch, push a block, align a grid ect and if you ever find yourself stuck there are also helpful hints in the options!

Other than getting to the end there are a few other things to accomplish as detailed by the achievements. Scattered throughout Kairo are 18 runes to collect, a few beacons to activate and a couple of tricky secrety puzzles to solve. I personally feel that if you are invested even in the slightist for Kairo's world then these extra goals should be mandatory for players to solve. The reward in narritive and overall experience trumps the extra hour or two one puts in to accomplish these goals. A helpful tip/warning though, always make sure you collect all the glyphs in an area before moving on! Backtracking for glyphs can be a pain in the ass! And if you must backtrack wait until the last hub!

Overall Kairo is a very very short game. This is a good thing though as with such games you will find yourself thinking more about the world as apposed to the gameplay. Kairo is very good food for your brain and whether it's on sale or for the normal five dollars trust me if you like exploration and mystery this is a fantastic deal.

review:
This is definitely one of the prettiest games on Steam, not because of high quality textures or models, but because of the sheer simplicity of it's presentation. It has a lovely soundtrack which you can listen to on Spotify, and every room and puzzle is something to remember. This game also has a good story if you dig deep enough (it took some reading and guides for me). All that said though, some of the puzzles are frustrating (I'm looking at you Einstein room), but the hint system doesn't leave you hanging.
If you like adventure games and abstract art, I'd give this game a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035655574', 'num_games_owned': 1323, 'num_reviews': 204, 'playtime_forever': 959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 959, 'last_played': 1383959724}
review:
Well this definitely is a strange one.
To those that message me every time I write a recommendation saying “you write long recommendations” … THIS is going to be a long one.

I have a thing for first person puzzle games at the moment, and I was rather intrigued by this games trailer and description. I think what interested me most, was the sense of ‘mystery’ that I got from the trailer. It doesn’t tell you what it is about, or why you are there or what’s going on… and to be honest this game has a real mysterious feel to it throughout the whole thing, you’re asking yourself questions on the who, what and whys but in fairness they aren’t answered all that clearly. 
And that isn’t necessarily a bad thing. 
I think games that are open to interpretation are great in their own way. The whole mystery and wonder to this game is great and all, but the structure and direction can sometimes make you just feel lost. At least for me anyways, that’s just my opinion of course, but there was a few times during the play through that I just asked, what the hell am I supposed to be doing here…

The puzzles themselves are very interesting, they are creative, they really make you think and make you put things together in ways that I’m not really used to. They are unique kinds of puzzles and there is a lot of symbols and shapes and colours that you have to try and think about what they might mean and what the logic behind the puzzle might be.

The music in the game is very moody, it really brings out that feel of the game. Which for me was quite cold, and dull. There isn’t really a whole lot of “bright” warm colours in the game, there is still colour, but it feels dulled down. There’s also a lot of white in the game, which some people may think ‘pfft well that’s “bright”’ but to me it’s an empty kind of white. The whole game is set in ancient looking dull buildings with strange structures and dull empty colours. You’re on your own with no one around and no one to comfort you but these strange surroundings and sounds and noises that give it a little bit of a creepy twitch to it.

Personally, I liked this game. It definitely wasn't one of those games that I couldn't put down until I had finished it 100% full on in one sitting, but it was something I kept coming back to every now and then, taking breaks, until I finally completed it. It took me 15 or so hours to complete it spread over the course of two weeks or so, at times I just wanted it done because getting stuck is a real pain in this game and I felt pretty clueless. I even admit that at a few points I needed help to get past certain obstacles, but all in all I think this was a good game. I enjoyed it, it’s unique and interesting and you can tell the creator is really quite creative.

If you enjoy first person puzzle games, I would say it is something that should at least be tried. I can see how it might not be some people’s cup of tea, but I think it’s worth the experience.


TL;DR : It's weird, buy it. Creative puzzles, eerie music and generally unique.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967714806', 'num_games_owned': 895, 'num_reviews': 372, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 371, 'last_played': 1378767001}
review:
Wow.

Kairo is absolutely stellar. It is ominous, confusing, ethereal, gorgeous, and fascinating.

The whole time you play, you're kept curious and driven to discover what is going on, and how all the pieces fit together.

The minimalistic design just serves to heighten the sense that this is a strange and alien place. The music, performed by Wounds, lends much of the foreboding nature to the feel of the environments.

There is one puzzle that feels artificially difficult and out of place, but the rest are really organic and are wonderful to solve.

Absolutely worth a play through.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982754644', 'num_games_owned': 719, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1508312824}

review: Brilliant. Completely dedicated to abstraction from beginning to end. No text, no tutorial, no explanations, no HUD. It's very much what I had hoped Antichamber would be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062001132', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1890, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1102, 'last_played': 1576255598}
review:
The creepiest game I've ever played, but the only creepy one I've actually liked.  The way Kario creates puzzle solving completely through player movement is pure genius, and the odd machines and structures of this world are awe-inspiring.  The world of Kario will be in my mind forever, even if I don't know it.  I haven't have any dreams about it yet, but I'm sure there there will be remanants of it, deliberate and accidental, in everything I do from now on.
Purely moving, disturbing, and amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003558790', 'num_games_owned': 428, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1591416035}
review: This game made me feel like I was in an Arthur C. Clarke novel, exploring weird, alien archetecture.  The atmosphere is fantastic and the design is excellent.  Everything (including the interface) is elegant and stripped-down.  I was surprised at how many distinct, memorable places could be made from such simple building blocks.  The puzzles are engaging, but not very difficult; for me, the game was paced exactly right, with no area wearing out its welcome before I was able to move on and see something new.

review: Nedoporučuju. Puzzle a příběh jsou možná zajímavé, ale zvuková stránka hry je neskutečně příšerná (za celou hru byly myslím 3 zvuky - tření kamene o kámen neustále ve smyčce (neustále!), gong když se mi něco povedlo a jiný gong když jsem něco posral). Otáčení myší je střídavě moc rychlé a neskutečně pomalé (otáčeni kamerou je většinu hry zpomalené o cca 1 sekundu (naschvál)).. Nikdy mi nebylo z žádné hry špatně, za jízdy v autě jsem přečetl několik knížek naprosto bez problémů, kinedryl jsem v životě ani neviděl, ale po hodině hraní tohoto paskvilu je mi z té (naschvál) opožděné kamery opravdu špatně od žaludku (a bolí mě hlava jak jsem hodinu poslouchal tření kamene o kámen ve smyčce).. :D Tohle bych nehrál ani kdybych za to bral 250,-/hod

author: {'steamid': '76561197999970857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1375545627}
review: Kairo is a great little game with really nice logic puzzles that aren't too difficult but requires some thinking. The game hints at a story but it's very vague and it could just as well have no story. The thing I really loved about Kairo was the atmosphere it created, it made me feel very isolated and small because the levels were usually very big and empty and it had a very minimalist environment. The atmosphere got creepy at times as things such as static on the screen would flare up and number station recordings would play as you got closer to certain areas. The game always had me questioning things, because sometimes strange objects or symbols would be around and it would make me want to know why they were there or what they meant. I also liked the ambient music as that too helped with the atmosphere and it fits right into the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025088156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 432, 'last_played': 1375536701}
review: This game is way more immersive than I originally expected it to be! It has as much story as you want it to have; if you just want to play through the game and do the puzzles, you can. No story at all. But if you actually look around, try to decipher what everything means, look at all the subtle hints you're given, you actually see what  Kairo is about. What Kairo itself is, who and what you are, why you are there, etc etc. It's definitely not for everyone though. No combat, the controls are a bit floaty at times and there is no real "challenge" as the puzzles are, with a bit of thinking, relatively easy to solve. There is no real pressure as you can't really die and every puzzle that requires a little running or reflexes can be done over and over again until you get it just right. The game is really forgiving, but that is part of what makes this game so relaxing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971956583', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 722, 'last_played': 1375423407}

author: {'steamid': '76561197974046543', 'num_games_owned': 4808, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 673, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 673, 'last_played': 1383482331}
review:
This first-person puzzle game relies on a minimalist, surreal environment to pull you in...but boy does it deliver.  I think if you liked Myst, you'll like this game...wandering around a vast, abandoned landscape fiddling with technology you don't understand.  But the game's not about the fiddling...it's about the wandering and the discovery (you'll know what to fiddle when the time comes).  If you like exploring and the visual style appeals to you (watch the video) then definitely pick this up.

I'm going to come back and flesh out this review more, but for now, I want to make a note of the fact that the coolest thing about Kairo, for me, was the ambience of the environments.  It was quite Myst-like in that it created this constant sense of wonder at the surreal landscapes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033618384', 'num_games_owned': 1539, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1375395305}
review:
一人称視点のパズルアドベンチャー

広大で神秘的な古代遺跡の中を探索しながら謎を解いていくゲームです。とにかく雰囲気が独特で、プレイしていると不気味なBGM・SEや色使い、演出などにより精神的に不安定になるかもしれません。

アドベンチャーゲームにもかかわらず、ストーリーや訴えたいものが非常にわかりにくく、それを類推するためのヒントが少ない上に、ファンタジーに現実的な要素が混ざっていることでゲームそれ自体で完結することは難しいです。プレイヤー自身による補完があっても変わらないかもしれません。私にはまったくわかりませんでした。

システム面では、視点移動時の画面揺れが激しく変更も出来ないため、上記の要素も相まってプレイして1時間で猛烈な吐き気を催しました。人生で初めてゲームで気持ち悪くなりました。3D酔いなどの経験がある方は注意が必要です。

ボリューム自体はそこまで大きくありませんが、パズル要素が若干難しい（ヒントが見つけにくい）ことによりプレイ時間は3～4時間程度、収集実績解除や隠し要素発見を目指すと4～5時間程度かかるでしょう。

価格の引き下げにより８ドルから５ドルになったので、トレイラーやスクリーンショットを見て惹かれるものがあればプレイをオススメできます。

author: {'steamid': '76561198028959993', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1377719315}
review: Surreal and unnerving, Kairo is a short exploration and puzzle game that revels in the abstract.  Puzzles are straightforward, and the in-game hint system for the rare moment when you get stuck is actually useful.  There is no direct plot, and like a lot of quiet exploration games, it leaves a lot of the storyline interpretation up to the player.  The atmosphere becomes increasingly skin-crawling and nerve-wracking as you go further into the game, and there are one or two moments that are jump scares.  There are no enemies, no health, deaths, or traps.  It is simply the player and the environment, and your goal is to move forward and explore the dream-like world you have been deposited into.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026401875', 'num_games_owned': 1529, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1375613200}
review:
Kairo is an interesting sort of first-person adventure game. It's rather minimalist in that 99% of the time there is zero HUD, and there are no "use" keys. The only way to interact with the world is, much like Proteus, by just being. Standing on switches and pads, moving against things, and walking around so that objects react to your very position relative to them will solve most of the puzzles in this game.

Kairo's puzzles are mostly (if not all) logical. They are, however, of the type where you will often walk into a room, have literally no idea of how the room works, leave, come back later, and solve it immediately upon walking back in. So goes Kairo. If you're ever completely and absolutely stumped, there are hints provided by the in-game menu (which unfold in a UHS-style increasingly-specific manner), though it should rarely come to that.

There is a story to Kairo. I am no fan of the obtuse "insert your own ending/meaning/plot here" plots that have become so commonplace in indie games these days, and I was initially under the impression that Kairo had followed suit. But I was embarrassingly wrong. There is, underneath it all, a highly interesting story that Kairo tells. It is told over the course of the game, and the elements which make it up stare you in the face wherever you go - though you do have to put the puzzle pieces together, yourself. While I myself had noticed all of these elements and even picked up on a hint or two of where they were leading me, I completely glazed over most of it and didn't connect anything that cried out for connection.

Do try not to make my mistake.

There are many interesting elements at work, here. It is in the interest of receiving the best experience that you can, for you to not only solve the puzzles, but to also pay attention to the world around you, and draw as many conclusions as possible along the way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066453782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1370218558}

author: {'steamid': '76561198074164330', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1370191194}
review: Zurück aus Kairo also....dem verwirrendsten Indiegame, das ich jemals gespielt habe. Kairo kombiniert jede Menge gute alte Rätsel (Labyrinthe, Enigmi, etc.) und funktioniert dabei ohne ein einziges Wort! Der Spieler erlebt alles aus der First-Person-Perspektive und ist wandert durch teils sehr verwirrende, sich stetig ändernde Welten, bestehend aus geometrischen Formen. Während des gesamten Spiels kommt sich der Spieler fehl am Platz vor; gar so, als ob er die feine Balance in den wie natürlich wirkenden Abläufen dieser Weltensysteme stören würde. Der wunderbar stimmige Soundtrack wechselt dabei zwischen klassischen Klängen und  irgendwie industriell klingenden Soundeffekten. Der einzige wirkliche Anker, den der Spieler bei der Entdeckung dieser riesigen Welt vorfindet, sind bekannte Bilder und Fotos (u.a. Albert Einstein, Go spielende Geishas, verwaiste Wüsten, etc.) Nach und nach, indem Rätsel gelöst werden, wird diese doch triste, meist in schlichten Farben und Beton gehaltene Welt wieder zum Leben erweckt. Kryptische Zeichen zeigen dem Spieler dabei den Weg. Hört sich verrückt an? Ist es! Manche Rätsel verlangen wirklich Hirnschmalz, andere bestehen wiederrum aus dem einfachen Erraten von Reihenfolgen. Eine Empfehlung für Rätselfreunde alle mal, genauso wie für kunstbegeisterte Architekten :D EInziges Manko: Ich würde mich über ein paar mehr Soundeffekte freuen. Zwar gibt es Sounds für fallenden Regen und Hall in größeren Räumen, elektrisches Knistern, etc. Fließendes Wasser hingegen, genau wie stehenden Wasser, durch welches durchgewatet wird, besitzen keine Sounds. Würde der Atmosphäre definitiv ein Sahnhäubschen aufsetzten! Kairo ist dennoch zu empfehlen - mit nichts zu vergleichen und ein Abenteuer wert!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041022985', 'num_games_owned': 2270, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1376238224}
review:
Okay, normally I'm a fan of these games that lean more towards "art" than "entertainment". However, if you take away some neat film grain, you don't have much left. The world was constructed sloppily, and although the lack of engineering *sometimes* gives a sort of eerie feeling, it wasn't up to par. 

The puzzles lacked interesting mechanics and were not at all fun to solve, and the story (from what I played) was also pretty weak and virtually nonexistent.

I feel like not a lot of work was put into this game, and do not recommend that you buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034663705', 'num_games_owned': 8151, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1375472729}
review:
Kairo is a first-person 3D exploration and puzzle game—something I’ve been wanting more of since beating Antichamber.  It drew my interest because people have been mentioning it in the same breath as Myst; unfortunately, it doesn't hold a candle to any entry in the Myst series.  

The game feels like a 15-year-old tech demo meant to show off early 3D environments more than anything.  Movement is floaty and inaccurate, story is subtle and there is no meaningful interaction with puzzles or objects: only walk, run and jump.  It's really a shame because the atmosphere is appropriately dark and mysterious.  I finished Kairo in one sitting and it is completely forgettable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065740735', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1375543534}
review: A great game. It feels like it is a spiritual successor to the original Myst in the way it make you feel isolated and small in a mysterious world. The puzzles are sufficiently difficult as to be rewarding to solve, but they are not as frustratingly vague as they can initially appear. All in all, it is a short but enjoyable game to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984801908', 'num_games_owned': 1188, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1367132400}
review:
A fantastic indie game. An unique (almost meditative) experience where you slowly uncover the truth and story of this abstract world, by solving clever puzzles and activating each room. The atmosphere can be quite scary and daunting at first, but somehow evolves so you feel peaceful and calm at the end. 

Last night I actually dreamt of this game; very odd yet fascinating.

review: Eeehhh... See, this might not strictly be a recommendation, because Kairo is essentially a collection of what indie games can do wrong sometimes. review: A really surrealistic and atmospheric experience. The soundtrack really complements the visuals (which are pretty well done for a blocky game like this). The puzzles are pretty simple most of the time and can be solved by observing your surroundings. The game lasts for ~3 hours (if you get the glyphs and stuff). If you're into a short, interesting adventure, grab it.
